Title: Microgreens are all the rage, so grow them at home
Content: Ever noticed how your neighbourhood vegetable vendor always has his nose and mouth nicely covered with a kerchief or mask while handling the veggies? Has it occurred to you that he is conscious of the copious amounts of pesticides on them? If you have answered yes to both, you may also be among the growing number of people who make a conscious effort to not only rid these vegetables of this poison, but also grow some of them in the space available to you. These days, eating healthy is not just about making the right choice of food items and cutting down on oil, salt, sugar, etc. It is just as much about ensuring that you source products that are grown organically, without chemical fertilizers and pesticides. And the best way to do that is to grow your own veggies as far as possible. The easiest to do is to grow microgreens at home.According to Anamika Bist, who promotes community farming through her enterprise, the mismatch in demand and supply of microgreens is a major factor for people growing them in their own homes. “Microgreens are healthy and tasty, and are a part of the menu in most urban homes today. But they are not readily available in the market at most times. Even if you do find them in the market, they are very expensive. Add to that the fact that they could be sprayed with pesticides, it makes better sense to just grow them at home. You don’t need a lot of space or equipment and it doesn’t burn a hole in your pocket. This could be why there has been a spurt in the number of people who have taken to it,” says Anamika.City-based diet consultant Anu Gayathri says that microgreens pack in a lot of nutrients, which is why they are a rage today. “Microgreens are rich in Magnesium, Manganese and Iron, among others, and are usually consumed raw, thereby retaining their nutritive value, unlike other mature greens that have to be cooked leading to nutrient loss,” says Anu adding, “Even though we consume microgreens in small portions, the absorption of nutrients is more, because they are available in higher quantities.”Arundathi Shiggaon, an early childhood educator, says, “Growing microgreens is very easy. You need basic equipment like a tray or a bowl, cocopeat, a little manure and the seeds. Start with simple varieties like methi, coriander, radish or fennel, before moving on to the more complex ones like sunflower and flax seeds.”What you will needA tray or a containerCocopeatManure (optional)SeedsWaterPlace the tray or the container in a partially sunny spot. Add cocopeat and organic manure (optional). Sow the seeds in the cocopeat mixture and mist it with water twice a day. Within 5-6 days the seeds will sprout. Once the seedlings are about two-inch tall, cut them using a pair of scissors. This is a one-time process and has to be repeated for fresh batches. (*Growing microgreens may not always yield the same result)Soak the seeds overnight before you sow them.Keep the cocopeat moist and do not expose the tray to harsh sunlight.Here’s what to do with microgreensMicrogreens can be eaten rawThey can be used as garnish on toasts, pizzas or soupThey pack in a nutritive punch when added to saladsStir fry with butter/ oilCan be added to smoothies, shakes and juicesUse them in sandwich and wrap fillingsl Radishl Amaranthusl Basill Kalel Peasl Rocket

Title: TV actors set to make their first Valentine’s Day memorable
Content: Last year, quite a few popular faces from the Kannada television industry tied the knot. And for a lot of them, this Valentine’s Day is the first for them as a married couple, so, they are hoping to make it special for their significant other. Actors Raksh, Bhavani Singh, Amrutha Ramamoorthi, Aishwarya Pisse , Deepika and Jagannath Chandrashekhar , are working around their hectic shooting schedules to make elaborate plans.The actor got married to his long-term girlfriend Anusha in May, but has been busy since then with shoots for his film debut and TV series. “Since I have been so busy, I did not even get to take Anusha on a honeymoon trip. And now that I am in the midst of promotions for film Naragunda Bandaya, which is releasing this month, I may not even get time to spend a cozy Valentine's Day with her. So, I have decided to make the most of the time we have before that and plan to take her on a bike ride to Mysuru, which is something she really likes, ” says Raksh.Bhavani Singh married Pankaja Shivanna in November and is looking at celebrating the day of love amid nature. “We are both nature lovers. So, the plan is to go on a long drive to a nature/wildlife reserve outside Bengaluru and spend a few days there. I want to surprise Pankaja by cooking for her and giving her a special gift that will definitely bring a smile to her face,” says Bhavani.Amrutha married her Mr and Mrs Rangegowda co-star Raghu in May last year. “We will be in Madikeri on February 13 and 14 to attend a wedding. We will be celebrating Valentine's Day with a newly married couple. I am also giving a special gift to Raghu, which I don’t want to reveal right now,” says Amrutha.The actress will be in Hyderabad on Valentine's Day. “I am busy shooting for my Telugu serial Agnisakshi in Hyderabad. My husband, Hari Vinay , will join me here, and I hope to finish my schedule and take him for a special candlelight dinner. There is a surprise gift awaiting him, which I will give him then,” says AishwaryaDeepika married actor Akarsh in May. “Akarsh will be in Hyderabad on work shoot this week. I have quite a few plans for the special day, including a romantic proposal. I am also looking at cooking something special for Akarsh; after all, the way to a man's heart is through his stomach," she laughs.His shoot schedule means that Jaganath cannot make elaborate plans to spend the day with wife, Rakshitha. But that doesn't mean that there will be no celebrations at all. “I am currently shooting for Seetha Vallabha, so, all I can do is take her out for a special dinner. I hope to make it up to her later,” says Jaganath.

Title: Raveena Tandon: I am doing a powerful role in KGF sequel
Content: We recently reported that Bollywood actress Raveena Tandon is returning to Kannada cinema after a gap of nearly two decades, with the sequel to Yash’s multilingual film, KGF : Chapter 2. Now, there is an update on that — the ‘mast mast’ hudugi has already begun shooting in Mysuru , and she is all praise for the director of the film, Prashanth Neel . Excerpts from a conversation…“I was in talks with the KGF team for quite some time, and have been fairly impressed by its storyline. Prashanth had narrated the script to me long before I watched the first part. Later, when I saw the film, I was blown away by its edgy, new-age cinema approach,” says Raveena. “Having said that, it was important for me to thoroughly understand the narrative and its course in the second part. My character in the sequel is so powerful that I couldn’t say no to it,” says Raveena, who will be shooting for a week in Mysuru, before travelling to Hyderabad for the next leg of the schedule.Raveena seems to be extremely fond of Prashanth. “He is such a cool and composed young man. There is an air of calmness around him. But, when you see the work he does on the big screen, it is incredible. This is what makes him so special,” she says.Raveena’s last outing in Sandalwood was when she was part Upendra directorial, Upendra. Ask the actress if it only takes filmmakers who have attained a cult status in Kannada cinema to get her to do films here, and she responds, “Upendra had a story that was much ahead of its time. And the movie was a phenomenal success. The concept, thinking and vision behind the project were such that it easily qualified as new-age cinema. Similar is the case with KGF. When Prashanth narrated parts of the sequel to me, it already felt phenomenal. When a film offers something challenging, it always makes the cut for me.”Unlike many of her contemporaries, Raveena has not been seen in as many films during recent times. “I am a little choosy when it comes to films now. I have been offered a lot of roles, in films as well as in web series. But, honestly, I’ve also maintained that acting in films is only a part of my life. Between taking care of my kids and managing home and running a production house, I have been quite busy. Hence, I choose to do roles that really excite me,” she explains.“My love affair with Mysuru and Bengaluru started when my parents took me and my brother on a road trip from Mumbai to Kanyakumari. I fondly recall this green belt that we travelled through. We had a stopover at Mysuru, and visited Mysore Palace and also went for the lights and sound show at KRS. Also, in the 90s, most of the Bollywood song sequences were filmed in Mysuru and Ooty. For instance, the Elo Ji Sanam song from Andaz Apna Apna was shot in Ooty.”

Title: Bongos and medleys mark Usha Uthup’s thumping Bengaluru show
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Generations of music lovers have swayed to her distinctive baritone and her thumping tracks. But when Usha Uthup took the stage at the recently-concluded Times Lit Fest in Bengaluru, the singing sensation was seen playing a set of bongo drums with equal finesse that she plays her signature instrument, the tambourine . Needless to say, the audience were bowled over.

Expressing her love for namma ooru, the veteran artiste said that she particularly loves the city’s eclectic mix of musicians and its receptive audience. At the fest, Usha kept everyone entertained with a medley of hits in English, Hindi, Marathi and Tamil. The performance was mostly interactive, as she also shared her childhood stories, telling the audience that she began her singing career at the age of nine. Usha’s sister, Indira Srinivasan , also performed with her on stage.

Title: Nikhil Kumar gets engaged to Revathi; to wed this year
Content: On Monday morning, actor-politician Nikhil Kumar got engaged to Revathi at a heritage hotel in Bengaluru. Nikhil’s grandfather, HD Deve Gowda, and his father, HD Kumaraswamy, were present at the ceremony to bless the couple . This alliance was made by the couple’s parents. The actor, who is currently working on four films, will tie the knot with his fiancée later this year. Title: Microgreens are all the rage, so grow them at home
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Ever noticed how your neighbourhood vegetable vendor always has his nose and mouth nicely covered with a kerchief or mask while handling the veggies? Has it occurred to you that he is conscious of the copious amounts of pesticides on them? If you have answered yes to both, you may also be among the growing number of people who make a conscious effort to not only rid these vegetables of this poison, but also grow some of them in the space available to you. These days, eating healthy is not just about making the right choice of food items and cutting down on oil, salt, sugar, etc. It is just as much about ensuring that you source products that are grown organically, without chemical fertilizers and pesticides. And the best way to do that is to grow your own veggies as far as possible. The easiest to do is to grow microgreens at home.

What’s pushing people to grow microgreens at home?

According to Anamika Bist, who promotes community farming through her enterprise, the mismatch in demand and supply of microgreens is a major factor for people growing them in their own homes. “Microgreens are healthy and tasty, and are a part of the menu in most urban homes today. But they are not readily available in the market at most times. Even if you do find them in the market, they are very expensive. Add to that the fact that they could be sprayed with pesticides, it makes better sense to just grow them at home. You don’t need a lot of space or equipment and it doesn’t burn a hole in your pocket. This could be why there has been a spurt in the number of people who have taken to it,” says Anamika.

Nutritive value make microgreens a rage

City-based diet consultant Anu Gayathri says that microgreens pack in a lot of nutrients, which is why they are a rage today. “Microgreens are rich in Magnesium, Manganese and Iron, among others, and are usually consumed raw, thereby retaining their nutritive value, unlike other mature greens that have to be cooked leading to nutrient loss,” says Anu adding, “Even though we consume microgreens in small portions, the absorption of nutrients is more, because they are available in higher quantities.”

Start with simple varieties of microgreens

Arundathi Shiggaon, an early childhood educator, says, “Growing microgreens is very easy. You need basic equipment like a tray or a bowl, cocopeat, a little manure and the seeds. Start with simple varieties like methi, coriander, radish or fennel, before moving on to the more complex ones like sunflower and flax seeds.”

Grow your own microgreens

What you will need

A tray or a container

Cocopeat

Manure (optional)

Seeds

Water

Method:

Place the tray or the container in a partially sunny spot. Add cocopeat and organic manure (optional). Sow the seeds in the cocopeat mixture and mist it with water twice a day. Within 5-6 days the seeds will sprout. Once the seedlings are about two-inch tall, cut them using a pair of scissors. This is a one-time process and has to be repeated for fresh batches. (*Growing microgreens may not always yield the same result)

Tips:

Soak the seeds overnight before you sow them.

Keep the cocopeat moist and do not expose the tray to harsh sunlight.

Eat your greens

Here’s what to do with microgreens

Microgreens can be eaten raw

They can be used as garnish on toasts, pizzas or soup

They pack in a nutritive punch when added to salads

Stir fry with butter/ oil

Can be added to smoothies, shakes and juices

Use them in sandwich and wrap fillings

Get started by growing...

l Radish

l Amaranthus

l Basil

l Kale

l Peas

l Rocket

Title: Missile shield over Delhi: India may buy NASAMS-II air defence system from US
Content:
The indigenous Akash area defence missile systems will form the layer over the NASAMs, according to the plan i... Read More

NEW DELHI: India has got one step closer to deploying a new missile shield over its Capital, with US state department notifying its Congress of the impending sale of an integrated air defence weapon system ( IADWS ) to New Delhi for $1.86 billion.TOI in July 2018 had first reported that India was moving swiftly ahead to acquire the IADWS or the National Advanced Surface to Air Missile System-II ( NASAMS-II ) from the US, which will be used along with indigenous, Russian and Israeli systems to erect an ambitious multi-layered missile shield over the National Capital Territory of Delhi against aerial threats ranging from drones to ballistic missiles.India and the US have already held several rounds of negotiations, including selection of sites for deployment of the missile batteries around Delhi, for the proposed sale under the American foreign military sales (FMS) programme, as was reported earlier by TOI.Once the deal is inked, the NASAMS-II deliveries will take place in two to four years, say sources. Though the US was also mounting pressure on India to also consider its Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) and Patriot Advanced Capability (PAC-3) missile defence systems, New Delhi went ahead to ink the $5.43 billion (almost Rs 40,000 crore) deal with Russia for five squadrons of the advanced S-400 Triumf surface-to-air missile systems in October 2018.As per the proposed overall air defence plan for Delhi, the innermost layer of protection will be through the NASAMS. It will be a combination of different weapons like Stinger surface-to-air missiles, gun systems and AIM-120C-7 AMRAAMs (advanced medium-range air-to-air missiles), backed by three-dimensional Sentinel radars, fire-distribution centers and command-and-control units. “The networked system, capable of even shooting around buildings, will take care of 9/11-like and other close-in threats,” said the source.The outermost layer of Delhi’s missile shield, in turn, will be provided by the indigenous two-tier ballistic missile defence (BMD) system being developed by DRDO. This system’s AAD (advanced air defence) and PAD (Prithvi air defence) interceptor missiles are currently geared to intercept enemy missiles, in the 2,000-km class, at altitudes from 15-25 km and 80-100 km respectively.The second layer will be through the highly automated and mobile S-400 systems, which will have missiles with interception ranges of 120, 200, 250 and 380 kms, backed by their associated battle-management system of command posts and launchers, long-range acquisition and engagement radars.Then will come the Barak-8 medium-range surface-to-air missile systems, jointly developed by Israeli Aerospace Industries and DRDO, which have a 70-100 km interception range. The indigenous Akash area defence missile systems, with a 25-km range, in turn, will form the layer over the NASAMs.

Title: Kashmir news: 25 foreign envoys to be taken on Jammu and Kashmir visit, Russia declines invite
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Envoys from several countries were taken to Kashmir last month (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Russian ambassador to India Nikolay Kudashev won’t be visiting J&K despite having received an invite from the Indian government to visit the Union Territory, diplomatic sources here said. According to the Indian government, another lot of foreign envoys – 25 in all - based in Delhi will be taken to Kashmir this week.

The first visit of foreign envoys to Kashmir had been organised by Indian authorities in the second week of January.

Russia has stood firmly behind India on the government’s decision to revoke the special status of J&K and Kudashev was quoted as having said last month that Moscow never had any doubt about India’s approach to the Valley. He had said that Russia did not feel the need to find out what was happening in Kashmir as it was India’s internal matter and belonged to "the Constitutional space of India."

“It is not an issue in our bilateral ties. Those who believe this is an issue, those who are concerned about the situation in Kashmir, those who have doubt about Indian policy in Kashmir can travel to Kashmir. They could see for themselves. We never had any doubt,” he had said. Unlike last time though, India on this occasion extended an invite to Kudashev, which he declined.

The envoys are likely to land in Srinagar on Wednesday and, sources said, will be travelling to Jammu and Budgam as well. The envoys are expected to interact with locals and also attend a briefing by senior army officers.

Official sources here said that since the last visit of envoys to J&K on 9-10 January 2020, MEA had received several requests from foreign ambassadors here for a visit to the newly created UT. "A group of Envoys from different geographical regions, will be visiting Jammu and Kashmir this week," said a source requesting anonymity.

Unlike last time, several envoys from European countries are likely to travel. Officials here didn’t rule out participation of French, EU and German envoys. While the last delegation comprised, among others, the US ambassador to India, European envoys had given it a miss. Some had reportedly said that they didn’t want a guided tour but Indian authorities had claimed it was more because of scheduling issues. Outgoing UK high commissioner Dominic Asquith had recently said British diplomats were very much interested in visiting Kashmir. The delegation will likely also have envoys from some Gulf countries.

"The visit will be same as the first one in terms of form and substance. There’s no need to read too much into it as it’s happening only because of requests received from envoys," said an official here.

Title: Isro veteran G Narayanan to head space PSU NSIL
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

NEW DELHI: Veteran space scientist G Narayanan has been named the chairman of Indian Space Research Organisation’s newly formed commercial entity New Space India Ltd ( NSIL ).

Narayanan was earlier working as deputy director (systems reliability and quality assurance) at the Liquid Propulsion Systems Centre ( LPSC ), a Thiruvananthapuram-based unit of Isro that designs, develops liquid propulsion stages for launch vehicles. Narayanan has to resign from Isro before taking charge of NSIL as the new commercial entity is a public sector undertaking.

Narayanan, who hails from Kerala’s Palakkad, had earlier worked as first secretary (space) at the Indian embassy in Paris. An alumnus of the College of Engineering, Thiruvananthapuram, Narayanan joined Isro in 1983.

NSIL was set up in March last year to meet the ever-increasing demands of the Indian space programme and commercially exploit the emerging global space market. It will also manufacture the small satellite launch vehicle (SSLV) or mini-PSLV in collaboration with the private sector and help in the production of polar satellite launch vehicle (PSLV) and other space-based products through the industry. For the SSLV launches, Isro is already working on a new launchpad in Kulasekarapattinam in Tamil Nadu.

Despite having commercial arm Antrix Corporation that handles commercial satellite launches, the department of space set up the NSIL in order to push transfer of Isro technologies to the industry and market spin-off technologies and services.

Title: Randeep Hooda: The one thing that I lost as an actor is my vanity, and I am trying to get it back
Content: Last seen in Baaghi 2 (2018), Randeep Hooda is all set to end his break from movies with director Imtiaz Ali’s Love Aaj Kal . In a chat with BT, the actor talks about working with Imtiaz, the young star cast of the film and missing out on the sports drama, ‘83. Read On...It is always a joy to work with Imtiaz, as he is organic in his approach. Talking about Love Aaj Kal, working on this film was a different experience altogether. The environment on the set was more fun, as this is a lighter film. Even Highway had romance, but it was tragic. It showed the complexities in a relationship between two individuals, who belong to different strata of society. But in Love Aaj Kal, they are from the same strata. Also, compared to Highway, I have a lot more dialogues in Love Aaj Kal. Highway was a well-made film, but the shooting process was not enjoyable. My character had a lot of emotions, which he was unable to express. To bring those expressions on screen was taxing. When Imtiaz narrated the script of Love Aaj Kal to me, I liked the concept of love set in two eras — in the 90s and the present times. As far as ‘kal’ is concerned, in the 90s, there was no social media, and people weren’t so casual about physical intimacy.The ‘aaj’, on the other hand, is high on finding love through social media and dating apps.Well, that has always been the case with me. I was appreciated in Once Upon A Time In Mumbaai (2010), but there was a lull post that. It was the same after Highway, Main Aur Charles (2015) and Sarbjit as well. I am just happy that in my journey as an actor, I got to portray a plethora of characters and work with many talented directors. Every movie has been special for me. After Sarbjit, I felt that I should take my craft a notch higher and signed Battle Of Saragarhi . I immersed myself in it, and did not take up any other projects for the next two years. However, the film didn’t happen and I ended up being on a hiatus. Then, Baaghi 2 happened in 2018 and now, I am back with Love Aaj Kal. In between, I shot for an international project for an OTT platform. I am also currently shooting for Radhe with Salman Khan, with whom I have done films like Kick (2014) and Sultan (2016). As an artiste, I explored my talent, and I am happy about that. However, the one thing that I lost as an actor, and which I am trying to get back, is my vanity (laughs)!I think they call me that because it is hard to make a parody of me. I see people imitating other actors, but maybe, they are unable to pin me down. As far as social media is concerned, there are times when I feel that I need to be more proactive, but at the same time, I strongly believe that your work should speak for itself, rather than you going all out. Having said that, I am active on social media — I put up wildlife pictures on Instagram and address social causes on Twitter. Overall, I want my work to speak for itself and I guess, it has not gone unnoticed to that great an extent.It is wonderful to work with a bunch of young actors, as they are high on energy. I like their enthusiasm to learn constantly and their willingness to surrender themselves to the director. In fact, Kartik and Sara were so good that they didn’t seem like newcomers. I had a lot of scenes with Sara, and she is extremely disciplined — she would wake up at 4 am, go to the gym, come on the set, get her hair and make-up done and by the time the camera is ready to roll, she would be ready with her lines. I was really impressed. She would bring healthy food from home, while I would be binging on burgers.I had put in a lot of effort for the film based on the Battle of Saragarhi. It is disappointing that all that hard work never reached the audience, and you do feel let down, but what can you do about it? In the end, one has to just pick up the positives and move on. I have imbibed the goodness of the character, and I also got to learn a lot about Sikhism from that project. In terms of ‘83, I would just say that as actors, we sometimes say ‘no’ to projects, but this time, it was the other way around. I wish the team well, and I am sure that it will be a great film to watch.No, there was no communication with me at all.

Title: Watch what you say in the cab, lest you trip the ride
Content: Passengers often complain that they are forced to turn agony aunts for their “chatterbox” cab drivers who decide to share their life’s plight the moment they board the cabs. While silence is what many passengers desire, it seems that on their turn, passengers need to pay heed to what they say inside cabs – be it to fellow passengers and more importantly, the phone conversations that they have while taking a ride.Last week, an Uber driver in Mumbai took his passenger to the Santacruz police station, without his knowledge. The passenger, who is from Jaipur, was talking to a friend over the phone about the anti-CAA/NRC protests around the country. Offended by his views, the cabbie took him to the police. In a similar incident, in January, a netizen had tweeted that his Ola driver told him off, implying that he’s an “anti-national”, after overhearing his phone conversation where he was talking about India’s economic situation. While Ola didn’t take any action, an Uber spokesperson told us, “As soon as the incident was brought to our attention, we took it up on priority. We are in touch with both the rider and the driver, and are reviewing the matter.” We spoke to NCR riders who shared with us how cabbies eavesdrop on their conversations, offer them advice – ranging from social to political – and even at times, drill them for their political views.

Content: Passengers often complain that they are forced to turn agony aunts for their “chatterbox” cab drivers who decide to share their life’s plight the moment they board the cabs. While silence is what many passengers desire, it seems that on their turn, passengers need to pay heed to what they say inside cabs – be it to fellow passengers and more importantly, the phone conversations that they have while taking a ride.Last week, an Uber driver in Mumbai took his passenger to the Santacruz police station, without his knowledge. The passenger, who is from Jaipur, was talking to a friend over the phone about the anti-CAA/NRC protests around the country. Offended by his views, the cabbie took him to the police. In a similar incident, in January, a netizen had tweeted that his Ola driver told him off, implying that he’s an “anti-national”, after overhearing his phone conversation where he was talking about India’s economic situation. While Ola didn’t take any action, an Uber spokesperson told us, “As soon as the incident was brought to our attention, we took it up on priority. We are in touch with both the rider and the driver, and are reviewing the matter.” We spoke to NCR riders who shared with us how cabbies eavesdrop on their conversations, offer them advice – ranging from social to political – and even at times, drill them for their political views.

Title: Milind Soman: Lucknowites ran with Milind Soman in this half marathon
Content: The 5th Lucknow Half Marathon was a resounding success with over six thousand people participating in it. The marathon, divided into three categories of 5, 10 and 21 kms was flagged off from the 1090 Women Power Line Chauraha last Sunday morning at the crack of dawn by Chetan Chauhan , Minister of Sainik Welfare, Home Guards, PRD, Civil Security, UP Government and actor-model and a consistent marathoner Milind Soman Milind Soman (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Abhishek Mishra, one of the organisers, explained the rules to the participants and looked after the arrangements. A cheer went up in the crowd as Milind’s wife Ankita Konwar also joined him on stage, along with bureaucrats Anil Kumar and Lalita Pandey. "It’s heartening to see such a large turnout of runners in Lucknow today,” said Milind as he cheered the runners on, adding, “Six years ago when I had come for the first marathon, there were hardly 600 participants. This time it’s ten folds, cheers for you Lucknow!"(L) Abhishek Mishra (R) Chetan Chauhan (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Another plus point of the marathon this time was that the organisers did away with plastic water bottles for the participants and provided water for them in paper cups. “This way we have managed to save more than six thousand litres of water and also reduced plastic waste” said Abhishek.(L) Amit Singh and Dr Archana Chauhan (R) Anjali Chaurasia (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) With more than 300 troops and officers of the Gorkha Regiment itself, the participation of the defence personnel was also high in the marathon, despite all of them busy with the Defence Expo 2020.(L) Guillaume Gallouin (R) Khushbu Gupta (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)The winner of the 21-km male category was Ravindra Kumar, whereas in female category Arpana Vishwakarma won the race. The price distribution to the winners was done by Milind Soman and Sanjay Gupta, Vice President HCL Corporation (L) Pragya (R) Shreya Pal (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)(L) Ravindra Kumar Tiwari (R) Pratistha Maheshwari and Dr Monika Awasthi (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

Title: Nikkhil Arya files police complaint against Ankit Mohan
Content: Not all endings are happy. At least not in the case of actors Nikkhil Arya and Ankit Mohan , who are a part of the TV show 'Haiwan', which is set to end in a few days. Things got ugly between the two last week, a day after they wrapped up shoot, prompting Nikkhil to file a non-cognisable complaint against Ankit for threatening him and his family, and using abusive and vulgar language.Ankit was apparently upset because their co-actor Gayathiri Iyer had stopped talking to him. He believed that Nikkhil had spoken ill about him because of which she started maintaining a distance. In a fit of rage, Ankit called Nikkhil, who had landed back in Pune (his hometown), and abused him. Over the next 48 hours, he sent several abusive messages and threatening voice notes, post which Nikkhil approached the Pune police.When we spoke to Nikkhil about this, he said, “Initially, I thought that it was just another bull on steroids. But when his abusive messages and voice notes went on for almost two days, I realised that he wasn’t in a normal state of mind. And then, he crossed all limits when he used the most derogatory language for the women in my house. That’s when I decided to take action.” Nikkhil, who has been a part of a number of popular TV shows over the years, added, “I wish people didn’t indulge in juvenile stuff and focussed on their job on the set, which is acting.”Ankit, who is married to actress Ruchi Savarn , admitted that he sent the messages in anger. He told BT, “I was upset as he spoke ill about me with Gayathiri because of which she stopped talking to me. I have worked hard to reach where I am and don’t appreciate anyone casting aspersions on my character. Yes, I lost my cool and in a fit of anger, abused him. But all I wanted was to evoke a response from him. When that didn’t happen, it further angered me. My emotions got the better of me.” When asked about the need to turn abusive and drag Nikkhil’s family into the fight, he replied, “I didn’t mean any of it.”Meanwhile, Gayathiri, who was in touch with Nikkhil till about a few days ago expressing shock over Ankit’s behaviour, seems to have had a change of heart. While those present on the set told us that she initiated the conversation regarding Ankit with Nikkhil, the actress told us otherwise. She said, “Nikkhil told me a few things about Ankit, which prompted me to maintain my distance from him. I was affected since it was a friendship of six months. But Ankit and I have clarified everything and are back to being friends. Having said that, he shouldn’t have abused Nikkhil.”

Title: Delhi elections: Counting to start at 8am, trends to start pouring in after 11am
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Security personnel guard at the Atal Adarsh Bengali Girls Senior Secondary School, one of the counting centres... Read More

NEW DELHI: Counting for the 70 assembly seats in Delhi will begin at 8am on Tuesday and trends will start pouring in around 11am. Officials said the votes will be counted at 21 locations in 11 districts. About 2,600 administrative officials will be involved in the process.

Though the official announcement of results will be done only in the evening, Election Commission officials said the winning candidate and the estimated margin of votes will be known by the afternoon.

The smaller the size of the constituency, the sooner the result will be announced.

East Delhi district election officer Arun Kumar Mishra said the counting centres have a three-tier security involving the local police, CAPF and paramilitary forces.

"The outermost ring will have Delhi Police personnel, while the second ring will have local police and CAPF. The innermost security ring will have paramilitary forces," he added.

The counting centre at Commonwealth Games Village has been set up as a model centre with state-of-the-art facilities, Mishra said.

In all, 33 counting observers have been appointed to oversee the process. The counting of votes will start with postal ballots.

Votes polled in EVMs will begin only after that. The EVM votes will be counted simultaneously at 10-14 tables set up for each assembly segment. Depending on the size of the constituency, the votes will be counted in 10-16 rounds.

After each round, the results will be uploaded on the "Suvidha" mobile app. Once all votes are counted, election officials will randomly pick VVPAT slips from five polling stations in each assembly segment and match the results with those generated by EVMs.

Paper chits with the number of each polling station in an assembly constituency will be put in a container and shuffled in presence of all candidates or their agents. The returning officer will then pick up five slips to tally with the EVM results.

"The paper trail of votes will be kept in separate bundles and then matched with the EVM results. The tabulation of paper trails will be carried out simultaneously. The result will be declared after completing the entire exercise," said an official.

Title: Delhi election: BJP and Congress pooh-pooh exit poll results
Content:
A security personnel stands guard outside a strong room (PTI)

NEW DELHI: In the next few hours, the fate of 672 candidates - 593 men and 79 women - in the electoral fray for 70 seats in Delhi Assembly would be known. Though the contest to form a government in Delhi is largely seen to be between the party in power, AAP, and BJP, Congress may emerge as a dark horse and upset calculations.Counting of votes will begin at 8am and which party gets the mandate to govern Delhi for the next five years will be known by 2pm.Stakes are high for the three political parties that ran a campaign for almost a fortnight before the votes were polled on February 8. Victory of AAP will validate its claims of doing good work in education, health and power sectors while looking after the vulnerable sections through free power, water and travel for women in public transport.Bharatiya Janata Party, which had been extremely critical of the five years of the Aam Aadmi Party government in the capital, made the work done by Prime Minister Narendra Modi-led central government its election plank to woo voters apart from focussing on national issues such as abrogation of Article 370 and 35A in Kashmir, citizenship amendment law and protests against, a favourable judgment in the Ram Temple case and surgical strikes on Pakistan.The party, which is looking to form a government in Delhi after 22 years in exile, ran an aggressive campaign with Union home minister Amit Shah micro-managing everything on a day-to-day basis. Senior BJP functionaries, including several Union ministers and MPs from across the country, addressed close to 10,000 public meetings during the fortnight-long campaign, banking on planks of Hindutva and nationalism.Congress, on the other hand, made the legacy of the Sheila Dikshit government and infrastructure development during 1998-2013 when it was in power its main poll plank. Several senior Congress functionaries, including former party president Rahul Gandhi, AICC general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra and chief ministers of four states held public events in the last week of electioneering.The exit polls telecast by various TV channels have predicted a comfortable victory for AAP by giving it 44-68 seats in the 70-member House. In the 2015 assembly polls, AAP had won a record 67 seats and polled over 54% votes. BJP, which got over 32% votes in the last election, had won just three seats while Congress was decimated with a vote share of less than 10% and no seat. Most exit polls have predicted around 10-12 seats for the BJP, marginally better over the last assembly poll results and none for Congress.Both BJP and Congress have rubbished the exit poll results. BJP leaders exuded confidence "based on a micro analysis of all seats. The exit polls are rough estimates, and I am confident that BJP will form the government in Delhi with full majority," said Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari, adding that they would win 45 of the 70 seats. Delhi Congress chief Subhash Chopra said the "actual" results would surprise everyone.

Title: SC to define scope and ambit of right to religion
Content: NEW DELHI: For the first time in 70 years, the SC on Monday decided to take up the sensitive task of defining the scope of right to freedom of religion guaranteed under Article 25 .A bench of CJI S A Bobde and Justices R Banumathi, Ashok Bhushan, L Nageswara Rao, Mohan M Shantanagoudar, S Abdul Nazeer, R Subhash Reddy, B R Gavai and Surya Kant framed seven questions on fundamental right to religion and its interplay with right of every religious denomination to establish and manage religious institutions. It will also decide whether a person, not belonging to a religious denomination, can file a PIL questioning validity of practices of that religion.In the process, SC rejected resistance from lawyers led by senior advocate Fali S Nariman, who argued against SC undertaking the exercise of laying down guidelines for courts to deal with cases involving a clash between faith and fundamental rights.Nariman had argued that the issues arose in petitions seeking review of the SC's judgment allowing the entry of women of all ages into the Sabarimala Ayyappa temple and a five-judge bench could not have in a review jurisdiction referred unconnected religious customs - curbs on entry of women into mosques, entry of Parsi women married outside the community into agiyaris and practice of female genital mutilation among Dawoodi Bohras - to a larger bench. The court, however, agreed with Solicitor General Tushar Mehta and said, "We hold that this court can refer questions of law to a larger bench in a review petition."Apart from defining the ambit of right to rel igion, and examining the implications of Articles 25 and 26, the SC will decide whether a person, not belonging to a religious denomination, can file a PIL questioning validity of customs and practices of that religion. Article 25, while guaranteeing freedom of conscience and free profession, practise and propagation of religion, subjects this to "public order, morality and health". It also allows the government to regulate or restrict by a law the economic, financial, political and other secular activities associated with religious practices. It also allows the government to pass a law to provide social welfare and reform or throw open public religious institutions belonging to Hindus, Jains, Sikhs and Buddhists to all classes of persons belonging to these religious denominations.Article 26, guarantees right of every religious denomination to establish and manage religious institutions subject again to "public order, morality and health". Arguments will be opened by former attorney general K Parasaran, who had defended the ban on entry of women in the age group of 10-50 years into the Sabarimala temple.In Video: Larger questions of law can be framed by a review bench: SC on Sabarimala case

Title: Six bank chiefs facing CBI, ED probe, says govt
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Former ICICI Bank MD Chanda Kochhar is among those facing investigation.

NEW DELHI: The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) and Enforcing Directorate (ED) are investigating cases against half-a-dozen managing directors and CEOs of commercial banks, although no arrests have been made so far, the government informed Parliament on Monday.

Separately, the CBI has sought prosecution of over 800 public sector bank employees, including presidential appointees such as chairmen, MDs and executive directors of state-run entities since 2017. In at least 139 cases, the government had declined request for prosecution, the finance ministry said in Lok Sabha. The ministry, however, was silent on whether the probe involved serving or former top bankers. Apart from former ICICI Bank CEO and MD Chanda Kochhar , ex-PNB chief Usha Ananthasubramanian , and United Bank's former CMD Archana Bhargava and ex-UCO Bank boss Arun Kaul are among those facing investigation. An inquiry need not translate into prosecution.

In recent years, action against bankers has been on the rise. "Banking corruption and occurrence of frauds was enabled by lack of discipline in the financial system and a lax credit culture across across various stakeholders. The role of bankers, too, was not as rigorously examined earlier, and auditors were not independently regulated. Through extensive reforms, change in credit culture has been instituted and controls have been tightened for every stakeholder in the financial system, which has enabled a tighter check on corruption," the government said.

Title: Under oppn fire, BJP says SC’s quota ruling was on Cong govt’s 2012 order
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Social justice and empowerment minister Thawarchand Gehlot

NEW DELHI: The government said on Monday that it was not party to a case where the Supreme Court ruled that it is not mandatory for states to implement quotas, and asserted that it is committed to reservations in the face of a concerted opposition attack in Parliament that the Centre had failed to defend the measures in court.

The MPs demanded that a review petition be filed in the SC. In Rajya Sabha too, the opposition came together to demand that the Centre approach the court on its ruling which held that Article 16(4) is enabling in nature permitting implementation of quotas but not making them mandatory. Disappointed with the Centre's response, the opposition staged a walkout.

Social justice and empowerment minister Thawarchand Gehlot said the Centre is committed to the welfare of SCs, STs and OBCs and will take "appropriate steps" after discussions at the "highest level". He said the Centre was not asked to file an affidavit.

Sources said the Centre believes it has options of judicial review and ordinance to redress the situation arising out of the SC's order. While the issue has not been formally taken up at the top echelons of government, there was a preliminary discussion in the SJE ministry on the sensitive subject.

The options have been exercised in recent years when the Centre found the court orders on Dalit rights and quotas unacceptable, be it the dilution of the Prevention of Atrocities Act and the 100-point roster for reservation in promotions. In Parliament, BJP alleged that the previous Congress government in Uttarakhand initiated the matter in 2012.

Gehlot said the top court order pertains to a 2012 decision of that government and asserted that the Centre is "committed" and "dedicated" to quotas for SCs, STs and OBCs.

A s soon as Question Hour started, Congress' Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury raised the issue. He was joined by others, including A Raja (DMK), Kalyan Banerjee (TMC), E T Mohammed Basheer (IUML), CPM's A M Ariff, Supriya Sule (NCP), Ritesh Pandey (BSP).

The SC has held that states are not bound to provide reservation in appointments and there is no fundamental right to claim quotas. The SC was dealing with pleas regarding the Uttarakhand government's September 5, 2012 move to fill up all posts in public services without quotas to SC/STs. The order was quashed by the HC.

Defence minister Rajnath Singh said Congress is trying to politicise a sensitive issue. Chowdhury and Banerjee said there has been an onslaught on SC/ST quota since the Modi government took over.

Anupriya Patel said one of the reasons for such rulings was low representation of SC/ST and OBCs in judiciary. "The government should immediately intervene," she added.

In RS, leader of opposition Ghulam Nabi Azad said it was a serious issue concerning about one-fourth of the country's population.

Title: Sunny Leone looks ravishing in shiny white thigh-high slit ensemble!
Content: Sushant Singh Rajput’s death case is currently being investigated by the Central Bureau Of Investigation (CBI) and they have been questioning a lot of people connected to the late actor. According to the latest report on India Today, three officers who are a part of the probe, have stated that their team has so far not found any evidence that suggests Sushant was murdered on June 14.

Title: Govt plugs Ayushman gap that denied treatment to the poor
Content:
Pankaj (L) died after failing to get a bone marrow transplant at AIIMS even though his brother was available a... Read More

Bringing relief to hundreds of poor patients, the health ministry has finally decided to allow Ayushman Bharat beneficiaries to be given financial assistance up to Rs 15 lakh under the Rashtriya Aarogya Nidhi (RAN), a scheme meant for below poverty line families, if their treatment is not covered under Ayushman Bharat's approved list of packages.On January 31, the ministry issued a memorandum stating that "if as per medical advice the suggested treatment is not covered under any of the approved list of packages of AB-PMJAY ", financial assistance up to Rs 15 lakh could be provided for treatment at government super speciality hospitals.Poor patients suffering from end-stage renal disease, chronic kidney disease, chronic liver disease, aplastic anaemia and cancers needing transplant stand to benefit from this decision.Last month, TOI had reported the death of 17-year-old Pankaj, a patient of aplastic anaemia, who was prohibited from availing financial assistance under RAN because his name figured in the Ayushman database. We had also pointed out that many others face a similar situation.A health ministry office memorandum on guidelines for RAN dated February 1, 2019 stated that families covered under Ayushman would not be eligible for financial assistance under RAN and the Health Minister's Cancer Fund .That sealed Pankaj's fate as his father ran from pillar to post for almost a year trying to get funds for a bone marrow transplant for him which was estimated to cost Rs 12 lakh even at AIIMS.Bone marrow transplant is not covered under Ayushman.AIIMS' medical SI had brought this issue to the ministry's notice in August 2019. However, it wrote back to AIIMS on October 4 stating that the suggestions of the National Health Authority and AIIMS "cannot be agreed to" since there could be "misuse"."There are hundreds of patients who were being denied treatment in super specialty government hospitals across India because of the guidelines issued last year. It was frustrating for doctors to turn away patients whose lives could be saved," said Dr Vijay Gurjar, assistant professor in the department of Geriatrics at AIIMS, Delhi, who had championed the cause.According to the latest memorandum, the financial assistance will be in the form of 'one-time grant'. It further clarified that patients suffering from rare diseases listed in the annexure to the February 2019 RAN guidelines would continue to be eligible for financial assistance under RAN for packages not covered under Aysuhman.

Title: Two Yuva JD(U) officials expelled
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

PATNA: Two state Yuva JD(U) functionaries have been expelled for running a campaign on social media platforms in support of poll strategist Prashant Kishor, who was expelled from JD(U) on January 29 for his stand different from party line on Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), NPR and NRC.

“While Chandan Kumar Singh, state general secretary and former president of Patna Mahanagar Yuva JD(U), was expelled for speaking in favour of the expelled JD(U) leader and poll strategist Prashant Kishor. Another state general secretary, Pawan Singh Rawat, has also been expelled for extending his support to rebel party leader and former state minister Narendra Singh,” Yuva JD(U) state president and MLA Abhay Kushwaha told TOI on Monday.

“Despite Kishor’s expulsion from the party, Chandan kept writing in his support on Facebook and WhatsApp. Similarly, Rawat has launched a campaign on his Facebook page urging people to attend a meeting called by former agriculture minister Narendra Singh at Jamui on February 16,” Kushwaha said. He said, both Chandan and Rawat continued to work against the party’s line despite warnings.

Still a JD(U) leader, Narendra is up in the arms against the state government ever since Munger SP Lipi Singh ordered to issue warrant of arrest against him and his son and former MLA Sumit Singh for their alleged involvement in a criminal case.

Narendra and his supporters on Sunday held a dharna in Patna to protest the action of Munger SP, who enjoys the support of a section of senior JD(U) leaders.

Title: Five-day ‘Bihar Expo’ concludes
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

PATNA: The five-day ‘Destination Bihar Expo ’, which was jointly organized by the Bihar Industries Association (BIA) and the state industries department at Gandhi Maidan, ended on Monday.

Addressing the concluding ceremony, health minister Mangal Pandey said, “Bihar is attracting industrialists as it has the capability to fulfil their demands. The state has every necessity, be it roads or electricity.”

Pandey also claimed that Bihar’s health sector was growing at a fast pace.

BIA president Ram Lal Khetan said, “The motive behind organizing the expo was to show that Bihar is as an industrially and economically developed state and has numerous resources as well as infrastructure for kick-starting any business.”

Over 350 stalls, including those of different government departments, were set up at the expo, which started on February 6. Traders and entrepreneurs from states like Karnataka and Maharashtra also displayed an array of products.

The entrepreneurs reportedly did brisk business at the five-day expo. “The response from shoppers was great as I earned nearly Rs 65,000. Several people revisited my stall for buying soaps,” said Arun Prakash, the owner of a stall selling natural soaps and candles.

Title: Bus carrying 50 students overturns near Chikhli, six injured
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

The condition of the injured children is said to be normal

Surat: About 50 students and five teachers of a primary school in Ankleshwar, who were going to Saputara for picnic , had a miraculous escape after their bus overturned near Chikhli on early Monday morning.

While majority of the students escaped unhurt, about six children in the age group of 12 years to 13 years were shifted to the New Civil Hospital (NCH) at Surat for further treatment. The condition of the injured children is said to be normal.

Shikshan samiti of the Ankleshwar district panchayat had organized the picnic for the primary students of the Amrutpara primary school. They had started early in the morning.

Sources in the Chikhli police station said the bus driver lost control at the sharp curve naer Kukeri-Chakaria village on the Rankuva-Vansda road. Immediately after the accident, people from nearby village came to the rescue of the children and they were removed from the bus.

Police stated that the bus is owned by Krishna Tours and Travels based in Ankleshwar. The driver of the bus Raju Pandit escaped from the spot after the accident.

School principal Raman Gohil told TOI: “We had taken permission from the competent authorities before organizing the picnic. We sent a separate bus from Ankleshwar to Chikhli for bringing the students back. Except for the injured students, the other students returned home safely.”

Owner of the luxury bus, Gajendra Singh said, “The driver lost control at the sharp turn even as he was driving slowly. We are lucky that the children are safe.”

Title: Wadhwan jeweller kidnapped by three
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Rajkot: A jeweller was kidnapped from Wadhwan town of Surendranagar district on Sunday night. Police said they found the car in which the victim, Shashikant Mandalia , was allegedly kidnapped. It was abandoned by the roadside near Darbar Boarding in Wadhwan on Monday.

“We suspect that the accused abducted Mandalia for money. However, the family members of Mandalia have not received any ransom call from the kidnappers so far, said police. “As the car in which Mandalia was kidnapped was abandoned, it is suspected that the accused have changed the vehicle,” said a senior official from Wadhwan B division police station.

Though the identities and the accused is yet to be ascertained, sources in the Wadhwan police said that atleast three persons were involved in executing the crime.

Mandalia was kidnapped from near his residence in Vishwaprem Park near Wadhwan milk dairy. “According to an eye-witness, the accused had arrived in a white car without a registration number and kidnapped Mandalia,” said the police official, adding that it was the same car which was found abandoned.

Meanwhile, protesting against Mandalia’s kidnapping, jewellers of Wadhwan Soni Bazaar observed a day long strike by downing shutters of their shops on Monday.

Title: Son kills 80-year-old father over property dispute in Talaja village, held
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Rajkot: A man hacked his father to death in Datrad village of Talaja taluka, following a property dispute on Sunday night. The accused son was arrested on early Monday morning.

According to police, the accused, identified as Bharat Rathod, had killed his father Narshi Rathod (80) to death with an axe. Along with Bharat, police also arrested Bharat’s son Vishal and brother-in-law Arwind Makwana for helping Bharat in the crime.

Narshi had divided his land and had distributed among his two sons — Bhim Rathod and Sukha Rathod. However, he did not give share of his property to Bharat.

When Bharat asked for his share, Narshi would tell him that his brothers were giving him money and that if he started giving him money, he too would be given his share.

On the fateful night, a meeting of the Rathod family was organized which turned stormy with Bharat asking for his share of land from Narshi.

“When Narshi stubbornly refused to budge from his stand, Bharat allegedly dragged him down from the cot he was sitting on. When Narshi hit Bharat’s leg with a stick, an angry Bharat went into his house and came out with an axe with which he hit Narshi on his head. Vishal and Makwana were also involved in the attack,” said an official from Talaja police station.

Initially, the accused tried to mislead the cops by saying that unidentified robbers had attacked Narshi. However, when the police interrogated the accused, they broke down and confessed to their crime.

Title: Two arrested in angadia loot case
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Rajkot: Two men who had allegedly robbed an angadia firm employee of Rs 1.60 lakh cash in Surendranagar on Saturday were nabbed on Monday.

The accused were identified as Ghanshyam Satapara and Pankaj Rajgor, both residents of Botad. Satapara and Rajgor had allegedly barged into Madhav Magan Angadia Firm in Dwarkesh Complex on Tower Main Road in Surendranagar. At that time the firm employee, identified as Arjan Rabari, was alone.

“The accused had allegedly hit Rabari on his head with a hammer and robbed him of Rs 1.60 lakh cash. However, the accused were caught on the CCTV camera of the firm, following which we launched a manhunt for them. Their hunt led us to Botad from where the duo was arrested,” said A H Gori, inspector with Surendranagar A division police station.

Of the accused, Satapara used to work in Surendranagar earlier, and he had allegedly done the recce of the angadia firm and had plotted the loot plan.

Title: Review meeting for sanitary workers’ welfare held
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Madurai: Member of the national commission for safai karamcharis, Jagadish Hiremani conducted a review meeting for sanitary workers working in various establishments in Theni district on Tuesday.

Theni district collector Pallavi M Baldev presided over the meeting, in which the members listened to the grievances of sanitary workers from the six municipalities, eight panchayat unions and 22 town panchayats, TADCO, Adi Dravida welfare board among others. He enquired about their wages and facilities provided to them. Many of the workers expressed their grievances and were assured of action. Later, he said that the various schemes being implemented for the welfare of these workers in Theni district were satisfactory.

It should be ensured that the salaries of the permanent workers were directly deposited in the bank accounts of the concerned workers and the wages through contractors should also be monitored closely by the authorities, he said. They should be provided protective gear for their work, including gloves, slippers and uniforms. In no circumstances should manual scavenging be encouraged anywhere in the district, he said. Education of children of sanitary workers should be given priority and it should be ensured that they benefited from the government schemes without delay, he said.

Title: Three killed as car gets crushed between bus, truck
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Mangled remains of the car

Palanpur: Three persons including a woman were killed in an accident involving three vehicles — a luxury bus, a truck and a car— near Iqbalgadh in Amirgadh taluka of Banskantha about 30km from here on Monday. Eleven people injured in the accident that took place around 5pm are under treatment at different hospitals.

The accident took place at about 5pm when the car in which six people were travelling got crushed between a truck and the bus carrying a marriage party. Police said that the truck driver had tried to enter the national highway from wrong side.

The car was going from Palanpur to Rajasthan, while the bus was headed towards Bharuch from Jodhpur in Rajasthan, said police.

The deceased were identified as Meghna Joshi (42), her daughter Adhya Joshi (12), both resident of Palanpur and Nitish Kumar (45) Joshi currently living in Rajkot. Three injured in the accident are critical and have been rushed to Ahmedabad, while remaining eight injured were admitted in civil hospital in Palanpur.

Title: Rajkot first to get Green Building Certificate for PMAY scheme
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Rajkot: Rajkot has become the first city in the country to obtain the ‘Green Building Certificate’ for it’s affordable housing scheme.

Rajkot Municipal Corporation (RMC) claimed that the civic body received this honour for providing better services for houses constructed for people from lower income.

The certification was issued for the houses constructed near Aryaland Residency near Mavdi area under PMAY (Pradhan Mantri Awas Yogna) scheme.

The civic body has constructed 1,176 houses for economically weaker sections, RMC said in a statement.

These houses have openable windows instead of sliding ones, ventilators on all the openings, provision of cavity wall on southern side, solar rooftop system for common electricity requirement, rain water harvesting, and centrally located green space.

Title: Bihar government to boost scientific farming: Sushil Kumar Modi
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Sushil Kumar Modi

PATNA: Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi said on Monday that the project to incentivize and promote new scientific farming and crop cycle as necessitated by irregular weather conditions would be introduced in all the districts of the state from the next fiscal.

Modi said such a farming practice is already under implementation in 1,442 acres of land spread over 40 villages on an experimental basis in Gaya, Nawada, Nalanda, Bhagalpur, Banka, Munger, Khagaria and Madhubani districts and would now be replicated in rest of the districts.

The farming activities of selected farmers who have opted for this experimental farming practice in the eight districts are being guided and monitored by agriculture scientists, so that new crop cycle comes into use in the state in view of the adverse conditions caused by climate change and extreme weather conditions, Modi also said, adding that the government has allotted Rs60.50 crore to be spent over the next five financial years in the selected 40 villages.

Modi was addressing the farmers who had been invited to participate in the pre-budget consultative exercise on the agriculture sector to get their suggestions. Principal secretaries of finance and agriculture departments — S Siddharth and Sudhir Kumar, respectively — were also present on the occasion.

Modi said 1.20 crore farmers were getting money under various schemes directly into their personal bank accounts through the direct benefit transfer method, while Rs1,157.21 crore had been disbursed among 18.85 lakh farmers as assistance to them due to adverse weather conditions and natural disaster in the last two financial years.

Modi said the government has been trying to promote organic farming in the state due to the increased demand for farm products produced by that method. Accordingly, each farmer choosing to practice organic farming was being given Rs11,500 per acre of land as input subsidy. The budgetary allotment of Rs155 crore had been made for it in the 2019-20 fiscal.

He also pointed to 40-80% subsidy being given on the purchase of farm equipment, as part of the government’s bid for farm mechanization, adding that general category farmers were getting 75% subsidy, while those belonging to the extremely backward caste, scheduled caste and scheduled tribe sections were given 80%.

Title: Residents complain about ‘slow progress’ of cleaning in Patna
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

A sanitation worker of Patna Municipal Corporation removes garbage on Bailey road near Raja Bazar locality in ... Read More

PATNA: Residents of several localities on Monday complained about garbage still strewn on streets even 48 hours after the sanitation workers of Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) ended their indefinite strike on Saturday evening.

Patna mayor Sita Sahu had assured on Saturday that the city would be cleaned in 48 hours. Residents of Rupaspur, Bhikhna Pahadi, SK Puri and Jagdeo Path among other areas complained that neither garbage was removed nor bleaching powder was sprinkled in their localities.

Babita Kumari of Ram Krishna Nagar said the PMC is concentrating only on major roads and other posh areas for removing garbage. She complained that even door-to-door household garbage collection has not started in her neighbourhood. “People are still throwing garbage on roadside and in the overflowing dustbins,” Babita said.

Hemlata of Rajendra Nagar road number 12 complained of carcasses of cattle and dogs lying near a park in her neighbourhood. “We have even called the helpline number of PMC but no one came for cleaning,” she said.

Rajkesh Dubey near Bakri Bazaar at Station Road said the workers dumped all garbage at the proposed site for vending zone under Patna Smart City project. “They throw garbage as well as carcasses,” he said.

“Residents are still throwing garbage on the roadside instead of waiting for auto-tipper. In search of food, stray dogs and cattle tear open plastic bags and spill the waste over the road. It is simply sickening,” said Sharmishtha of Thakurbari Road.

PMC officials, on the other hand, claimed that the sanitation workers were continuously on the job. The mayor told this newspaper that all the major roads were cleaned. “We are now focusing on narrow lanes and other localities. The situation will be normal by the end of this week,” she said.

PMC’s public relations officer Harshita said the executive officers and sanitary inspectors have pressed all the 375 auto-tippers, 182 e-carts, JCB machines, automatic sweeping machines, hand-held fogging machines and vehicle mounted fogging machines into service to make the city clean.

“The PMC has set the target to remove all the garbage from secondary points in next three days. Also, people who are littering garbage will attract a fine up to Rs1 lakh,” she said.

The PMC’s social media pages, helpline numbers and City of Patna mobile application have also suddenly come alive as the civic body has been receiving a large number of complaints to remove garbage from their localities. Harshita said sanitary inspectors were redressing the complaints in 24 hours. “However, we are facing some issues in interior areas of the city. But the situation will improve in three days,” she said.

Title: Bihar: Maoists have close links with liquor mafia
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The state police have exposed close links of some country liquor brewers with the Maoists operating in Munger, Jamui and Lakhsarai districts.

The startling fact came to light during a special operation launched by the police to flush out Maoists in the three districts under Munger range. The police also destroyed the country brewing units in deep forests and hilly terrains during the recent drive.

Sharing details of the operation, DIG (Munger range) Manu Maharaaj said on Monday that some hardcore Maoist leaders, including Arjun Kora and Baleshwar Kora, revealed during interrogation that country liquor brewing units were running with the tacit support of the banned Naxal outfit.

The Maoist leaders also admitted that the tribal residents were being encouraged to brew liquor with mahua and supply the consignment to the liquor smugglers in the region. “Needless to say lion’s share of the income goes to the Naxal outfit,” the DIG said, quoting the Maoist leaders.

The police would intensify raids in the areas identified as ‘safe zone’ of liquor brewing in the three districts. “The motive behind the operation is to attack the sources of income of the Maoists. In Munger, the police operation met with success. Lakhisarai and Jamui are on the pipeline,” Maharaaj said.

More than 100 hardcore Maoist activists, including self-proclaimed commanders such as Ramesh Hebram, Kailu Kora and Gorelal Naiyar were arrested ever since the 2005-batch IPS officer was posted as DIG about a year ago. “We are motivating the tribals not to indulge in unlawful activates. At the same time, we are trying to provide them alternative sources of income,” Maharaaj revealed.

Title: Gas leakage incidents in Patna raise safety concern
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The high-intensity explosion probably due to leakage from LPG cylinder at a house in Salimpur Ahra near Gandhi Maidan here on Monday morning has once again raised concern about safe handling of gas cylinders and precautions needed to be taken by the residents while using LPG in their homes.

According to police officials, there was no ventilation in the room where the cylinder was kept and gas leaked. Traffic SP D Amarkesh, who is incharge city SP (central), told this newspaper that the LPG leaked from the broken hosepipe and spread in the house. “There was no ventilation in the kitchen and all windows were closed. When a woman lit a matchstick, fire broke out,” he said.

Officials of Bihar Fire Services claimed that such incidents are quite common in state, but most of the fire incidents take place in rural areas during winter season.

RK Mishra, DG of Bihar Fire Services, told this newspaper that it was the second fire incident due to gas leakage in Patna in the last five months. “We have compiled the data of fire incidents in the state in the last five years and we are now trying to find out the reason behind such incidents. Accordingly, we will make people aware about precautions to be taken to prevent such incidents.”

Mishra said around 10,000 fire incidents occurred in Bihar in 2019. “We have conducted 3,000 fire audits and 5,000 mock drills across the state last year,” he said.

The oil marketing companies said they issued handbooks of dos and don’ts to people when they buy LPG connections and cylinder.

An official of Indian Oil Corporation Limited said most of the cooking gas fire incidents take place due to gas leakage from rubber tube, burner mistakenly kept on and poor handling of gas appliances. “We issue all important instructions about usage of cooking gas in our manual handbook but customers do not pay much attention to these things,” an official said.

Title: Gujarat: Duped by tall claims, 3'9" woman kills self
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Afreen Khatiq with husband Anwar

SURAT: In a bizarre case, a 22-year-old woman committed suicide after prolonged depression caused by her short height on Monday.

The woman Afreen Khatiq was found hanging by the ceiling fan at her house in Magdulnagar in Sachin GIDC area. She had sent her husband Anwar, who owns a photography studio, to purchase toilet cleaner. When he returned after an hour, he saw her hanging.

Anwar and other family members told police that Afreen was extremely depressed over her short height. She was around 3.9 foot while Anwar was 5.4 foot tall.

Seeing an advertisement on social media three months ago, she had also started taking some ayurvedic powder of a popular brand that promised to increase height. However, when the medication did not yield desired results, her depression aggravated.

"After attending family functions or community gatherings, Afreen often rued even kids were taller than her. She used to get very upset after visiting such functions and felt depressed," Anwar told TOI.

Anwar added that she looked constantly worried over the past few days. “She told me that despite all efforts and medicines, her height was not increasing. She had consumed three bottles of ashwagandha churna of a popular brand in three months but did not get any result," he added. Initially, officials of Sachin GIDC did not fully believe that this could be the reason for the drastic step. Cops verified the reason with neighbours and her parents too who live in Limbayat.

"Her neighbours and other known people confirmed that there was no other issue between the couple, but she was obsessed with her short height. She always express her wish to grow taller," said a police officer at Sachin GIDC police station.

Anwar had purchased three bottles the churna from a store of the brand in Bhestan area. Each bottle costs around Rs 105 and Afreen started drinking milk as per the directions mentioned on the bottle. She had even stopped consuming oily food and started dieting to ensure that the medicine has the desired effect, her family members said.

Before marriage too, Afreen had tried various medicines but her height did not increase.

Title: Coronavirus in Surat: Three patients test negative for coronavirus
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

SURAT: City health officials and family members of three patients, who were under isolation after returning from China, heaved a sign of relief after they tested negative for the deadly coronavirus.

National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune confirmed that none of the three were infected.

Of the three, a 41-year-old Varachha resident was discharged from SMIMER hospital as his observation period ended. However, the 21-year-old MBBS student from Puna area and the 33-year-old businessman from Adajan are still under observation at SMIMER and New Civil Hospital (NCH) respectively.

"The two haven’t been discharged as the period to keep them under health observation has not yet ended. They agreed to stay admitted in hospital," said a health official. However, they are no more in isolation and are being allowed to meet family members.

The patients were suffering from cold and coughing and their health did not improve despite medication after which they were put under isolation and samples were collected for tests on January 4 and 5.

Meanwhile, city's government hospital has declared that those approaching for medical test with fever, cough, cold or any respiratory problem should approach the separate ward created for this purpose. These patients should not go to the outpatient department (OPD), the hospital officials informed.

Some other individuals have been advised home quarantine as they returned from China. But, none of them have been found ill till now. Health officials are not declaring the exact number of patients under observation as per the guidelines.

Title: Borrower’s consent must for change in interest rate on loan: Consumer court
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The district consumer court has ruled that a borrower’s consent is critical to applying change in the floating rate of interest by banks or financial institutions.“Mere sending of letters to the borrower does not mean that the latter has given consent to continue his loan account with change in interest rate,” the bench of consumer court president Umesh V Jawalikar and members Kshitija Kulkarni and Sangita Deshmukh observed in a recent order. The banks/financial institutions are also bound to strictly adhere to Reserve Bank of India’s guidelines regarding change in rate of interest, it added.The consumer court directed City Financial Consumer Finance India Limited (now CitiCorp Finance India Limited) and Citi Bank NA to handover no-dues certificate and all documents received at the time of mortgage, to Kharadi resident Manik Khedkar and also pay him Rs45,000 towards compensation and cost of litigation.City Financial claimed in its written submission that it was unnecessarily made party to the proceedings, as the loan portfolio stood assigned to Citi Bank NA It claimed that the complainant was intimated about the takeover of his loan portfolio by Citi Bank NA and details of the new loan schedule was also conveyed by way of speed post.Citi Bank NA claimed that by signing the loan agreement, the complainant had accepted the clause relating to the right to assign loan and his negligence in understanding the terms and conditions of loan agreement precluded him from blaming the bank.The court, however, observed that the opposite parties (the two firms) did not produce on record any proof about the complainant’s consent in respect of a change in interest rate. Also, the RBI’s guidelines relating to application of change in interest were not followed, it observed. The court relied on two judgments by the National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission in 2012 and 2017 with regards to adherence to RBI guidelines.“There are certain clauses in the loan agreement, which are apparently not in conformity with RBI guidelines and these clauses constitute an ‘unfair trade practice’ on the part of the opposite parties. Also, the agreement itself becomes voidable as certain provisions in it are against the law of the land,” the court held. It gave 45 days, from the date of order, to both the firms to comply with its directives.

Title: Union Bank posts Rs 575 crore profit in Q3
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

(File photo)

MUMBAI: Union Bank of India has reported a net profit of Rs 575 crore for the quarter ended December 2019, nearly four times the Rs 153 crore it earned in the year-ago period.

Profits were higher on the back of lower provisions of Rs 1,570 crore towards NPAs during the quarter, down 72% from Rs 5,783 crore in the previous year. Overall provisions fell 64% to Rs 1,827 crore. Of the total provisions, Rs 2,260 crore was made toward a single large account in the housing finance sector, believed to be DHFL. Apart from that, the slippages were in keeping with trend, the bank’s MD & CEO Rajkiran Rai said.

The banks gross advances grew 5.9% to Rs 3.36 lakh crore. Deposits rose 10% year-on-year to Rs 4.45 lakh crore from Rs 4.02 lakh crore. The bank also reduced its home loan interest rates by up to 30 basis points (100 bps = 1 percentage point) from 8.2% to 7.9% for some categories.

“There is a steady improvement in operating efficiency. This quarter, we had good recoveries in Essar Steel, Ruchi Soya and Prayagraj. These three accounts brought in nearly Rs 2,000 crore. Recoveries and upgradations amounted to Rs 2,837 crore,” said Rai. He added the bank is looking at another Rs 3,000-crore recovery and upgradations during the current quarter.

Around Rs 1,500 crore recoveries are expected from large accounts in the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT), he said.

Rai said the bank expects good credit growth in the last quarter and the RBI’s term repo will bring down the lender’s cost of funds, which will be passed on to borrowers in the form of lower marginal cost of lending rate (MCLR). He said the interest rates on one-year deposits could come down by 25 bps in the one-year category.

Title: Girl rescued, three held in Begusarai
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

BEGUSARAI: A 15-year-old girl from Patna was freed from the clutches of a gang of sex racketeers after a police team led by Begusarai DSP (headquarters) Kundan Kumar raided a house in Bakhri red-light area under Bakhri police station in the district on Saturday evening. After conducting medical examination, the girl has been sent for counselling, the police said.

According to the DSP (HQ), the raid was conducted on information provided by a Delhi-based NGO that the girl had been forcibly kept there.
