Bakhri police station SHO Mukesh Kumar Pawan said members of the NGO were present during the raid. The police team also arrested three persons from whose house the girl was recovered. Those arrested were identified as Mantun Nut, Sunita Devi and Mira Devi.

Sources said the girl told police that she was brought to Begusarai from Patna several years ago by one Punam Devi, another wife of Mukesh Nut, and was forced into the flesh trade. The local police conducted the raid following information provided by the NGO that the gang was running a sex racket, involving minor girls.

Title: RJD seeks review of SC order on quota
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

PATNA: The leader of opposition in the assembly, Tejashwi Yadav, on Monday demanded that the Centre either file a review petition against the Supreme Court’s ruling on reservations in government jobs and promotions, or pass a Constitution amendment bill in the current Parliament session and make such reservations a fundamental right.

The apex court on Friday had said that states were not bound to give reservations to scheduled castes (SCs), scheduled tribes (STs) or other backward castes in government jobs or quota in promotions.

“We are not going to stay quiet. This government talks of benefitting Hindus and I want to know whether Dalits or Backwards who have got reservation are Hindus or not? They are trying to do away with all kinds of reservation, but we will never let that happen. Their words differ from their work,” said Tejashwi, adding, his party would hold protests on the streets and Parliament.

Attacking the BJP government in Uttrakhand for advocating against the reservation in SC, Tejashwi said, “Their lawyers in the court had argued against reservation.”

He also took on LJP patron Ram Vilas Paswan and JD (U) chief Nitish Kumar for “helping in executing RSS agenda” and staying silent on the issue. “I want to know where is Ram Vilas is ji and Nitish ji now? Both are sitting quietly and instead helping RSS,” Tejashwi said.

Incarcerated RJD chief Lalu Prasad also took to Twitter and said: “Why don’t those who talk about ending reservation talk about doing away with the caste system? It is because the caste system elevates them… I talk of doing away with the disease, but they talk of doing away with the treatment.”

Govt will resolve quota issue: JD(U): JD (U)’s Munger MP Rajiv Ranjan Singh said in Lok Sabha on Monday that the government will resolve the issue relating to Supreme Court order on SC/ST Act amicably. “The Supreme Court order on February 7…The subject is highly sensitive. We are of the view that the entire House is of one opinion on this issue. When entire House is of one opinion and an order has come from the Supreme Court there should not be any politics on this matter.”

He added: “When the Supreme Court had given its judgment on SC/ ST Act, then an environment of doubt was being created in the country. But the government brought an amendment bill and proved its intentions. Hence, we believe that that government is capable of resolving this issue amicably.”

Title: Foundation laid for café library
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

PATNA: Vice-chancellor (VC) Rash Bihari Prasad Singh laid the foundation for a 24X7 cafeteria library in Patna University (PU) on Monday. With internet facilities and e-books, it is located adjacent to the central library.

“A decision in this regard was taken during the centenary celebrations of the PU library last year. The government has already sanctioned necessary funds for constructing a building and buying computers. The library will start functioning in a couple of months,” the VC said, adding that at least 24 computers would be purchased in the first phase.

5-day workshop: PU VC Rash Bihari Prasad Singh on Monday pleaded for an extensive survey of the entire state for collection of manuscripts that have not been taken care of.

Singh was the chief guest of the valedictory function of a five-day workshop on ‘Preservation and Conservation of Manuscripts’ organized by PU library in collaboration with the National Mission for Manuscripts.

“By preserving rare and valuable manuscripts, we will be preserving our heritage and culture,” the VC said.

National Mission for Manuscripts coordinator Kirti Srivastava, museologist Sanjib Kumar Singh and archaeologist Sanjay Kumar Manjul also spoke on the occasion.

Title: Power engineers call off proposed strike on HC intervention
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

PATNA: Union bodies of Bihar State Power Holding Company Limited as well as its subsidiary companies on Monday called off their proposed 24-hour strike on February 11 and 12 after the intervention of Patna high court. They were to go on strike on a rumour that the power companies will be privatized.

Division bench of Chief Justice Sanjay Karol and Justice S Kumar on Monday asked the union bodies of the power companies and their office-bearers to exercise restraint from causing unprecedented plight to people of the state and immediately call off their strike or resume their work as soon as they could.

The direction was issued by the division bench while hearing a writ petition filed by one Sudhanshu Trivedi from Nalanda district. “The Unions may have their legitimate grievances in a democratic process, where role of law is the cornerstone of the Constitution of India. If any legitimate and expedient right or grievance is required to be redressed, the court is, therefore, the best forum apart from availing other alternatives, like conciliatory, mediatory and arbitrational actions,” the HC order stated.

The order further stated: “We are confident that the voice which we have raised and ventilated in this order will not be a cry in wilderness and reach to the ears of the leaders and they will resume the work, otherwise we shall have to consider stricter and sterner action after hearing the parties on February 11 at 2.15pm.”

The order was issued to BSPHCL and its union bodies including Power Engineering Services Association general secretary Surendra Kumar, Bihar State Electricity Supply Workers Union general secretary Chakradhar Prasad Singh, Junior Engineering Service Association general secretary Upendra Kumar Chaudhary, Bihar Bijli Majdoor Union general secretary Arjun Prasad and Bihar State Power Electricity Workers Union general secretary Dhirendra Kumar among others.

“We respect the court’s order and will fight for our rights under the jurisdiction of law. As the court has summoned us on February 11, we would put forth our grievances before the court,” Upendra told this newspaper.

“We need a written consent from the BSPHCL CMD Pratyaya Amrit that no privatization of power holding companies would take place. We don’t believe his words.”

Title: Kolkata: IT firm executive loses Rs 99,400 in fraudulent e-transactions
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

KOLKATA: A 43-year-old executive of an IT firm from Survey Park has claimed that he lost close to Rs 1 lakh from his account after three fraudulent transactions took place in January and February, allegedly to buy expensive items from an online portal. While the main FIR was lodged at Survey Park police station, the bank fraud section has also begun a probe as a new modus operandi seems to have surfaced with the victim insisting he had never shared any banking detail with anyone.

“Avijit Saha of Harisadhan Patwary Road had received at least three OTPs on January 29. He had, however, not noticed them and insisted he never shared any banking details with anyone. He became aware of the transactions when he found three payments of Rs 59,400, Rs 30,000 and Rs 10,000 had been made from his bank account for purchases from a seller on Amazon. When he went to the Prince Anwar Shah Road branch of the bank, he was told to update his passbook. His fears of being robbed were confirmed and the officials asked him to approach the police,” said an officer.

“The complaint is against three transactions from the complainant’s account for which he did not share OTPs received through SMS either with his bank or with any unknown person. Thus, the accused persons cheated the complainant to the tune of Rs 99,400 by making wrongful loss to complainant and corresponding wrongful gain to themselves,” the FIR stated.

In another incident, Hemant Singh from Belgachhia was duped of Rs 50,000 in the name of playing an online game of cricket. Singh was induced by a caller who promised huge returns if he played an online game called Dream 11 that carries instant monetary prizes. “He was asked to invest Rs 50,000, after which the caller stopped contacting him,” said an officer.

Police sources said that the questioning of five persons from Jamtara and Dhanbad who were recently arrested for their role in multiple similar crimes in the city since 2019 has lent fresh insight into how these gangs operate.

“Most gang members — including the leader — have not passed Class X. All members use different modus operandi to dupe people online. But if one person gets good results with a particular modus operandi, the entire gang begins using it. Initially, all the money gets transferred into a central account — essentially a village development fund account — before being disbursed among multiple others within a short span of time. For example in an e-wallet fraud detected by cops, the money looted was distributed among 250 accounts,” said joint CP (crime) Murlidhar Sharma .

Title: Kolkata: Ex-IAS officer dies as car falls into lake
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

The officer, Manabendra Chakraborty, who was working as an officer on special duty with the agriculture depart... Read More

KOLKATA: A former IAS officer working in extension with the state agriculture department died after his car fell into a lake while he was returning from a programme at Suryanagar near Baruipur on Monday.

The officer, Manabendra Chakraborty , who was working as an officer on special duty with the agriculture department, was returning from a fair at Nimpith when the accident happened.

According to cops, when Chakraborty’s vehicle reached Suryanagar, the car hit a lamp post, overturned and fell into a lake. Locals helped the driver, Kalideo Prasad , and his assistant Ershad Alam to rescue Chakraborty from the vehicle. “He was taken to a local nursing home and transferred to Baruipur sub-divisional hospital, where he was declared brought dead,” an officer said.

“It seems he sustained injuries on his head and neck when the car overturned and died before the car went in the water. The body has been sent for post-mortem,” a hospital official said. “The driver may have fallen asleep and lost control. We have detained him,” an officer said.

Agriculture minister Ashis Banerjee mourned Chakraborty’s death. Speaking to TOI, Banerjee said, “He was an honest and hard working officer and a nice human being. It was because of his sincerity that we referred him for extension. His death is a loss for the department.”

Title: Bihar: Protesters hurl eggs at Kanhaiya Kumar’s convoy in Jamui
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Kanhaiya Kumar

PATNA: CPI leader and former JNU students’ union president Kanhaiya Kumar ’s convoy faced the wrath of some supporters of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) once again in the state. The incident took place in Jamui district on Monday.

According to reports reaching the police headquarters, a group of CAA supporters threw eggs and sprinkled lubricants on the vehicle carrying Kanhaiya at Mahisiri Chowk near Adha in Jamui district. The former JNUSU leader was on his way to Aliganj from the district headquarters to address a public meeting against CAA, National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR).

Vehicular traffic on the Jamui-Sikandara Road remained affected for more than half an hour due to the protest against Kanhaiya’s visit to Jamui by some CAA supporters. His convoy left for the destination after the intervention of senior police officers.

“Nothing untoward happened with Kanhaiya, who is in Jamui to garner support for his ‘Jan Gana Mana’ rally in Patna,” a police officer said.

Kanhaiya, who is spearheading the anti-CAA, NRC and NPR campaign in the state, had earlier faced protests in Saran and Supaul districts. The CPI leader had reached Jamui on Sunday and stayed at the circuit house in the night. On Monday, he left for Aliganj, but his convoy was intercepted near Mahisiri Chowk by some youths, who shouted ‘Go back, Kanhaiya’ slogans.

Title: Proposal to reduce incentive for early tax payers rejected
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Rajkot: The standing committee of Rajkot Municipal Corporation (RMC) on Monday approved the budget of Rs 2,131.15 crore for the financial year 2020-21. The municipal commissioner had presented the budget of Rs 2,119.98 crore on February 1. The standing committee increased the budget size by Rs 12.17 crore and added some new schemes as this being an election year.

The standing committee has increased the saleable FSI (floor space index) target by Rs 10 crore. Standing committee chairman Uday Kangad said, “We have not imposed any new tax on citizens and tried to present the realistic picture. The new schemes announced have realistic targets and soon the citizen will see the results.”

RMC commissioner Udit Agrawal had proposed to reduce the amount of incentives for early tax payers, which the standing committee rejected and continued with the incentive scheme for those who pay tax early or online. The panel approved Rs 10 crore for road work and hiked the municipal councillor’s grant to Rs 15 lakh from current Rs 10 lakh.

The approved proposal also includes urban forestation in Aji dam area and recreational activities in the same area besides landscaping, water harvesting, and road development. For this the standing committee allotted Rs 12 crore.

A provision of Rs 50 lakh has been made for providing medical facilities to the stray animal in animal hostels. RMC also plans to construct new community halls in ward 1,3,6 and 13 in next financial year and for this a budget of Rs 3.35 crore has been allotted.

Title: IMFL worth Rs 5.76L seized from milk tanker
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

A total of 1,920 bottles of IMFL seized from Morbi on Sunday

Rajkot: Bootleggers appear to have zeroed in on milk tankers as their favourite mode for bootlegging. A total of 1,920 bottles of Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) worth Rs 5.76 lakh were seized from a milk tanker in Bharatnagar locality of Morbi on Sunday night.

“We had received a tip-off that a milk tanker was taking a cache of IMFL bottles from Maliya to Morbi, following which we kept a watch. Soon the tanker matching the registration number we were given arrived. However, the tanker driver abandoned the vehicle and disappeared into the cover of darkness,” said Bharat Jilaria of Morbi local crime branch.

The bootleggers had created a secret storage inside the tanker into which they had hidden the liquor bottles.

TWO ARRESTED WITH IMFL WORTH RS 1.74 LAKH

Two bootleggers were arrested with 540 bottles of Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) worth Rs 1.62 lakh and 120 cans of beer worth Rs 12,000 from Karachalipara Bharwadwada locality of Bhavnagar on Monday. The accused were identified as Rafiq Sheikh and Mohemmedhussein Belim.

Title: Stitch in time: Fabric makers to benefit as imports from China drop
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Surat: The coronavirus outbreak in China has come as a blessing for the country’s largest man-made fabric (MMF) sector where the powerloom weavers are targeting to ramp up the manufacturing of polyester fabric.

Industry sources said that the manufacturing of polyester fabric in the powerloom sector is likely to increase by about 20% with the import of cheap fabric from China has been stopped due to the outbreak of the epidemic.

Also, the weavers are expecting the cheaper import of fabrics from Vietnam and Bangladesh also to reduce after the government announced stringent check on imports under Free Trade Agreement (FTA) and the revision of ‘rules of origin’ to protect domestic industry.

Chairman of Federation of Indian Art Silk Weaving Industry (FIASWI), Bharat Gandhi said, “The MMF sector was hit hard due to the cheap import of fabrics from China. However, the import from China has significantly reduced due to the virus outbreak. The orders for fabric has increased in Surat and this is likely to increase the production of fabrics by almost from 3 crore metres per day to more than 3.5 crore metres”

Surat’s MMF sector consumes about one lakh metric tonnes of yarn per month. The industry has an installed capacity of 7.5 lakh powerloom machines, which includes highly sophisticated water jet, rapier and air jet looms.

The import of fabric from China, Vietnam and Bangladesh into India has increased from 207 million metric tonnes in 2015-2016 to 1,300 MMT in 2018-19, which hurt the local industry badly.

Gandhi said, “China was dumping cheap silk, viscose, polyester and nylon fabrics worth Rs 200 crore per month. We expect the import of fabric to stop completely from China due to corona virus and the government’s move to curtail imports through FTA and rules of origin.”

n 2015-16 about 207 million metric tones of fabric was imported and it went up to 1,300 million metric tones in 2018-19

Dinesh Zaveri, secretary of the Surat Art Silk Cloth Manufacturers Association (SASCMA) said, “The fabrics manufactured in the city were uncompetitive against the cheap fabrics manufactured in China. The Chinese fabrics are cheaper by Rs 46 per square metre compared to the fabric manufactured in Surat and other places. The demand for domestic fabric has increased now.”

Ashish Gujarati, president of Pandesara Weavers Association said, “Majority of the powerloom weavers were operating at 70% of their production capacity. Now, the production capacity has been increased with the demand for local fabrics has gone up after the corona virus outbreak in China. It is a win-win situation for the fabric manufacturers”

Title: Magicbricks lets lenders improve home loan recovery
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Mumbai: Magicbricks is helping small lenders improve recoveries in home loans by providing an e-auction platform for foreclosed properties. Lakhs of such properties are expected to come to the market given that housing is turning out to be the largest loan segment for banks.

According to Magicbricks CEO Sudhir Pai , banks and sellers are looking to liquidate their repossessed assets through credible platforms. “This has opened up a window of opportunity for banks and non-banking financial companies (NBFCs) to leverage Magicbricks for e-auction and recover some of their investments,” he said. Besides offering lenders an e-auction platform, which has certification by the government, Magicbricks also offers its retail reach. Magicbricks is part of the Times Group , which publishes this newspaper.

According to Care Ratings, the share of home loans to GDP has grown from 5.3% in 2004 to 9.1% in 2018. “The mortgage-to-GDP ratio for India is expected to grow significantly over the next few years as this is low, compared to other developing countries,” the report said. Outstanding home loans stood at Rs 12 lakh crore as of June 2019, according to TransUnion Cibil data. Assuming defaults of even 1%, the repossessed property market would stand at Rs 12,000 crore.

A host of lenders — including SBI , Indian Overseas Bank, Union Bank , Indian Bank , Saraswat Bank and UCO Bank — have used the platform to liquidate their re-possessed assets. Customers buying repossessed homes can also draw comfort from the fact that the banks have already done all the appraisal with respect to the property. “One must remember that all these properties have been put up by banks that have their own robust due diligence process. However, customers would be best advised that the properties put up for e-auction are on ‘as in, where in’ basis. This means that buyers should also avail the services of a lawyer to get the due diligence done,” said Pai.

“With more and more home buyers coming online and monthly traffic exceeding 20 million visits, we have become the automatic choice for all banks. In the last few years, e-auctions on Magicbricks have also improved retail reach and listings quality. It also offers a transparent process and educates customers while offering a level playing field through a transparent price discovery system,” he said.

Title: Three rounded up for murder of security guard in Vesu
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Surat: Umra police rounded up three persons on Monday in connection with the murder of a 35-year-old security guard in Vesu.

The body of Umakant Tiwari was dumped in an open plot behind Sarsana convention centre and the accused had poured acid on his face to make identification difficult. Tiwari, a security guard at Manira Garden apartment, had a fight with another guard Prem Singh over theft of mobile phone charge on February 4 at their common accommodation room. Singh hit him on the head with some blunt wooden object after which Tiwari collapsed. Singh left thinking that Tiwari would recover, but he returned the next day only to find him dead, police investigation revealed.

Meanwhile, when security supervisor Rajesh Pal came there, Singh described the incident to him. Fearing that he would have to face legal trouble, Pal planned to dump the body. Pal called his friend Sanjay Mishra, a scarp trader, for help and they wrapped the body and dumped it near the national highway 53 behind the convention centre. Later during the day, Pal and Singh went and poured acid on face of Tiwari.

On Monday, however, Pal approached police and described the details of the incident. "Police have rounded up few suspects and they are being questioned. The deceased was murdered over a petty issue," said a police officer at Umra police station.

Police are questioning Singh Pal and Mishra for their alleged.

Title: DHFL shows risks faced by lenders: Axis Bank chief
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Axis Bank managing director & CEO Amitabh Chaudhry (File photo)

MUMBAI: Axis Bank managing director & CEO Amitabh Chaudhry , said the DHFL default has turned lenders risk-averse and that reforms are needed to generate funds required for the Rs 100-lakh-crore infrastructure projects planned by the government.

Delivering the A D Shroff memorial lecture on ‘Who will finance risk in India’, Chaudhry said that to achieve the government’s target of $5-trillion economy, the growth rate would have to more than double to 12%, while Axis Bank’s projection was that it would grow by less than 6% in the next fiscal.

According to Chaudhry, funding will have to come from entrepreneurs, banks, new financial institutions, foreign investors, insurance and pension funds. Highlighting the risks faced by lenders, Chaudhry gave the example of DHFL.

“Last year, the wholesale loan book was declared to be Rs 22,000 crore. By December, it became Rs 32,000 crore and the latest number is Rs 45,000 crore,” he said. Pointing out that the company’s bonds were trading at a 75% discount, he said this was a company that was publicly quoted, audited and rated by agencies.

“Please understand that A bank or anyone who deals with a company are relying on some systems to do their job. When you find the wholesale book has doubled in size and there are a hundred thousand fake accounts, the faith in the system gets shaken,” said Chaudhry. This then leads to banks stopping funds to companies like DHFL. According to Chaudhry, lenders are not in a position to take such large losses on an account where there is not much scope of recovery from DHFL’s wholesale loans.

Highlighting the need for investment-driven growth, Chaudhry said the current slowdown has manifested in several ways — consumer goods, cars, real estate, electricity.

While the country needed capital, there were challenges. These included, the ability to create jobs, technical challenges, the robustness of institutions, the availability of capital, and the linkage in various networks of economic value.

“We have political risks; cancellation of licences, large tax demands, abandonment of projects from previous regime. The manifestation of political risks shows up in the sanctity of contracts. Sudden and sharp changes not just from administration but also from judiciary can throw economic system into peril,” he said.

Title: Amazon India slams probe by CCI, moves HC for a stay
Content:
(File photo)

BENGALURU: Amazon India has moved the Karnataka high court, seeking a stay on a probe by the Competition Commission of India (CCI). The e-tailer has slammed the probe, terming it “perverse, arbitrary and untenable in law” as it prepares for a legal battle.While Amazon has requested the court to quash or set aside this probe by the CCI, the e-commerce major is seeking an interim stay, without which, the company said, it would see “irreparable loss” and the same will hurt its brand goodwill.On January 13, CCI had ordered an investigation into the operations of US-owned e-tailers like Amazon India and Flipkart (in which Walmart owns a 77% stake) for various trade practices, including deep discounts and favourable terms to select sellers. This was done following a complaint by the Delhi Vyapar Mahasangh, a group representing small- and medium-sized businesses, against the two e-tailers who dominate the online retail market with an over 70% share.Legal experts said there was some strong language used by Amazon, which has invested $7 billion in India, against the competition regulator. “There is a strong prima facie case for a stay in favour of the petitioner (Amazon) as the impunged order has been passed without application in mind, the balance of inconvenience for the stay lies in favour of the petitioner…” Amazon said in its petition filed on Monday.The Amazon petition added that, while a stay order won’t impact CCI, it would affect Amazon if not granted. Interestingly, CCI’s order to probe Amazon came days before the US giant’s CEO Jeff Bezos landed in India last month, where he announced a fresh investment of $1 billion. Right after Bezos’s announcement, commerce and industry minister Piyush Goyal kicked up a row saying Amazon wasn’t “doing any favour” to India by investing as it was to cover up losses, even questioning how can a marketplace lose so much money.An Amazon India spokesperson said, “The matter is sub judice and hence we cannot offer any comments.” It is not clear if Flipkart is also likely to follow the same route. A Flipkart spokesperson did not immediately respond to TOI.A lawyer, who did not want to be named, pointed out a Bombay high court order in 2017 where the court had quashed a cartelisation probe against telecom companies like Airtel, Vodafone and Idea. The Supreme Court also later upheld the same order against the probe. “There is precedence in that sense. But it remains to be seen how this application moves,” this lawyer said. The matter is expected to be heard during this week.The complaint against Amazon and Flipkart has been in the making for a while as small traders have been complaining to the government over various practices by the e-tailer throughout 2019, which eventually led CCI to announce the probe. Prior to that, CCI had conducted a detailed study on the e-commerce market. Also, effective February last year, the government tightened the laws for FDI in e-commerce, which forced Amazon and Flipkart to make operational changes that affected their relations with certain sellers.Both Amazon and Flipkart officially maintain they are compliant with local laws but executives in these companies have been wary of frequent policy changes by the government, saying it hurts the growth of e-commerce here. In the Budget on February 1, the government announced a new withholding tax for e-commerce transactions, which would cause a liquidity squeeze for small and medium sellers. The e-tailers are seeking clarity and Amazon had said it was hoping for a simple and uniform tax regime in India.

Title: CRPF DG meets martyred jawan’s family in Bhojpur
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

CRPF DG Dr.A.P.Maheshwari honouring the family members of martyred CRPF personnel at CRPF office in Patna on M... Read More

ARA: The Director General (DG) of Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF), A P Maheshwari, on Monday visited Dev Tola, the native village of martyred jawan Ramesh Ranjan, under Jagdishpur block in Bhojpur district. The CRPF jawan had died fighting with the terrorists on the outskirts of Srinagar in Kashmir on February 5. Ramesh had joined the CRPF in 2011.

The DG met the martyr's father, Radhamohan Singh, a retired sub-inspector, his mother Sumitra Devi and wife Baby Devi and consoled them. He also offered floral tributes to the martyr.

Talking to mediapersons, Maheshwari said: “The forces as well as the entire country are with the martyr’s s family. We are proud of our martyred jawan. According to the rules of the government of India, all benefits and help that a martyr’s family deserves, are being given to Ramesh’s family.”

He added: “The martyr’s wife will get a job in CRPF as per the rules and her wish. As per the Prime Minister’s instructions, the school from where the martyred jawan has studied will be named after him and a function should be held in that school in his honour, so that the children could get inspiration for serving the country. We are also sending a proposal to the government of India for awarding a gallantry medal to Ramesh.”

Maheshwari said a high-level committee of the government will take a decision on the proposal for the gallantry medal.

Meanwhile, Ramesh’s father demanded that a memorial be constructed in honour of his son. The DG said: “Your son sacrificed his life after killing two terrorists. We all are very proud of him. We will do all things possible to accord him due honour.”

Title: Sri Lankan PM offers prayers at Mahabodhi Temple in Bodh Gaya
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Sri Lankan Prime Minister Mahendra Rajapakcha offers Prayer at Jaya Shree Mahabodhi Temple (Srilankan Temple) ... Read More

GAYA: Sri Lankan Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksha on Monday offered prayers at Mahabodhi Mahavihara at Bodh Gaya , the symbol of Buddha’s enlightenment.

After offering prayers, the visiting PM wrote down his impressions in the shrine’s visitor book. “I consider it a great honour and privilege to set foot on these sacred grounds. I thank the staff at the Mahabodhi Mahavihara for preserving this holy site for Buddhists around the world,” he wrote

As per the shrine custom, the visiting dignitary was presented with a sacred scarf by temple chief Monk Ven Chalinda on behalf of the shrine management and a memento by state agriculture minister Prem Kumar.

Kiran Lama, former chairman of the International Buddhist Council, made a presentation on the contribution of 19th century Sri Lankan Buddhist missionary Angarika Dhammapal in the rejuvenation of the shrine and its upkeep as the most sacred centre of Buddhists across the world.

The Sri Lankan PM also visited a Sri Lankan monastery located in the Mahabodhi Society premises that houses the statue of Angarika Dhammapala.

Earlier, on his arrival at the Gaya airport, the Sri Lankan PM was received by Gaya Town MLA and agriculture minister Prem Kumar, IG R Rathi, district magistrate Abhishek Singh and SSP Rajiv Mishra.

The Sri Lankan PM, who arrived by a special plane, was accompanied by a 20-member delegation that included two ministers and one MP. The minsters who accompanied the Sri Lankan PM were community empowerment minister A Thondaman and fisheries minister KND Devnanda.

Title: Two women killed as tractor-trailer turns turtle in Bareilly
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

BAREILLY: Two women were killed and five reportedly injured, when a tractor-trailer turned turtle after it was hit by a speeding UPSRTC bus in Bithri Chenpur area of Bareilly district on Monday evening.

An FIR has been registered against the bus driver under IPC sections 304A (death by negligence) and 279 (rash driving). The survivors have been admitted to Bareilly district hospital, where the condition of a woman is reportedly critical.

According to police, the victims were returning home on a tractor-trailer after attending a feast in Siroli to celebrate the birth of a child. As the tractor approached Invertis, it was hit by a UPSRTC bus. The tractor lost balance and turned over into a roadside pit.

Three women in the trailer, along with several children, received critical head injuries. One of them, Rambeti (30) died before reaching hospital, while Preeti (29) died during treatment. The condition of one survivor, Shanti Devi (35), is said to be critical.

Ashok Kumar, the SHO of Bithri Chenpur police station, told TOI, “The tractor trailer fell into a pit after it was hit by the bus. Five people were critically injured, two of whom died during treatment.”

Title: 30 teams take part in police shooting meet in Rohtas
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

SASARAM: Bihar DGP Gupteshwar Pandey on Monday inaugurated the 20th All India Police Duty Meet shooting competition on the campus of the second battalion of Bihar Military Police (BMP) stationed at Dehri-on-Sone in Rohtas district. Altogether 30 teams from 23 states, including two union territories and eight central armed forces, are participating in the event.

The national police shooting competition has been organized for the first time in Bihar. Inaugurating the competition, in which around 800 participants are expected to take part in 13 events, the DGP called upon the participants to spread the message of non-violence, peace and love across the country.

He also congratulated the participants on behalf of chief minister Nitish Kumar, who was to inaugurate the competition.

Title: Trial run of train at 130km/hour ends
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

PATNA: Senior railway officials and technical experts of the Research Design and Standards Organization (RDSO), an organization under the Ministry of Railways , successfully conducted a two-day trial run of a special train at 130km per hour on the Jhajha-Patna-Pt Deendayal Upadhyay Junction route on Sunday and Monday.

According to officials, the railways is likely to increase the speed limit of all mail and express trains from 110 kmph to 130 kmph from April 30, after getting a green signal from the commissioner of railway safety (CRS), eastern zone, Kolkata.

Danapur divisional railway manager (DRM) Sunil Kumar told this newspaper, “The special train, running with a load combination of 24 coaches between Jhajha and Pt Deendayal Upadhyay Junction, covered a distance of 387km in just four hours. At present, the same distance is covered in almost six hours.”

Title: PM Modi to inaugurate 26 projects, unveil DDU statue in Kashi on Feb 16
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Varanasi: Prime Minister Narendra Modi will inaugurate over 26 projects worth Rs 1,009 crore, including the 430-bed super specialty centre for AIIMS equivalent Institute of Medical Sciences-Banaras Hindu University and expanded Chowkaghat-Lehartara flyover during his proposed visit to his parliamentary constituency on February 16.

He will also lay the foundation of several projects worth Rs 208 crore at a programme to be held at DDU Trade Facilitation Centre in Lalpur area. Before the inauguration, the PM will also unveil the 63-foot tall statue of BJP ideologue Pandit Deen Dayal Upadhyaya worth Rs 6.50 crore at Padav, the area being developed as Antim Padav in memory of the leader.

Talking to TOI on Monday, divisional commissioner Deepak Agrawal said the list of projects for inauguration and laying foundation stone has been finalised.

Among the major projects to be inaugurated, the 430-bed centenary super specialty block at Sir Sunderlal Hospital of IMS-BHU is on the top, said Agrawal, adding the block has eight major super specialty disciplines besides 13 modular operation theatres.

IMS-BHU officials said the centre will extend best healthcare services at affordable rates in the region. Besides, BHU’s Vedic Vigyan centre, trauma centre and 100-bed maternity wing of SPG divisional hospital will also be inaugurated by the PM, said Agrawal.

The PM will also inaugurate the extended Chowkaghat-Lehartara flyover, a long-awaited project that would bring major relief on busy Andhrapul and Englishialine crossing, he said, adding the Anna-kshetra of Kashi Vishwanath temple, 200-bed barrack at police lines, ITI at Rajatalab and 16 newly-constructed roads are also among the projects to be inaugurated.

Besides, the PM will gift over a dozen new projects worth Rs 208 crore to the city. These will include civic facility augmentation in wards of Old City area under Smart City project, multi-level parking at Town Hall, beautification of public parks and ponds and projects of electricity department.

The PM will unveil the statue of Pt Deen Dayal Upadhyaya, the foundation of which was laid by Amit Shah, Union minister Piyush Goyal and chief minister Yogi Adityanath on August 5, 2018 when they visited Chandauli for formal renaming of Mughalsarai Junction as Pt Deen Dayal Upadhyay Junction.

Modi will also release the translated version of Siddhant Shikhamani, an epic of Veershaiva (Lingayat) sect, in 19 languages with their digital app versions during the valedictory ceremony of 38-day centenary year programme of Sri Jagadguru Vishwaradhya Gurukulam and Veershaiva Mahakumbh at historical Jangamwadi Mutt, said the Mutt’s 86th Peethadhshwar Jagadguru Dr Chandrashekhar Shivacharya.

Title: Mumbai man held for thefts
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Surat: Police arrested Rahul Shimpi (45), a resident of Kalyan West in Thane , Maharashtra on Monday for alleged involvement in multiple mobile phone thefts reported in the city. Police recovered 21 mobile phones worth Rs 1.93 lakh from him. So far five cases of theft have been registered against him in Mahidharpura police station and two cases with Surat railway police station.

Investigation revealed that Shimpi was jobless after a company in which he was employed shut down.

He then started working with a gang of thieves in Mumbai and carried out thefts for them.

Title: Diamond workers demand abolition of professional tax
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Surat: The Surat Ratnakalakar Sangh (SRS) met deputy chief minister Nitin Patel on Monday demanding abolition of the professional tax system for the diamond workers employed in the world’s largest diamond cutting and polishing centre.

A delegation of SRS led by president, Jaysukh Gajera met deputy CM, Nitin Patel at Gandhinagar with the demand to abolish professional tax payment by the diamond workers and fixing the minimum wage system in the industry.

Talking to TOI, SRS president, Jaysukh Gajera said, “The diamond workers are earning on piecemeal basis and that they have to pay professional tax to the state government. Majority of the workers are employed in the small and medium diamond units earning less than Rs 15,000 per month.”

Gajera added, “We have demanded that the state government should abolish the professional tax system in the industry in interest of the diamond workers. There is no wage structure existing in the sector and majority of the diamond units are not registered with the industries department.”

According to Gajera, the yearly collection of professional tax from the diamond industry is pegged at Rs 150 crore.

Title: Iraq pins hope on Rajkot for investment
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Rajkot: Iraq is looking at Saurashtra’s commercial capital - Rajkot - to boost inward investments and create jobs in the war-ravaged country.

For the first time in since 2002, an 11-member delegation from Iraq consisting of businessmen and government officials will be participating in the annual international trade show organized by Saurashtra Vepar Udhyog Mahamandal (SUVM), an apex body of small industries of the region. The three-day trade show begins today.

The delegation visit is being coordinated by The State Company for Iraqi Fairs and Commercial Services, one of the Iraqi ministry of trade companies that aims to boost economic activity in the country.

“The participation in SUVM trade fair aims to expand the economic cooperation between Iraq and India in different fields, not just trade but also in industrial, technological and other fields,” Siddeq Shakir, deputy director, of the company’s exterior fair department told TOI in an e-mailed response.

“We are looking an investment in agriculture technologies, detergent making, packaging, handiwork in genuine leather industries, electronics and other sectors,” said Shakir.

Shakir said this is the first time after 2002, when it participated in a trade fair in New Delhi, that an Iraqi delegation is coming for a similar event in India.

Parag Tejura, president of SUVM, said, “Iraq has requirement of machine parts for its defence and Rajkot’s engineering industry has the potential to do business with them. They are keen on technical knowledge from Rajkot’s machine tools industry and we expect them to source various kind of machines and technology from here.”

Nearly 150 foreign delegates from various countries are participating in this seventh edition of SUVM trade show, said Tejura.

Shakir said the role played the governments of Iraq and India to facilitate the commercial exchange is represented by not making easing import-export between the two countries but also the travelling of citizens besides participating in the fairs held in the two countries.

Meanwhile, Tejura said that a special gathering of farmers will be organized on February 12 for businessmen from African countries who are looking to provide opportunities to locals here to cultivate land in their continent.

Title: ICICI moves NCLT to get dues from Mercator
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

(Representative image)

MUMBAI: ICICI Bank has moved the National Company Law Tribunal ( NCLT ) to initiate insolvency proceedings against Mercator Limited for recovering dues. Mercator, once the second-largest private shipping company in India, owes over Rs 50 crore to the banking giant.

However, Bank of Baroda and Axis Trusteeship have sought intervention to protect their rights over Mercator’s subsidiary as its assets are pledged to them. The subsidiary owes more than Rs 200 crore to the two financial majors. NCLT will hear the matter on Wednesday.

On January 23, the NCLT had said that if Mercator fails to file a reply to ICICI’s insolvency application before February 10, then the matter will be adjudicated on merits.

The city-based shipping company’s woes came to the fore when it failed to pay salaries to its crew members last March. To pare liabilities, Mercator has been divesting its assets. Recently, it sold a 1999-built floating storage and offloading (FSV) ship, Prem Pride, for Rs 50 crore.

Mercator was acquired by Harishkumar Mittal in 1998. He owns about 20% in the publicly-listed company, but 73% of that stake was pledged as on December 31, 2019, regulatory filings showed. Mercator, which used to trade at Rs 57 on the stock exchanges in 2017, is now trending at less than Re 1, giving it a market capitalisation of Rs 25 crore.

During the first half of fiscal 2020, Mercator reported a loss of Rs 592 crore as against a loss of Rs 79 crore in the same period of fiscal 2019.

Title: Kolkata: Police station gheraoed after detainee’s death
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

KOLKATA: Locals gheraoed Sinthi police station for several hours on Monday after a 53-year-old who was being questioned fell ill and died before he could be taken to a hospital. Police said a post-mortem will be conducted to ascertain the reasons for the death and, if necessary, a high-level probe will be ordered. A few locals tried to ransack the police station, and banged on the doors and threw benches and chairs around, but the matter was brought under control by late evening.

According to locals, an SI from Sinthi police had informed Raj Kumar Sau that he needed to come to the police station for questioning. Sau went to the police station with his son Ajay and brother Rajinder around 11.30am. The Sinthi police were investigating complaints of taps being stolen from apartments and three women had been questioned. One of them claimed they had sold the stolen taps to Sau, after which he was asked to come to the police station.

Ajay alleged that his father was assaulted in the police station, after which he fell ill. Cops said Sau had high blood sugar and complained of dizziness during questioning. Though Ajay claimed cops did not help take the ailing Sau to hospital, the officers said they had taken him to RG Kar Hospital, where he was declared brought dead. Cops have registered an unnatural death case.

It was after this that locals gheraoed the police station. Jt CP (headquarters) Subhankar Sinha Sarkar said, “The situation was brought under control. There was no ransacking or damage.”

Title: Tallah detour: 2 die in accidents
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

KOLKATA: Though the diversions due to the demolition of Tallah Bridge are slowly becoming a habit for motorists, areas around it have been witnessing accidents, some of them fatal.

Two such accidents were reported from Canal West Road and Ultadanga Main Road in the past two days.

Around 7.25am on Monday, a bus on the Bagbazar-Garia route ran over a 58-year-old resident of Chandanpur in Titagarh on Ultadanga Main Road, close to the Ultadanga underpass. The accident happened when the victim, Loknath Ghosh , was trying to cross the road. He was taken to RG Kar Hospital where Ghosh was declared brought dead.

On Sunday evening, around 4pm, 48-year-old Md Nehal of MN Chatterjee Road lost his life after a bus on route 12A/B/C hit the bike he was riding pillion on. Nehal fell and was run over by the bus. His skull was crushed and he died at the spot. The rider, though, managed to escape unhurt. The incident took place on Canal West Road.

In both, a case of death due to rash and negligent driving was registered.

A few days ago, a 50-year-old resident of Narayanpur — Amar Das — fell while trying to board a moving bus on Canal West Road, under Tallah police station.

“At times, buses stop in the middle of the road, forcing cars to overtake from the left. This is the main reason for accidents on this stretch,” said a bus owner.

Title: Fire in Taltala: Fire guts plywood shop, spreads panic in Taltala
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

The fire at Taltala on Monday

KOLKATA: Fire broke out in a plywood godown-cum-shop in Taltala, off SN Banerjee Road , on Monday night. Though no loss of life was reported, 20 fire tenders were pressed into service as the warehouse is located in a densely populated neighbourhood opposite Taltala Bazar. Occupants of the residential building next to the shop had to be evacuated as the flames spread to their home.

Some workers of the warehouse sustained minor injuries while trying to escape after the fire started, but none of these were burn injuries.

According to locals, they noticed smoke billowing from the three-storey building on 8, Puran Chand Nahar Avenue around 8.30pm and immediately informed the fire brigade headquarters and the local police station. Fire fighters from Free School Street, which is barely two kilometres away, rushed in with nine fire tenders.

But as the flames kept spreading, more fire tenders were called in.

Pathologist Subir Dutta , who is in his 90s, and his octogenarian brother Samir Dutta , had to be rescued as the fire spread to their building next door. However, the firefighters managed to douse the flames, averting major damage.

Witnesses said workers in the warehouse managed to escape after the fire broke out, but since the building had inflammable stacks of plywood, it turned into an inferno in no time. “We are trying to ascertain if the unit had fire safety measures in place,” said state fire minster Sujit Bose who visited the spot.

It took firemen about two and a half hours to douse the blaze which, officials said, may have been caused by a short circuit from an electrical pump.

Title: Corpn checks sewage water entering residential area
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Madurai: Madurai corporation resolved the issue of sewage water deluging a residential area of Sastha Street in ward 29 of Pandian Nagar within a few hours on Monday, after a report published in TOI highlighted the plight of residents.

Syed Ahamed Basha, a resident, while thanking TOI said that a team of officials reached the spot early in the morning with an earthmover and started working. People in Sastha Nagar were much relieved as the work was completed in a few hours, he said. At least 50 houses in the residential locality were inundated by sewage water on Sunday morning due to a block in the channel which used to carry excess water from the sprawling Vandiyur tank to Vaigai river. It also restricted the movement of vehicles through the street as the sand pathway was cut down to drain sewage water.

Officials said that sewage enters the channel from Vandiyur and its surrounding areas where underground drainage facility is yet to be created. The water got blocked by garbage and it entered the low-lying residential area. An official from the engineering wing of Madurai corporation told TOI that sewage water got blocked due to garbage dumped by people residing alongside the channel. The trouble recurred every three months due to the dumping of materials including plastic bags. “Residents should cooperate with us by disposing garbage appropriately. Door-to-door waste collection is being done throughout the city. The issue will not resurface if they stop dumping waste in the channel,” he said.

Residents demanded that a retaining wall be constructed in the channel after removing the encroachment alongside it. Officials said that since the channel belongs to PWD, the onus is on its officials to find a longterm solution like construction of retaining wall.

Title: Jamia students hurt during CAA protest march to Parliament
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

As students tried to climb over the barricades near Holy Family Hospital, some of them were hurt in police’s e... Read More

NEW DELHI: The protest march to Parliament against CAA-NRC called by students of Jamia Millia Islamia on Monday turned chaotic when several of them tried to climb over the police barricades near Holy Family Hospital. While many were pushed back by police, a stamped-like situation caused injuries to some students. A few became unconscious and were sent to Ansari Health Centre on the university campus. An alumni claimed 30 students were brought to the health centre.

As misinformation about policy brutality spread, locals turned up at the protest site and continued to raise slogans till late despite pleas from police and the Jamia administration. Chanda Yadav, a student who was seen atop the barricade, was taken to the hospital after being pulled down by police.

Later in the evening, Jamia VC Najma Akhtar met the injured students at Al Shifa Hospital.

The “Chalo Parliament” march called by Jamia’s Joint Coordination Committee (JCC) started from gate number 7 around 1.30pm. The protesters were stopped near the Okhla main road intersection by police. When the students continued their march, they were stopped with the help of barricades near Holy Family Hospital. For the next two hours, students tried to climb the barricades and cross over, but were stopped. JCC claimed nine students were detained by police.

Around 3pm, Jamia proctor Waseem Ahmed Khan urged the students to go back to the campus. “You can continue with a peaceful protest at gate number 7, but don’t get into a tussle with police,” he told them. Jamia PRO Ahmed Azeem said, “The varsity officials are with the students to make sure no untoward incident takes place. We even asked the locals gathered there to disperse.”

Later, DCP (Southeast) RP Meena asked the students to move back as their protest had been heard. A case of obstructing a public servant from conducting his duty, assaulting a public servant and damage to public property has been registered against the students. “We detained a few students and later produced them before the proctor. There were no incidents of lathi charge or tear gas shelling, as alleged on social media,” said a Delhi Police spokesperson.

Title: End discrimination towards Kerala, CPI urges Centre
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: CPI state council here, on Monday, passed a resolution urging the Union government to put an end to the alleged discriminatory attitude the Centre maintains towards Kerala.

“The Union government attitude towards Kerala is cruel. It continues to neglect the state, which is struggling to come out from the financial stress inflicted by natural calamities. Since the Centre-state relationship is not a master-slave relation, there is no justification for the abject neglect to Kerala,” the resolution said.

Centre refused to sanction any assistance to Kerala when a meeting chaired by home minister Amit Shah decided to allot Rs 5,908.54 crore to seven states for flood relief activities in 2019, the resolution said. “The Union government is yet to release its share of Rs 1,035 crore to be given to Kerala for paddy procurement. The cut in central share to coconut board, spices board, tea board and rubber board also affects the state’s agriculture sector,” the resolution said.

CPI state secretary Kanam Rajendran, central control commission chairman Panniyan Raveendran, national executive member K E Ismael, assistant secretaries K Prakash Babu and Sathyam Mokeri participated in the meeting.

Title: Pune: Parents protest against change in MIT school’s affiliation to CBSE
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Parents form a human chain to protest against the management’s decision on Monday

PUNE: Parents of some students enrolled with the MIT Vishwashanti Gurukul School, Kothrud, protested inside the campus at 7am on Monday against the management’s decision to change affiliation from the state board to the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) over fees hike fears.

The parents alleged that the decision was solely aimed at introducing massive hike in school fees from Rs 21,000-Rs 25,000 per student to Rs 60,000-Rs 70,000. “The schools intends to maintain the staff, infrastructure and just wants to switch affiliation to CBSE for the sole reason of increasing the fees,” Gajendra Patil, one of the protesting parents, said.

The parents said the school was affiliated to state board for 30 years.

School principal Madhuri Gokhale said the school had already received CBSE affiliation and the process was on for the last three years. “The parents were also informed about the decision at a meeting held last year and also through the parent-teacher association (PTA) committee,” she said.

Refuting Gokhale’s claims, Patil said almost 80% of the parents had opposed the decision, but the school management still went ahead with it. The parents now plan to hold a protest on the school premises on Tuesday and at the regional directorate of education at 11am on Wednesday.

Gokhale said the school received the CBSE affiliation in July 2019. “From April onwards, the school will adopt the CBSE syllabus for all the classes, while SSC board syllabus will be discontinued. There is opposition from a few parents, while a majority have no problem with the change in school affiliation to CBSE,” she said.

Gokhale said the CBSE affiliation was important for students to prepare for competitive examinations in higher classes. “All the other branches of the school are already CBSE affiliated,” she added.

Title: Guards keep a hawk eye to prevent garbage dumping at Marunji village
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: Fed up with people dumping garbage on the road, Marunji gram panchayat, situated near Hinjewadi IT park, has deployed security guards to deter people from throwing trash in the open.

“There are five spots in the village where garbage dumping occurs. The panchayat has deployed three security guards - one each at Gaothan, Shindenagar and Sairung Samruddhi on HInjewadi-Kasarsai road. The guards do not allow residents to dump garbage. They also ask people to give segregated garbage to ghantagadis when they visit their locality. A daily review of the feedback from ghantagadi workers and security guards is taken,” sarpanch Poonam Buchade said.

Marunji village came under the limelight when Rajiv Gandhi IT park was set up here more than 20 years ago. The population of the village increased manifold in the past two decades with IT professionals those working in industries in Pimpri Chinchwad city setting up their homes here.

Instead of giving garbage to the ‘hatagadis’ operated by the gram panchayat, they prefer throwing garbage in the open along the road or open spaces. This prompted the gram panchayat to deploy security guards in areas prone to garbage dumping a fortnight back.

Buchade said the gram panchayat has deployed three ghantagadis who traverse various parts of the village collecting garbage from 6 am to 4 pm daily. There are around 3,000 houses and 300 shops in the village from whom we collect garbage. The panchayat has distributed two bins to the villagers around 1.5 months back for segregating the garbage at source. The ghantagadis collect wet and dry garbage separately. The daily garbage collection is around 3 to 4 tons. This garbage is taken away by contractor for processing and disposal.

“The garbage thrown along roadsides and open areas is a big menace. So, we have begun a public awareness drive through ghantagadi workers to stress the need for garbage segregation at source. They also collect feedbacks on the reason for throwing garbage in the open. As a result, we now receive segregated garbage from 80 to 90% of residents,” she said.

Title: Industry urges policy tweaks to buoy biz climate
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Jaipur: Industry bodies in the state made several recommendations to improve the business climate and encourage investment.

Federation of Rajasthan Trade and Industry president Suresh Agarwal drew attention to realign the e-way bill rules with other states where the exemption limit higher. “In Rajasthan, e-way bill is not required if goods for transport is up to Rs 50,000. The limit should be increased to Rs 1 lakh like many other states,” said Agarwal.

He also wanted to remove mandi tax on sugar and dal and reduce the overall rate from the current 1.6% to 0.5%.

Similarly, CII-Rajasthan urged the government to reduce land rates to make Rajasthan a lucrative investment destination. Currently, the government is selling land through auction which fetches better price and improves transparency even though the system runs the risk of losing investors.

CII-Rajasthan chairman Anand Sharma said the government should also bring down GST on khadi readymade clothes which attracts tax rates of 5% and 12%.

While appreciating the recent policy announcements by the state government, FICCI-Rajasthan said the next level is to promote these policies to the target audiences nationally and internationally to leverage the benefits.

N K Jain, member, FICCI Rajasthan State Council, said the crude oil refinery being constructed holds lots of potential. “There is a need to sensitise the industry about the business opportunities in petrochemical sector in western Rajasthan to realise the potential.”

Jain said around 81 varieties of minerals are available in the state and 57 minerals are produced on a commercial scale in the state. “There is a need to incentivize private sector participation and FDI in mineral exploration,” added Jain.

Major Demands

Raise e-way bill exempt limit to Rs 1 lakh like Maharashtra, Delhi, Gujarat and other states

Remove mandi tax sugar and dal, reduce rate to 0.5% from current 1.6%

Ensure sellers of goods pay GST not the buyers

Radar based study to assess the water table like in Maharashtra and Haryana

Payments to companies and contractors are pending. They should be paid on time

Radar based study to assess the water table in Rajasthan like in Maharashtra and Haryana

Payments to many industries and contractors are pending. They should be paid on time.

Title: Two brothers shot, kin lodge FIR against two
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Varanasi: Two brothers were shot dead by some miscreants in Nandganj area of Ghazipur district when they were returning home on a bicycle on Sunday late night.

SP Ghazipur Dr Om Prakash Singh said that family of the deceased have lodged a named FIR against Phulli Bind and Suraj Yadav of the same village in this connection. Police teams have been engaged to nab the accused at the earliest. The bodies have been sent for postmortem, he said.

According to the police, two brothers Vijay Yadav and Pradyumna Yadav, residents of Tukdaha village under the limits of Nandganj police station, used to run a petty shop of bicycle repairing between Tokdaha and Sargatha villages. On Sunday night, they were returning on their bicycle after closing the shop when some miscreants opened indiscriminate fire on them and fled, said the SP.

On hearing the sound of firing local natives rushed to the spot. On being informed, the police also reached the site and rushed the duo to the district hospital where Vijay was declared brought dead by the doctors. Pradyumna was referred to Varanasi, however, he also succumbed to injuries during the course of treatment, said Singh, adding that the family has lodged a named FIR in this connection.

Initial investigation of police revealed that some altercation took place between the brothers and the accused a few months ago after which the latter had set their shop on fire. To settle their dispute, the villagers had convened a meeting in which it was decided that Phulli and Suraj will pay Rs 60,000 to Vijay and Pradyumna as compensation. The accused were supposed to pay the amount on February 1. When they failed to pay the amount Vijay and Pradyumna allegedly threatened them. Police suspect the murder to be a fallout of the same dispute.

Title: Govt for total withdrawal of internal marks, says minister
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Higher education minister K T Jaleel said in the assembly that the decision to withdraw internal assessment marks in the state technical university will be made applicable in all arts and science colleges of the state. Health university too has been recommended to implement it. The proposal has been given to health minister K K Shailaja, he said.

The minister said the decision to withdraw the internal assessment mark has been taken following requests from students. They have alleged that the teachers are misusing this, he added.

Transport minister A K Saseendran said in the assembly that 4,439 people were killed in road accidents in 2019. Registered 2.67 lakh traffic violations have yieled Rs 33.80 crore as fines. For violation of rules 28,020 licenses have been suspended.

The minister said that the education department has been requested to make the presence of ayah in school buses mandatory. The proposal is under the consideration. There is a proposal to convert all autorikshaws above 15 years into ecofriendly vehicles. The decision is to convert them into LNG, CNG, LPG or electric vehicles.

Title: Officials in Ramnad trying to curb panic among locals
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Madurai: The health department in Ramanathapuram district is fighting against unnecessary panic lingering among locals over the spread of novel coronavirus (nCoV) by creating awareness and educating about the virus, its spread and preventive measures.

“The disease has not spread to India but there is a general fear among locals here, who are panicking about nCoV at the very mention that someone is from China,” said a health official.

On February 8, a Chinese tourist in Rameswaram opted to return to China after locals panicked and alerted health officials.

Similarly, on February 2, rumours were spread about a 35-year-old man, who had returned from China, as suffering from nCoV and he was forced to be admitted to the nCoV isolation ward at Ramanathapuram government hospital and undergo a test. However, the result was negative.

The official said that even doctors and health officials are not taking chances with nCoV. Ramanathapuram has among the highest number of people being monitored under home quarantine for nCoV in the state.

“We are closely following up and checking, calling over phone and meeting them in person. So far, no one has any symptoms of illness,” said a senior health official.

Officials are now conducting awareness programmes in all schools and colleges in the district.

“Personal hygiene and washing hands is emphasized. We hope to spread the message to the children and their families that there is nothing to be afraid of and we need to stay away from those quarantined for a while,” said the official.

Meanwhile, Madurai district health officials said that for the past two days, no one has required screening at the Madurai airport.

“No one with a history of travel to China has crossed the airport for the past two days. There is a gradual decline in the number of such passengers,” said an official.

In Madurai, around 70 are being monitored under home quarantine for nCoV.

Title: Telangana: 27,000 abortions in 3 years, some of them by quacks
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

HYDERABAD: Telangana saw 27,559 abortions (spontaneous and induced) in the more than three years since the fiscal year 2016-17, according to the Health Management Information System (HMIS) report. Experts estimated that at least half of these took place in single-room nursing homes and clinics on the city’s outskirts.

Meanwhile, the abortions reported in Telangana are only a fraction of the 45.2 lakh abortions that took place in the entire country during the same period (April 2016 to December 2019).

Replying to a question in the Rajya Sabha recently, minister of state for health and family welfare, Ashwini Kumar Choubey , said Telangana reported 6,481 abortions in 2016-2017, 7,862 in 2017-18, and 8,154 in 2018-2019. For the fiscal year 2019-20 the figure stood at 5,062 (till December 2019).

Worryingly, these figures do not include the number of abortions conducted illegally, which pose a huge challenge to the healthcare system.

Meanwhile, the National Family Health Survey-4 (2015-16) has pointed out that 46.6% abortions (across India) are conducted by non-doctors (including nurses, midwives, dai, family members, self or quacks) and 27.4% are done outside a medical facility (public and private), hinting at the gravity of the problem.

The reasons for increasing abortions include rise in unwanted pregnancies (largely due to lack of awareness on the use of contraception) and reluctance of doctors to do abortions at both government and private hospitals. As a result, many end up at illegal nursing homes and consult quacks. “In the city, pregnant teenagers mostly end up at the doorstep of quacks running single-room clinics,” said a task force member, who has been part of decoy operations.

Although, medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) is allowed (under certain circumstances) for any woman (married or unmarried) over 18 years of age, doctors often refuse to do it. “Most doctors refuse to do it due to ethical reasons as it is considered a sin. Also, an abortion pill has to come with a prescription, however doctors don’t write prescription due to social reasons,” said Dr Sanjeev Singh Yadav , general secretary, Indian Medical Association (IMA), Hyderabad.

Yadav said that raising awareness about contraception and giving early knowledge on safe sex to children could prevent unwanted pregnancies.

Title: Telangana gets notice over Raidurg land transfer
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

HYDERABAD: The Telangana high court on Monday issued notices to the state, Acqua space developers, My Home Constructions and DLF Rayadurg Developers and others, asking them for their stand on a PIL. The PIL, filed by Congress MP A Revanth Reddy, questioned the transfer of 31 acres of land at Rayadurg area in Serilingampally mandal near Hi-Tec City to Acqua Space company.

“There were certain permissions given for exchange of land and My Home Constructions emerged as the ultimate beneficiary in the episode,” said Revanth Reddy, who sought a declaration to the effect that this land transfer is illegal.

Revanth Reddy was also seeking prosecution of the officials responsible for the transfer of land, which was done ‘contrary to the rules and existing laws’.

The bench headed by Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan gave the state four weeks to file its counter. TNN

Title: Coronavirus in Pune: Another Pune man quarantined to rule out coronavirus infection
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A 33-year-old traveller, who returned from the novel coronavirus-affected Vietnam recently, was isolated at the civic-run Naidu hospital to rule out contagion possibility late on Sunday evening after he complained of minor illness.“The man, a resident of Pune, had returned from Vietnam on February 8 and had been under our surveillance since then. We quarantined him on Sunday evening after he developed cough and fever,” Ramchandra Hankare, the chief of the Pune Municipal Corporation’s health department, said.The man’s throat swab sample will be tested at the National Institute of Virology (NIV) for the novel coronavirus infection , he said, adding, “Another 26-year-old traveller, who was quarantined on Sunday, tested negative for the virus and was discharged on Monday.”“Of the 37 travellers with minor illnesses, 36 have tested negative for the infection in the state so far,” a state health official said.

Title: Communication is the key
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

In the ensuing budget , the state does not have the desired resources to do all what people would like it to do. Hence, it is important for the government to communicate to people what it plans to do and how it will impact their lives.

First of all it must tell people that in the 150th year of Gandhi it will follow his talisman of looking for the face of the poorest woman in the state to check whether their decisions will benefit her. Secondly, the government must communicate to people in the following six areas, which are causing huge concern to people:

Job creation: How many jobs will be created in both the formal and non-formal sector by its budgetary exercise. Closer attention will need to be paid to rural non-farm sectors, so that urban migration is arrested.

Enabling environment: The business environment must be improved drastically hence the need to determine ease of running (not just doing) a business by cutting out red tape and unnecessary transaction costs. But business needs to respect workers’ rights so that they become good consumers.

Human capital: This concerns the whole population and covers education, health, nutrition etc. Mission mode must be adopted to address each of these areas and their sub areas. For example, in education, strengthening capacity of teachers at the panchayat level to enable good learning outcomes.

Addressing the drawbacks in the PPP projects on primary health care and why they have not succeeded. Address road safety deficit, which costs 3-4% of the state GDP, by doing awareness coupled with education of drivers, and expanding the traffic police strength. To ensure that children are able to get protein-rich food or supplements to enable their healthy growth.

Governance: To improve governance in all areas of administration by improving accountability mechanisms. Large number of maladministration cases by incompetent babus cause much of the setbacks to the good intents of the government. There is no disincentive for them to not do so.

Implementation audits: Large number of complaints come from people that the project or scheme is not being implemented properly. For example, the

Right to Education Act has not been able to meet its objectives of ensuring good education to poor kids. Similarly there are many schemes and policies of the government which should be reviewed through public participation.

State-federal relations: In light of the current political scenario in the country state-union relations are being strained in many ways which impact people directly and indirectly. Social instability is one major factor. But if one looks at the Constitution and its coverage of the topic, the state could draft its own education policy. It should do it. It can develop its own business promotion policy which would be an amalgam of industrial policy, trade policy and competition policy.

In conclusion that state must ensure a ‘whole-of-government’ approach in its implementation strategies. Working in silos, various branches of the government end up harming the good work being done by others.

(The writer is secretary general, CUTS International, a public policy research and advocacy group. Views expressed in the article are personal)

Title: Leopard killed in highway accident near Koregaon Bhima
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: A two-year-old male leopard died in an accident while crossing the Pune-Ahmednagar highway near Koregaon Bhima in Shirura taluka on Sunday morning.

This is the second leopard death in a road accident on Pune-Ahmednagar highway since January.

Manohar Mhasekar, the range forest officer (RFO) of Shirur, said, “A speeding vehicle hit the leopard when it was crossing the Pune-Ahmednagar highway at Vade Gaothan Phata near Koregaon Bhima. The police patrol informed the forest department about the accident, after which our team reached the spot.”

P A Kshirsagar, the round officer of Shikarapur, said, “The leopard had died before we reached the spot. The body was sent to Shirur for post-mortem and cremated later.”

Forest guard V M Chavan said, “The leopard was hit by a large four-wheeler, most probably a truck. The driver of the speeding vehicle tried to apply brakes after spotting the leopard, but in vain. We saw tyre marks stretching about 10 to 15 metres from the spot. The driver sped away with the vehicle after the accident.”

He said, “The leopard died because of severe internal injuries. The doctors told us after the post-mortem that the bones of one of its front legs was broken, while there was a fracture in the bone of the other front leg. There were no external injuries.”

Chavan said well-irrigated Shirur taluka was leopard-prone because of large-scale sugar cane plantation as Bhima river flows nearby.

“Earlier, a three- to four-year-old male leopard died while crossing the Pune-Ahmednagar highway at Borademala, about 5km before Shirur city, on the night of January 2”, Chavan said.

He also said two to three goats and sheep were killed in leopard attacks in and around Vadu village in Shirur taluka. “So, we installed a cage in the village on Saturday,” he added.

Title: Secunderabad on road to relief from traffic woes
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

The authorities will soon take up road widening works to ease traffic congestion

SECUNDERABAD: The state government on Monday cleared a proposal for road widening from Lalapet nala to Ambedkar statue at Lalapet in Secunderabad to provide relief to people from traffic congestion on the existing road.

Deputy speaker T Padma Rao Goud on Monday disbursed cheques to the tune of nearly Rs 7 crore as compensation to landowners who lost their land as a result of the land acquisition.

Providing details of road widening works to be taken up, the deputy speaker said that the works would be taken up from Lalapet Flyover to Moula Ali Flyover, which stretches across 0.50 km, from Tukaramgate to Military Railway Track (0.50 km), Chilkalguda Junction to Sitaphalmandi X roads (1.454 km) and from Sitaphalmandi to Jamia Osmania (2.55 km) in Tarnaka division of Secunderabad constituency.

Around 140 property owners have agreed to give up their properties on the stretch for the road widening, said the deputy speaker. “The property owners have given up the land which is between 30 and 50 square yards for the road widening. At present, the road width is 73-foot and we plan to widen it to 100-foot. The works pertaining to land acquisition will begin next week,” said deputy commissioner, GHMC (North Zone), Ravi Kumar.

The GHMC said that the plan will ease traffic woes of several commuters coming from Moula Ali, Nacharam and adjoining areas and heading towards Secunderabad railway station and other parts of Hyderabad.

Title: Snatcher who escaped from police custody held
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Times News Network

Ludhiana: The Crime Investigation Agency-III of Ludhiana commissionrate on Sunday night arrested the snatcher who had escaped from their custody on February 4.

Deepak Kumar, 25, a resident of Mohalla Preet Nagar in Shimlapuri, was nabbed from Gill Canal Bridge on a tip-off.

The police had arrested Deepak on February 3 and recovered 11 snatched cellphones from his possession. A day later, additional deputy commissioner of police (detective) Harish Dayama had held a press conference on his arrest. After the press meet, Deepak was taken to the CIA-III office on Gill Road. There, he told the cops he wanted to go to the washroom. He had escaped from an open window of the washroom.

CIA-III in-charge sub-inspector Yashpal said, “During questioning, Deepak told that after giving police the slip, he went to Dehradun. As he had no money, he returned to the city a day later. Thereafter, he hid in Sahnewal and Samrala. As he was keen to take shelter in Haridwar, he had to arrange money. Therefore, he went to his house on Sunday night and stole his mother’s gold jewellery.”

Police caught him while he was trying to flee to Haridwar.

“Deepak is a drug addict. He is facing trials in five snatching cases,” the sub-inspector added.

Title: City docs’ first success in complex treatment
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Varanasi: With the newly established Bone Marrow Transplant and Stem Cell Research Centre at Banaras Hindu University becoming functional, the city doctors successfully performed the first autologous bone marrow transplantation on a female patient with multiple myeloma (blood cancer) recently.

“I am glad to announce that the first autologous bone marrow transplantation has been successfully performed on a female patient at BMT-SRC by Dr Kailash Kumar Gupta and his team,” said the BHU vice-chancellor Prof Rakesh Bhatnagar while talking to reporters on Monday.

The 12-bedded BMT-SRC is equipped with the state-of-the-art facility having HEPA filtered air and modern equipment, said the BHU VC.
