The centre is equipped with the latest equipment for flow cytometry for patient care and research and X-ray-based blood irradiator, first of its kind in the country which is capable of irradiation of blood and its products. The centre also has three stem cell research labs.

The VC said that the first bone marrow transplantation was done under the guidance of Dr Rahul Bhargava from Fortis Memorial Research Institute, Gurugram. The centre aims at doing 50-60 bone marrow transplantations in a year, he said adding that the bone marrow transplantation in BHU costs one-tenth of any private hospital. The financial liability of the entire treatment has been met out from the Prime Minister’s fund, he said.

He further said that the autologous bone marrow transplantation is significant because in this process there is no need of a donor, rather the bone marrow of the patient is being used. “Hopefully we will be able to provide treatment to those ailments which presently do not have a cure, said the VC adding that every year around 20,000 bone marrow transplantations are required in the country out of which around 10% succeed. The BMT-SRC of BHU will not only prove to be a boon for the people of east UP region who have to go to Delhi, Mumbai, Madras and Vellore for advance medical treatment but it will also help the hospital in providing quality medical services for treatment of more complex diseases through hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, he added.

Title: Virus spreads good news for importers
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Ludhiana: Spread of coronavirus in China has set cash registers ringing of some importers, who are seeing a sudden spurt in their sales and orders of Chinese goods. Some of the most sought-after goods from China that are seeing a huge demand these days include fabrics like interlock, ponte, jacquard knit and footwears.

Businessmen say the situation is the outcome of fear psychosis among the end customers and manufacturers that imports from China may stop any time. Besides, there have been long delays, with production in China hit due to shutdowns caused by virus spread. The development is turning out to be a blessing in disguise for the importers, who had a dead stock of goods, which is now in demand. As per industry sources, rates of Chinese fabric and footwear are seeing a surge of 2% to 5% and are likely to climb further.

Speaking to the TOI, a leading importer of footwear in the region says, “After the spread of coronavirus in China, demand for footwear has doubled. Customers, who earlier used to take 15-20 days’ credit, are now making spot payments and also giving partial advance for new orders. This is happening because of the uncertainty about future of imports from China. Therefore, wholesalers want to stock adequate quantities to combat the situation that may arise if imports from China come to a complete halt. At present too, the movement of goods is very slow from China. We have hiked our rates marginally.”

The importer adds, “A problem that will become more serious in coming days is that we will not be able to visit China to physically check the samples of goods. In case of footwear, without checking the samples, it is not possible to place an order just by seeing pictures on WhatsApp or email.”

According to a fabric importer from Ludhiana, “This is a happy time for us as not only there is high sale of Chinese fabric, but the dead stock, too, has started selling. Due to the huge demand for fabric, the rates in market have increased by 5%. Another good thing is that people who were behindhand with payments are not only clearing the backlog, but also offering to purchase next order on cash. However, the problem will arise in case the fabric imports stop completely. Then, our business will be ruined.”

Local businessmen who are using Chinese fabrics are, however, unhappy.

Narinder Mittal, a garment manufacturer, says, “The coronavirus situation has given rise to confusion and there is panic in the market. As we do not know about the future of trade with China, we are ordering quantities more than required to keep the material in stock. This is increasing our investment without any concrete orders. If imports stop, we will be at the receiving end as similar fabric is not available in India even at higher rates.”

Bhushan Abbi, president of Knit and Fab Cluster, Ludhiana, says, “This is a serious situation and Indian government should give it a thought. Our dependence on Chinese goods has backfired. What if tomorrow relations between India and China get so strained that imports stop. Then India’s industry will be completely destroyed, as there will be no alternative of goods at same rates here.”

Local units to gain

The local manufacturers, particularly those of fabrics, are set to gain if imports from China come to a temporary halt. Due to the influx of Chinese fabrics, their businesses had taken a hit as demand for the local fabrics fell due to their high price and low quality as compared to the Chinese ones. Manufacturers of footwears, sanitary products, LED lights, among others, too, will benefit from it.

Title: Edappally Church witnesses rare auction
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Kochi: In a rather interesting auction held at the St George Forane Church, Edappally, on Sunday, the highest bidder quoted a rate of Rs 3.05 lakh, the item sold — a white horse .

It was a horse donated to the church by a believer which was sold in the auction. In a video, which has now gone viral on social media, the white horse can be seen surrounded by parishioners as the auctioneer calls out the bids.

At Edapally church, it is a tradition to give poultry as offerings. “The tradition is called ‘nada iruthal’ and it is usually poultry, which are being offered. But this time, I guess for the first time, we got a horse,” said Anil Palathinkal, a church official.

According to sources, it was a faithful named Ukkan Devassy of Chalakudy and family who made the offering. The horse, about two-and-a-half-year old, was bought from Ooty by the family. The horse, sources said, was named Alfin Lydda, after the birthplace of St George.

Church officials said that a horse is a significant animal as it is connected with the legend of St George. As per the legend popular among Christians, St George, a soldier mounted on horseback, slew a fierce dragon to rescue a girl. The saint, mounted on a white horse and using a lance to kill the dragon, is one of the most venerated image in Christianity.

‘Kozhi nercha’ (offering poultry) is a popular ritual at Edapally church and the horse offering on the lines of ‘kozhi nercha’ was made two weeks ago. The believer who made the offering had even made the arrangements for taking care of the horse, till it got auctioned off. It was even provided medical care, said a source.

On Sunday, about four persons attended the auction which started with a base price of Rs 1 lakh. However, church sources said that there was some confusion about paying the quoted amount.

“It was auctioned off for over Rs 3 lakh but the one who had quoted the winning bid later expressed some concerns. We are trying to clear that, before finalizing the deal,” said Palathinkal.

Title: Coronavirus: Meerut man aboard quarantined ship in Japan appeals to govt for help
Content: Meerut: Piyush Vashist, 29-year-old resident of Meerut, had boarded the Diamond Princess on January 25 from Hong Kong. Little did he know that his experience on the cruise will be a harrowing one. The Diamond Princess cruise ship was quarantined in Japan’s Yokohama on February 3, after the crew got to know that one of the passengers who disembarked the ship on January 25 was detected with coronavirus a few days later. Preliminary tests were conducted on all the 3,700 people on board and they were asked to remain in their cabins to prevent spread of the virus. So far, 135 people have tested positive and the Japanese authorities have now decided to properly screen all the suspected cases on board.Talking to TOI over phone, Piyush said, “From February 4 to February 8, I was isolated in my cabin. It was only on February 9 that I was allowed to go in for fresh air when I exercised and stretched my body to feel at ease. Different set of passengers are being allowed to go in the open on different days to prevent spread of infection. The ship is providing food, but after February 6, I have been avoiding all kinds of food being cooked here and eat only packed items. These include cup noodles, sterilized fruits, cornflakes etc. Being a vegetarian, my options are anyway limited. While the ship crew is helping us as much as they can, I am surprised that the Indian government has taken no steps to rescue the 138 Indians on board. The embassy just contacted me once and said there was little they could do. I raised the concern for more packed food items, to which, they said they would look into. I am yet to hear from them.”According to Piyush, passengers on the quarantined ship have also been provided with thermometers and told to monitor their body temperature from time to time, and report in case it exceeds the 37.5 degrees Celsius.Back at his home in Meerut's Shastri Nagar, his family is worried and praying for his safe return.Piyush’s father Mool Chand Sharma , a doctor, and his mother Sukhwant Sharma, a staff nurse, have been speaking to him throughout the day to check on his health parameters.Talking to TOI, Piyush’s uncle Pankaj Sharma said, “Nobody in the family is doing anything, except worrying about him.”Piyush, who works with a private company in Gurgaon, was to disembark the cruise on February 9 in Taiwan. However, he is now stranded on sea in Yokohama as the ship has been quarantined and the Japanese government has denied permission to the cruise to dock anywhere in the country.“We have been given hand sanitizers to keep ourselves clean at all times. I am just concerned that if no help comes from the Indian government in time, even those who are healthy will end up getting infected,” said Piyush.

Title: Government to set up film institute on a par with international standards at Shamshabad
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

HYDERABAD: The Telangana government will set up a film institute of international standards at Shamshabad soon. The revenue department has been asked to scout for suitable land near Shamshabad. Apart from this, it has been directed to look for land near Jubilee Hills and Nanakramguda for providing training and a culture centre for cine artistes and workers belonging to 24 crafts.

These decisions were taken at a meeting held on film industry development on Monday, which was chaired by cinematography ministers Talasani Srinivas Yadav and attended by actors Chiranjeevi and Akkineni Nagarjuna .

The minister assured the representatives of film industry that 10 acre land would be identified to allot houses for cine and television artistes on the lines of Chintrapuri colony. During the meeting, the film personalities expressed their concern over piracy and sought the help of the government to curb the menace as the produces were incurring losses. It was decided to implement online ticketing system soon to bring in transparency in ticket sale that would benefit both producers and film-goers as well.

“The film-goers will get rid of service charges with online ticketing. The government is ready to implement the system, but legal hitches were delaying it,” the minister said. He hoped the government would overcome these issues and implement online ticket system.

Both Chiranjeevi and Nagarjuna urged the government to issue identity cards to over 28,000 cine workers through Film Development Corporation , extend health insurance facility and introduce single window permissions for film shoots. They also asked the government to allow theatre managements to increase ticket rates during release of new movies. The minister directed FDC and ESI authorities to examine providing free health scheme for cine workers.

The minister assured them that chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao would hold a meeting on issues pertaining to the film industry.

Title: Has solid waste management board been set up, asks HC
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

HYDERABAD: The HC on Monday sought to know from the state whether it has set up state-level solid waste management board. The bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Ahishek Reddy was hearing a PIL filed by Col. Sitarama Raju , who told the court that the residents of Sainikpuri and neighbouring areas are adversely affected by the foul smell emanating from Jawaharnagar dumpyard .

The bench also sought details on alternative arrangements being made by GHMC to mitigate the problems of the residents. The case was posted to March 3.

Title: Kamptee Road flyover new design unsafe, says NHAI
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Gadkari has directed officials of MahaMetro and NHAI to hold a meeting and have a relook at the Kamptee Road f... Read More

NAGPUR: The National Highways Authority of India ( NHAI ) has rejected MahaMetro ’s new design of Kamptee Road flyover as it would have endangered the lives of motorists.

MahaMetro had earlier decided to start the flyover ramp opposite SFS Cathedral. However, following strong opposition from locals it submitted a revised design extending the ramp to near LIC Square on the directions of Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari .

A technical team of NHAI, headed by senior officer Atul Kumar, had surveyed the spot about three weeks ago. NHAI rejected the revised design on the basis of Kumar’s report.

Kumar told TOI that extending the ramp to near LIC Square was dangerous. “As per the new design, the square will be very close to the flyover landing and speeding vehicles coming down the flyover can hit vehicles standing at the traffic signal. We have taken the decision after considering safety of all citizens,” he said.

Kumar further said that NHAI had made a concession to Metro by reducing the width of service road from 7.5 meter to 5.5 meter. “When Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) hands over extra land to us, we will widen the service road,” he added.

The NHAI official blasted Metro officials for submitting irrational proposals. “If they want to build unscientific structures, they should do it using their own money. The original proposal was sanctioned because it ensured safety of motorists,” he further said.

The revised ramp location was between VIMS Hospital and LIC Square. On possibility of starting the ramp between VIMS Hospital and SFS Cathedral, a Metro official said that it was not possible as it would block Mount Road. “We are planning to construct a subway opposite the church to offer safe passage to locals,” he added.

Meanwhile, Gadkari has directed officials of MahaMetro and NHAI to hold a meeting and have a relook at the Kamptee Road flyover plan. MahaMetro managing director Brijesh Dixit said a meeting would be held soon.

However, Kumar’s stand makes it clear that future talks will be fruitless as NHAI would hardly agree to a proposal that does not ensure safety of motorists.

Correspondence between MahaMetro and NHAI shows that the latter took very long to decide on the Kamptee Road flyover. Metro had sent a letter to NHAI informing them of its intention to revise the flyover design in February 2019. It then submitted the design in May 2019. NHAI team visited the spot in January 2020, eight months after the design was submitted. However, the letter rejecting the revised design was issued within a week of submission of Kumar’s report.

Title: Four of a Delhi family killed in road accident in Saharanpur
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Strap: Car rams into timber-laden trolley, lone injured passenger is in critical condition

Meerut: In a major accident in UP’s Saharanpur district, four members of a Delhi-based family succumbed to injuries while returning from a wedding function in Saharanpur on Sunday night. The only injured survivor is currently in a critical state. Low visibility is said be one of the reasons behind the accident.

“The accident took place around 11 pm on Sunday when five members of a family - residents of Rani Bagh area in Delhi - was returning after attending a wedding function in Saharanpur when their car rammed into a tractor trolley laden with timber,” Saharanpur SSP Dinesh Kumar P said.

While four of the car’s occupants - Bhagwati Sharma (55), his wife Mamta Sharma (50) and their son Gaurav Sharma (28) and daughter-in-law Nidhi Sharma (26) - succumbed to injuries on the spot, 25-year-old Pradeep Sharma sustained grievous injuries and is currently under medical observation at district hospital in Saharanpur.

The incident occurred at Nangal area in Tapri. A rescue operation began after locals informed the police. Before all the five persons could be taken out of the mangled remains of the vehicle, four were already dead while the critically injured was rushed to the nearest hospital, a local cop said.

The exact cause of the accident is yet to be ascertained though witnesses claimed that low visibility on the stretch could be one of the factors. “Overloaded timber trolleys are a nuisance on the stretch. They usually commute at night to avoid police detection. The stretch is poorly lit with almost no street lamps,” a local said.

Title: PPP trains to get fireproof coaches
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: Trains operating under private-public partnership (PPP) in the South Central Railway (SCR) zone will soon be equipped with fireproof coaches, the South Central Railway (SCR) said on Monday.

“We have a fool-proof system to deal with fire mishaps. In long-distance trains, the fire extinguishers are set up in AC coaches and also with guards and the driver,” officials said, talking about the situation of fire safety in the trains of the SCR zone. The Linke Hofmann Busch (LHB) coaches which are replacing the traditional ones in the zone are expected to have improved safety features with fire retardant interiors and modern couplers with anti-climbing features, say officials. The specifications for such furnishing materials have also been reviewed by the Indian Railways in order to make sure that they are of optimum quality.

Railway unions, however, seem unhappy as the facilities are restricted to the private trains only. “The trains running here are hardly in accordance with fire safety rules. Also, passengers are worried whether these fire extinguishers available with the guards and loco driver will be accessible if there is a blaze in one of the general bogies,” said a member of South Central Railway Mazdur Union (SCRMU).

Title: Delhi woman stops live-in partner’s marriage in Kota
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

Title: Follow Constitution if you want to live in this country: Sangeet Som tells Owaisi
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Meerut: Taking a swipe at All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen (AIMIM) leader Asaduddin Owaisi’s recent remark on “not showing any documents”, BJP’s Sardhana MLA Sangeet Som has said, “Owaisi kagaz bhi dikhaenge aur joote bhi khaenge [He will show papers and will be beaten with shoes as well]”.

The BJP MLA also had a curt advice for the AIMIM chief. “I want to tell Owaisi, if you want to live in this country you will have to follow the Constitution and will have to show whatever documents government wants you to show. This kind of statement ‘will not show the papers, shoot us in the chest’ are of no use,” Som said on Monday. Som’s remarks came after Owaisi’s recent speech at an anti-CAA public gathering at Kurnoor in Andhra Pradesh, where the latter said, “We are ready to face bullets but won’t show any papers.”

The BJP MLA did not stop at that. He raked up the ‘burqa’ issue too. “Burqa is a symbol of male dominance and anarchy. It has no provision in Shariah and subjugates women to no end. In fact, our Constitution is in danger,” Som added.

The AIMIM chief had said, “Main watan me rahunga aur kagaz nahi dikhaonga. Kagaz agar dikhaane ki baat hogi to seena dikhaenge ke maaro goli. Maar dil pe goli kyonki dil mein Bharat ki mohabbat hai. [I will stay in the country and will not show papers. If asked to show papers, we will show our chests and ask them to shoot at us in the chest because there lies in my heart the love for India].”

Title: Bengaluru: Woman fights helmet-clad bro-in-law
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Susheela

BENGALURU: Stabbed eight times by a helmet-clad intruder, a woman fought back. But when she pulled off his helmet, she was in for a shock: The attacker was her brother-in-law.

Susheela, 36, succumbed to stab wounds on Sunday after explaining to police the sequence of events: She said her brother-in-law attacked her because he was eyeing their ancestral property worth over Rs 10 crore. “Susheela put up a stiff resistance and identified her assailant. But the stab injuries proved to be fatal,” said a police officer. Based on her statement, Ananth Kumar, 42, was arrested on murder charges.

The attack occurred on February 7 at Honaganahatti village in Tavarekere, off Magadi Road. Susheela, whose husband Gangaraju died in a road accident 12 years ago, was living with her 14-year-old daughter and 75-year-old mother, Rudramma.

On Friday, her daughter had gone to school and Rudramma was sitting outside the house when a man walked in wearing a full-faced helmet and attacked Susheela with a knife. She defended herself with a stick used for making ragi balls and by throwing chilli powder at his face. But the attacker stabbed her on the hand, neck and head. He fled when Susheela identified him and raised an alarm. Neighbours rushed her to a hospital.

During questioning, Kumar reportedly confessed to the crime, saying he wanted to get rid of her as she was not agreeing to sell five acres of their ancestral property. Susheela’s nephew Kiran G told TOI: “The family owned six acres. Kumar sold one acre for Rs 50 lakh a few years ago after convincing Susheela. He, however, paid her only Rs 5 lakh. Lately, he was pestering Susheela to sell the remaining land as buyers were ready to pay Rs 2.5 crore per acre. But she was hesitating as she had been cheated by him earlier.”

Police are now examining the circumstances under which Gangaraju was killed. “We learnt the driver who had been arrested in connection with Gangaraju’s accident is currently working with Kumar,” said an officer.

Title: MLA Ramesh still a German citizen, MHA informs HC
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

HYDERABAD: In a huge setback to TRS MLA from Vemulawada, Chennamaneni Ramesh , the Union home ministry on Monday informed the Telangana high court that he did not relinquish his German citizenship.

The Centre’s assertion assumes significance in the wake of the claims made by the MLA that he had given up his German citizenship.

Assistant Solicitor General Namavarapu Rajeswara Rao furnished to the court a note issued by the Union home ministry to this effect. The Centre, in its communication, informed that the MLA did not give up his German citizenship. Not only that, he went to Germany as recently as on December 16, 2019, from Chennai airport using his German passport, Rajeswara Rao said citing the contents of the note. It is evident that Ramesh held German nationality as on December 16, 2019, the Centre’s counsel said.

The controversy arose following a complaint by Congress leader Adi Srinivas, who was defeated by Ramesh in an election. The complaint said that Ramesh did not stay in India for the prescribed period before reacquiring Indian citizenship. The Centre held an inquiry and concluded that Ramesh misled the authorities in respect of his compulsory stay in India before applying for Indian Citizenship. It also suspended his Indian citizenship. Brushing aside Ramesh’s contentions that he is a sitting MLA, the Centre said that a legislator is supposed to display more integrity when his conduct was questioned.

Adi Srinivas’s counsel Ravi Kiran Rao has been contending that Ramesh’s claim of relinquishing his German citizenship is also a false one. “The Centre’s letter now proves that what I have been saying is correct and Ramesh has been playing fraud on the system and things are now slowly getting unfolded,” he said.

Justice Abhinand Kumar Shavili, too, turned critical towards Ramesh’s counsel and sought an affidavit from him on the status of his German citizenship. “Whether he gave any letter to the German authorities, if so, what was their reaction to that etc. File an affidavit by February 24, the judge said and extended the stay on Centre’s suspension order that earlier nullified Ramesh’s Indian citizenship.

Title: 20 years on, family of baildar who went missing in 1995 still fighting for his pension
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Ludhiana: A poor labourer family had to fight 20 years to get what is rightfully its – the family pension for son, a government employee, who went missing on duty in 1995. But even after two decades, they could only cross half the bridge – they are getting pension from 2017. Now, yet another battle is on to get the arrears beyond 2017, too.

On February 14, 1995, 24-year-old Sudagar Singh, son of Modan Singh of Toose village and a baildar in irrigation department in Doraha sub-division of Ludhiana district, never returned from work.

“We registered a missing report at Sudhar police station with the help of sarpanch. When he didn’t return home even after a year, we asked the department to take necessary action under law. Later, sub-divisional officer of Doraha marked an enquiry into the matter after which statement of villagers and department officials were recorded,” said 75-year-old Modan Singh.

Meanwhile, the irrigation department, “instead of granting family pension” after declaring him missing, as stated in the government rules 1991, 1992, 1996, terminated his services after two years without providing pension and economic benefit.

The family, with the help of an NGO Universal Human Rights Organisation (UHRO), started the legal action against the department in 2012.

“After scanning the case history and getting necessary details under RTI, we found that instead of declaring the missing person untraced, they had destroyed the record related to missing report. We sought record under RTI from finance and personal departments and then pleaded with the governor, chief minister of Punjab and irrigation department secretary that termination is wrong and family should get pension. However, the department refused to do so,” said Iqbal Singh Rasoolpur, general secretary of UHRO. “In 2015 we filed a petition before Punjab State Scheduled Caste Commission, which sought reply from irrigation department. And then arguments were held from both sides. After considering the evidence on the record, the commission in 2017 allowed benefits (arrears and family pension) as per 1991, 1992 and 1996 rules,” added Rasoolpur.

According to Rasoolpur, acting on the orders of the commission, Punjab government referred the case to accountant general Punjab for Family Pension in 2018. In December 2019, the family got arrears and family pension with effect from December 2017, he added.

“Instead of granting family pension to the victim family from February 1996, the government started it with effect from 2017. Now, we are bracing up for another legal battle,” said Rasoolpur. “We have sought disciplinary action against officials responsible for such delay as well as arrears from 1996 and its interest. We have written around 4,500 letters to various departments to get justice to the family. We will continue to fight till the family gets what its owed,” said Rasoolpur.

When contacted, irrigation department authorities said the family is getting pension from the day the court had ordered. “We are giving pension as per the court’s direction. If the family still has grievances, it can file a review petition,” said Jasinder Bhandari, canal department, Rupnagar division.

Title: Leopard scare casts shadow over kanwar yatra
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Bijnor: With Mahashivratri festival on February 21, forest authorities in Bijnor have issued an advisory to devotees who will be heading for Haridwar to collect water from the Ganga to move in groups and make a noise by playing songs on their mobile phones in view of numerous leopard attacks in the district. Since November 27, six people have been killed in leopard attacks and scores have been injured in Bijnor. Leopard sightings have increased manifold as cane harvesting is underway.

The authorities are in the process of setting up a special control room to monitor the kanwariayas. Lakhs of kanwariyas from neighbouring districts of Amroha, Sambhal, Moradabad, Rampur, Shahjahapur and Bareilly converge in Bijnor before heading for Haridwar. They embark on the journey days ahead of the festival on foot and and after collecting the holy water, return to their native places to offer it at their local Shiva temples on Mahashivratri day.

Plans are afoot to deploy drones for security of the devotees. At several places, route diversions will be put in place and additional forces will be deployed in Bijnor. The plans will come into force during the upcoming kanwar yatra.

The forest authorities have prepared a route map of the kanwariyas. Special vigil will be maintained in areas where leopard sightings were reported. The leopard task force equipped with a vehicle, cage, drone and nets will also patrol the area to deal with any untoward incident. The control room is being set up at the division forest office here.

The kanwariyas usually take short cuts like crossing canals, forest officials said. This is also the route where big cats have been spotted. Divisional forest officer M Semmaran said, “A large part of the route passes through forest areas. We will deploy our staff at such places. Forest teams will be active for 24 hours. As soon as we receive any tip-off about a big cat or any other wild animal on the route taken by the devotees, teams will reach the spot.

“We are making people aware about how to avoid big cat attacks. The leopard is a shy animal. It normally does not attack a human and certainly not, when they are moving in a group. We have suggested to all the devotees to keep a mobile phone, play music on it and shout slogans in forest areas as the noise scares the big cat away. Our teams will help the devotees.” Semmaran added.

Apart from leopards, rogue elephants also obstruct the way taken by the devotees.

Title: Repeal CAA or face massive stir: Bhim Army chief to govt
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Bijnor: Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad on Monday warned of a “massive” agitation if the Centre does not repeal the Citizenship (amendment) Act as he met the families of those killed and injured during the anti-CAA protests in Bijnor’s Nahtaur area.

“Our Constitution has given us the right to hold protests. Policemen had no right to fire at the protestors. If CAA is not repealed, we will launch a massive agitation,” Azad said.

He met the families of Suleman and Anas, who were shot dead during the anti-CAA protest on December 20. Later, the Bhim Army chief also went to the home of Omraj Saini in Kasmpur village to meet him. Saini sustained bullet injuries during the clash.

After the meeting, Azad said he would ensure that the victims get justice. “FIRs against erring policemen will be lodged on the order of court soon,” he said.

Later, addressing a press conference, Azad said, “People have rejected CAA and the government should repeal it. Otherwise, our outfit will launch a massive agitation across the country. BJP government is like Hitler’s regime which believes in bullet and not in talks.”

Earlier, Congress leader Priyanka Gandhi and SP leaders had visited victims’ families.

Anti-CAA clashes had taken place in Bijnor city and several adjoining areas including Nagina, Nahtaur, Najibabad, Jalalabad, Chandpur and Sherkot on December 20. Police had registered 34 cases against 3,900 protestors in the district. Of them, 149 protesters were arrested and sent to jail.

Protesters were booked under various sections of IPC, including sections 147 (rioting), 148 (rioting, armed with deadly weapon), 149 (unlawful assembly).

Title: Woman jumps off building during police raid, dies
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Varanasi: A woman died after jumping from the top floor of a residence in Sanjay Nagar colony of Pahadiya area under the limits of Cantonment police station on Sunday late night when police raided the place to bust a sex racket.

Police have arrested seven persons, including four women, and lodged an FIR. Passports of women of foreign origin and other articles were recovered from the house.

SSP Prabhakar Chawdhary suspended Pahadia police outpost in-charge KN Upadhyaya and a beat constable in this connection. The identity of the deceased woman could not be ascertained.

Locals, who suspected that flesh trade was going on in the house, alerted police after seeing many people there on Sunday late night.

Senior officers, including SSP and SP City Dinesh Kumar Singh, reached there with heavy police force.

On seeing police, one of the women present inside jumped from the top floor and died on the spot, said SP city adding that the body was sent for postmortem.

The police arrested three men and four women, including two from Assam and one from Mumbai, after finding them in objectionable state. SP city said the house was owned by one Sanjay of Dhaurahra area. He had been operating sex racket at his residence since a long time, the SP added.

Many foreigners are also involved in the racket, he said mentioning that many passports of women from foreign countries were also recovered from the house during the raid. Police have lodged an FIR under section 3, 4, 5 of immoral trafficking (prevention) act in this connection.

Title: Hospitals asked to junk obsolete gadgets
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Jodhpur: The high court has directed chief secretary, medical & health department, to conduct a survey of all government hospitals (district-level and above) and list obsolete equipment that were still being used.

The division bench comprising justice Sandeep Mehta and justice Vijay Bishnoi gave these directions while hearing a suo motu petition pertaining to deaths of 90 infants in Mahatma Gandhi Hospital in Banswara in 2017 and a petition pertaining to recent deaths of infants in Kota, Jodhpur and Bikaner hospitals. The petitions included one by Congress MLA Sanyam Lodha pointing to lack of infrastructure and medical and other staff in the hospitals.

The division bench has sought an action plan to replace these obsolete equipment with those with latest technology and directed the state government to consider creating a post for qualified hospital management specialists in district-level hospitals and higher centres in the state.

On bringing to the notice of the court by the amicus curie Kuldeep Vaishnav that the problem of blockage of sewerage discharge in Mahatma Gandhi Hospital, Jodhpur, had not been resolved, the court issued notices to the commissioner (Jodhpur Municipal Corporation) and the chief engineer (PWD).

Vaishnav argued that because of unattended sewerage issue, there was threat of bacterial infection in the hospital.

The court directed that immediate steps be taken to ensure that proper sewerage facility is set up in Mahatma Gandhi Hospital by the next date of hearing on March 19.

Before this, the amicus curie submitted a report of the visit of government hospital in compliance of the direction of the court on last hearing on January 7.

AAG Pankaj Sharma also submitted a report on the number of children who died in the state hospitals in December.

Title: Maharashtra: Five undertrials escape from Karjat sub-jail
Content:
The sub-jail from where the five undertrial prisoners escaped on Sunday, around 7.15pm

PUNE: Three murder suspects, a rape suspect and an illegal arms supplier, escaped from a sub-jail in Karjat taluka in Ahmednagar district, about 150km from Pune, around 7.15pm on Sunday.“The five suspects cut the plywood ceiling of their barrack, climbed up on the roof after removing the roof tiles and escaped,” Sagar Patil, superintendent of Ahmednagar police, told TOI. “We have deployed five teams to trace them on the basis of some clues,” he said.The suspects include Akshay Ramdas Raut and Chandrant Mahadev Raut, both from Jamkhed in Ahmednagar district, who were arrested for murdering a fruit vendor from Mumbai. Mohan Kundalik Bhore of Kavadgaon in Jamkhed was arrested in another murder case.The fourth undertrial, Dnyaneshwar Tukaram Kolhe, was lodged in jail for his involvement in supplying illegal firearms and the fifth person, Gangadhar Laxman Jagtap, was arrested in a rape case.A Karjat police officer said the five undertrials, along with another, had been kept in the last barrack (No 4) in the sub-jail.On Sunday, there were about 30 undertrials in the four barracks. “The five suspects used a cutter to saw the plywood sheet of the ceiling in their barrack. They made a small whole in the ceiling through which they climbed up and removed the roof tiles,” the officer said.The suspects had tied two blankets provided to them and then climbed down the sub-jail from the rear portion and escaped.“There was sixth undertrial in their barrack but he did not raise an alarm as the suspects had threatened to kill him,” the officer said.After they fled, the undertrial in the barrack raised an alarm around 7.30pm and alerted the guards on duty. “We immediately sent teams to trace them, but failed to nab any of them,” the officer said.Dilip Pawar, inspector of the local crime branch of the Ahmednagar police told TOI, that five teams have been sent out to arrest the suspects. “We are keeping a watch on their possible hideouts and have various clues. We will arrest them,” Pawar said.

Title: Green drive on February 17 to mark KCR’s birthday
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

K Chandrasekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: TRS leaders called upon party workers to plant a sapling each on chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao ’s 66th birthday on February 17. TRS working president KT Rama Rao in a tweet said: “As we all know his passion for Haritha Haram, I request all TRS leaders and members to make sure you celebrate and mark our leader’s birthday by planting at least one sapling. #Eahone PlantOne.”

Rajya Sabha MP J Santosh Kumar said people should plant a sapling and take a selfie. “They have to take the photograph ‘Selfie with CM sir sapling’ and send it to 8790909999.” Panchayat Raj minister E Dayakar Rao directed all elected representatives of local bodies, including ward members, ZPTCs, MPTCs, chairpersons, co-option members, panchayat secretaries and other officials to plant a sapling each.

Title: Water board to handle sewer network in peripheral circles
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

HYDERABAD: In a major move, the Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB) has decided to take over the operation and maintenance of sewer network in GHMC peripheral circles from GHMC from March 1.

At a joint meeting held at HMWS&SB main office on Monday, HMWS&SB managing director M Dana Kishore and GHMC commissioner D S Lokesh Kumar along with other officials, discussed the process of the takeover.

According to a water board official, the move comes after Municipal Administration and Urban Development (MA&UD) minister K T Rama Rao directed the HMWS&SB to take over the responsibility of handling the sewer network in peripheral circles of GHMC.

The existing sewer network covers 66 municipal wards spread over a length of 3,600 km and has 3,26,354 manholes. There are nearly 700 sanitation workers for sewer-related works. “The GHMC will pay Rs 8.3 crore towards expenditure for operation and maintenance of the system to the water board for a period of five years,” said Dana Kishore.

The GHMC will also hand over 29 Air Tech machines and 66 mini-jetting machines to the water board soon. “The water board will also impart training to 700 sanitation workers in safety measures and new techniques in handling the sewer system,” said water board officials.

Title: Despite ban, commercial vehicles ply in Old City
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Ludhiana: Even as commissioner of police Rakesh Agarwal renewed the orders banning commercial vehicles in Old City between 5am and 11pm on February 7, the ground reality presents a different picture.

A TOI team visited several areas of Old City and found commercial vehicles, including trucks and load carriers, plying in Chaura Bazaar, Mata Rani Chowk, Kesar Gunj Mandi, Trunk Bazaar, Transport Nagar, Chauri Sadak and Clock Tower between 3pm and 4pm.

Residents blame lack of will for the failed enforcement.

Rajan Kapoor, 42, a resident of Taj Gunj, said, “Commercial vehicles can be seen on Old City roads 24x7. The police stations concerned have failed to put the directions into action.”

Raj Kumar Sharma, 63, a resident of Gaushala Road, said, “The ban was implemented only for the first few days. Now, heavy vehicles are back on narrow, congested lanes of Old City. Cops challan other traffic rule violators, but do not check these vehicles.”

Rivesh Mahindru, 35, a hosiery manufacturer from Madhopuri, said, “Ludhiana police issue one after the other order, but fails to ensure their execution. Recently, several orders were issued like restricting timings of restaurants; ban on songs glorifying weapons, violence, liquor and drugs; curb on the movement of heavy vehicles in Old City and no encroachments on roads. Except the anti-encroachment drive, no other direction has been realised with an iron hand.”

On December 4, 2019, a load carrier had run over a 6-year-old boy, Harshit Kaushal, on Gokul Road. The accident had triggered protests, with residents seeking a ban on the entry of commercial vehicles in the area. The locals had not even let the area transporters open their shops for two days. After forming a committee to look into the issue, the police, on December 13, 2019, had imposed a ban on commercial vehicles in Old City between 5pm and 11pm. Following the issuance of orders, the transporters had hit the roads to protest against it. After a delegation of transporters met the police, the timings were changed — small and medium commercial vehicles were allowed in Old City between 8am and 10am and from 2pm to 4pm and the heavy ones from 11pm to 5am.

However on February 7, Agarwal issued fresh orders banning all commercial vehicles between 5am and 11pm.

When asked about the 5am-11pm orders, additional deputy commissioner of police (Zone-1) Gurpreet Singh Sikand said, “There must be some mistake. Small vehicles that carry weight up to 1 tonne can ply from 7am to 9am and 1pm to 2pm.”

On heavy vehicles entering the area during restricted hours, he said, “It should be brought to the notice of cops.”

Fresh orders

On February 7, the Ludhiana Police had renewed the ban orders and restricted entry of commercial vehicles in Old City between 5am and 11pm. Orders issued under Section 144 of the CrPC have to be renewed after every two months

Title: Government terminates DSP accused of orchestrating murder of wife’s lover
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Meerut: The state government has terminated the services of a deputy superintendent of police (DSP) who was accused of orchestrating the murder of his wife’s alleged lover.

The DSP, who was posted at Meerut-based Police Training School, was axed “for not discharging his duties”. He was under suspension after an FIR was filed against him for the murder.

The chief minister’s office said in a tweet, “UP CM Yogi Adityanath’s zero-tolerance on corruption continues. The CM has directed the termination of suspended Deputy SP at Meerut Police Training School for not discharging his duties as per the protocol.”

According to police sources, the accused’s wife was having an illicit affair with a Moradabad-based man who was working as a clerk in the railway department. After the accused got the whiff of it, he and his nephew hired contract killers who shot the man dead on February 1, 2017, near railway crossing which is close to Majhola area.

Later, an FIR was filed by the government railway police. Within days, the two contract killers were arrested, but the main accused and his nephew remained absconded, only to surrender after the police pressure.

As of now, the accused, his nephew and the contract killers are lodged in jail.

Title: Woman teacher in UP suspended for anti-CAA remarks made at Shaheen Bagh
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

A delegation of local right wing group created ruckus at school where the teacher taught to pressurise school ... Read More

MEERUT: Over 20 days after a woman teacher from Saharanpur made anti-CAA remarks during her visit to Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh , a group led by local saffron leaders held a protest at her private school on Monday forcing the authorities to suspend the 40-year-old educator. Another teacher who was with Nahid Zaidi is also facing a probe for her remarks.

However, the “pressure tactics” and the school administration’s decision didn’t go down well with district police.

Saharanpur superintendent of police (city) Vineet Bhatnagar , said, “Locals and activists from a certain group identified the teachers from a viral video and used pressure tactics against school authorities. It is improper behaviour.

“The veracity of the video is yet to be verified, and the remark is inflammatory or not is yet to be established. Strict action will be taken if anyone tries to rake up the issue and create law and order problem. If anyone has objection, he/she can take legal recourse but any step or attempts to pressure school or individual will be dealt strictly as per law,” he said.

Following the ruckus by the group, the school authorities suspended Zaidi.

Divya Jain, principal of the school, said, “The teacher has been suspended. Further action will be taken based on procedure and guidelines laid down by the education department. She had gone there (Shaheen Bagh) on a Sunday and school had no prior intimation about it.”

A video of Zaidi, speaking to local media in Delhi, was shared widely. Another teacher from a different school, who was with Zaidi, has also been put on notice.

The group, which held the protest at the school, demanded Zaidi be sacked for her alleged inflammatory remarks during her visit to protest site in Shaheen Bagh where hundreds of women have been agitating against Citizenship Amendment (CAA) Act and national register of citizen (NRC).

“I keep on going to Delhi. On January 19, I accompanied a group to Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh. We went there out of sheer curiosity. Local media there started asking questions. The video in question was edited to focus on the negative things while all positive aspects were cropped. I have given my life in teaching profession and I meant no harm to anyone’s religious sentiments,” Zaidi said.

The mobilisation had begun on social media when a few locals identified the teachers and began demanding strict action.

“The video was widely shared on social media. A roadmap was drawn and we reached out to locals and parents of wards studying in the school and we finally decided to meet at around 11am on Monday on Court Road. From there, we went to schools where we spoke to the principal,” Rahul Jhamb, a local activist, said.

Title: One more person dies of swine flu, toll rises to 2 in Meerut
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Meerut: With the death of one more person on Monday, the toll due to swine flu has risen to two in Meerut district. So far, as many as 17 patients have been diagnosed with H1N1 virus, three more than what was reported on Sunday.

According to health department sources, a 50-year-old man in Panchsheel colony died on Monday while a 60-year-old woman, a resident of Kishanpura, succumbed to the virus on January 3.

“So far, 17 cases of swine flu have been reported in Meerut. Two deaths have also been reported. The health department is on its toes and is spreading awareness about the disease. We urge people to maintain cleanliness so that the infection doesn’t spread as easily,” said Rachna Tandon, Meerut district epidemiologist.

Meanwhile, private hospitals have been asked to set up isolation wards for patients suffering from swine flu to ensure that other patients or hospital staff are not infected.

In areas where swine flu cases have been detected, surveillance is being conducted to check if there are more cases in proximity. Awareness camps are also being organized there so that people in those areas can exercise caution. Also, epidemiological study and travel history of patients is being checked, the health department authorities said.

In 2019, a total of 399 cases of swine flu were reported in contrast to 24 cases in 2018.

According to doctors, the period between January and March is considered the “peak time” for the disease caused by H1N1 virus. The main symptoms are fever, cough, runny nose, bodyache and headache. In case of shortness of breath or vomiting, the patient must contact the doctor.

Title: CU to halve overseas distance education fees
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Kozhikode: Calicut University will slash the fees charged for overseas students registered under the school of distance education (SDE) by half to attract more students under the distance education mode.

The meeting of the syndicate standing committee on distance education made the recommendation to the syndicate after finding that the fees charged by the varsity was higher when compared to other universities.

“We have decided to recommend cutting the existing fees for overseas students registered under SDE by half. The recommendation has been made as the existing fee charged in US dollars was affecting the enrolments of foreign students,” syndicate member Ugin Morely said.

Currently, the varsity is charging $225 as registration fee from overseas students apart from $70 as tuition fee per semester and special fee of $75.

Morely said that the syndicate standing committee has recommended reducing the registration fee to $130 and the tuition fee and special fee to $35 and $40, respectively.

Morely said that there has been a decrease in the number of overseas students registered under SDE over the last few years.

The university had to shut down 24 overseas centres which offered distance education courses in the Gulf following a Kerala high court order in December 2014.tnn

Title: Mahapanchayat gives 2 days to cops to solve farmer’s murder at toll plaza
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Meerut: A mahapanchayat convened at Dulhera village on Monday unanimously decided to give 48 hours to police to solve the murder of a local farmer, Sohanveer Chauhan (30), who was allegedly killed by bouncers at Daurala toll plaza on February 3.

Hundreds gathered at the mahapanchayat called by Samajwadi Party leader Atul Pradhan to brainstorm on the further course of action in the brutal murder of Sohanveer.

“A delegation of police and administration, including local MLA Sangeet Som, came over on Sunday evening requesting a week to solve the case and also defer plans of convening the mahapanchayat. But we stuck to our plan and held the mahapanchayat on Monday. It was decided to give two days to police to solve the case and arrest the real culprits or else we will begin an indefinite strike at the commissioner’s office from Thursday,” said Ravindra Chauhan, 42, elder brother of the deceased.

Sohanveer was killed on February 3 when he and Ravindra were returning home from the fields on a tractor laden with cane. “There was a long queue in the cash lane and we decided to take the FASTag lane. This did not go down well with the plaza employees who initially confronted us. The argument soon turned into a brawl and bouncers at the toll plaza began thrashing my brother with rods, lathis and other weapons,” Ravindra had said.

Despite efforts by toll plaza employees to portray the murder as an accident, evidence and post-mortem report paint a completely different picture. The post-mortem report of the victim has also corroborated claims of torture before death. According to the report, the victim sustained 10 injuries on his body with fractures and ruptures in the internal organs at five places. It read, “The cause of death is shock and hemorrhage as a result of ante-mortem injuries following blunt force trauma.”

The victim’s family members claimed that the toll plaza staff tried to portray the incident as an accident and not murder. Ravindra claimed, “The toll plaza staff have been giving different statements every time and are trying to destroy evidence. When I returned to the spot, I saw the tractor abandoned near a 11KV power line. The staff told police that my brother was electrocuted. Later, they claimed that my brother lost control of the tractor due to which it turned turtle, resulting in his death. They have been making this up despite the fact that I was present at the spot with him.”

Police have also conceded that six minutes of the footage from CCTV DVR was erased -- which also points at destruction of evidence to cover up tracks. “We have sent the CCTV DVR for forensics examination. If the report also corroborates claims of tampering with footage, additional sections of destruction of evidence will be added to the existing FIR,” said Akhilesh Narayan Singh, Meerut SP (City).

Though two accused have been arrested after filing of a case of murder, family of the deceased has alleged a cover-up by police to protect the actual culprits. “As of now, we have arrested two persons who were on duty in the particular lane where the incident happened, We are yet to ascertain the complicity of others, based on which further arrests will be made,” the SP said.

Title: Ahead of polls, Sena inaugurates devpt work in Satara-Deolai
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Aurangabad: In the wake of the forthcoming Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) elections, state minister Sandeepan Bhumre, Aurangabad West MLA Sanjay Shirsat and former Sena MP Chandrakant Khaire on Monday held the groundbreaking ceremony of development works in Satara and Deolai worth Rs 5 crore.

The locals have been demanding a separate municipal body as the civic body had failed to initiate development in the area. The works are being undertaken through the funds approved by the district planning committee (DPC) for the development of the areas. Monday saw the inauguration of 8 road construction works.

In December, the corporators of Satara and Deolai had tendered their resignations from corporatorship seeking the NOC of the AMC so that a separate municipal council can be created for Satara and Deolai as AMC failed in providing any development for the area.

According to residents, the inauguration of works done on Monday does not bring any relief as the works are unlikely to finish before elections. Meanwhile, MLA Sanjay Shirsat in his speech stated that all the 8 works will be finished within a month’s time.

Title: Consumer court pulls up NBFC over truck seizure
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Vadodara: A Navi Mumbai-based non-banking finance company (NBFC) has drawn the ire of consumer court for dishonouring its earlier order.

On February 7, the court had asked WitFin, which has a local office in Alkapuri, to immediately release a truck owned by a resident of Ajwa Road, which it had seized despite the owner paying the defaulted loan amount. However, the finance company did not release the truck and demanded parking charges from the borrower Paresh Rathod. The court ordered WitFin to immediately release Rathod’s truck without demanding any further amount.

Rathod had borrowed Rs 6.2 lakh in February 2017 to purchase a used truck and was supposed to pay Rs 20,228 every month as instalment. Rathod regularly paid till September last year but defaulted two instalments. Following the default, the company’s executives stopped Rathod’s driver near Dumad crossroads and seized the truck forcibly. They asked Rathod to pay Rs 1.1 lakh to get the truck back.

Two months later, Rathod borrowed the money and went to the company’s office but he was informed that he will have to repay the remaining loan amount of Rs 4.1 lakh by November 30. Meanwhile, Rathod filed a complaint with consumer court as the seizure of the truck was illegal.

Rathod then sold the truck to one Imtiyaz Sheikh as he was in dire need of money. Sheikh even paid Rs 4.2 lakh to the finance company yet the truck was not released as the finance company that the complaint in the consumer court. Rathod withdrew the complaint, but the truck was not released following which, both Rathod and Sheikh filed another complaint in the district consumer forum.

In an interim order, the court asked WitFin to hand back the truck but the company asked for Rs 16,400 parking charges of a godown where the truck was kept.

“We filed a contempt application as WitFin did not release the truck. The court came down heavily on the company and directed it to return the truck without charging any money,” said P V Moorjani, through whom Rathod had approached the consumer forum.

Title: Delhi: Missing 4-year-old’s body found in drain, family alleges foul play
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

NEW DELHI: The body of a four-year-old boy missing for the past four days was found dumped in a drain at Karawal Nagar on Monday. The child ’s parents had even lodged a kidnapping complaint on Saturday, alleging foul play behind his disappearance. Police are probing into the possibility of a sexual assault as well.

Police sources said that prima facie it appears that the child died after drowning in the drain water. However, his family has demanded a thorough probe into the death, claiming that he might have been lured out of his house by someone and then thrown into the drain. The family blocked the Khajuri main road on Monday, demanding action.

Police said that the child stayed with his parents at a rented house in Karawal Nagar. The family told the cops that the boy had stepped out of house to see an election rally on February 6 and had started walking behind the procession before he disappeared. The family looked for him in the locality till late before lodging a police complaint.

The family claimed that they had even checked the drain but found nothing. The kin also alleged inaction by police into looking for the child and claimed timely action would have saved him.

On Monday morning, a local spotted the decomposing body in the drain and informed the police, who sent it for an autopsy. Doctors have collected viscera samples from the child’s body and will send them for forensic analysis to determine whether he was assaulted before he drowned.

An inquest has been initiated into the death. The possibility of an accident has also not been ruled out. The cops suspect that the boy might have lost his balance while walking with the crowd and slipped into the deep drain. However, locals say that no one had heard him call for help.

Title: Two-day international Urdu conference in April
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

CHARMINAR: The Telangana State Urdu Academy will host a two-day international Urdu conference in April this year in the city.

Moulana Mohammed Raheemuddin Ansari , president, Telangana Urdu academy, said that a committee will soon be formed to look into the process pertaining to the invitation of delegates from different countries. “The conference will be organised in the last week of April,’’ said Ansari.

The academy is also planning to introduce an Urdu learning app for young and innovative minds to promote the language and make it easy.

Ansari told TOI that the academy had computer centres and libraries which were handed over to Minority Finance Corporation so that they can be run smoothly, but many of the centres that were established were shut and all possible efforts are being made to take them back and reopen them.

“We have taken up the matter with officials concerned. Last time, we had set up almost 40 computer centres, however, now only 10 are functioning as the rest of them have been shut,” the president said.

The academy has said that the lifetime achievement awards will be presented in six categories including poetry, criticism, research and promotion of Urdu and journalism.

Title: The buck stops with the traffic police, or does it?
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Chennai: Last year, after the Madras high court came down heavily on the traffic police for poor enforcement of the helmet rule, the number of fatal accidents among two-wheelers fell. The number of deaths among riders not wearing helmets came down from 72% in 2018 to 54 in 2019.

“That was the effect for just one offence,” said M Kasimayan, a Chennai-based traffic activist. “Courts can’t speak about traffic violation and road safety every day, but if policemen do their job there won’t be these many violations and accidents. Sadly, many accident hotspots don’t have police during peak hours because they are posted on bandobast duty or as line up for VIP convoys,” he said.

According to the city traffic police, nearly one-fourth of their strength is stationed at signals and the rest are deployed at intersections in shifts. But if there are no police at signals or at intersections, it is also because more than 2,000 of the 7,800 sanctioned posts are vacant. “Add to this people who go on leave or have a weekly off,” said a traffic policeman at Madhavaram. “We work for 12 hours a day to make up for vacancies. Standing there and managing traffic is a challenge. There is no time to book people for violation ,” he said.

Activists like S Suresh from Federation of Ambattur Residents Welfare Association, who has been campaigning for better policing for years, call for use of technology. Mumbai can make entire penalty system online to track repeat offenders. The CCTV camera footages can help police catch offenders. The challans can be posted to their houses. All we need is some investment in smart technology, he said.

The city police have installed 25,000 CCTV cameras in the last one year, but the department hasn’t upgraded itself to technology. “We don’t know how many of these cameras are working,” said activist Kasimayan. “Traffic police claim they have make apps for making complaints, receiving e-challans and paying fines. But not many people are using them because they are not aware,” he said.

The problem exists even at signals. There are 408 traffic signals in the city. The signals are first-gen pre-timed signals which don’t consider real-time traffic data. “This means the signals will not change even if there are no oncoming vehicles. This will lead to more violations and accidents eventually,” said a traffic expert who works with the Union IT ministry.

Many senior policemen are pushing for reforms, resources and innovations. “Many countries have equipped their police forces with high-end equipment long ago. It’s time for Tamil Nadu to do so,” said former DGP S R Jangid.

Title: Pilot’s office writes to ACS rural devpt to examine demands of PwDs
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Jaipur: Deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot’s office has written to additional chief secretary (ACS) rural development and panchayati raj department, Rajeshwar Singh, forwarding a letter by Hemant Bhai Goyal on the issue of nominating persons with disabilities (PwDs) as panchayati raj body members. Singh has been asked to take appropriate action after examining the matter.

In a representation to Pilot, Hemant Bhai Goyal, national vice-president of Divyang Adhikar Mahasangh, had urged him to nominate one person with disability as a member/councillor in every gram panchayat, panchayat samiti, zila parishad, nagar palika, nagar parishad and nagar nigam just like in Chattisgarh.

Goyal also wrote that Chhattisgarh cabinet had decided to amend the Panchayati Raj Act and nominate disabled persons as councillors in every gram panchayat. He further stated that around 40 lakh persons with disability and 16 lakh families will benefit by this move.

Goyal also raised this issue with chief minister Ashok Gehlot during the pre-budget dialogue with NGOs, civil societies and consumer forum. He also raised the issue pertaining to giving status of BPL category to the families of PwDs.

Earlier, the court of the commissioner for specially abled persons had directed local self government (LSG) department and the rural development and panchayati raj department to nominate one PwD as member/councillor in every panchayati raj institution and urban local body.

In an order, dated November 29, addressed to ACS, rural development and panchayati raj department and director, local self government, the deputy commissioner for specially abled persons has directed them to “Nominate one divyang person as councillor/member in each gram panchayat, panchayat samiti, zila parishad, nagar palika, nagar parishad and nagar nigam.”

Title: Hyderabad man goes missing in sea at Puducherry
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

HYDERABAD: A 22-year-old man from Kushaiguda went missing in the sea at a beach in Puducherry on Monday. According to police, the missing youth has been identified as N Nikhil Reddy . His family left for Puducherry after they were alerted by his friends.

Nikhil works at a Gachibowli-based interior designing firm. He went to Puducherry with eight of his friends. At around 6.15pm, Nikhil went missing in sea waters at the beach.

Title: KPCC dharnas on Feb 26 over increase in service fees
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The KPCC has decided to organize dharnas in front of village offices in the state on February 26 to protest against the fee hike for pokkuvaravu (conveyance), fair value of land, building tax, etc.

KPCC president Mullappally Ramachandran said the state budget has levied fees for services which have so far been free, especially getting documents from government offices.

The people have been burdened with the increase in the pokkuvaravu fees and building tax. The government has imposed a tax burden of Rs 1,103 crore in the budget, he said.

Several assembly constituencies, not given due recognition in the budget, are of the opposition MLAs, he alleged. The proposals of Kuttanadu package, coastal area package and Idukki package are not new. tnn

Title: Sonam Kapoor looks all dreamy in a white saree; take a look at the pictures here
Content: The CBI called actress Rhea Chakraborty for the third consecutive day on Sunday for questioning in the case of death of her boyfriend and filmstar Sushant Singh Rajput, a police official said. The 28-year-old actress is accused of abetting Rajput's suicide.

Title: Green protocol in govt offices to face scrutiny
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Kochi: Suchitwa Mission along with Haritha Keralam Mission would soon undertake a district-level auditing of green protocol in government offices in the state and rank them based on their fidelity.

Adherence to green protocol became a norm from June 5, 2018 but this is for the first time that state is undertaking an evaluation of the protocol introduced to minimize waste generation in government offices and make employees accountable.

“In October 2019, a taskforce had drafted criteria for green protocol monitoring on the basis of which guidelines have been formed. This has now been sent for government approval,” said consultant for solid waste management, Haritha Keralam Mission, Jagjeevan.

Once they get the approval, which is a formality, a joint panel of Suchitwa Mission and Haritha Keralam Mission would audit the efficacy of green protocol and issue certification.

“This would be carried out on the basis of questionnaire,” said an official with Suchitwa Mission.

According to officials, lot of positive changes have taken place in government offices since the green protocol was adopted. “Till now, for public programmes green protocol implementation was based on exertion of social pressure. But now government is planning to make this mandatory,” said Jagjeevan.

According to officials, this would be easier now since the government has banned single-use disposables.

The primary focus is on waste minimization through prevention of use of disposables and use of reusable alternatives. Any waste generated has to be treated in the most scientific and environment-friendly manner.

As per protocol, organic waste should either be composted in office premise or given for community composting or other treatment facilities. Waste generation on account of disposables in minimized to zero-waste level by using reusable plates and glass or steel tumblers. To minimize waste on account of decorations, no disposable product should be used. As per the guidelines, paper waste should be recycled and the e-waste generated is to be sent to Clean Kerala Company.

Title: Beed farmers yet to receive govt relief, take out protest
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Aurangabad: The representatives of farmer bodies took out a protest rally to the Beed collectorate on Monday to receive relief against the damage they suffered due to excessive October rain.

In a memorandum of demand submitted to the Beed district collector’s office, the Maharashtra Rajya Kisan Sabha, Beed stated that after six years of drought-like situation, the district faced heavy rain in the last season causing heavy loss of kharif crops. The farmer body’s district president Mohan Lamb stated that the help announced by the state government towards compensation against crop loss is far from satisfactory. However, many farmers in Beed have not even received the compensation announced.

Earlier, the central team had conducted a survey to assess damage to kharif crop and announced a compensation of Rs 2 lakh.

On the other hand, Maharashtra Rajya Kisan Sabha, Beed district committee secretary Murlidhar Nagargoje claimed that none of the farmers in the Beed district have received grants under the state government’s horticulture area scheme.

The protestors highlighted that the various terms and conditions placed for loan waiver announced by the state government goes against the Shiv Sena’s election manifesto in which they promised to clear the 7/12 extract that is to make the farmer free of loans. “The Sena-led the government should remove the limit of Rs 2 lakh. Many farmers have borrowed loans for the purpose of irrigation, drip system or poultry farming. These loans are purely for agriculture purposes and should be covered under the state government’s loan waiver,” Nagargoje said.

In addition, the demand was made to also cover the farmers deprived of Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Yojana. The farmers said that addressing these pressing issues would prevent farmers from taking the step of suicide.

Maharashtra Rajya Kisan Sabha members stated that despite having necessary documents around 1.05 lakh farmers of Beed are still waiting for crop insurance of 2018.

The delegation met with the resident district collector and presented their demands.

The official said meetings of different departments will be held with the district collector so as to look into their demands.

Title: An accident took away his limb, left him with a pay cut and huge debt
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Chennai: When the TNSTC bus he travelled in met with an accident, it cost a 28-year-old engineer his limb, a salary cut and left him with a huge debt.

“It was a day that changed my life,” said Nagoor Meeran.

On February 10, 2019, Meeran boarded the bus to his native Polur in Tiruvannamalai district. When the bus crossed Vandavasi, it met with an accident. The driver was unable to control the vehicle while negotiating a curve and hit boulder. In the accident, Meeran’s leg was crushed. “The pain was severe. I could see blood pouring out of my leg,” he said.

He was first taken to a government medical college hospital in Chengalpet but his family members wanted to move him to a private facility. Doctors at the hospital said he will not be able to use 108 ambulance for transfer to a private hospital. By the time his relatives found a private ambulance and moved him to a hospital in Chrompet, it was already six hours. “Doctors told me it was too late to save my limb. While the negligent driver caused the accident, the policy not to permit an ambulance to ferry people to hospitals of their choice delayed my treatment,” he said.

The family borrowed more money to pay Rs 6 lakh towards medical expenses. When he was finally back on his feet, his company told him he will not be able to continue in the service department. They offered him job in the administration department. “The last blow was a pay cut from a monthly salary of Rs 25,000 to Rs 8000,” he said.

Meeran is now awaiting compensation from TNSTC, Villupuram.

Title: 250 students attend event on water issues
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Photo for representative purpose only

HYDERABAD: Around 250 students attended the ‘ Waterpreneurs ’ programme in the city aimed at making children understand and find solutions to water issues.

In the first session, students listened to YV Prakash from IIIT-H. “I spoke to the students over creating a framework to solve problems. The whole idea of the workshop is to provide students with the tools to address issues that they see around them.”

The first batch of 250 children will go through a four-month course and come up with 250 acts that will help address water-related issues. The programme was started by Rain Water Project, a social initiative started by city-based activist Kalpana Ramesh , which is partnering with Silver Oaks International School.

Ramesh said, “In the age of climate change, we want students to not just stand and protest, but to also be change-makers on the ground. It is important that they be part of the problem-solving process.”

Pradyun Chakraborty , a Class 6 student, said, “We have gotten a chance to address an issue that has been plaguing the city, that is, water crisis. Through actual action, we hope to make a difference.”

Title: Kathi booked for abusive comments
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

HYDERABAD: The cybercrime police registered a case against actor and film critic Kathi Mahesh on Monday for allegedly making derogatory comments against Lord Ram . Nampally police also received a complaint against him for his remarks.

Cyber crime ACP KVM Prasad said they have received a complaint from one Umesh Kumar , a businessman from Begum Bazar, saying that a video of Kathi Mahesh’s derogatory speech is available on YouTube. “Based on the complaint and the video, a case has been registered,” the ACP said.

Hindu Sangathan chief Karunasagar also lodged a complaint with Nampally police referring to the video. “In the video, Kathi Mahesh used derogatory words towards Lord Ram,” Karunasagar said.

Title: Allahabad gridlocked as devotees rush back home after Magh Purnima snan
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

chaos central: Vehicles queue up in traffic jams in Allahabad on Sunday

Allahabad: Devotees and kalpwasis rushing back home after taking a dip in Sangam on Magh Purnima triggered yet traffic jams on several routes of the city on Sunday.

The rush of devotees hurrying back to their native towns and homes led to traffic snarls in routes near Shastri Bridge, Baihrana and Alopibagh. Some of these roads were choked due to movement of several tractor trolleys.

Apart from routes connecting Sangam and Magh Mela ground to the city, Phaphamau on Lucknow–Allahabad highway was chock-a-block with vehicles as visitors from districts like Pratapgarh, Jaunpur, Lucknow, Amethi and Rai Bareilly hurried back home.

Traffic inspector Harendra Singh said, “Several roads in Allahaabd were congested due to the large number of devotees retruning home, escpecially kalpwasis, from the Magh Mela ground.”

He also said that the devotees returning in tractor trolleys with their baggage added to the chaos on roads. The diversions introduced in view of the Magh Purnima snan did little to control the traffic mayhem.

Kalpwasis returning from the Magh Mela ground, meanwhile, blamed the chaos on roads on traffic police.

“We had planned to return to our native town in Mirzapur after the Magh Purnima snan. However, we were trapped in a traffic jam for more than two hours near Shastri Bridge. A few pilgrims were also stuck in a snarl for over an hour near New Sohbatiyabagh Road as well,” said one of the kalpwasis Atul Pandey.

Aditi, a devotee from Lucknow who was in Allahabad to visit the Magh Mela, said, “We were stuck in a snarl for over an hour near Baihrana.”

Sunday’s jam is not an isolated occurrence. The city has been reeling under traffic jams almost every weekend ever since the Magh Mela started.

Another commuter Harsh Mehrotra said, “It’s just like last Sunday and the one before that. My family and I were on our way to Jhunsi, but we were trapped in a jam. Meanwhile, the police did little as taxi and cab driver brazenly flouted traffic norms.”

Vehicles moved at snail’s pace near Baihrana, Alopibgah, Shastri Bridge and Daraganj throughout the day.

Traffic movement was worst hit between 11am and 6pm.

Title: Dengue Cases in Delhi: In a week: 3 chikungunya, 2 dengue cases
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Photo for representative purpose only

NEW DELHI: Dengue cases continue to be reported in the capital in spite of the long winter and unfavourable weather conditions for the breeding of mosquito larvae, suggests a report released by South Delhi Municipal Corporation ( SDMC ) on Monday.

According to the weekly report, two cases of dengue and three cases of chikungunya were reported last week. Similarly, six cases of malaria were reported last month. These figures are higher in comparison to number of dengue, chikungunya and malaria cases reported in 2019 till the end of February.

An SDMC official denied there was any specific reason for the early reports of dengue and chikungunya cases but accepted that the exercise for door-to-door visits of residential houses have been affected due to engagement of staff in assembly elections as well as Swachh Survekshan.

“However, clear instructions have been issued to all staff of the health department to restart exercise of visiting residential houses intensively from Monday,” said the official.

On February 19, SDMC also targets to call a joint meeting with officials from all three corporations, the Centre, Delhi government, sentinel surveillance hospitals, World Health Organisation and other agencies concerned for chalking out a detail action plan for controlling vector-borne diseases in 2020.

Title: Vehicle registrations hit the slow lane
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Registration of new vehicles in the capital district recorded a nearly 14% decline last year. As many as 1,09,760 were registered in Thiruvananthapuram in 2019 against 1,27,518 in 2018.
