This is in stark contrast to the trend of the previous years. In 2018, the number of new vehicles had increased by 7% from a year earlier. “Vehicle registration in the past several years had recorded a positive growth. The drop in 2019 is attributed to the economic slowdown. The decline was sharpest in the commercial category, which was worst hit due to the crisis,” said R Joy, joint regional transport officer, Thiruvananthapuram RTO .

“However, two-wheeler registrations were little changed. A total of 25,067 two-wheelers were registered under Thiruvananthapuram RTO in 2019. This was 25,431in 2018. It is mostly the youth and office-goers who opt for two-wheelers,” Joy said.

Another reason cited by experts is the new pollution level norms notified by the Union government. The shift to Bharat stage (BS) VI emission standards by April 2020 has prompted a section of buyers to wait for new models with the standard specification.

Vehicle dealers claim the proposed shift to BS-VI and the recession have adversely affected the industry.

“There was drastic drop in vehicle sales in 2019, when compared with 2018 as the automobile industry was affected by the economic slowdown. Also, with the shift to BS-VI emission standards, people will not opt BS-IV vehicles unless they are given certain offers. Another issue is the unavailability of BS-VI fuel here,” said Jagan K Geroge, sales head, Pothens Hyundai, Thiruvananthapuram.

Thiruvananthapuram RTO posted a 14% decline in registrations 2019, while at Attingal RTO the drop was 15%. Nedumangad saw a 21.9% slip, Neyyattinkara 42%, Parassala 25% and Kazhakkoottam 8.46%.

The sub-regional transport office at Kattakada, because it was set up in September 2018, registered a 225% jump in 2019. No registration was recorded at the nationalised sector office at Kudappanakunnu, where transport buses are enrolled.

Title: Four auto-lifters held with 6 bikes
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Allahabad: Four men associated with two different auto-lifting gangs were arrested in Shahganj and Shankargarh areas of the city on Monday. Police collectively seized 12 motorcycles from the accused.

In the first case, Shankargarh police arrested Madhya Pradesh native Shubham Pandey and recovered six stolen two-wheelers from him.

Sub-inspector of Naribari police outpost Jag Narayan said, “We had received a tip-off that Pandey was spotted near Dhari village. He nabbed him while he was getting ready to sell a stolen motorcycle using forged documents.”

Police later raided one of his hideouts in Itwa Devra village and seized five more motorcycles, which had been dumped under a shed made of straw.

In Shahganj, three men were arrested with six stolen two-wheelers. The accused were identified as Shahid Ansari, Deepal Pandey and Ajay Singh — all residents of Koraon.

Station officer of Shahganj police station Brijesh Singh said, “The auto-lifters were arrested near Mall Godown Railway Colony, when they were trying to dispose off the stolen motorcycles.”

The station officer said that the gang had been active since the past two years and used to target vehicles parked on streets or in unauthorized parking slots.

Meanwhile, two men were arrested with nine crude bombs during a vehicle checking drive, under Naini police station, on Monday. The accused were identified as Vishnu Singh and Shera alias Shivam — both residents of Jhunsi.

Title: Pvt schools for rollback of proposed tax hike on school buses
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: All India Private Schools’ & Children’s Welfare Association appealed to the state government to roll back the decision to hike tax on school buses of unaided schools .

Finance minister T M Thomas Isaac, in his recent budget speech, announced a significant increase in the tax levied on school buses run by unaided schools.

Terming the proposed tax hike a deplorable move, the Kerala chapter of the association urged the government to immediately withdraw the proposal.

“School managements are already troubled by the steep fines slapped on buses by transport authorities. Natural calamities such as the recent unprecedented floods have already left the unaided sector in doldrums,” the association said, in a memorandum submitted to chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan here on Monday. tnn

Title: BSNL employees to protest during lunch hour
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Aurangabad: Bharat Sanchar Nigam Ltd. ( BSNL ) employees have decided to hold a protest during the lunch hour on Tuesday, as a part of a nationwide agitation.

According to the BSNL Employees’ Union, the organisation’s staff have not received their salaries for the last two months, while the contract workers for four to six months.

“The employees who recently opted for the voluntary retirement scheme (VRS) are also suffering as their payments are also outstanding.”

The union stated that the amount deducted from the salaries of the employees for various purposes like society, GPF and LIC are not deposited in the respective accounts.

Around 80,000 employees of BSNL across the country, including 220 in Aurangabad opted for VRS.

According to Ranjan Dani of the employees union, a vacuum has been created with the absence of these employees, affecting work.

Besides the salary issue, the union is demanding introduction of BSNL 4G across the country and implementation of the Union cabinet decision on financial assistance to BSNL through bonds.

Title: Utkarsh Ambudkar: American Actor Utkarsh Ambudkar, rapper who stole the show at Oscars, has a Chennai connection
Content:
Utkarsh Ambudkar performs onstage during the Academy Awards in Hollywood, California.

The rapper (right) with his uncle S Raghavan

CHENNAI: Rapper Eminem may have got a standing ovation when he performed at the Oscars, but there was another rapper too who stole the show – Indian American Utkarsh Ambudkar . While Utkarsh’s freestyle Oscar recap rap lit up social media all of Monday, it seems to have also inadvertently put Chennai in the spotlight — the actor’s mother Indu Bashyam is from the city.The suit Utkarsh wore to the Oscars, which was a standout owing to its conspicuous zari cuffs, was custom-made in India and shipped to him in the US.“His family has a lot of history with the city,” says Raghavan, who lives in Chennai. “His forefather was Sir Vembakkam Bhashyam Iyengar, the first Indian advocate-general of the Madras Province,” says Raghavan, the former owner of auction house Murray and Company. “Utkarsh’s grandfather worked in the Indian Railways and after retirement settled down in Chennai. His parents met in college in Madurai,” says Raghavan.Utkarsh, he says, was also interested in the arts and in acting, and his parents supported and encouraged him to pursue a career in showbiz, which began 16 years ago. “The family would come down quite often to meet all of us here.”The 36-year-old completed his acting programme at New York University’s Tisch School of Arts and spent many a night in clubs freestyling and battle rapping. He has also acted in ‘Pitch Perfect’ and ‘Brittany Runs a Marathon’ and is the star of the Broadway rap-improv show Freestyle Love Supreme. Utkarsh’s Oscars rap also caught everyone’s attention as it was eerily predictive of this year’s winners.

Title: DoB details given during Aadhaar drive not good enough for NRC
Content:
Photo for representative purpose only

HYDERABAD: The date of birth (DoB) details provided during Aadhaar card enrolment will not hold water when the officials take up the National Register of Citizens (NRC) exercise.Normally, DoB details given (orally) by respondents are entered in the Aadhaar cards by the authorities. Also, there was no insistence on producing birth certificates to corroborate the DoB details. “However, during the NRC exercise, the authorities will insist on birth certificates of the respondents while filling the forms. This is where the crux lies. The Aadhaar card DoB details will have no meaning in NRC,” highly-placed sources said.The Unique Identity Authority of India (UIDAI) has data of people who, at the time of enrolment, did not produce their birth certificates but merely gave the operators their DoB details. Though Aadhaar cards would not reveal if the DoB is genuine or not, the back-end data will have information, say officials.UIDAI had clearly marked two categories of DoBs — notified and non-notified. Notified are the ones who have shown their birth certificates at the time of enrolment. And non-notified ones are those who had given their DoB details verbally.The non-notified DoBs were again sub-categorised into two — declared and assumed DoBs. Assumed DoBs belong to those who are not in the know of their DoB and merely quoted some date. Declared DoBs belong to those whose DoB is confirmed as per the birth certificate.“But, in both cases, it will be considered invalid. Only those who had shown their birth certificates will have DoBs as verified,” an UIDAI official told TOI. “It is better to revisit the DoB given during enrolment so that there’s no ambiguity,” another official added.

Title: Poultry farmers in financial trouble due to coronavirus-related rumours
Content:
Photo for representative purpose only

NAGPUR: Social media rumours about the spread of coronavirus through non-vegetarian food have started bringing losses to poultry farmers in Maharashtra and Andhra Pradesh. Especially, chicken and egg consumption in Vidarbha has seen a remarkable decline in last three weeks as many people have started avoiding chicken, eggs and meat believing rumours that coronavirus spreads through it.Dr Raju Dudhbade of Vidarbha poultry farmers’ association (VPFA) said that farmers are left with no option but to sell full grown birds at throwaway prices. “Keeping a full-grown bird for a day costs Rs4.5 to a farmer. Small farmers having 500 to 1000 such birds suffer huge losses. Small poultry farmers usually deal through traders. So, they have no option but to sell their birds at low costs to traders,” he said.Top restaurants in Nagpur, too, said that there’s a drop in chicken consumption.Maharashtra Animal and Fisheries Science University (MAFSU) came in support of poultry farmers on Monday. MAFSU vice-chancellor, Dr Ashish Paturkar , appealed to people to not believe any fake news regarding coronavirus.“Research about the origin, pathogenesis and epidemiology of coronavirus is presently at a very initial stage. It might have originated through non-vegetarian food but the food practices in China are more responsible for it,” he said, adding, Indian food practices make food free from virus and bacteria.“Traditionally, Indian non-veg delicacies are well cooked and full of spices which make our food nearly virus-free. There is no need to curb non-vegetarian food if we are cooking our traditional recipes,” he said.MAFSU director of research, Dr Nitin Kurkure , said that the university has decided to create awareness about coronavirus. “Students in all colleges affiliated to MAFSU will soon visit nearby towns and villages to clear these misconceptions. Having good quality non-veg food will keep your immunity intact and maintain fitness level. This is very important to fight any viral infection. Hence, there is no need to stop eating chicken, eggs or meat,” he said.MAFSU will soon establish a health centre in Nagpur where research on such mutations in viruses will be conducted separately.Fake news effectEgg prices in Nagpur declined from Rs4.75/piece on January 1 to Rs3.90 on Feb 10: NECKChicken consumption in Nagpur came down to 150 tons/day from 300 tons/day in last 2 weeks: VPFAAs consumption has declined, traders are buying less birds from poultry farmersBut, farmers must sell off full-grown birds because its loss-making to keep them at farmsBird buying rates for traders which used to be around Rs80/Kg in Jan is less than Rs50/Kg in FebPoultry farmers stare at uncertain future as they don’t know when rumours will get clearedAccording to MAFSU, there is no harm in having well-cooked non-veg foodEggs, meat and chicken helps maintaining fitness and improves immunity and should be consumed

Title: 52 IPS officers including 5 ADGs transferred
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Bhopal: In a major reshuffle of Indian Police Service (IPS) officers on Monday, the state government transferred 52 officers including five of the rank of the additional director general of police (ADGP), five of the rank of inspector general (IGs) and 16 superintendents of police.

Those transferred include Manoj Kumar Rai SP of Chhindwara, the native district of chief minister Kamal Nath to Neemuch.

Likewise, SP Bhopal, South Sampat Upadhyaya has been transferred to Sheopur. He will be replaced by Sai Krishna S Thota who was AIG intelligence PHQ. DIG Indore, rural, Sanjay Tiwari has been transferred to Bhopal.

Among top officers, ADG (Administration) Kailash Makwana and ADG (Narcotics) Ajay Sharma have swapped each other's positions.

Similarly, ADG (State Crime Record Bureau) GP Singh has been transferred as ADG (Anti-Naxal operations). ADG (Home guards), Jabalpur, Rajesh Chawla will replace Singh. G Janardhan, ADG (JN Police Academy, Sagar) has been moved to Shahdol in the same capacity.

Besides, SPs of 16 districts, namely Shahdol, Hoshangabad, Chhatarpur, Bhind, Indore (East), Agar Malwa, Guna, Betul, Damoh, Bhopal (South), Burhanpur, Sheopur, Singrauli, Neemuch, and Harda have been transferred.

The transfer order sparked a Twitter war between BJP and Congress. Leader of opposition Gopal Bhargava tweeted, “Transfer industry has again started in Madhya Pradesh. Till now, only 52 IPS officers have been transferred. In future, long lists will come. ‘Bring money and take order’ — this remains Nath government’s real meaning of law and order. MP government has no other work. Everyone is mentally oppressed.”

State Congress spokesman and CM Kamal Nath’s media convener Narendra Saluja hit back by tweeting: “The government which made transfers an industry during its 15-year rule is levelling false allegations against the Kamal Nath government. During its rule, it was an open secret that officials were asked to bring money and take transfer orders. Everyone knows who ran the transfer industry and who possessed a currency counting machine. Even ministers were unhappy with the transfer industry during BJP rule.”

Title: Dist porters’ protest to seek pending payment dues
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Aurangabad: The district-level porters’ body on Monday held a demonstration at Beed district collectorate seeking payment of their pending dues while working at the government grain godowns.

Out of the 199 porters registered with the body, 180 porters participated in the protest. The stir was withdrawn after district supply officer assured them that their issues will be addressed within four days.

The Shaskiya Dhanya Godam Hamal Panchayat submitted a letter to the office of Beed district collector on Monday. Rajkumar Ghayal, the president of the porters’ body stated that owing to various technical reasons the porters working at the government grain godowns are not getting their wages for the last six months.

According to Maharashtra Mathadi Hamal and other Manual Workers (Regulation of Employment and Welfare) Act, 1969, the porters’ are paid through district-level mathadi board. The contractors in the godowns should deposit their wages and the district collector should deposit the levy to the Board. The workers are paid when the Board receives both payments on time.

Out of the 23 government godowns in Beed district, 12 are run by contractors and 11 have no contractor. “In the 11 godowns directly run by the district supply office, the mathadis have not received payment since December while in 12 godowns, the contractors have not deposited the payment since August due to which the workers are bereft of their wages for the last six months,” Ghayal said.

The delay in payment is also because the go-down keeper does not issue bills on time, he said.

Marking the protest, all 23 government godowns were shut on Monday. Notably, in the absence of a full-time district collector for the last 2 months, the issues were piling up. When a delegation of the protesting porters met with the district supply officer on Monday, they were told that the new district collector Rahul Rekhawar has taken charge of the office on Monday and the payments of workers will be cleared within 4 days.

Title: Inebriated man attacks wife, father
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Allahabad: A man was arrested on Monday for attacking his father with a knife in an inebriated state in Aspur Devsara village of Pratapgarh.

According to police, Kunwar Singh alias Rajan Singh (40) returned home drunk late Sunday night and thrashed his wife following a tiff.

When his father, Amar Bahadur, opposed the act, Rajan attacked him with a knife.

“When I objected, Rajan attacked me with a knife. I sustained injuries on my waist, hand and back. When other family members rushed to my rescue Rajan fled the spot,” Amar Bahadur said in his complaint.

Title: Hyderabad: 1,000kg of waste collected from Saroornagar Lake
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Volunteers collect waste from Saroornagar Lake

HYDERABAD: Volunteers who have been cleaning up Saroornagar Lake at their own expense have collected around 1,000 kg of waste from the lake. They said that the struggle to keep water bodies clean is becoming an uphill task.

Kota Saikumar, a college student who gives up his Sundays for the drive, said, “We find huge amounts of plastic and puja material. People pray at home and dump religious items in the lake.” He added that the waste picked up is not even a fraction of what gets into the lake. “We are only able to reach the borders of the lake and have requested authorities to help clean the entire water body,” he said.

Putting the onus on residents, Satish Chandra from the group Helping Hands Humanity said, “Awareness must be created among people to ensure that they do not litter. Laws pertaining to keeping lakes and other water bodies clean must be implemented.” From the government’s perspective, he said it was time fencing is carried out.

Gali Vinila Reddy, who works with Vrikshit Foundation , said the problem lies in the lack of awareness among people. “We get no support from locals who should be more proactive in saving the environment.”

Title: Dalit man shot, one other hurt in clash
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Allahabad: A 20-year-old Dalit man was shot dead while another was injured when two groups clashed over a petty dispute at Shringverpur under Nawabganj police station late Sunday night.

SP, trans-Ganga, NK Singh told TOI that two rival camps were at loggerheads over the theft of wood for bonfires in Shringverpur.

The situation took an ugly turn when following a scuffle, a man, Pappu, came out with a rifle and opened fire on Sanjay Pasi. The bullet hit him on the chest killing him on the spot.

Agitated over this, Pasi’s supporters and other villagers attacked Pappu, his aide Suresh Tiwari and another unidentified man. While the other two managed to flee, the mob nabbed Suresh and thrashed him.

A team of Nawabganj police rushed to the spot and shifted Suresh to hospital.

A case was registered against three persons under Section 302 of the Indina Penal Code and SC/ST Act. Police have detained two persons for quizzing.

Title: IUML slams Pinarayi, says intimidation won’t work
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Kozhikode: IUML has come out against chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan for his recent statement against aided school managements warning them against appointment of teachers by providing inflated number of students.

IUML state general secretary KPA Majeed said at the state conference of IUML-affiliated Kerala State Teachers’ Union (KSTU) on Monday that the chief minister should not think that education sector can be cleansed by intimidating school managements.

“The chief minister has taken an intimidating stand against school managements in his traditional style. No one should think that they can cleanse the education sector by threatening managements, teachers or staff. It is not going to work. The chief minister should think about the substantial contributions of school managements for towards the educational development of the state,” he added.

Majeed said that around 3,000 school teachers in the state were not getting their salaries as the government was delaying sanction to their appointments.

Majeed said that it is natural to have protected teachers in the state and that was due to the overall decrease in the number of students. “The problem should be resolved constructively without taking a negative approach towards it. Teachers should not be penalized for that,” he added.

Meanwhile, the remarks made by Majeed in the speech that people are being made to look for holes in the classrooms after some student got bitten by a snake in the classroom created a controversy, following which he issued an explanation. He was referring to the death of Shahala Sherin, a Class V student of the Government Sarvajana Vocational Higher Secondary School at Sulthan Bathery, who died after being bitten by a snake in the classroom in November last year.

In his Facebook post, Majeed said that he was drawing attention to the stand by the Pinarayi Vijayan government to hound the aided school managements.

“The student had died following snakebite in a government school. But instead of improving the facilities at government schools, the government was trying to hound aided schools in the name of the incident,” he added.

Title: Vadodara: Five who returned from China complete 2-weeks observation
Content:
Representative image

VADODARA: Five persons who had returned to the city from China have completed the two-week observation period in which they had to stay in isolation at home.In all, 18 persons had been put under observation by the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) after they returned in wake of the novel coronavirus outbreak there.Sources in the VMC health department said that the 18 persons whose details were shared with the civic body had come to the city since around January 20. These persons were examined on their entry to the country at one or even more airports through which they passed. Some had even gone to the SSG Hospital to get themselves examined. VMC officials said that as per the protocol, such persons had to stay in isolation at home and VMC teams kept a check on their health daily.Five of these persons had been in the city for two weeks or more without any symptom of a novel coronavirus infection. “The remaining 13 are still under our observation,” said a VMC official. So far, only one sample was sent for examination for the viral infection. The tests turned negative.

Title: Taslima takes potshots at Akbar seeking Rs 10 crore for temple
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Author Taslima Nasreen (left) & AIMIM MLA Akbaruddin Owaisi

HYDERABAD: A day after AIMIM legislator Akbaruddin Owaisi met Telangana chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao seeking funds to develop a temple in the Old City, Bangladeshi author Taslima Nasreen took a jibe at him wondering if he had become a “better man”.

In her tweet on Monday, she said: “Akbaruddin Owaisi who wanted to kill Hindus if police is removed for 15 minutes, now want Rs 10 crore for the development of Mahankali temple! Is he wearing a mask? Or he has become a better man!(sic)” She also recalled Akbaruddin’s speech he had made at Nirmal in 2013.

In 2007, Nasreen was allegedly roughed by AIMIM members in Press Club when she was in the city to launch a book . Some party legislators were also part of the group which allegedly attacked her verbally and hurled bouquets at her. Nasreen has been living in exile since 1994.

Akbaruddin, in some of the public meetings he had addressed, was also critical of her. “Taslima Nasreen aayi thi, kahan gayi kisi ko pata nahi (Nasreen came here but no one has a clue as to where she has gone),” he used to say at the public rallies.

Meanwhile, after Akbaruddin urged the CM to allot Rs 10 crore towards development of Simhavahini Mahankali temple at Lal Darwaja, members of the temple committee visited AIMIM headquarters Darussalam and felicitated Yakutpura MLA Ahmed Pasha Quadri.

“We thank AIMIM and the chief minister. When we met Akbaruddin at a meeting, he told us that mosque and temple are like two eyes to him. We are going by the Ganga-Jamuna tehzeeb,” said a committee member. When questioned about BJP legislator from Goshamahal T Raja Singh, he said that they were not bothered about him. “We are members of the temple committee. Why should he (Singh) comment on the temple,” he added.

Title: Electrical shop in Mangal Bazaar gutted
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

25 fire fighters from two fire stations defuse the fire which broke out on Monday evening due to short-circuit

Vadodara: A big fire broke out in an electrical shop at crowded Mangal Bazaar on Monday evening.

However, as the market remains closed on Monday, there was no evacuation or panic.

The fire broke out around 5.30pm due to short-circuit on the ground floor of the shop which was closed. Due to presence of lights and several other electrical equipment, the fire spread across the shop quickly.

It further spread to the shop’s godown on the upper floors.

“The shop has its godown on three floors above the shop which was also engulfed. Our staff of 25 fire fighters from two fire stations controlled the fire in an hour,” said fire officer Manish Mod. He added that the fire fighters had to break shutters of the neighbouring shops to shift their goods so that the fire does not spread further.

Although the market was closed, hundreds of people gathered at the spot due to which fire fighters found it difficult to bring their vehicles in the narrow lane and conduct the operation.

A fire department source said that a couple of policemen were sent from the local police station but they could also not control the crowd.

Eventually, the fire fighters themselves had to close down the lane from Nava Bazaar and Mangal Bazaar ends.

The owner of the shop told the fire officials that the loss caused by fire ranges in lakhs of rupees.

Title: Tinderbox Hauz Khas Village: Court leaves it to agencies
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

A drill by fire department had showed that agencies couldn't even reach the inner parts of the market

NEW DELHI: Seven years since it issued a series of orders to check illegal eateries in Hauz Khas Village, Delhi high court has now left it to the agencies concerned to take action.

The court had described the area as a “ticking time bomb” after it emerged that a drill conducted by security agencies and fire preparedness by Delhi Fire Department showed agencies couldn’t even reach the inner parts of the market due to rampant illegal commercialisation.

While the petitioners insisted that court’s monitoring is needed to prevent civic agencies and police from ignoring illegal restaurants, more so since many didn’t even posess valid fire clearance, a bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and Justice C Hari Shankar put their faith in the authorities, asking these to “act as per law” and disposed of two PILs filed in 2013 and 2017, respectively.

The bench made it clear that if any pubs, restaurants or bars are running illegally in Hauz Khas Village, agencies must take action after hearing out the owners or occupiers.

One of the petitions had alleged that over 120 restaurants and pubs were running in the area without any approved building plans or no objection certificate (NOC) from the authorities including the fire department.

“We hereby direct respondent 1 to 5 (Centre, Delhi government and civic bodies) to look into the grievances ventilated in this petition and if any illegal pubs, restaurants, bars, etc. are being run in the area, action shall be initiated by respondent 1 to 5 in accordance with law, rules, regulations and government policy applicable to the facts of the present case after giving an adequate opportunity of being heard to the owner or occupier of the premises in question,” the court observed in its order last week.

In 2017, an alarmed bench of justices Gita Mittal and C Hari Shankar had described Hauz Khas Village as “a ticking time bomb”, underlining that neither government agencies, nor restaurant owners of the area responded to its queries on safety and other issues.

It had subsequently ordered sealing of 21 eateries, warning the associations of restaurants owners that they will not be allowed escape civil and criminal liability in case any unfortunate incident takes place, as there was virtually no space for emergency vehicles to enter the area.

It had also sought to know how South Delhi Municipal Corporation, Delhi Police, Delhi Fire Services and other agencies, had allowed commercialisation of the village that had led to public nuisance and health hazards.

While the first plea was filed by activist Pankaj Sharma , a second petition in 2017 by advocate Anuja Kapur also raised the same problem, alleging that the streets in the village were not wide enough for a fire tender to move easily in case of an emergency and very few restaurants had fire clearances.

Title: ‘India may be independent, but far from free’
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Chennai: “Freedom isn’t just political, or limited to raising flags and slogans. It is so much more – annihilation of caste, safety of women, growth of downtrodden. And that way, India may be independent, but far from free yet,” said poet, writer and Tibetan activist Tenzin Tsundue, as media students at Loyola College listened to him in rapt attention.

Visiting his alma mater to give a talk on ‘writing and resistance’, the activist with the red head band - which has become a symbol of his free-Tibet movement - urged the students to fight for freedom judiciously and in a non-violent way as thinkers, writers, educators and journalists. “We see incidents being captured by CCTV and sophisticated mobile phone cameras, and yet cannot ascertain what happened,” he said. “You don’t have to join a political party to fight for freedom. But in an age when the truth is neutralised, fake news is spreading and media houses caught up with breaking news are losing credibility, the role of a writer is to determine the truth through information and perspectives from many sources, and refrain from becoming judgmental,” he said.

Tsundue also delved into his own journey as an activist, poet and writer, and reminisced how as a student he often wrote poems touching upon the idea of home and brotherhood to his “rich friends with fancy houses”. He expressed how being in exile, slapped with court cases and jailed 16 times – the latest at Chennai Central Jail during Chinese premier Xi Jinping’s visit last year – pushed him to think, write and express.

“The idea of exile is this – you have to leave your home, come to a new place and be unable to settle down, physically and emotionally. Your future looks bleak and you’re trapped in the reality of today and the dream of tomorrow. But one who doesn’t belong anywhere, can live everywhere. For me, home is not a house. It is the adjustment you make in your heart,” the award-winning author said.

Highlighting the need to change the way English language and literature is taught, Tsundue said greater emphasis should be given to independent writing and thought in the curriculum. “English literature was started by the British as an experiment to make it easier for Indians to serve them. But for the last 271 years, we have been reading the same age-old Victorian literature, their comedy, politics, etc. While there’s nothing wrong with this, we have to be able to write our own language and stories too. We must find our own voice.”

Title: Mukarram Jah School voted 2nd-best BPS
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

HYDERABAD: The city’s Mukarram Jah School has been voted the second-best budget private school ( BPS ) in the country in a survey by Education World. Other schools from the state such as Vijaya Sai High School in Nizamabad and Vasavi High School in Nirmal also secured a spot in the top 10 Budget Private School Rankings 2020.

As many as 2,458 respondents, comprising 2,115 parents with children studying in BPS and 343 BPS principals and teachers took part in the survey to rate 300 BPS in 143 cities and towns in the country.

“For parents from low-income households, who often make sacrifices to enroll their children even in affordable private schools, making the right choice is even more important than in middle class and elite homes,” says Premchand Palety , founder-CEO of C fore, which conducted the survey. As per the ranking, the top budget private schools in the state are mostly Hyderabad-based schools .

Title: Swift action brings kidnapped Sehore boy home in 4 hours
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Child who was recovered by police

Bhopal: A 7-year-old boy, who was allegedly abducted by two unidentified persons, was rescued within 4 hours on Monday in Sehore district.

The incident took place at Sonkatch village. The accused duo abducted Saras Meena on their motorcycle, said police. After a while, when the kid not return, his kin started looking around for him. They learnt that the child was seen on a motorcycle with some people. The kin then rushed to the police station and lodged a complaint.

“We cordoned off the entire area and started searching for the kid. Around 7.30pm, we received information that the child was seen at Shyampur bus stand. Some of the people were seen trying to make the child board a bus,” additional SP Sehore, Sameer Yadav told TOI. “Our teams rushed there and rescued the child. He is safe and sound,” said Yadav.

“A few suspects have also been rounded up and we are carrying out detailed investigations,” he added.

Title: Ward reservation: AMC flooded with objections as deadline nears
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Aurangabad: With only one day left to receive objections on ward reservations and ward formation, the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation’s (AMC) election department has so far received bagful of objections from citizens.

The Satara and Deolai wards were added to the AMC in the year 2016 after by-polls were held for the two seats (ward numbers 114 and 115). During the by-polls, ward 114 was open, while 115 was reserved for the scheduled tribes (ST) category.

However, this time around, the area has been divided into five wards i.e. ward number 105 Atharva Classic-Sudhakar Nagar, 112 Kasliwal Bhagyoday-Vasant Vihar Deolai, 113 Gopinathpuram-Hariom Nagar, 114 Satara Ganv-Sangram Nagar and 115 Deolai Ganv Satara Tanda.

According to the ward plan declared for 2020 civic elections, ward number 105, 112, 113 and 114 are reserved for scheduled caste (SC) women, while 115 is reserved for SC. For all the other wards, the election department has decided the reservation based on the three previous general elections held in 2005, 2010 and 2015.

Residents and aspiring candidates have stated that as the area have been included in AMC general elections for the first time the reservations should have been fixed only through draw. Objections related to ward reservation and formation of Satara and Deolai have been filed with the election department.

Sena corporators convey discontent to Ghosalkar

On Monday, Shiv Sena communication head Vinod Ghosalkar held discussions with corporators and aspiring candidates from the party who registered their objections related to ward formation and ward reservation.

The corporators told Ghosalkar that ward reservation process has led to dissatisfaction among party workers. Some of the corporators said that the very existence of their wards have been removed from the new plan.

After hearing the objections, Ghosalkar said if the norms of the election commission have been side-lined in the process then these objections will be brought to the notice of the guardian minister who will then take up the issue with the chief minister. “It will be ensured that no one faces injustice due to wrongful implementation of the plan,” he said.

Title: Asaduddin Owaisi: Will die but not show documents for CAA & NRC
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Asaduddin Owaisi

HYDERABAD: AIMIM president Asaduddin Owaisi upped the ante against the Citizenship Act, saying he will choose death but will not display any documents during CAA, NRC and NPR exercise.

“You guys are threatening me. Will you shoot me? Do whatever you can, but I will stay in this country and never ever show my documents,” thundered Owaisi while addressing an anti-CAA rally in Kurnool on Monday.

Going all out against the BJP leadership, the Hyderabad MP said: “If the question arises of showing documents, we will show our chests. This is where our documents are hidden. Shoot me in my heart as my love for the nation resides in my heart, which you (rightwing members) people are yet to understand.”

During the course of his fiery speech amidst loud claps and cheers, Owaisi kept repeating to the crowds that neither he nor any Muslim would show documents to the authorities. “Our name is enough to prove our love and loyalty towards this country.” Kurnool has sizeable Muslim population.

Taking potshots at PM Modi and home minister Amit Shah, he said: “Only those who are raising their voice against Modi-Shah duo are true crusaders.”

Owaisi also said the protests across the country should not stop. “These protests should continue for the next three months. If we fail in this fight, then remember Bharat will become a Hindu rashtra,” said the AIMIM chief, who also raised the quota issue.

“I want to say to my Dalit brothers and sisters, if you love BR Ambedkar, this is the time to prove your love. This is the time to show your love towards Babasaheb. Article 14 of the Constitution says reservation should be given to SCs. But, the BJP government in Uttarakhand says in the SC that quota and promotion are not fundamental rights,” he said.

Exhorting Dalits to oppose this strongly, he said: “ Please wake up my Dalit brothers, please read paragraph 21 of the judgment which says appointments and promotions are not fundamental rights.”

Title: Manuu students condemn Jamia attacks in Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

HYDERABAD: Condemning the police attacks on the students of Jamia Millia Islamia in Delhi during their anti-Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) march to Parliament on Monday, students of Maulana Azad National Urdu University (Manuu) and intensified their stir.

Manuu students union invited Khalida Parveen and Sara Mathews , who have been at the forefront of anti-CAA protests in the city, to address the students.

Parveen not only condemned the attack in Delhi, but also criticised the crackdown by Telangana police on peaceful protests. Referring to mass detentions in Mallepally on the intervening night of Saturday and Sunday, Parveen said, “The police are violating the democratic rights of the people. They are conducting protests peacefully and not indulging in any violence.”

Parveen was one of the 50 protesters who were detained by the police in Mallepally following a flash protest against CAA-NRC-NPR.

Title: GHMC resolution against Act is juvenile, says BJP
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

HYDERABAD: Telangana BJP on Monday took a strong objection to GHMC passing a resolution against CAA and said mayor and deputy mayor have made a fool of themselves with their actions.

In a press statement here, BJP spokesperson K Krisha Saagar Rao said this exposed their intellectual and political bankruptcy. “The GHMC mayor and his deputy have made a fool of themselves along with TRS and AIMIM corporators,” he said.

He said passing a resolution against a non-existent national law by a local body was juvenile.

He said NRC is a figment of imagination of minority appeasers as there is neither a bill nor a law so far on NRC. “GHMC mayor and his deputy should explain how one can pass a resolution against a national law which is non-existent.”

Title: Cops at Barakhamba pool in for wedding of sweeper’s daughter
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

The staff handed Rani over a lakh rupees and several gifts for her daughter's wedding

NEW DELHI: Rani , a sweeper at Barakhamba police station, was worried for the past many days. Reason: Her daughter was scheduled to get married on February 14, but she did not have enough money to buy jewelleries for her and even manage the logistics for the guests. But she got a pleasant surprise this Sunday when the police station officers and staff handed her over a lakh rupees and several gifts for her daughter’s wedding .

Rani (45) is the breadwinner of her family, and her husband, who used to work with her earlier at the same police station, had passed away three years back. “I have been working at the police station for over 13 years now. After my husband’s death, our financial condition has deteriorated. My earnings mostly go in paying the house rent and the day-to-day expenses. I had asked police officers for some help, but did not expect them to do so much for my daughter’s wedding,” Rani told TOI.

The sweeper earns a meagre Rs 7,500 per month and has been employed by a private company.

“Now, there will be raunak (shine) in the celebrations. I am planning to buy my daughter a gold earring and arrange for decent logistics for the guests. I had approached several people for money, but in today’s world no one lends a helping hand. I am grateful to SHO Prahlad Singh and Delhi Police for this noble gesture,” she said.

“Since we were aware about her financial condition, we decided to pool in money for her daughter’s wedding. Some officers even bought sarees and gifts for her,” said an officer at the police station.

“Rani is a hardworking and a kind woman. This is the least we could do for her. We all will be going for the wedding,” added Singh.

Rani has five children, including three daughters. Her eldest son is married and stays separately. Sonali is the first among the three daughters to get married.

Title: 14 college students, 2 schoolboys held for attacking MTC crew
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Chennai: The city police on Monday arrested 14 college students and two schoolboys for attacking MTC buses and their crew in separate incidents.

On Monday a group of Class XII students of a private school in K K Nagar boarded MTC bus 12G to Anna Square. As some of the students were hanging out of the foot-board, the driver couldn’t close the door. When the bus reached Kamarajar Salai, driver Manoharan asked them to get inside, but the boys wouldn’t listen, a police officer later said.

“As the students continued to travel dangerously, the driver stopped the bus, got them inside and locked the doors. asked them to get inside and locked the door. The boys meanwhile, contacted some of their friends who came on two-wheelers and intercepted the bus. The students group then picked up an argument with the bus driver and conductor and bashed them up before fleeing the place,” the police officer said.

Driver Manoharan sustained injuries on his head and was taken to the Government Royapettah Hospital. Other passengers called the police. “When we reached the spot, we found the students had left on bikes after the attack. Their vehicles were seized and later we traced two boys and detained them for interrogation,” said the officer.

In the second incident, the Flower Bazaar police arrested 14 students at Chennai Central railway station for pelting an MTC bus with stones on February 4. The college students had attacked the bus 21 after an argument with the crew. A senior police official said on the day the incident took place they managed to arrest two students involved in the attack. On information from them police learned that the rest of the group were from neighbourhoods in Avadi and beyond and they came to Central by suburban trains.

A police team waited at the Moore Market Complex and took them into custody as soon as they got down from a train on Monday.

Title: BAMU to give soft-copies of degrees to students
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Aurangabad: The Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University ( BAMU ) has decided to make soft-copies of the degrees available to students on its official website.

Addressing media persons on Monday, BAMU vice-chancellor Pramod Yeole said that students can obtain the soft-copy of their degree certificates on the day of convocation itself along with physical degree certificates.

“For the first time, the convocation degrees will be available online also on the official website of the university. We hope that the digital initiative helps students in many ways,” he said.

Yeole said that students who have completed their courses by October –November 2018 session and March-April 2019 sessions will receive their degrees during the convocation.

As per the university authorities, around 59,934 students will be awarded degrees, diplomas, M.Phil and graduate certificates during Tuesday’s mega event.

University authorities said that each affiliated college has been instructed to organise the degree distribution ceremony within a period of one month of university convocation. “The colleges are expected to hold the desired event at their level before March 11. These events must be carried out in keeping with the protocol followed for the university convocation,” said authorities.

During the 60th convocation ceremony of the university, a law college building situated on the university campus will also be inaugurated by Maharashtra Governor Bhagat Singh Koshyari and Council of Scientific & Industrial Research (CSIR) director Ashwini Kumar Nangia after the convocation ceremony. The state-of-the-art building has come up at the cost of Rs seven crore.

Title: MSU’s retired professor found dead at home
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Vadodara: A retired associate professor of microbiology at MS University (MSU) passed away at his home in Sama on Sunday morning.

Johannes Manjrekar (62) was found dead when his friends went to check on him on Sunday morning. According to police, Manjrekar’s family members, who live in Mumbai, used to call him every morning. But on Sunday when the calls went unanswered, the family members called his friends to go to his home and check. On reaching his home Manjrekar’s friends found that he had passed away in sleep, police said. “We are waiting for the post-mortem report. But prima-facie it very much seems to be a natural death,” said a police officer.

Majrekar had retired in June last year but continued as a visiting researcher. He was currently investigating the role of heat shock proteins which should act as capacitor for evolution. Manjrekar taught at MSU and for two years he worked as research associate at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Manjrekar also wrote on political and social issues in social science journals and was also a haiku trainer.

Title: CAT asks for presence of PS, GAD if Meena is not given fresh posting
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Bhopal/Jabalpur: Taking strong exception to non-compliance of its order to retain Manipur-cadre IAS officer, Mohanlal Meena, and give him fresh posting, Jabalpur bench of Central Administrative Tribunal (CAT) has set a deadline to comply with the order till the next date of hearing i.e. February 20 and said if it doesn’t happen, principal secretary, GAD, Deepti Gaud Mukherjee, should be present before the tribunal that day.

Hearing Meena’s contempt petition, judicial member of tribunal, Ramesh Singh Thakur and administrative member, Naveen Tandon, gave these directions. Meena, a Manipur-cadre IAS officer was posted in MP in 2010 on deputation after intelligent reports that he faced threat to life from an extremist group of Manipur. Meena, posted as director, agriculture in 2019, was sent back to Manipur by the state government.

Meena had filed a petition with CAT contending that the ground on which he was posted to MP, still persisted and also produced an intelligence report of the central government in support of his arguments.The tribunal had allowed his petition and asked the state government to retain him in MP and give him a fresh posting. After the order was not complied with, the IAS officer moved CAT again with a contempt petition.

Title: Students from Northeast complain of racism at Kirori Mal College
Content:
Kirori Mal College (File photo)

NEW DELHI: After being harassed and called ‘ Coronavirus ’ on campus, a student of Delhi University ’s Kirori Mal College who hails from the Northeast has complained to the college authorities. The student, along with others who face harassment and racial slurs, have written a letter detailing the harassment and racial slurs they face on campus.In their letter to the KMC principal, the students of the North East Students’ Cell alleged that there have been recurring incidences of racial discrimination against them in the college. The students said that students from the Northeast are subjected to all forms of racism by “their peers as well as faulty members within the campus”.In a testimonial submitted to the principal, a student recalled how she was called “Coronavirus” in the college canteen by a group of students. The letter elaborated how the students felt uncomfortable and powerless by the use of such language and other slurs. It asked the principal to take “concrete action against the students” who used derogatory language as “these incidences are not isolated and they represent the general attitude towards those who come from a different region and look different.”Taking strong objection to these complaints, KMC principal Vibha Singh Chauhan said she had apologised to the students who faced the harassment and had called for a meeting with the convener of the Northeast cell. “We will have a proctorial meeting and conduct a sensitisation programme for our students,” Chauhan said.She added that the college would take up all efforts to improve behaviour of the students who used such objectionable language and informed that they would be identified and action would be taken against them.

Title: University for Hyderabad initiative by UoH
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

HYDERABAD: The University of Hyderabad ( UoH ) will launch its public outreach initiative “University for Hyderabad” on the 141st birth anniversary of Sarojini Naidu at Golden Threshold, the nationalist poet’s residence, in Nampally , on Thursday. Prof T Vijay Kumar , former Dean of the faculty of Arts, Osmania University , will deliver a special lecture.

As part of its Institution of Eminence mandate to convert the heritage premise into a literary and cultural hub, the university plans to leverage its city campus to host, among other things, popular lectures by its faculty members as well as by distinguished visitors to the university, poetry and book readings, music concerts, theatre and dance performances , and art exhibitions.

Title: Gargi College Delhi: Delhi cops just stood there, drunk men groped girls, Gargi College students recount horror
Content:
The girls had sordid tales to tell about the evening, and many of them submitted testimonies highlighting the ... Read More

(All names have been changed to protect identity)

NEW DELHI: February 6 was a black day in the life of Esha, a third-year political science student at Gargi College. She had walked in expecting to enjoy and dance to the tunes of singer Jubin Nautiyal, who was to perform at the annual fest “Reverie”. However, she and other students of the girls’ college were in for a rude surprise.The musical evening turned into a harrowing experience as outsiders, mainly middle-aged men, barged into the college campus by prising the gates apart and even climbing over the boundary wall, which had barbed wire, and started groping, molesting and touching the girls. Many men even rubbed against the helpless girls.The girls had sordid tales to tell about the evening, and many of them submitted testimonies highlighting the horror they went through. The night turned even more traumatic for Esha as her friend, who has asthma, collapsed on the ground making it difficult for them to escape the sexual harassment.Esha said, “Around 3.30pm, a huge crowd had gathered outside the two gates, one for girl students and other for men. By the time we entered, the ground was packed with drunk men, who were passing lewd comments at the girls. My friend, who was suffering from asthma, collapsed after feeling claustrophobic and we had to call her father to come to our aid.”While college students were allowed to attend the fest by showing their identity card, each of them were also issued a pass to bring along an outsider. The 3,000 students, coupled with their passes, would have accounted for 6,000 people on the ground, but the girls said that there was a 10,000-strong crowd there.“The entry was supposed to close at 4.30pm, but people kept entering even two hours later. Though a stampede nearly occurred, police just stood there and did nothing. Security had been breached, but no action followed,” said Sayema, a third-year political science student.Another student narrated how a man ran towards her and dashed into her purposely. He then went on to grope her and left. One girl decided to confront a few men, but regretted her decision. “I was so angry that I went toward a group of men. I realised they were all drunk. I feel ashamed to narrate what they told me. I got scared and ran away,” she added.A second-year student started panicking when, taking advantage of the crowd, a man started groping her. “It became impossible for me move to a safe place as there was no space,” she said. It took her nearly 40 minutes to go from the ground to the gate, which usually takes five minutes.Describing how the security ring was broken, a student said, “A car came and the guards opened the gate to let it in. The crowd, which had swelled to a considerable number due to the slow checking process, then barged in. Some men even jumped over the wall despite the barbed wire on top of it.”Many students also complained that they couldn’t dial 100 as there was no mobile network coverage. Priya, a second-year student, said, “It seems the men had just come to harass girls. They also threw eggs at us.”In Video: Students complain of 'Mass molestation' at Gargi college fest, Delhi Police and Principal face heat

Title: Mob attacks RFO office, flee with poaching accused
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

CHANDRAPUR: In an unprecedented incident, a group of people, mostly women , raided Bhadrawati range forest office and whisked away an accused , nabbed on charges of poaching wild animals, from the forest custody.

Both forest and police departments have registered offences in this connection and have launched manhunt to nab the culprits.

Two pairs of leopards and bears were poached by using electrified wire in the forest under Ordnance Factory Chanda, and carcasses were recovered on February 1. Forest department had zeroed in on Piparbodi village under OF area and had arrested an accused Ravi Chetti on February 5.

Based on further investigations, Bhadrawati RFO, Swati Maheshkar, had raided the village again on Saturday evening and arrested other accused Vinod Chetti (19). As she brought the accused to RFO office in Bhadrawati, a mob of villagers belonging to same community and having same surname followed the accused to her office.

“The mob, mostly comprising women, came after us to RFO office. Even as we closed the main gate, they jumped over it. Some of the women twisted my hand with which I was holding the accused and whisked him away before our staff could respond,” said Maheshkar while talking to TOI.

Maheshkar claimed the behaviour of the assailant women, all kin of accused, took the range office staffers by surprise. The women were using abusive language and tearing their own clothes . Startled male staffers were helpless, she told.

Maheshkar called police, but the mob fled with the accused before the help could arrive. She informed that forest and police departments have registered offences in this connection and have launched manhunt to nab the accused and assailants.

PSO, Bhadrawati, Sunil Pawar, said the police have booked four people identified by Maheshkar. He informed that police team had raided the village to look for the absconding accused and the assailants, but entire block of around 10 to 15 families of the Chetti community is missing from the village. Police have issued lookout notice for the absconding accused.

Title: Murder convict ends life at Harsul jail
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Aurangabad: A 37-year old murder convict from Jalna hanged himself from the toilet window at Harsul Central Jail here during the wee hours of Sunday.

The deceased Saluji Yadav Magare, who was from Thakurwadi village in Ambad taluka of Jalna district, was serving a 10-year imprisonment after his conviction in a murder case.

Police sub-inspector Pandurang Bhagile from Harsul police station said the convict used a portion of a bedsheet to tied a knot and handed himself.

“Like other jail inmates, Magare was given a bedsheet by the jail authorities. These clothes are prepared by undertrails and prisoners as a part of rehabilitation programme and possess good tensile strength. Magare tore a portion of the rough cloth and used it for hanging,” he said.

Citing jail authorities, police said the convict committed suicide during the wee hours. “He went inside the toilet meant for barrack number 14 and hanged self by the window at around 3.45am. The incident came to light at around 4.38am. Magare had breathed his last by then,” the police said.

Magare had served as an under-trial for three years till 2018. His jail term would have ended by 2025, police said.

The police have registered a case of accidental death in connection with the suicide and will carry out an inquest panchnama and in-camera post-mortem on the dead body as per rules.

A section of social groups has sharply reacted to the suicide inside Harsul Central Jail. “Besides routine investigation into the death, we want a special inquiry into the lapses at the jail security. The safety and security of prisoners is the responsibility of jail authorities. The latest incident has raised serious questions over the arrangement at the Harsul central jail,” said Sandip Mankar, a social activist.

Title: Yavatmal doctor’s suspension for not taking minister’s call revoked
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

YAVATMAL: The suspension of junior resident doctor at Shri Vasantrao Naik Government Medical College, Yavatmal , was revoked on Monday.

The doctor Dr Achyut Narote was suspended for eight days on February 4 apparently on the orders of district guardian minister Sanjay Rathod for allegedly showing disrespect to the people’s representative by refusing to take the minister’s call.

According to officiating dean Dr Milind Kamble , the suspension has been revoked with retrospective effect. The show cause memos served on three nurses (two male and one woman) have also been withdrawn, said Dr Kamble.

On February 3, an elderly man, claiming to be an acquaintance of state forest minister Sanjay Rathod, had brought in his son to the casualty ward and wanted doctor on duty to examine the patient immediately. When Dr Narote asked the man to wait as he was busy attending other patients, the man had called a ‘bhau’ to complain.

After a brief conversation with ‘bhau’, the man had asked the doctor to talk to the person at the other end. Not knowing that the ‘bhau’ on phone was minister Rathod, the doctor had refused to attend the call saying ask the ‘bhau’ to come to the hospital.

Rathod, who apparently overheard the conversation, contacted Dr Kamble demanding action against the junior doctor. Dr Kamble had suspended the doctor for eight days on February 4. Show cause memos were also served on two male nurses and a woman nurse who were on duty when the incident took place.

Later, a delegation of Maharashtra Association of Resident Doctors (MARD) had met the dean and demanded revocation of the suspension failing which its members would resort an agitation.

The dean had set up a three member committee to probe the incident. After the inquiry panel exonerated the junior doctor, the suspension was revoked.

Title: Magh Mela snan for kalpwasis who stayed back
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

home-bound: Devotees return home after the Maghi Purnima snan on the Magh Mela ground in Allahabad on Monday

Allahabad: Apart from the five snans that draw devotees from all across the world to the Magh Mela, there is one more few know about — the Trijata snan. As per tradition, kalpwasis who stay back on the Magh Mela ground even after the end of their month-long penance take a dip in Sangam during the Trijata snan. The snan will be observed on Tuesday.

City-based religious scholar Ashutosh Varshney said, “Most kalpwasis leave for home after after taking a dip in Ganga during the Maghi Purnima snan. As the Hindu month of Magh culminates after Maghi Purnima, some kalpwasis wait for the right muhurat (auspicious period) for returning after a special snan called the Trijata snan.”

Varshney said that Trijata was a demoness in Ramayan, who was assigned the duty of guarding Sita in Ashok Vatika after Ravana abducted her.

He also said that Ram and Sita had given Trijata a vardan (boon) before returning to Ayodhya. “According to Hindu mythology, Ram and Sita said that any one who takes three dips in Ganga after Magh ends in the name of Trijata will gain punya equivalent to a month of kalpwas,” Varshney said.

“It is also believed that kalpwasis can atone for all mistakes and sins committed during their stay by taking a dip in Ganga during Trijata snan.” he added.

Meanwhile, hundreds of devotees continued to leave the Magh Mela ground after taking holy dips in Sangam on Monday. The deployment of police forces on the venue helped in managing the crowd. Traffic police also enforced diversions to regulate traffic.

Title: JNU News: Police have put JNU probe in cold storage, allege teachers
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

JNU teachers claimed that the police ‘inaction’ reinforced suspicions about the reasons behind the failure of... Read More

NEW DELHI: The members of Jawaharlal Nehru University Teachers’ Association ( JNU ) assembled in front of the Delhi Police headquarters on Monday protesting against the inaction regarding the violence by masked miscreants on the campus on January 5.

“This inaction serves to only reinforce suspicions about the reasons behind the failure of police on that fateful day to prevent the mob violence or apprehend any of the culprits,” they stated in a memorandum addressed to police commissioner Amulya Patnaik.

During its January 10 press conference on the progress of the investigation, Delhi Police emphasised almost exclusively on previous incidents while remaining silent about the mob violence, they alleged. “No further progress has been reported,” the memorandum added. According to JNUTA, none of the 60-odd complaints filed on the mob violence, including those submitted by teachers, has been converted into an FIR. “All the evidence, therefore, indicates that the Special Investigation Team has put the investigation in cold storage,” JNUTA alleged, adding that, “it appears to be a part of a larger pattern where police are more proactive in restraining the exercise of democratic rights in the name of maintaining law and order than it is in protecting these rights”.

A delegation met special CP (intelligence) Praveer Ranjan. A spokesperson said they had briefed the delegation about the status of the probe. “Special CP (intelligence) Ranjan has also assured them of all cooperation ,” he added.

Several students and teachers were injured in the attack, during which hostel properties were also damaged.

Title: ‘3 vehicles were stolen in Allahabad every day in Jan’
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Allahabad: Auto-lifters made off with three vehicles every day in the city in January in Allahabad district, says police data released on Monday.

According to the data, 115 cases of auto thefts were reported between January 1 and January 31, 2020 in Allahabad district — the highest among the eight districts comprising Allahabad zone.

The eight districts comprising Allahabad zone are Allahabad, Pratapgarh, Kaushambi, Fatehpur, Banda, Hamirpur, Mahoba and Chitrakoot. Hamirpur was at the bottom of the list with zero auto-thefts during the period, followed by Banda (2) and Chitrakoot (2).

Allahabad was followed by Pratapgarh (30), Kaushambi (15), and Fatehpur (seven).

In 2019, Allahabad recorded over 1,500 cases of auto-theft, which included 1,345 stolen motorcycles.

Crime branch officials said that 18 auto-lifting gangs were busted last year and most of the accused were in their 20s and 30s. The arrests indicate how more and more youth are foraying into this crime, said police.

Police said most youths resort to stealing cars and motorcycles in order to earn quick money and to lead a lavish lifestyle. In 2019, police arrested over 150 men for auto-lifting and most of them did not have a criminal background.

During the period, police also recovered more than 300 stolen vehicles. Police said that auto-lifters see localities in trans-Ganga and trans-Yamuna areas of the city as safe hideouts for their loot.

IG (Allahabad range) KP Singh said, “Police units have been directed to work on an effective strategy to tighten the noose around auto-lifting gangs.”

In 2019, police had identified at least 32 spots in the city prone to auto-lifting.

Title: Med college to have SPECT scanner
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

less radiation

Thiruvananthapuram: The health department is set to introduce SPECT (single-photon emission computerized tomography) scan at Thiruvananthapuram Medical College for the first time.

SPECT scanner (help in analysing internal organs) will be installed in the department of nuclear medicine as part of upgrading the medical college into a centre of excellence, health minister said. SPECT scan will enable scanning using lesser amount of radiation when compared to X-ray or CT scan, the minister said. SPECT scan is rarely used in hospitals in the state. The state budget has allotted Rs 8 crore for the project, the minister said.

According to hopkinsmedicine.org, nuclear medicine is a specialized area of radiology that uses small amounts of radioactive materials, or radiopharmaceuticals, to examine organ function and structure. Nuclear medicine imaging is a combination of many different disciplines. These include chemistry, physics, mathematics, computer technology, and medicine. This branch of radiology is often used to help diagnose and treat abnormalities early in the progression of a disease, such as thyroid cancer, the website notes.

Digirad website defines SPECT as a type of non-invasive nuclear imaging test that allows doctor to see how well the internal organs are functioning. It uses a radioactive substance and a special gamma camera to create 3-D pictures of the organs at different angles.

The technology not only offers better sensitivity and high energy resolution, but also makes the camera smaller in size than a traditional MRI machine. And, with their open and upright design, they’re much more ergonomic and patient-friendly. While an X-ray takes a picture of what the organs look like at a given point in time, a SPECT image shows blood flowing to and from the heart or blood flow restrictions due to narrow or blocked arteries. It can also be used to evaluate brain and neurological conditions and bone disorders.

It can also help diagnose disease processes that may be underway, including narrowing of the arteries, clogged arteries, identifying scar tissue due to heart attacks, or evaluating the success of surgeries like bypass surgery, according to Digirad.

Title: Devendra Fadnavis gets last chance to appear before court on 20th
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

NAGPUR: Leader of Opposition Devendra Fadnavis continues to give the judiciary the slip. On Monday, he cited an important meeting in Mantralaya to skip his case hearing for the fourth time.

While granting a last chance to the former chief minister, the court of chief judicial magistrate (CJM) PS Ingle directed him to appear on February 20. He sought an exemption from appearing before the court in a case filed by lawyer Satish Uke, contending that the Southwest MLA had allegedly suppressed information about two pending criminal cases while filing his affidavit for the 2014 assembly polls.

Earlier, Fadnavis’ lawyer Uday Dable filed an application stating that an important meeting of the assembly’s advisory committee was convened at Mantralaya at 3pm to discuss the business transaction for the upcoming budget session and hence, it was not possible for his client to appear before the honourable court.

The Mantralaya meeting was attended by CM Uddhav Thackeray , deputy CM Ajit Pawar , cabinet ministers and Fadnavis, who was there as Leader of Opposition.

Fadnavis’ application was strongly opposed by Uke’s counsel Sudeep Jaiswal .

Uke also filed an application for criminal contempt of court against Fadnavis, who was made the accused in the case.

Uke accused the ex-CM of deliberate fraud which interfered in the delivery of justice. Dable then sought time to reply to the contempt application.

While allowing Fadnavis’ application for adjournment, the CJM granted him a last chance to appear before the court on February 20.

Earlier, Fadnavis skipped the hearings on December 4, January 4 and February 10 citing “official” reasons.

On October 1, 2019, the Supreme Court ruled against Fadnavis, clarifying that a candidate must disclose all criminal cases at the time of contesting the election. The SC then sent the case to the JMFC court for retrial. The trial court of judge SB Mehta issued summons to the ex-CM as an accused and asked him to remain present on December 4 for seeking bail.

Title: Over 76L kids below 5 don’t have Aadhaar
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Aurangabad: More than 76 lakh children , between the ages of zero and 5 years, are still not enrolled for Aadhhar in Maharashtra , which has reflected in terms of the poor 21st rank for the state at the national level among 37 states and Union Territories in terms of Aadhaar saturation.

As per the latest official data of the Unique Identification Authority of India (UIDAI), out of a total population of 0-5years children (1,01,57,823), only 24,02,011 have been assigned the key 12-digit Aadhaar number.

While Maharashtra has relatively less Aadhaar penetration among this population, the state has also found itself at a poor 24th place when it comes to the desired enrollment for the 5-18 years age group. In this case, of the total target population of 2,95,26,954, only 2,34,17,030 had enrolled with Aadhaar till January 20. This accounts for 79.3% Aadhaar saturation in the 5-18 years age group.

At the national level, Haryana and Delhi top in Aadhaar enrolment for children below five years and up to the age of 18 years, respectively.

In January 2017, Osmanabad district in Marathwada had achieved state-level distinction by becoming the first district in Maharashtra to offer Aadhaar card at the birth of a child. While Madhya Pradesh had witnessed the first issuance of Aadhaar card to an infant in May 2016, Osmanabad administration replicated the practice on a large scale.

An official e-mail sent to Rupinder Singh, the deputy director-general of UIDAI’s regional office in Mumbai, and three assistant directors, seeking reasons for the relatively poor Aadhaar enrolment in the state remained unanswered till Monday night.

A senior IAS official, preferring anonymity, said lack of awareness among parents was one of the reasons. “Rural areas have Anganwadis at many places and special instructions have been given to the staff to carry out Aadhaar enrolment of children. In urban areas, the enrollment is initiated by parents for scholarship or other purposes. It is a fact that some of the larger states such as Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh have lesser Aadhaar saturation when compared to other states,” he said.

Social activist Vishnu Dhobale said the state government must facilitate Aadhaar enrollment at birth at all major hospitals. “Aadhaar enrolment must be made available at state-run hospitals as well as private hospitals. Such a measure would benefit parents as well as the state agencies,” he said.

Title: National Commission for Women team visits Gargi College
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Gargi College (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Expressing shock at the Gargi College incident where girls were allegedly molested by outsiders who gatecrashed into the premises when a cultural festival was on, National Commission for Women chairperson Rekha Sharma has sought strict police action.

Sharma, who sent the NCW team to the college on Monday, also raised concern over the security lapses on the part of the college that enabled the men to enter the college.

Speaking to TOI, the NCW chief said that the commission’s team visited the college and has spoken to the girls. “Our team spoke to the girls and police. We want police to take strict action as it is shocking how outsiders were able to enter the college. This kind of mentality where men barge into premises and pounce on girls cannot be tolerated,” she said.

Title: Cops to rope in IT experts as ‘Cyber Prahari’
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

NAGPUR: City police have started a scheme to rope in IT expert watchdogs as ‘ Cyber Prahari’ to help the law enforcers in solving cases.

The sleuths of the cyber cell would also have a special social media group of volunteers. The decision to form the group of volunteers was taken after a one-day session ‘Cyber crime prevention and measures’ organized held on Saturday on the instructions of city police chief BK Upadhyay . The discussion was chaired under additional CP , crime, Nilesh Bharne. Cyber cell officers, APIs Vishal Mane and Ashwini Jagtap and others also participated in the discussions.

Those keen to join the group of cyber watchdogs can call on mobile number 7875478780.

Title: ‘22 trees felled at Lodhi Gardens’
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

An NGO has written to the Delhi forest department, asking for action against NDMC for cutting 'healthy' and fu... Read More

NEW DELHI: A Delhi-based environmental NGO has accused New Delhi Municipal Council ( NDMC ) of chopping at least 22 fully grown Ashoka trees at Lodhi Gardens—well beyond the “permissible” pruning limit under Delhi Preservation of Trees Act, 1994. In a letter sent to the Delhi forest and wildlife department, New Delhi Nature Society (NDNS) has said that 22 “healthy” Ashoka trees have been felled at Lodhi Garden.

“On Sunday, I found that 22 healthy Ashoka trees had been felled (head-backed) in Lodhi Gardens by NDMC. All the tree canopies were completely removed. These trees were not even a threat to anybody’s life or property,” said Verhaen Khanna , founder of NDNS.

The NGO has also attached photographs in the letter, asking the forest department to act immediately. “You are requested to follow procedure under Section 8 of Delhi Preservation of Trees Act, 1994,” Khanna added.

When contacted, the forest department said they have already formed a team of officials to inspect the trees and determine the extent of the damage caused. “The team will first assess if they were fully grown trees or not. They will also determine how much damage is caused and whether it is beyond the permissible limits. Later, we will check if permission was sought for the same,” said Ishwar Singh , principal chief conservator of forests .

“A report will be prepared and if anyone is found to be guilty, we will initiate immediate action in the matter,” added Singh.

A senior NDMC official, however, denied the allegations and said no trees had been cut or chopped. They have only been pruned to improve their shape, he added.

“These are not trees, but topiary planted in different sizes and shapes to give an aesthetic look to the garden. We don’t need permission from the forest department to prune them as per requirement, unlike full-fledged trees grown in forest, roadsides or even park areas. Another reason for pruning these 15 plants was to allow sufficient sunlight in nearby butterfly garden. With sufficient sunlight, citrus plants can attract butterflies. We are doing everything in a planned manner,” the official said.

Title: Zoo authorities face flak for addition of female spotted deer
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Aurangabad: Even if the state zoo authority has clearly taken a stand against introducing any new creature in the city zoo, the latter has decided to get in four spotted deer from Mumbai zoo in exchange of two tigers.

Notably, the Zoo Authority of Maharashtra (ZAM) had asked for the ban owing to inadequate space at the local zoo along with other glaring non-compliances, which had led to temporary de-recognition of the zoo by the Central Zoo Authority of India (CZAI).

When contacted, zoo director B S Naikwade on Monday said that addition of four spotted deer can be viewed as a totaling exercise and would not increase the count of total creatures in the zoo significantly.

“Two creatures are getting deducted from the local population of animals at our zoo due to relocation of tigers. Mumbai-based zoo is expected to hand over two male and two female spotted deer after receiving the pair of tigers from Aurangabad. The zoo has only one herd of female spotted deer and male partners were needed for mating,” he said.

While unavailability of mating partners for some of the creatures housed in the zoo was one of the non-compliances observed by the CZAI and it is getting addressed, animal lovers have questioned the rationale behind increasing the female population.

“The zoo authorities must make public the rationale behind increasing the count of female spotted deer at the city zoo. The enclosure for spotted deer is also small and unnecessary crowding must be avoided till the zoo gets moved to the new place,” animal lover Nilesh Dharashivkar said.

A two-member team from the ZAM, comprising senior forest department officials, had inspected the local zoo on December 5, 2017. The visit was planned in the wake of suo-motu PIL initiated by Aurangabad bench of Bombay High Court for relocation of two elephants in response to TOI report highlighting the sorry state of affairs at the city zoo.

Following the visit, top officials concerned had clearly decided against any addition at the local zoo. The visiting members also maintained that the movement of Sambar deer could be only allowed only for changing the bloodline.

Animal lovers and activists, meanwhile, have expressed anger over the procedural delays taking place in the relocation of the existing zoo to Mitmita.

Title: MSU’s retired professor found dead at home
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020
