Vadodara: A retired associate professor of microbiology at MS University (MSU) passed away at his home in Sama on Sunday morning.

Johannes Manjrekar (62) was found dead when his friends went to check on him on Sunday morning. According to police, Manjrekar’s family members, who live in Mumbai, used to call him every morning. But on Sunday when the calls went unanswered, the family members called his friends to go to his home and check. On reaching his home Manjrekar’s friends found that he had passed away in sleep, police said. “We are waiting for the post-mortem report. But prima-facie it very much seems to be a natural death,” said a police officer.

Majrekar had retired in June last year but continued as a visiting researcher. He was currently investigating the role of heat shock proteins which should act as capacitor for evolution. Manjrekar taught at MSU and for two years he worked as research associate at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Manjrekar also wrote on political and social issues in social science journals and was also a haiku trainer.

Title: Handiwork of TN women set to go online
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Marketing for S Anandhi, a Sirumugai silk sari weaver, and her 12-member self-help group ( SHG ), has meant selling her work to middlemen — either the wholesaler who also supplies her raw material or the handloom owner for whom she would work for daily wages. That the weave made headlines only a couple of months ago being Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s gift to Chinese President Xi Jinping, did nothing for her profits. But now a memorandum of understanding (MoU) between the Centre and e-commerce company Flipkart to sell products opens up the market for rural women like Anandhi.

The collaboration will be instrumental in turning small-time artisans into entrepreneurs by expanding their customer base, and helping them with the skills of digital marketing, financial management and branding. Under the Deendayal Antyodaya Yojana-National Urban Livelihoods Mission (DAY-NULM) by the union ministry of housing and urban affairs, the Tamil Nadu government has decided to begin the online initiative with a few SHGs in the western districts of Coimbatore, Nilgiris, Erode and Tirupur.

"We have planned to identify around 25 products produced by SHGs in each district as of now. The products of the SHGs could be found in the Flipkart website within a couple of months," said a senior government official. The training programme for the members of SHG groups began in Coimbatore on Monday where makers were introduced to the idea of online trade. Sirumugai silk saris, traditional Toda embroidered shawls, jute bags, products made of upcycled paper and herbal products, are among the selected items which will be put up for sale under the Tamil Nadu Urban Livelihood Mission (TNULM).

For most rural women making a living out of handicrafts, mounting debts are a constant battle. Till a few years ago, Anandhi got just Rs200 for every sari she wove. After becoming part of SHG, though bank loans made it easier, sale of products was still an issue. "Competing with cheaper powerloom versions, our handloom saris priced from Rs5,500 onwards did not have many takers in the local market. So our sale would be limited and we could make only Rs500 to Rs1,200 per piece," said Anandhi, who hopes the online initiative will help her reap a good profit for the soft and lustrous Sirumugai silks.

Eliminating hurdles in conventional sales and marketing, the move is expected to widen the market for the SHGs, said the official. "The wider market would increase the product demand and so higher income," he said.

Partnering with local artisans, weavers and crafts producers, Flipkart under its ‘Samarth’ initiative has been working to provide underserved, domestic communities and businesses an access to the national market. "The initiative would enable sellers to overcome geographical and socio-economic constraints by leveraging the Flipkart platform to reach more than 200 million customers across India," said a Flipkart spokesperson over e-mail. Last month the e-commerce firm tied up with the Gujarat State Handloom and Handicrafts Development Corporation to take the work of craftsmen online. Flipkart representatives will also set a standard of quality and help artisans fix a price for the products after doing a market analysis. For instance, a group from Nilgiris is producing cups, baskets and bowls made of waste paper. Even though the products are sold for Rs500 in the market, the members are selling them for Rs200 to the middlemen.

Excited about the shift, K Udhayaselvi, 53, of Pasumai SHG, said, her group members have decided to double the number of kurtis they stitch, once their products go online. But she also hopes to get assistance for designs based on the market trend. "Without much exposure, we are unaware of market trends and tastes," she said. Expressing similar concern, V Jayalakshmi of Poonthalir SHG, said, "I may have to ensure better quality of products. But, I would definitely need support from the government," she said.

Much ahead of the government push, some like Avila Juliet, an SHG member, had already begun selling online. "It did not just introduce SHG members to a different customer base but also increased sales and motivated us to innovate the products." Avila, who has been making products out of coconut shells now exports to customers in Japan, Saudi Arabia and the US.

To keep up with the competition online products need a USP, said D Swamikannan , professor and head of department of environmental economics, Madurai Kamaraj University. "As the SHGs have been limited to local markets and concentrate on making just enough to meet their daily expenses, the best bet would be to focus on indigenous handmade products that not easily available to catch people’s attention," he said.

Title: Let’s honour true heroes from Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

From top business executives who lead the world’s biggest companies to champion sportspersons to prime ministers and world-class cuisine, the city of Hyderabad has given a lot to the country and the world.

But there are some Good Samaritans from Hyderabad who believe in giving back to the city that has nurtured and nourished them. They help out the needy without expecting anything in return.

We at The Times of India have decided to honour these do-gooders with a special initiative called ‘Times Hyderabad Heroes ’.

Launched in association with Freedom Healthy Cooking Oil, the initiative seeks to highlight the work of people who have taken it upon themselves to give back to society without expecting anything in return.

The initiative starts from Tuesday. Hyderabadis can nominate people from the city who work for a good cause, whether big or small, by logging on to www.hyderabadheroes.in. Nominations are welcome from any field, whether it is health, education, feeding the hungry or looking after stray animals. You can also log on and vote for the people you think deserve this honour. Your vote will play a big role in choosing our Heroes.

TOI has already profiled some of these heroes over the past few months. Like Samuel Karunakar and his wife Priyanka who have a food truck that feeds nearly 1,500 needy people at hospitals every Saturday. Or Urvashi Kundra who left her six-figure IT job in 2017 to help women deal with menstrual health.

A jury of prominent citizens from the city would assess the nominees and come up with a final list. Following this, the Good Samaritans would be profiled in the newspaper.

Title: Over 1,500 cyclists participate in two-day Nashik Peloton
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Nashik: Over 1 ,500 cyclists took part in Nashik Peloton, the two-day cycling event, organised by the Nashik Cyclists Foundation (NCF) in two categories — competitive and a non-competitive — over the weekend.

The 80-km and 50-km races were held in the competitive category on Saturday, while 5-km and 10-km events were held in the non-competitive category on Sunday.

The 80-km race was held in two categories — outside and local. In the outside category, Manik Nikam and Sachin Marathe of Nashik emerged victorious, while Nitin Dahake and Hiraman Ahire bagged second position. Sujit Pawar and Ajit Kulkarni claimed the third prize.

In the local category, Samir Marathe and Manik Nikam clocked the best time while Dinkar Patil and Mahendra Mahajan emerged second.

NCF president Ratnakar Aher said, “The objective of the association is to promote use of bicycles and make the Nashik the cycle capital of the country.”

Title: Higher education minister announces to open 210 libraries across Srinagar town
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Dehradun: State’s higher education minister Dhan Singh Rawat on Monday announced to make one public library in each block of his constituency in Srinagar town of Pauri Garhwal district. The minister said this would be a pilot project and after analysing the response, each block of the state would have a library.

Talking to TOI, Dhan Singh Rawat said due to lack of proper public libraries, the students in hills have been deprived of basic reading materials like newspapers and magazines that are informative and beneficial in terms of getting information on jobs and careers.

“We are planning to start public libraries in all blocks of my constituency, which are almost 210 in number. The libraries will have basic books and regular subscription of newspapers and journals that are helpful for both students and common people,” said the minister.

Commenting on a student poll that would be carried out by the state government to seek votes on banning of mobile phones inside the classrooms, the minister said, “The poll schedule will be released on February 15, and all the colleges and educational institutions will be asked to make their students vote on the issue.”

Title: HC for CBI probe in B’shahr land scam
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Allahabad: The Allahabad high court on Monday directed the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) to conduct an enquiry in the matter of misappropriation of public fund in Bulandshahr land acquisition scam .

In February 1991, a notification was issued for acquisition of about 969 acre land by UPSIDC for industrial development. The Special Land Development Officer had determined Rs 2,87,14,996 as compensation. On reference court increased the amount to Rs 7,13,37,504.

However, certain farmers did not hand over their possession. Subsequently, UPSIDC entered into an agreement with Tehri Hydro Development Corporation in 2013 to transfer land and in this process authorities increased compensation to Rs 3,87,17,71,833 — enhancement of Rs 380 crores under ex gratia compensation though farmers had already been paid.

Directing the CBI to investigate the matter, a division bench comprising Justice Sudhir Agarwal and Justice Saurabh Shyam Shamshery observed, “In the present case, all the facts are glaring. The top officials on their own had decided to pay ex gratia compensation, which was known to them to be illegal. In this case, state police would not be able to investigate fairly and we are of the considered view that in order to unearth truth, present matter should be referred to CBI for investigation”.

The court was hearing the writ petitions filed by farmer Kamal Singh and others. The court directed the CBI to conduct a preliminary enquiry and register an FIR to unearth the scam and also submit the status report of investigation to this court in sealed cover after three months. The court fixed May 11, 2020 as the next date for hearing.

Title: Youth held for making obscene video of girl
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Kanpur: Police arrested a youth, who allegedly filmed an obscene video of a minor girl and blackmailed her.

According to police, the girl, hailing from Naubasta police area, was allegedly befriended by her college mate, Anurag Mishra.

“One day, Mishra, after sedating the girl, filmed her obscene video and started blackmailing her, and asked her to get physical with him else he would make the video viral on the Internet,” the police sources said.

On the basis of an FIR lodged by the girl’s parents, the police arrested the youth on Sunday.

“He has been charged under sections 376 (rape), 328 (causing hurt by means of poison) and 384 (Punishment for extortion) of IPC besides section 3/4 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Posco) Act and sent to jail,” said inspector Naubasta Ashish Shukla.

Title: Securing duplicate school marksheets a herculean task
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Madurai: Obtaining one’s lost school education certificates, especially the SSLC and higher secondary mark sheets, have become a herculean task in the state. Neither the local education department officials nor the online website is apparently of much help.

Recently, Karthik (name changed), who had completed his higher secondary examination nearly a decade ago, found that he had lost his file and bag containing all the originals of his school education certificates. Panicking, he rushed to the chief education officer’s office in Madurai. “From what I know, you have to pay a challan for a specified amount at the treasury, attach a missing certificate and send it to the department, but you may get a better idea from the people selling forms for certificates outside the district collectorate,” said one of the staff there.

Those selling forms for certificates outside the district collectorate are not recognised persons. Kavitha (name changed), who was also trying to get a duplicate SSLC mark sheet, said that a man outside the collectorate offered to give her a printed application form and also helped in filling it for Rs 200. “However, he said he would only help fill the form and did not give me much information about the whole process so it is difficult to know who to go to,” she said.

After finding the information he got from the CEO’s office confusing, Karthik rushed to another officer of higher ranking. “Oh everything is online and you will not have to do anything manually, so just go on the school education site,” he said. The desperate candidate found that only the application form for a duplicate certificate was available online, and it had to be downloaded and filled up to start the process.

The application form says, you should pay Rs 505, at the treasury, get a missing certificate duly signed by a gazetted officer, an affidavit signed by a notary public and a missing notice published in a newspaper to be duly submitted with the application. But all this have to be submitted only after getting a copy of the FIR from the police, in the limits of which the documents were lost. “This is the easiest part of the entire process, thanks to the e-seva website of the Tamil Nadu police, where you can get a lost document report by logging into the site and a payment of Rs 50 for each document lost,” he said.

Next is to get the affidavit signed by the notary. The affidavit needs to be printed on a Rs 20-stamp paper, and the numerous shops near the collectorate type the affidavit and get it signed from a notary public for a payment of Rs 500, if you go in person and have authentication to prove your claim. A Notary public will sign the certificate only if the Lost Document Report from the police is furnished.

Armed with these two certificates, you have to go to a local newspaper for publishing the notice for a payment that may range between Rs 1,500 to Rs 2,500. When it appears in the newspaper, you have to approach the government treasury.

The person at the treasury would not be very helpful if you do not produce the last part of the application form downloaded from the website, which has details of the challan and fees to be paid. He will only put his seal and signature on the challan, but the money has to be deposited in the specified branch of the State Bank of India. Here the bank officer will give you the receipt and challan number, which have to be kept carefully to file with the application.

Further, you need the signature of a gazetted officer or Tahsildar vouching for the missing mark sheets on a certificate that you can obtain from agents outside the collectorate premises. “Going to the Tahsildar’s office to get the signature was difficult and time consuming. Already we had to keep running from one office to the other during the process,” said Rajesh (name changed), who recently applied for a duplicate higher secondary mark sheet. Finally, the application form downloaded from the directorate of government examinations has to be filled up carefully and taken to the school where the candidate studied, where the principal or headmaster would authorise it at their convenience.

Though the application form says the school would forward the application to the department of examinations, it is often the candidate who is forced to do it, said the applicants. Then, he/she has to keep their fingers crossed and wait for the certificate for a period of at least two months. Both schools and education department officials said that they get only few applications every year. “We hardly get even 10 applications in a year sometimes. So, that is also again a reason why many are not aware of the processes, which keep changing as well. Many don’t even bother applying unless they desperately need it for a job or such,” said the principal of a private school.

Title: Telangana has 3rd most cases of mental disorders among states: Report
Content:
Photo for representative purpose only

HYDERABAD : Telangana has the third-highest incidence of depressive disorders after Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh , a new study published in The Lancet Public Health journal has estimated after analysing cases over 27 years. Each of the three states also reported over 3,760 people with depressive disorders per 10,000 population.As per the report titled, ‘The burden of mental disorders across the states of India: The Global Burden of Disease Study 1990–2017’, India had about 197·3 million people suffering from mental disorders. While Telangana also has the third-highest incidence of anxiety disorders among 45·7 million people with depressive disorders and 44·9 million with anxiety disorders in the country.“The higher prevalence of depressive and anxiety disorders in southern states could be related to higher levels of modernisation and urbanisation apart from other factors that are not yet well understood,” said the study funded by Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation , Indian Council of Medical Research, department of health research and the Union ministry of health and family welfare.The report revealed that in 2017, one among every seven people in India had a mental disorder, ranging from mild to severe. The prevalence of mental disorders that manifest predominantly during adulthood was generally higher in the more developed southern states than in the less developed northern states.Whereas the prevalence of mental disorders with onset predominantly in childhood and adolescence was generally higher in the less developed northern states, the study pointed out.Also the number of years lost to disability known as Crude DALY (disability-adjusted life-year) was found to be high in the south.“The crude DALY rate of depressive disorders varied 2.1 times between the states in 2017 and was highest in Tamil Nadu of high Socio-Demographic Index (SDI) state group, followed by Telangana and Andhra Pradesh of the middle SDI state group, and Odisha of the low SDI state group.“It is also important to note that the high prevalence of depression among older adults has substantial implications because the population in India is ageing rapidly,” the report stated.Eating disorders were the only mental disorders in Global Burden of Disease (GBD) 2017 to which deaths could be attributed directly. “A significantly higher prevalence of eating disorders in females than in males has been reported elsewhere and, apart from genetic and biological factors, it is also probably linked with socio-cultural, media and peer pressure on diet,” the report said.

Title: 60-year-old Australian slips from mountainous terrain, injured
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Dehradun: A 60-year-old Australian national suffered head injuries after his biked slipped from a mountainous terrain in Khirsu town of Pauri district on Monday.

The injured, who has been identified by his first nameMarco, was later airlifted to AIIMS, Rishikesh, after locals informed officials of the disaster management authority.

“The patient has a skull injury, but his limbs are moving with no spinal tenderness. He is being treated by neurosurgery experts, as we wait for some reports,” AIIMS PRO Harish Thapliyal told TOI.

According to Pauri district administration, Marco had arrived in Pauri along with another tourist on February 9 and took a bike on rent to travel to nearby areas. District officials said that when news of the Aussie national being injured came in, the district magistrate informed the CM’s office which dispatched a chopper to Khirsu to airlift the tourist.

Title: Women protesters resume agitation against CAA at Mohammad Ali Park
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Kanpur: Two days after the anti-CAA protesters called off their sit-in and vacated the Mohammad Ali Park in Chamanganj area of the city, scores of women protesters, allegedly from the other faction, on late Sunday night, assembled at the same place and staged a sit-in against the CAA.

Locals of the area, however, said that there was a tension in the area when police, on the intervening night of Sunday and Monday, arrived at the spot and started forcibly removing the protesters from the park. However, the women, instead of leaving the spot, started staging a road blockade at the nearby Inspector Road and demanded that they are allowed to hold demonstration inside the park to raise their voice against the CAA and NRC.

Later, more protestors, including men and women, joined and the number soon swelled into several thousand.

In order to avoid any kind of backlash, the district administration requisitioned more police force but the protesters refused to lift the road blockade even after repeatedly being warned of strict police action, said eyewitnesses. Sensing the gravity of the situation, police later allowed the demonstrators to resume their sit-in at the Mohammad Ali Park.

The women have been staging the sit-in at Mohammad Ali Park in Chamanganj and Tikuniya Park at Babupurwa since January 7 and January 19, respectively, to demand rollback of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA).

The protesters at both the sites had called off their sit-in after submitting a memorandum to the district and police authorities after getting an assurance from the administration on Saturday that it would withdraw the cases lodged as part of preventive action against them.

Many protesters at Mohammad Ali Park, however, stayed back, said, eyewitnesses.

“Police, on coming to know about the sit-in, rushed to the spot and asked the protesters to vacate the park on the intervening night of Sunday and Monday. When the protesters refused to budge, the cops at around 4.30 am on Monday, forcibly removed them. The protesters, however, returned later in the day,” they added.

The district and police officials told them that they have instructions not to allow people to stage protests there as the prohibitory orders were in force.

Meanwhile, the women protesters, staging a road blockade, alleged that the district administration and police have done this to prevent people from voicing their opinion against CAA and NRC which discriminate on the basis of religion and violates the Constitution.

DIG Anant Deo, however, claimed that a different faction of women has started the protest on Sunday.

“They are being instigated by some outsiders. We will investigate and locate thosewho are instigating the protesters,” the DIG added.

To recall, last Thursday, the district administration had slapped notices on 66 residents of Chamanganj area to sign security bonds of Rs 2 lakh for maintaining law and order at Mohammad Ali Park where women protesters have dug in their heels.

The notices were issued to them under Section 107/117 of the CrPC which empowers a magistrate to direct a person to furnish security bonds pending an inquiry.

Title: After five years, BCA revives school cricket tournament
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

This tournament may find a fixed place in yearly schedule

Vadodara: The thriving school cricket culture in the city has been instrumental in giving international cricketers like Anshuman Gaekwad, Kiran More , Nayan Mongia , Atul Bedade and many more first-class players.

The Baroda Cricket Association (BCA) management that had been ignoring school cricket over last few years seems to have realized the importance of this tournament.

The association on Monday announced that organizing Maharani Shantadevi Inter School Tournament which will start from Tuesday in the city. It is after a gap of five years that the tournament is being played in the city. The last time the tournament was played in 2015. “We had to stop the tournament as it wasn’t getting place in the other BCCI as well as local cricket tournaments. We were not having enough dates to play this tournament,” said Satyajit Gaekwad, chairman of BCA’s press and publicity committee.

The association was also facing criticism for sidestepping school cricket and promoting club cricket for years. “BCA had been getting talented players from school cricket, so we decided to start it again. It will give good opportunity to young players,” said Pranav Amin, BCA president.

A total of 16 school teams will play in the group of four groups. All the matches will be played as per one day rules.

When asked if the tournament will have a permanent place in BCA’s cricket calendar, Amin said, “We are preparing an elaborate calendar of cricket tournaments for every season. This tournament will have a fixed schedule every year,” Amin added.

The association is planning to look for sponsors for this tourney that took off in 1990s. BCA will also organize district level school tournaments on the grounds there.

New coach to be picked

After Ranji coach Sanath Kumar suffered brain stroke last month, former India pacer Munaf Patel is playing the dual role of Ranji team’s coach as well as mentor. Playing without a full time coach, Baroda team crashed out of the Ranji Trophy due to performance as well as selection issue. The association is planning to rope in a new coach for the next season.

200 applications for CEO post

The BCA has received nearly 200 applications for the post of CEO. BCA president, Pranav Amin said that they have zeroed in on 30 to 40 applications out of which three to five candidates will be short-listed. Sources in the BCA said that one of the strong contenders has demanded unreasonably high salary for the job.

Title: 56-yr old man trampled to death by elephant
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Rudrapur: A 56-year-old man was trampled to death by an elephant in Gularbhoj area of Udham Singh Nagar district on Sunday night. The deceased, Nand Lal, was sleeping in a field with some other farmers to guard crops when the incident happened.

According to the ranger of the Pipal Parao forests, Bhupendra Mehra, farmers heard some commotion in the fields and went to look for its source. Seeing an elephant, all the farmers ran away, barring Lal. According to eyewitnesses, the elephant scooped up Lal with its trunk and flung him to the ground several times before finally trampling him to death. Forest officials have sent the body for postmortem and asked farmers to fence their fields. Mehra said that the family will be compensated with Rs 5 lakh, which is the norm in case of elephant-related deaths.

In January 2019, 60-year old Roshan Lal was trampled to death by a wild elephant in the same area while he was guarding wheat fields near Baur outpost.

Title: Man commits suicide after wife goes to parents’ home
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Kanpur: A man , depressed after his wife left home and went to her parents’ house, committed suicide at his house in Gujaini area of Barra in the city on late Sunday night.

According to the police, Durgesh Kumar (30), a loader driver, resident of Gujaini area in Barra, had married Anita four year ago. He had taken to drinking alcohol after marriage.

Perturbed with her husband’s behaviour, his wife, along with their two children, went to her parents house. “Irritated with this, Durgesh, on late Sunday night, committed suicide by hanging himself,” said inspector Barra Satish Kumar Singh.

Police have registered a case and started investigation in this connection, said Singh.

Title: Corp removes 62,000 illegal hoardings, levies Rs 10L fines
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

The revenue wing of the city corporation has been dealing with undue pressure from political parties/organisat... Read More

Thiruvananthapuram: The city corporation removed 62,340 unauthorised hoardings and banners over the last few months following repeated orders by the high court calling for stringent action. It also levied penalties to the tune of Rs 10.29 lakh, the highest among civic bodies in the state. Kollam corporation removed 7,343 unauthorised hoardings and stood second in terms of fines levied, at Rs 7.92 lakh, according to data presented to the assembly.

The revenue wing of the city corporation has of late been dealing with undue pressure from political parties and organisations in its drive against hoardings. On Friday, things took an ugly turn after a revenue team was confronted by an organisation over removal of boards, banners and festoons which were arranged for a state conference. The matter escalated as the revenue wing was reportedly asked by corporation authorities to re-install the boards. Officials says that they are demoralised by such actions as they are caught between the legal obligation to comply with the court directive and pressure from political parties, organisations and sometimes from even within the ruling council.

The high court had recently directed local bodies to remove illegal hoardings , banners, boards erected on footpaths and roadside within 15 days. The local self-government department (LSGD) also issued a new set of guidelines in the wake of the court order. T Mithra, additional secretary with LSGD, directed local bodies to levy fines and initiate revenue recovery against violators.

According to the LSGD directive, the boards erected in violation of norms are not to be dumped in public waste management facilities and that their disposal will be the responsibility of violators. The licence of agencies which put up the unauthorised boards are to be cancelled and local body secretaries have been asked not to reissue licences to such agencies.

Between October 2018 and June 2019, the city corporation removed 37,368 boards, banners and flags and levied Rs 8.72 lakh in penalties. The civic body also filed complaints with the city police against repeat offenders and 12 FIRs have been registered.

Following the latest court order, corporation secretary has directed that FIRs be registered and criminal action be initiated against repeat violators. A penalty in the range of Rs 2,500-Rs 10,000 will also be levied. This is being done based on the court order which says that if any unauthorised board/banner/flag/hoarding is detected and consequentially removed and returned to the person or a group, an appropriate criminal case under IPC or Highway Act or under Police Act may be charged and registered against the persons or entities responsible.

Title: CAU announces women squad
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

The Cricket Association of Uttarakhand ( CAU ) on Monday announced the squad for the first four matches of the Senior Women’s One Day Trophy. The 15-women squad will be led by Preeti Bhandari with Radha Chand as her deputy. The domestic one-day tournament will start on February 18 with Uttarakhand playing their first match on the next day against Hyderabad in Surat. The hill state is being slotted in the Elite Group C which comprises teams such as Gujarat, Jharkhand, Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan.

Title: Waiter ends life in hotel, body found in store room
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Kanpur: A 24-year-old waiter allegedly committed suicide by hanging himself at a hotel in Harbanshmohal area of the city on Sunday night.

Inspector Santosh Awasthi, said the victim has been identified as Luvlesh Kumar, a resident of Banda. He worked as a waiter in the hotel, said the police.

The hotel staff noticed the body in the store of the hotel and informed the manager. No suicide note was recovered and no injury marks were found on the body, said the police.

Police have recovered an Aaadhar card and a mobile phone near the body. The body was sent for autopsy. Family members of the deceased have been informed.

Police are questioning the hotel staff to find out the reason behind his suicide.

Title: Farmer, 70, attempts self immolation in Roorkee
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Frustrated with lackadaisical attitude of officials, a 70-year-old farmer allegedly attempted suicide at the office of the sub-divisional magistrate (SDM) in Bhagwanpur area of Roorkee on Monday. Around 11 am, the farmer, identified as Teloo Ram, from Hallu Majra village poured kerosene oil on himself and tried to light a fire when the officials stopped him.

Ram said, “An influential man has encroached upon a footpath that connects my home to my field. I have been running form pillar to post for the past 10 years to get it removed but nothing has happened so far. Except committing suicide, I had no option left.” When queried about the matter, SDM SK Pandey said, “Ram approached us only a few days ago and I had instructed police to take action in the case at the earliest. Now the matter has been resolved and all encroachments have been removed.”

Title: Bengaluru: Body found in gutted car
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: An unidentified man was found charred to death in an abandoned Skoda Fabia that caught fire near a BangaloreOne centre in Kaval Byrasandra, DJ Halli, on Monday.

Passersby noticed the abandoned vehicle going up in flames at 7.30pm. Fire officials told TOI there was no engine in the car and they found a charred body of a man — who appeared to be in his 30s — in the front seat.

Police said the vehicle had been abandoned at the spot by a mechanic who owns a shop nearby. He told police that car had been brought for bodyshop work.

Police are yet to identify the victim. “Locals said a man had entered the car, reportedly after consuming alcohol in a nearby bar, and probably lit up a cigarette and dropped the burning butt inside the car,” and officer said.

Title: Goods driver sets example byplanting saplings on median
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Udupi: To make a beautiful garden, one doesn’t need land, but have the willingness to make the environment green. Zafar Saheb from Shirva is a case in point. This goods driver spends spare time to beautify his garden which is actually a road median, by planting saplings of flowering plants and crotons.

He feels people are aware of the need for green around them but the real challenge is watering the plants and nurturing them.

Zafar Saheb, 60, said: “Business has been dull for over a year. So, most of the time, I spend in the vehicle stand. I then thought of beautifying the median. Gardening is my hobby and I have a garden at home. When Shirva Main Road tarring was done, there was place for a divider and I filled it with soil for a 300-metre stretch and planted some plants from my garden.”

Zafar, who has studied up to SSLC, came up with a unique technique to water the plants. He picked waste bottles, opened the bottom part and made some holes in the cap and fixed it on the soil near the plants. He just needs to fill the bottle in the morning and water drips from the bottle directly to the plant through the day. “This system provides sufficient water for the plants and uses less water,” he said.

He added, “We have a Tempo stand on one side of the road, and an autorickshaw stand on the other side. We all water the plants. Initially, some were sceptical about about it, but now all appreciate it and come up with suggestions. Some get water and others get plants. The Mahila Mandal near the stand gives water every day. Some people keep water in a can near the Tempo stand. Though it was not a planned project, it makes me happy that all support me in it.”

An inspiration to others

“We spend a lot of time on the road. It should be our aim that our roads should be as beautiful as our homes,” he said.

He added: “This monsoon, I have to take out the soil and remove the tar from the median so that the plants grow nicely. I want to expand it up to a 1-km stretch and want others to also plant saplings on medians and make our city beautiful.”

Title: Anti-CAA protesters in Tiruvarur, Thanjavur stay put
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Trichy: The sit-in condemning the lathicharge on against anti-CAA protesters in Chennai continued for the third day on Monday at Muthupettai and Koothanallur in Tiruvarur district, Peravurani and Mathukur in Thanjavur district. A large posse of police have been deployed for protection.

There are more than 500 people protesting at New Street grounds in Muthupettain in Tiruvarur for the third consecutive day on Monday. Among them, many people affiliated to Muslim outfits are demanding action against the police since Saturday. DMK farmers wing secretary AKS Vijayan, VCK state leader Ilanthendral, SDPI state secretary Abubakar Sidique and Marxist district-level leaders participated in the protest to express their solidarity. Tiruvarur DMK MLA Poondi Kalaivanan expressed his support to the protesters in Koothanallur.

Despite police holding talks with the protesters, they refused to vacate. Following this, DIG J Loganathan convened a meeting with higher police officials to manage the situation.

Hundreds of protesters gathered at Vedhantham grounds in Peravurani in Thanjavur at the protest organised by the federation of all Muslim outfits on Monday. Dravidar Viduthalai Kazhagam leader Kolathur Mani, AICC member K Mahendran, Thamizhaga Makkal Puratchi Kazhagam leader Aranga Gunasekaran and Marxist district secretary G Neelamegam spoke at the protest venue. Several opposition party leaders from DMK, VCK and MDMK also participated.

Students from Khadir Mohideen College in Athirampattinam staged a demonstration in front of the institution skipping their classes on Monday. TNN

Title: Southco, govt dept spar over bus accident
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Berhampur: Sunday’s accident in which 10 people lost their lives after the bus they were travelling in came into contact with a low-hanging high-tension wire in Ganjam district has sparked a blame game between power distribution company Southco Utility and the state rural development department.

The accident, which took place at Mandrajpur under Ganjam district’s Golanthara police station limits, left 18 people injured.

A senior Southco officer said they had written to the executive engineer of the rural development division (Ganjam) for permission to move electric poles from the middle of the road at Mandarajpur to one side.

The poles were ended up being smack on the road after it was widened a while ago.

“On July 4, 2018, we asked the department to deposit Rs 4 lakh towards shifting of the electric poles. The executive engineer of the rural development department, however, did not pay the money,” said chief operating officer of Southco, Arun Kumar.

The executive engineer of rural development (Ganjam), P K Jena, contested the charges and said Southco had only provided an estimate of the money needed to move the poles away from the road.

“It did not tell us about the danger posed by the wires. It also did not pursue the matter,” Jena said. He added that the incident could have been avoided had the live wire, which had sagged, been tightened on time.

Locals, however, continued to blame the power distribution company for the accident. They said they had repeatedly drawn Southco’s attention to the low-hanging wires, but their complaints were never addressed. “As it is the KV lines are very low. Now, even the poles are on the road after it was widened by the rural development department,” said Ch. Sudhakar Reddy, sarpanch of Ekasingh.

On Monday, the state government suspended four engineers from these two departments for negligence. Besides, regional transport officer (Ganjam), Sanjay Kumar Biswal, submitted to the collector the report of a preliminary inquiry held by additional RTO K Venketesh and motor vehicle inspector Santanu Kumar Parida.

Biswal also issued a challan of Rs 15,000 against the owner of the bus for plying the route without permission.

“The bus was in good condition but it had not taken permission to run on this route. The vehicle has a permit to run from Hinjili to Cuttack, via Berhampur,” said Biswal.

He added that the accident took place because of the negligence of the driver and that he had recommended the suspension of his driving licence for three months.

Title: This techie is a go-to crowdfunder for needy patients
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

MANGALURU: Five months, 27 fundraisers for needy patients, 1,500 donors and counting, and Rs 40 lakh collected so far. This is probably not on Arjun Bhandarkar’s CV but the 31-year-old software engineer is now a trusted name in crowdfunding for medical emergencies, with his heart in the right place and the logistics to boot.

Arjun’s foray into crowd-sourcing was triggered by a family emergency when his father was hospitalised. “Though we had sufficient insurance cover and resources at hand, we had to struggle to make immediate arrangements,” he recalls. “That got me thinking. If we, who had good jobs and were earning well, faced difficulties in rustling up funds, what about those who don’t have the wherewithal?”

Having worked for eight years with a private firm after completing his BE in information science, the techie felt this was an opportunity to try something new on the side. “I thought a lot and decided to help six patients a year by collecting just Rs 100 each from donors I could find. I began searching within my circle and while I was happy to pool together Rs 10,000 for a family, my friends and I managed to raise more than Rs 2.5 lakh,” says Arjun.

Arjun’s parents, wife and his sister who has a daughter, stood by him in his new venture. The initial days were tough and at times disappointing, he says, as not many people knew him or were willing to loosen their purse strings for him. “I had to reach out to more than 1,000 people to raise enough money to help one family,” he recalls. But case by case, Arjun built his credibility. “Most such messages for help circulated on WhatsApp or Facebook do not provide even 10% information about the family’s situation or the details of treatment. The more information one provides, the more credible the case will be.”

Bit by bit, word got around and Arjun’s appeals began to draw a robust response. He has raised Rs 40 lakh so far for 27 families and in January, floated an emergency fund that could be used to help patients right away without waiting for a crowdfunding campaign. “We have provided Rs 25,000 each to two families through this fund which they used for hospital admission charges,” Arjun says. “The lowest donation in my campaigns so far has been Re 1 and the highest has been Rs 50,000.”

The last campaign Arjun launched was for Sahana Pai, a breast cancer patient. “Cancer patients are in need of substantial amounts for treatment, accident victims need help to rebuild their lives and families in either situation need money to meet immediate or long-term expenses. We take up all such appeals,” says Arjun.

Recently, he has been working with GSB Charitable Trust which refers potential fundraisers to him. “The fund targets are planned in such a manner that they help the beneficiary meet a portion of the treatment cost,” he says, adding that has met the target successfully barring a couple of instances.

“We have more than 1,500 donors who have helped one or more families. I reach out to them via WhatsApp, Facebook, Instagram and email as the last resort,” says Arjun. “The challenge is to enlarge this list. We have launched an initiative where donors can pledge money on special occasions such as birthdays or anniversaries. This has been welcomed by many,” he says.

Arjun runs a Facebook page, ‘Help to save a life: Lend a helping hand’, and personally drafts the fundraiser petition. “Since this is my initiative, I personally make sure that the causes are verified. And I always provide the full details,” he says. “I also try my utmost to get the donors to meet the families and hand over their contribution so they know where their money is going. I don’t get into it unless I have to.”

Title: Hyderabad: Duty-free liquor on sale, gangs get rich while government loses tax
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Police present the seized liquor and the arrested duo before media

HYDERABAD: For smugglers, duty-free foreign liquor is as good as gold. They piggyback on international fliers to legally buy imported foreign liquor from duty-free shop at RGI Airport , then illegally sell it to local customers at a price lower than government-mandated rates for foreign brands at retail liquor stores. While the profit is neat for smugglers, the revenue loss for state is steep. In less than a fortnight, excise officials have seized 254 foreign liquor bottles worth Rs 30 lakh from gangs operating in the city.

International passengers can buy duty-free liquor for personal consumption by producing a flight ticket and passport. “But selling duty-free liquor is illegal,” an excise official said.

With the modus operandi of the fraudsters coming to light, excise officials caught T Venkatesh (55) of Chikkadpally twice in four months.

Venkatesh, who operated a departmental store in the US for over a decade, has been supplying foreign liquor to parties in the city for the past few years. “He has been supplying lakhs of rupees worth of foreign liquor to clients. At the time of his arrest, we seized 171 foreign liquor bottles from him and his two aides,” an excise official said.

Blue Label and Royal Salute whiskies seem to be the favourite brands of the gangs. According to excise sleuths, state government sells 750 ml bottles of the two imported brands for Rs 22,000 and Rs 21,000 respectively at retail liquor shops. But on the other hand, at a duty-free shop fliers (carriers for smugglers) can buy a litre of the same brands between Rs 13,000 and Rs 14,000, which is sourced by Venkatesh and then sold to clients for Rs 18,000 to Rs 19,000.

“Customers get a litre of imported alcohol for price lesser than a 750-ml bottle in the market. It is a win-win situation for both the supplier and the customer,” an excise official said.

Venkatesh was found to be procuring duty-free liquor from Chennai-based Doraisingam and Phaneendra Babu . In addition to the Chennai suppliers, Venkatesh also had contacts at the duty-free shop at RGI Airport, operated by GMR Hospitality and Retail Limited, officials said.

“Passengers who go to Malaysia to buy electronic goods such as camera lenses and LED TVs are being used by Venkatesh to bring duty-free liquor from Hyderabad airport. He used to give money to one Khaled, working at Hyderabad duty-free shop, and his former assistant Anil. They scan passports of passengers from Malaysia and send duty-free liquor out with them. Venkatesh collects the liquor outside the airport,” assistant excise superintendent N Anji Reddy said.

Deputy commissioner C Vivekananda Reddy said that in the past two weeks their teams had arrested six persons, including Venkatesh, two RGI Airport duty-free shop workers, a havildar of central GST, who used to work at the airport, and a Mumbai-based foreign liquor supplier belonging to three gangs.

“We strongly condemn such cases. We have a zero-tolerance policy against such misdemeanours. Based on prima facie information, we have already suspended the employee in question and we are conducting a thorough investigation from our side,” a spokesperson of GMR Hyderabad International Airport Limited (GHIAL), which operates RGI Airport at Shamshabad, said.

Title: 8 more of Manawar lynch mob arrested
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Indore: Five days after Manawar mob lynching that claimed life of a person, Dhar police on Monday nabbed eight more suspects in connection with the case, taking the number of arrests to 19.

Following the gruesome mob attack at Borlai village of Manawar tehsil in Dhar district on February 5, police had identified three main suspects and 15-20 others.

Dhar SP Aditya Pratap Singh said: “Preliminary investigation reveals that labourers - Bhuvan Singh and Avtar- who owed the money of the victims, were main conspirators as they spread rumour of child lifting by making phone calls to local villagers. The duo is still on the run.”

Earlier, a local BJP leader, who was arrested in the case, was alleged to be the kingpin of the violence.

Relentless raids by police teams are on in nearby jungles and suspected hideouts for people, who are on the run after their name surfaced in the crime based on video footage and photographs of the spot, Singh said.

The incident has triggered political storm in Madhya Pradesh. On Monday morning, health minister Tulsiram Silawat contacted Dhar collector Shrikanth Banoth and SP on phone and took stock of the ongoing investigation and arrests made in the case.

Earlier, Silawat had visited the survivors — Jagdish Radheshyam Sharma, 45, Vinod Tulsiram Mukati, 43, Ravi Patel, 38, and Jagdish Poonamchand Sharma — at Choithram Hospital, and announced a compensation of Rs 2 lakh to the family of Ganesh, who was killed in the brutal attack.

Meanwhile, members of Khati community of Borlai and Khirkiya villages led by their national president Manoharlal Mandloi met the SP and handed over a memorandum to register their protest. The community national secretary Mishrilal Choudhary demanded action against cops for their negligence in controlling the mob. They also demanded compensation of Rs 50 lakh to next kin of the deceased and other victims.

Title: Mishap orphans 2 teenage sisters
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Berhampur: After losing their father, two teenage sisters of Dankalpadu village were being brought up by their mother, who doubled up as father. But the cruel fate snatched away that lifeline too.

They have become orphan after their mother along with nine others was electrocuted in the bus in which they were travelling came in contact with a sagging live wire at Mandarajpur in Ganjam district on Sunday.

B Dropadi, 15, and her sister B Jyostna, 13, had lost their father 10 years ago due to snakebite. On Sunday, their mother B Pappama, 38, died. To add to the siblings’ woes, they will have to look after an 80-year-old ailing grandmother too.

“My mother was eking out a living by working as a daily-wage labourer. I don’t know how we could maintain the family,” said Dropadi, who studies in Class X. Her sister is in Class VIII in the local school. Dropadi and her sister survived as both of them refused to attend the ring ceremony of a youth of their village.

“Our mother died 15 minutes after her departure,’ said Dropadi as tears rolled down her cheeks.

One of their relatives said the government needs to adopt these poor sisters like it did to orphaned children in Gajapati district after they lost their parents in the severe cyclone Titli. The government has announced Rs 2 lakh to the kin of each of the deceased in the bus mishap. “Rs 2 lakh is not sufficient to bring up the two teenage girls. The government should adopt them and take care of their ailing grandmother,” said N Damburu Reddy, a villager.

Eerie silence prevailed in Dankalpadu a day after the incident as eight persons of the village were electrocuted. Some of the women of the village were seen serving cooked food to the family members of the deceased.

Similarly two sisters — K Sandhya, 30, and K Mohini, 35 — died in the accident. These two married women had come to the village to attend their bother Ashok Reddy’s ring ceremony. “On my request they came in the morning of Sunday. Like others, they were also going to attend the ring ceremony,” said 26-year old Ashok, who stayed back in his house.

Title: Vijayvargiya targets CM Nath, Congress hits back
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Ujjain/Bhopal: BJP general secretary Kailash Vijayvargiya on Monday accused chief minister Kamal Nath of trying to “divide tribals”, triggering a stinging retort from Congress, which said people of Ujjain have already given him their answer by boycotting his rally.

Leading a march to demand a “clear passage” for pilgrims to Mahakaal temple. He claimed Nath won’t be able to continue in office if he tries to stop 2021 census enumerators from marking tribals as Hindus.

Claiming that CM Kamal Nath had warned of action against officials “if any of them allowed tribals to call themselves Hindus in the Census”, Vijayvargiya said: “Kamal Nathji’s statement will create a new problem in Madhya Pradesh and the country. This is a dangerous, poisonous statement. Kamal Nathji is trying to trying to divide society. Till now attempts were made to create divisions between Hindus and Muslims. Now it is tribals, and that too for votebank politics.”

Tribals have been a part of Hindu community since the age of Lord Rama, he insisted. “Kamal Nath ji, if you try to take action against officials, you will not be able to remain chief minister. Census is carried out by the central government not state,” he said.

The state Congress hit back hard, with PCC spokesman and chief minister’s media convener Narendra Saluja saying, “Kailash Vijayvargiya, who had threatened to set Indore on fire, went to Ujjain temple on Monday and tried to disturb peace and amity there.”

“People of Ujjain gave a befitting reply to Vijayvargiya by boycotting his public meeting. Despite false claims by BJP leaders, including former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan and BJP state president Rakesh Singh, people kept away from BJP’s protest,” Saluja said.

“Vijayvargiya has challenged Kamal Nath once again, forgetting that during the state government’s campaign against mafia, he had thrown a similar challenge. He knows what happened after that. Fearing defeat, Vijayvargiya ran away from Mhow and did not contest the assembly elections. Instead, he helped his son Akash Vijayvargiya win from Indore-3, the only seat BJP could win in the entire Indore division,” Saluja added.

Vijayvargiya led the rally to ask the district administration to clear a road in Begam Bag area of anti-CAA protesters as it leads to Mahakaal temple. Vijayvargiya claimed the protest was blocking pilgrims from visiting the temple. “If the road is not cleared before Maha Shivratri (February 21), BJP will stage 101 protests,” he said.

Title: Bhitarkanika park, beach in Balasore set to get facelift
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Kendrapada/Balasore: Close on heels of their visits to different temples and subsequent announcement of packages for the development of the shrines, chief secretary Asit Tripathy and 5T secretary V K Pandian, among other senior officers, visited Talasari beach in Balasore district and Bhitarkanika National Park in Kendrapada district on Monday to tap tourism potential of the two destinations.

The state government is likely to come out with packages to develop the two destinations, said an official. The officials are scheduled to give a presentation of the proposed development plans of the two places before the chief minister Naveen Patnaik soon.

They discussed with the senior officials and others to promote ecotourism in Bhitarkanika and Gahiramatha marine sanctuary to attract more tourists to both the places.

The officials said ecotourism as an activity will create employment opportunities for many villagers around Bhitarkanika National Park. It is essential to make sure that growth and development of ecotourism sector is sustainable, socially responsible and creates decent job opportunities. “Ecotourism in Bhitarkanika is a big employment generator and has a multiplier impact on the economy. It is a major contributor to employment, particularly for women and youths, fishermen, boatmen and others. Ecotourism can lead to the alleviation of poverty and boost socio-economic development,” said Bikash Ranjan Dash, divisional forest officer (DFO) of the park.

The state government decided to promote ecotourism in Bhitarkanika as it has potential for adventure tourism. Villagers around the national park would earn more money in the process by extending homely hospitality to the tourists who each winter visit Bhitarkanika.

Ecotourism projects will act as the window to the treasure trove of natural resources in forests and the authorities directed the forest officials to promote ecotourism on a large scale, added Dash.

The water bodies of the park are home to around 1,700 salt-water crocodiles. It is also abode to birds, spotted deer, snakes and water monitors.

Title: Cashless service at Kaduru GP great success
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Udupi: Cashless transactions, introduced at Kaduru gram panchayat as a pilot project in 2018-19, is a big hit. Following its success, the government has ordered implementation of the same at 158 GPs in the district. It will later be extended to all GPs spread across the state.

For the record, Kaduru GP is also the recipient of Sansad Adharsh Gram Award. Srinivas Rao, chief planning officer of the zilla panchayat, said: “UDMA Technology has introduced a software, under which people can make cashless transaction even in the absence of internet. The app enables people to use any language of their choice. Villagers not having smartphones have the option to transact through their phones.”

The pilot project has collected 78% of the tax online from the GP. Through the app, transactions with regard to collecting house and other tax, water and electricity bills, and solid-liquid resource management (SLRM) changes can be made. The district administration has submitted a report on the same to state government. Based on the report findings, the government consented to extend the project to all GPs in district. The same will be implemented in stagewise, he added.

Mahesh, panchayat development officer of Kaduru GP, said former DC Priyanka Mary Francis had referred Kaduru for the cashless transactions project. The GP comprises Kaduru and Naduru villages having 1,106 houses. Of them, 780 households had paid taxes online last year.

UDMA technology had launched the software ‘Yuva Pay’ for cashless transactions. The currently available online app charges 2-3% of the amount. However, the company collects only 0.5%. Also, cashless transaction is not made mandatory here. People could also pay taxes/ bills by personally at the panchayat office or at some shops.

Though the system does not need internet or smartphone, the transactions need a mobile network to happen. But many places in these villages do not have network due to the absence of mobile towers. “Also, an online payment receipt is not considered as a valid proof for payment. So we need to distribute the receipts though bill collectors,” he added.

In the next phase, cashless transactions will be extended to GPs covering Aruru, Kukehalli, Cherkadi, Inanje, Kumbashi, Thekkatte, Hosadu, Trasi, Maravathe, Vandse, Warranga, Erlapadi, Bailuru and others.

Title: BJP and Cong pooh-pooh exit poll results
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

New Delhi: In the next few hours, the fate of 672 candidates — 593 men and 79 women — in the electoral fray for 70 seats in Delhi Assembly would be known. Though the contest to form a government in Delhi is largely seen to be between the party in power, AAP , and BJP , Congress may emerge as a dark horse and upset calculations.

Counting of votes will begin at 8am and which party gets the mandate to govern Delhi for the next five years will be known by 2pm.

Stakes are high for the three political parties that ran a campaign for almost a fortnight before the votes were polled on February 8. Victory of AAP will validate its claims of doing good work in education, health and power sectors while looking after the vulnerable sections through free power, water and travel for women in public transport.

Bharatiya Janata Party, which had been extremely critical of the five years of the Aam Aadmi Party government in the capital, made the work done by Prime Minister Narendra Modi-led central government its election plank to woo voters apart from focussing on national issues such as abrogation of Article 370 and 35A in Kashmir, citizenship amendment law and protests against, a favourable judgment in the Ram Temple case and surgical strikes on Pakistan.

The party, which is looking to form a government in Delhi after 22 years in exile, ran an aggressive campaign with Union home minister Amit Shah micro-managing everything on a day-to-day basis. Senior BJP functionaries, including several Union ministers and MPs from across the country, addressed close to 10,000 public meetings during the fortnight-long campaign, banking on planks of Hindutva and nationalism.

Congress, on the other hand, made the legacy of the Sheila Dikshit government and infrastructure development during 1998-2013 when it was in power its main poll plank. Several senior Congress functionaries, including former party president Rahul Gandhi, AICC general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra and chief ministers of four states held public events in the last week of electioneering.

The exit polls telecast by various TV channels have predicted a comfortable victory for AAP by giving it 44-68 seats in the 70-member House. In the 2015 assembly polls, AAP had won a record 67 seats and polled over 54% votes. BJP, which got over 32% votes in the last election, had won just three seats while Congress was decimated with a vote share of less than 10% and no seat. Most exit polls have predicted around 10-12 seats for the BJP, marginally better over the last assembly poll results and none for Congress.

Both BJP and Congress have rubbished the exit poll results. BJP leaders exuded confidence “based on a micro analysis of all seats. The exit polls are rough estimates, and I am confident that BJP will form the government in Delhi with full majority,” said Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari, adding that they would win 45 of the 70 seats. Delhi Congress chief Subhash Chopra said the “actual” results would surprise everyone.

Title: TDP MLA targeted on social media files plaint at Disha PS
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

RAJAHMUNDRY: Rajahmundry city MLA and TDP leader Adireddi Bhavani on Monday lodged a complaint at the Disha police station here, alleging that derogatory remarks were directed at her on social media .

The comments were made following a speech by the MLA in the assembly on December 16, 2019 and later brought to the notice of the speaker.

Bhavani said she lodged a complaint when no action was taken, adding that no action has been taken against the culprits till date.

The legislator said people may lose faith in the Act and the police stations set up under it if investigation is delayed. Other TDP functionaries present at the police station claimed that the government had set up Disha police stations only in name. The police, they added, had said the case would not be investigated under the Act.

Rajahmundry (urban) additional SP K Latha Madhuri said as the case falls under the limits of the assembly secretariat, the police would proceed only after taking a legal opinion, adding that the complaint was lodged 53 days after the incident.

The additional SP said similar complaints were lodged by two women from Eluru in West Godavari and Amalapuram in East Godavari, which did not fall under their jurisdiction, but all three complaints were received and action initiated after taking a legal opinion. She added that police stations set up under it would be a driving force in curbing atrocities against women and children.

Title: Gujarat: Bootleggers elude cops in 50 cases daily
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Bootleggers manage to give police a slip in nearly 50 cases daily as cops successfully seize liquor across the state in 612 prohibition cases, on average, registered across the state every day.According to details submitted by the state government to the Gujarat high court, in 515 days from May 1, 2018, to September 30, 2019, 3,15,614 cases of prohibition were registered across Gujarat.These cases included police raids conducted on liquor dens or the interception of vehicles carrying liquor. In all, in 25,891 cases, bootleggers could not be arrested.In four police commissionerate limits, 81,523 prohibition cases were registered between May 1, 2018, and September 30, 2019. Police admitted that they had failed to nab bootleggers in 1,285 cases.Despite the failure of this scale, police have initiated action against only 47 police officials in 20 cases over the past one-and-a-half years.Those facing action include cops up to the rank of inspector. A police inspector in Botad and two sub-inspectors in Dahod were arrested for lapses and possible connivance with bootleggers.The government provided the details on orders passed by Justice S H Vora while deciding on an anticipatory bail application filed by a bootlegger in Junagadh district. In this case, police had seized liquor by intercepting a vehicle, but the bootlegger had escaped.The judge observed that the police file numerous FIRs in prohibition cases showing the seizure of liquor but conceding that bootleggers have escaped. The judge demanded details of such ‘designed FIRs’.Following the court’s orders, the state police chief issued directions to all police commissioners and other senior officials to order inquiries into such cases.It was conveyed that senior officials should study the FIRs and set up an inquiry if the cases are found to be suspicious.

Title: Tragedy prompts state to set up burnsunit at MKCG hosp
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The state government has decided to set up a burns unit at MKCG Medical College and Hospital, Berhampur, after nine passengers seriously burnt in the Ganjam bus tragedy had to be shifted to SCB Medical College and Hospital, Cuttack, said health and family welfare minister Naba Kishore Das here on Monday.

At least 10 passengers died and 20 sustained injuries when a bus came in contact with a sagging 11KV live electricity wire near Mandrajpur village under Golanthara police limits in Ganjam district.

Though the injured patients were rushed to MKCG, they could not get treatment for burns due to lack of facilities. One patient died while being shifted to SCB. “People in southern Odisha depend upon MKCG but the government is yet to set up a burn unit at the premier hospital. It should be developed like SCB,” said Odisha Medical Services Association (OMSA) president Nirakar Bhatt. Medical superintendent of MKCG Santosh Kumar Misra said the hospital has already submitted a requirement for manpower and equipment to start the burn unit.

“We have a professor of plastic surgery. We need an associate professor, an assistant professor, three senior residents, four junior residents, 34 staff nurse, five technicians, laboratory attendants, class-IV employees and equipment to start the burn unit,” he added.

Title: Fill vacancies at KGH: Left
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: CPI(M) functionaries and activists staged a protest in the city on Monday, demanding the government fill up vacancies at KG Hospital in Vizag city as patients have been suffering from staff shortage .

Party functionaries said thousands from north Andhra Pradesh visit KGH , but a majority do not get medication due to staff shortage and lack of advanced equipment.

M Subba Rao of CPI(M) said though KGH is known as the poor man’s health fort, it has failed to provide treatment to the poor. Staff shortage and lack of equipment and medicines have led to patient deaths, he added.

Title: Koraput art teacher who loves making short films
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Koraput: By profession he is a teacher, but he is known better for his numerous short films, which have fetched him a number of awards. Meet Vishal Patnaik, 27, of Jeypore, a fine arts teacher in the government-run Adarsh Vidyalaya at Boipariguda, who has directed as many as 10 short films.

Patnaik’s films are known for their socially relevant content and use of local artists and locally available technology. His hard work has fetched him a number of state tele awards.

One of his shorts, ‘Chandalo’, won awards for best film and best actor at the 5th state tele awards in 2017. Another, ‘Pension’, depicting the struggle of the parents of a martyr in getting the pension due to them, received awards for best film, best story and best actor at the 7th state tele awards in 2019.

“In 2013, I made a short film titled ‘On a Sunday Evening’ just for fun. It was well received by viewers and it inspired me to make a second film,” said Patnaik.

Completely unaware of the nuances of film making, he surfed the internet to learn more. In a couple of years, Patnaik was successful in establishing himself as a well-known producer and director in the region.

At present, he is working on a short film titled ‘Maha Natak’, which depicts the slow death of theatre in the country. It will be released on World Theatre Day on March 27. “The aim of the film is to show how we are losing our identity under the influence of western culture,” said Patnaik.

Though producing and directing short films is not commercially profitable, the young filmmaker keeps at it simply to make a difference, and create awareness on social issues. “Depending on the needs of the script, I spend between Rs 10,000 and Rs 1.50 lakh on making each film. I have never thought much of the returns,” he Award-added.

Title: Bags with power banks run risk of being left behind, warn airlines
Content:
Photo for representative purpose only

KOLKATA : Airlines are planning to withhold checked-in bags containing power banks and other restricted items once the inline baggage screening system is commissioned between February 20 and 28 this year.The airlines will, however, issue a last minute warning to passengers when they drop their bags at the check-in counters.“If there is sufficient time between the inline screener flagging off a bag with a power bank and the flight’s departure, the airline will make an attempt to escort the passenger to the basement to open the bag and remove the restricted item. Otherwise, the bag will simply be held back. Under no circumstance a flight will be delayed to clear such a bag,” an airline official told TOI.The decision follows the bitter experience of airlines in Delhi and Mumbai two years ago when detection of a large number of power banks inside bags during inline screenning had led to massive flight hold-ups. “Till now, screeners at standalone X-ray machines ask passengers to remove restricted items from checked in bags before they are deposited at check-in counters. But once inline is commissioned, passengers will not get any prior warning,” said said the official. With Kolkata airport handling a larger number of first-time and infrequent flyers than Delhi or Mumbai, airline officials are worried low awareness on restricted items for checked-in baggage could many bags being flagged off when inline screening is in operation.To prevent flight delay, IndiGo — the largest carrier operating out of Kolkata with over 100 flights daily — plans to warn passengers at bag drop point (check-in counter) that their bags may be withheld if they contain a power bank. The airline asks passengers in Delhi and Mumbai to provide a declaration so that they are aware of the consequence.“We will paste stickers on the checked-in bags and on the reverse of the boarding card. We hope it will act as a final reminder for passengers to take the power bank out in case it is there. If a bag is withheld, the passenger will have to claim it later,” said an official of another airline. A senior airport official said they have also suggested the airlines to engage their staff to manually remind passengers during the initial days of the switch-over to ensure a seamless change into the inline system.The other major challenge in the migration to the new system is the need for baggage handlers to be disciplined.“In the run-up to the roll-out, we will undertake trial runs in the domestic as well as international wing to check the preparedness,” said an airport official.

Title: 7.2kg gold seized at SVPI airport, six held
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: In a major operation, officials of Ahmedabad customs booked 13 cases in the wee hours of Saturday, wherein 7.2kg smuggled gold was seized. This is the fourth case of gold seizure since January reported at Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International (SVPI) airport in Ahmedabad and six persons have been arrested by Ahmedabad customs. According to customs officials, the seized gold was valued at Rs 3.06 crore.

“The incident took place in the wee hours of Saturday, wherein some 13 passengers coming from different destinations were booked from the SVPI airport. Most of them were from middle-eastern countries including Sharjah and Dubai in the UAE along with Doha in Qatar and Kuwait. Some passengers were also from Bangkok,” said a well-placed source.

The passengers belonged mainly to Kerala, Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh. Three of these passengers were booked based on prior inputs whereas the rest were booked based on spot intelligence.

Upon investigation, it was found that multiple modus operandi were used to smuggle the gold. “Some passengers were carrying gold in paste form concealed in their rectums. Some other passengers were also carrying gold in their clothing including socks, trousers, jackets, jeans and even undergarments,” the source further added.

In fact, some passengers were also carrying gold in the support structure of trolley bags. According to Ahmedabad customs, only 6 of the 13 passengers who were booked were arrested, because the gold that they were carrying was valued less than amounts that merited arrest.

Further investigation is in progress in respective cases, confirmed senior officials of Ahmedabad customs.

Prior to these cases reported recently, Ahmedabad customs had registered some 113 cases of gold smuggling between April 1, 2019 and January 31, 2020, and seized 77kg gold worth Rs 27.11 crore from Ahmedabad and Surat airports. Majority of the apprehended passengers arrived from Dubai, Sharjah, Oman, Kuwait and Bangkok, customs officials said.

Sources also said that cases of gold smuggling have gone up with the rise in gold prices and high basic customs duty on gold which stands at 12.5% as on date. Gold price stood at Rs 42,040 per 10 gram in the Ahmedabad market on Monday.

Title: Design of nine circles will be altered for swift traffic movement
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Jaipur: Based on the suggestions received from the steering committee, the Jaipur Development Authority ( JDA ) has initiated work at major nine circle intersections and junctions of the city for swift traffic flow and make them accident-free.

The work of improving design of JDA circle has been started to prevent accidents . An official said, the design of island, median, zebra crossing and pole at the circle intersection will be rectified to prevent accidents.

After a survey, the committee constituted to improve traffic conditions suggested to alter the design of JDA Circle Square, OTS Circle Square, Rambagh Square, Collectorate Circle, Jawahar Circle, Riddhi-Siddhi Junction, Mansarovar Metro Station and B-2 Bypass, New Sanganer Road Junction.

An official said, “An amount of Rs 1.42 crore has been approved. The work will be completed in six months. After the steering committee constituted under the Traffic Control Board submitted suggestions for the prevention of accidents the work was started.”

The official added that to provide clear visibility from Ambedkar Circle and Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC) office, the civic body at Rambagh had earlier reduced the size of the railing and chopped the plants and trees. Similar exercise was carried out at JDA Circle. “It was also suggested to reduce the width of the slip lane to 5-7 metre connecting Ambedkar Circle Road and JMC office road,” said a JDA engineer.

The experts of four departments and CEG and L&T firm, after recent accidents, also suggest construction of flyovers at three junctions, including Rambagh, JDA Circle road and OTS Circle. According to the Indian Road Congress (IRC), a flyover should be built if any junction has over 10,000 passenger car units (PCU) crossing it in an hour. The committee had recommended to construct flyovers at these three points. “A proposal to construct a flyover at Rambagh is long pending. However, it was shelved due to lack of funds,” sources said.

Title: Tik Tok effect: Six held for parading man naked on road
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Jaipur: Six persons were arrested on Monday on charges of publicly parading a youth naked for making a TikTok video with a minor girl in Jawahar Nagar here.

The FIR named three persons, including the minor girl’s brother, but police arrested six persons included those who were seen in the video watching the parade .

Nine persons have already been identified in the video, which had gone viral. The brother of the girl, Sunny, is still absconding. An FIR has also been filed by the minor girl for posting the video on a social media app.

DCP (Jaipur-East) Rahul Jain said Vinay Sharma (18) on Saturday had filed a complaint at Jawahar Nagar police station accusing some youths of parading him naked at Tila number 3 of Jawahar Nagar. In the FIR, he mentioned that the incident happened on Friday around 1.30pm. Sharma alleged that the accused paraded him naked on the road and took him to his house and the entire episode was captured in the video. The police have registered an FIR under Section 143 (unlawful assembly), 342 (wrongful confinement), Section 323 (Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt) of IPC and section 66(E) of IT Act.

Police said Vinay had posted a video on TikTok with the minor girl, which the girl’s family objected. Police said the girl and the boy were known to each other. ACP (Adarsh Nagar) Pushpendra Singh is investigating the case.

Police said that on Friday afternoon, the girl’s brother asked Vinay to come at a garment shop in Jawahar Nagar from where they took him to Suraj maidan from where he was taken to Tila number 3 on his bike.
