Another youth Anil forced Vinay to take off his clothes and Sunny allegedly captured the video of the entire episode. He was also allegedly beaten with belts. Others identified as Arjun alias Sumit, Arjun Sarwal, Dilip Singh and others were also watching the incident.

Police said they have arrested key accused Anil and five others. Police have recovered two motorbikes used in the crime.

Title: Gujarat high court stays intake at preschool inside society
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat high court has stayed a preschool from admitting kids for the next academic year, 2020-21, after the housing society, where the school is located, took exception to the “commercial activity”.

The case involves a chain of preschool facilities, Lampros Kids, which has a branch situated at Jivan Prakash Co-operative Housing Society Ltd in Navrangpura area. The residents of the housing society raised objection to the preschool run in the residential area. They approached the board of nominee demanding that the preschool facility should be shut because it is a commercial use of property. They argued that carrying out any commercial activity in the society without permission of the society is against the provisions of cooperative laws.

The board of nominee ordered a status quo, but the residents were not satisfied with the order and approached the high court. A single-judge bench’s direction to the board of nominee to take decision on the dispute within six months also did not pacify them. They filed an appeal before the division bench demanding closure of the school contending that the commercial activity cannot be permitted in residential area.

The bench headed by the Chief Justice ordered the school not to grant new admission to kids for 2020-21 because the school told the court that there would not be any children left in the school on conclusion of the ongoing academic session.

This arrangement is to last till the board of nominee finally decides the dispute whether the school can be run in the society.

There are similar cases of residents of cooperative societies taking exception to use of houses or bungalows by the owners to earn from the rent. They have objected to running of hostels or paying guest facilities in housing societies without permission from a majority of residents.

Title: AAP vigil outside strongrooms and counting centres
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

New Delhi: Aam Aadmi Party candidates and their election agents have been tasked to maintain a vigil at the 21 centres at 11 districts across the city where the 92.5 lakh votes polled in the assembly election will be counted on Tuesday. AAP national convener Arvind Kejriwal will monitor the results from the party headquarters.

The focus will be on the war room at AAP’s office from where key functionaries will be monitoring the results and remaining in touch with all 70 candidates to get feedback in real-time. Senior AAP functionaries will be present at the headquarters. AAP volunteers, who are hopeful of the party winning the elections , are also expected to gather there.

An average of the exit polls has predicted that the broom (AAP’s symbol) will sweep Delhi on February 11. Some of the exit polls even predicted that AAP will repeat its 2015 landslide victory when it had bagged 67 out of 70 seats.

A huge number of AAP volunteers had come to Delhi from different parts of the country to participate in the poll process. They have planned to return only after the results are announced as they want to join in the celebrations, said party sources.

Meanwhile, on Kejriwal’s instructions, AAP’s volunteers are keeping a strict vigil outside the strongrooms across the city where the EVMs have been stored to ensure there is no “tampering” of the machines. Party functionaries are concerned about the security of EVMs and are not letting their guard down. “We have deployed around 20 volunteers outside each strongroom to keep a vigil round the clock in shifts,” said a senior party functionary.

In many constituencies, the contest is reportedly very close. Impressive voting has taken place in favour of both AAP and BJP and, in some areas, for Congress too.

Title: Subsidy on multi agri connections may end
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Patiala: Congress government is now considering a proposal floated by the Punjab State Power Corporation Limited (PSPCL) to cut down power subsidy bill by withdrawing free power to multiple agriculture pumpset (AP) connections held by rich farmers.

The proposal, drafted by the PSPCL, has been sent to the state government. The power corporation has found that there are around 83,000 farmers in the state who are enjoying free power on two or more than two tubewells, taking the total number of such connections to over 1.8 lakh. No final decision has been taken by the state government in the matter. None of the senior officials of the PSPCL were available for comments on the issue.

The report says while a large number of farmers have upto two tubewell connections, there are others who have four and even more than four tubewell connections on which power bill is being paid by the state government. Going by the calculations, if free power is withdrawn and multiple agricultural connections to these farmers, some of whom are big politicians in Punjab, the PSPCL can bring down the subsidy bill of the state government by at least Rs 450 crore.

It will be a fraction of the Rs 9,674.5 crore subsidy bill that the government doles out to various categories of consumers in Punjab with Rs 6,060.27 crore being given to the agriculture sector. However, it can help the PSPCL mop some revenue and lessen its financial burden. The state government is already considering withdrawing power subsidy to rich farmers. The move was prompted by the 30p hike in per-unit cost of power in the state allowed by the Punjab State Electricity Regulatory Commission (PSERC) after the PSPCL moved a petition claiming recovery of Rs 1,490 crore paid to the two case II power plants in the state against coal washing charges.

Sources in the state government said, “As the issue is politically sensitive and can trigger farmers’ backlash, the government is treading cautiously and is exploring all possible ways to cut down the subsidy bill and not annoy a large section of the farming community.

As per a report by Chandigarh-based research institution, the Centre for Research in Rural and Industrial Development (CRRID), the government can save up to Rs 4,848.216 crore if it withdraws free power to medium and rich farmers, who constitute more than 80% of the total farming community in the state. It has been recommended that free power should only be for small and marginal farmers so as to help them limit the agricultural input costs.

Title: SAD to Jakhar: Why go easy on plants?
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Chandigarh: The Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) on Monday said Punjab Congress president Sunil Jakhar, who had expressed concern over pollution by the Talwandi Sabo thermal plant, should explain why his own party’s government had recommended the plant be given extension to install anti-pollution devices. SAD leader Prem Singh Chandumajra said this was the second time Jakhar had tried to divert attention from the Rs 4,100-crore power scam and haste shown by the Congress government in protecting the interests of private thermal plants. “Why is he (Jakhar) silent about the Rs 4,100-crore power scam? Why hasn’t he taken his case for action in the matter to chief minister or Congress president Rahul Gandhi?” said Chandumajra

Title: Man held for producing ‘fake complainants’
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

VISAKHAPATNAM: A man accused of producing fake complainants in court and orchestrating a compromise, and his two associates were arrested on Monday.

The city police on Monday said that one Adari Ravi Kumar was under trial in two cases in ADM court (III) in Visakhapatnam city. However, Ravi Kumar conspired to close both cases with the help of two others at the recently concluded Lok Adalat in the city.

The police said Ravi attached the photos of Sanapal Santosh from Hyderabad and Andraju Ravi Kumar, but with the Aadhaar copies of the original complainants on the letter of compromise. The names of the original complainants were Aditya and Siva Teja. Ravi Kumar instead brought in his friends to impersonate as the complainants.

At the Lok Adalat process, some officials noticed the differences in the signatures of the two impersonators with those of the actual complainants on the case files. On questioning, the trio managed to escape. The trio was arrested based on a complaint.

Title: Setback for ‘saffron camp’ in Tolly polls
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Sankar Chakraborty (second from left), Arindam Ganguly (third from left) after the poll results were declared ... Read More

KOLKATA: In what has been described as one of the most talked-about polls of Tollywood ’s West Bengal Motion Picture Artists’ Forum involving 1,896 voters, none of the artistes, who joined Bharatiya Janata Party ( BJP ) or renewed their membership last July, has been elected.

However, none of them used their party colours while contesting the polls. They hope that their vote-share will increase significantly, if they can work for the members of the industry.

Soumitra Chatterjee had been re-elected uncontested for the post of president. Tapas Chakraborty and Soham Bandyopadhyay were elected as treasurer and assistant treasurer respectively. ·Jeet (1485 votes), Paran Bandyopadhyay (1460 votes) and Soham Chakraborty (1223 votes) were elected as vice-presidents. Arindam Ganguly (1539 votes) was re-elected as general secretary while Sankar Chakraborty (692 votes) was elected as the working president. ·Saptarshi Roy (1566 votes) and Santilal Mukherjee (1513 votes) were elected as joint secretaries. Debdut Ghosh (1064 votes) and Rana Mitra (737 votes) became assistant secretaries. ·Kushal Chakraborty (1297 votes), Sonali Chaudhury (918 votes), June Maliah (879 votes), Sagnik (810 votes) and Diganta Bagchi (805 votes) were elected to the five-member executive council.

In July last year, 11 actors from Tollywood had joined the BJP at the party’s Delhi headquarters while two others (Anjana Basu and Kaushik Chakraborty) renewed their membership. Among the new entrants were Kanchana Moitra, Rupanjana Mitra, Parno Mittra, Lama, Biswajit Ganguly, Moumita Gupta, Sourav Chakraborty, Anindya Pulak Banerjee, Debranjan Nag, Rrishii Kaushik and Rupa Bhattcharya . From this list, Sunday’s polls saw the likes of Rupa Bhattacharya, Anjana Basu, Lama, Anindya Banerjee and Kaushik Chakraborty in contention.

However, Monday’s result sheet wasn’t flattering for any of them with Anjana (295 votes), Rupa (459 votes), Lama (505 votes), Anindya (575 votes) and Kaushik (711 votes) not managing to bag any win. Actor-turned-BJP member Kanchana Moitra, who voted for the elections, refuses to see this as a setback. “It is the first time that Lama had contested and he got 505 votes. That is a good number for a first-timer. People voted because Rupa worked to get the dues of television artistes. If they continue with their work, their votes are bound to increase next time,” Moitra said.

According to Kaushik, his intention of contesting the polls was to “depoliticise the forum”. “Though I am a BJP member, I have voted for Soham because he can do better for the industry. I do not want any polarisation inside the forum or a particular lobby to make a clean sweep . Unless we can counter a lobby, we can’t make this forum apolitical,” Kaushik said.

Though Rupa isn’t ready to look at the polls through the political prism, Lama feels his saffron allegiance might have been an important factor. Not unhappy with his performance at the polls, he said, “This forum doesn’t have any political colour and I was not contesting as a party representative. I didn’t campaign and yet people voted for me because I am accessible and they know that I want to work for the industry. After joining politics, I have the colour of the saffron brigade. That too could be a reason for me not having won the elections.”

Title: Gujarat ATS arrests key accused in 1993 Mumbai blasts
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Gujarat ATS arrests accused of 1993 Mumbai blasts Munaf Halari Moosa at Mumbai Airport on Monday (ANI)

AHMEDABAD: After being on the run for nearly 28 years, Munaf Halari Abdul Majeed, alias Moosa, 56, a key accused in the 1993 Mumbai serial blasts , was arrested by the Gujarat ATS from Mumbai airport. He was in transit while travelling from Nairobi to Dubai when he was intercepted and held by ATS officials on Sunday night.

Top officials said that Halari is a close aide of Tiger Memon, the architect of Mumbai serial blasts, and was travelling on a Pakistani passport. Moosa had purporterdly taken the long route to meet his associates in Mumbai but was caught. A Red Corner Notice had been issued against Halari on the request of CBI as he had allegedly bought three scooters and placed them at strategic locations after loading them with explosives. A blast had taken place in one of the three scooters at Zaveri Bazaar.

The blasts in Mumbai on March 12, 1993, led to the death of 257 persons, injured 713 persons and caused destruction of property worth more than Rs 27 crore.

Deputy inspector general of police (DIG) ATS Himanshu Shukla said that Halari was picked up following a tip-off received by Gujarat ATS. “Halari was brought to Ahmedabad on Monday morning. He will soon be handed over to CBI for further investigation’, said Shukla.

DSP ATS, K K Patel, said that after the blasts, Halari had fled to Bareilly in UP from where he escaped overseas to Bangkok. He is reported to have then fled to Nairobi after Tiger Memon arranged a Pakistani passport for him. He has been living in Nairobi, Kenya, under the assumed identity of a Pakistani national, Anwar Muhammad, son of Abdul Majeed with passport No. BMI 799983 since nearly 27 years now. Cops said that Halari set up an export-import business of grains, mainly rice, in the name of Magnum Africa. “This was done at the behest of Memon and is suspected to be a front for smuggling erxplosives and contraband to India,” said a senior police official.

Gujarat ATS officials said they were on the trail of Halari as their information revealed that he was found active in narco-terrorism after his name had cropped up during the interrogation of five Pakistanis caught from the high seas near Gujarat coast involving seizure of 35kg heroin.

The Pakistani boat’s crew, arrested on January 5, had revealed that Halari was in touch with their boss, Haji Hasan of Karachi, to send arms and explosives into Gujarat. He was nabbed after specific input of travel to India in February.

Title: Parents protest against school fee hike
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Jaipur: Parents of students studying in the Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan's Vidyashram , Jaipur, gathered outside the school premises to protest over the fee hike issue on Monday.

Many parents have refused to pay the hiked fees since October 2019 in protest. Parents accused the school authorities of threatening to debar their wards from sitting in the exam until the fees were paid.

School’s principal Pratima Sharma, however, claimed there was no such protest. “There is no protest in the school and most of the parents have already paid the fees. The matter is sub-judice in Rajasthan High Court and we will take any action only after the decision,” Sharma told TOI.

Dinesh Surana, a parent, said the school increased fee last year although the case was sub-judice in the high court. “They hike fees even after knowing that the matter regarding it is sub-judice. We were demanding a school fees committee in which parents be made members as per the Fees Act 2016. School authorities have not complied with it,” said Dinesh.

Ragiv Aggarwal, another parent, said when parents refused to pay fees the school has threatened to take action against the students. “When the matter is sub-judice school cannot take action against us. They should wait for the judgement and any threatening message will not be acceptable,” said Rajiv.

Title: Lahore court to hear Nankana Sahib Sikh girl’s case on Feb 13
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Amritsar: Sikh girl Jagjit Kaur of Nankana Sahib, Pakistan, will have to stay longer at Dar-ul-Aman, a shelter for women in Lahore, after a local court on Monday fixed February 13 for the verdict in the case.

Her counsel Mohammed Sultan Sheikh told TOI over phone from Lahore on Monday that Jagjit’s brother Manmohan Singh had filed a complaint against her Muslim husband, Mohammad Hasan, for sending objectionable messages to them.

Sheikh said the cyber cell of Nankana Sahib police had registered a case against Hasan and began an investigation. He alleged that Jagjit’s family was adopting delaying tactics, even as the girl had recorded her statement in court that she didn't want to go back to her parents, but wanted to start her married life with Hasan.

On August 28, 2019, Jagjit adopted Islam to become Ayesha Bibi, and the next day she married Hasan according to Islamic rituals. However, her family lodged a complaint with police, claiming that Jagjit was abducted and converted to Islam, and married Hasan against her and their consent.

Title: Arora writes to Sonia over power pacts
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Chandigarh: Accusing the Congress government in Punjab of not fulfilling its election promise of scrapping or reviewing power purchase agreements (PPAs) with private thermal power plants, Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) MLA Aman Arora has sought Congress president Sonia Gandhi’s intervention.

In a letter to Sonia on Monday, Arora demanded that she should direct Punjab chief minister Amarinder Singh to fulfil the election promise and scrap agreements. “I wish to draw your attention to an issue of urgent public importance related to future generations of Punjab. AAP has been raising the issue since the formation of the Congress government at all platforms, but to no avail.” added the letter.

“The stand of AAP seems to be validated by a few conscious senior Congress leaders like state president Sunil Jakhar, cabinet minister Sukhjinder Singh Randhawa, Rajya Sabha MPs Partap Singh Bajwa and Shamsher Singh Dullo, who have been demanding scrapping of the PPAs,” said Arora.

Title: Farmers move HC, seek payment from CRDA
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

VIJAYAWADA: A group of farmers in the Amaravati capital region moved the Andhra Pradesh high court demanding compensation from Andhra Pradesh Capital Region Development Authority ( APCRDA ).

The HC bench headed by Justice Satyanarayana Murthy on Monday heard seven petitions filed by farmers on various issues related to development of the capital region.

One of the petitioners argued that APCRDA had promised to develop returnable plots within three years of the completion of the land pooling process. But it failed to create infrastructure in the layouts and handover the plots to farmers. The petitioner demanded a monthly compensation of Rs 30 per square yard for residential plots and Rs 50 per square yard for commercial plots.

Another petitioner wanted APCRDA to develop the plots as soon as possible.

The HC has sought APCRDA’s response and posted the case to February 24.

Meanwhile, the HC heard petitions challenging the introduction of English medium in government schools.

Title: Punjab: Two years after minor’s rape, singer arrested
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

Title: Three held for transporting 200kg heroin to Punjab from Gujarat
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

The accused in police custody

AHMEDABAD: Three drug traffickers, Razak Sumra 41, of Mandvi , Karim Siraj, 34, of Gandhidham and Sunil Barmase, 39, also from Gandhidham were arrested from Kutch by Gujarat ATS on Sunday. The arrests came after Punjab police seized 188kg of a 200kg heroin consignment sent from Gujarat to Punjab on January 31. The truck carrying the consignment for drug lord Simranjit Singh Sandhu’s men was apprehended at Bhatinda, Punjab. On information received from Punjab police, Gujarat ATS acted and arrested the three accused.

ATS officials said they had been receiving information about movements of drug traffickers near Mandvi in Kutch for about two to three months. “During that period Punjab STF caught 188 kg of heroin from Bhatinda. The probe revealed that the stuff had gone through Kutch coast of Gujarat. We learnt through informers that the stuff was taken to Amritsar and Punjab in trucks,” said an ATS official.

DIG, ATS, Himanshu Shukla said the accused confessed that about 500kg of heroin had been offloaded at Chachi Port at different times . Out of thes,e 300kg was taken by cars to Unjha and then transported with cumin to Punjab. “The rest 200 kg was hidden in Mandvi. This was then loaded on trucks and taken to Punjab. However, out of 200kg, 188 kg heroin was caught by Punjab STF on January 31,” Shukla said.

Title: Rural connectivity project on track after brief pause
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: The interior road connectivity project being taken up in Visakhapatnam Agency has re-started after a brief halt. Work for the construction of connecting roads to interior villages stopped last year as the government was struggling to pay for convergence projects.

However, dues under NREGS for road construction projects were cleared recently. Thus, construction work aimed at bringing people in the margins to the mainstream has begun again.

Sources in the engineering wing of the tribal welfare department informed that nearly 1,200 hamlets and around 12,000 households are going to benefit from the connectivity project. Taken up in 2017, around 709 roads are being built stretching across 107km, added the sources.

Speaking to TOI, DK Balaji , project officer of ITDA said, “This connectivity project is important because it will help those living in interior areas and villages connect to other areas. These roads should be pliable for four-wheelers as well as two-wheelers.”

The project officer said that all previous dues for the road convergence projects have been cleared. “Work is being taken up after the project was reviewed by the state government in July, 2019. Projects were reviewed and new proposals made. After which, we have begun work.”

Title: Pakistan-based KLF behind narco-terror network, says NIA
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Mohali: The National Investigation Agency (NIA) on Monday told a special NIA court that Pakistan-based Khalistan Liberation Force (KLF) chief has been instrumental in running cross-border narco-terrorism in the country.

The premier investigating agency revealed this in the court while seeking police custody of three accused — Nirmal Singh, Satpal Singh and Hiralal, arrested in connection with the Amritsar heroine haul case of 2019. The court subsequently granted seven-day police custody of the accused till February 17.

Presenting its case for police remand, the NIA told the court that during the investigation, role of Harmeet Singh alias PHD, Pakistan-based chief of KLF, a proscribed terrorist organisation, has emerged in running a cross-border narco-terror network through drug smugglers, militant elements and hawala operatives based in Punjab and other states of India. Harmeet Singh is believed to have been killed in Pakistan recently, the agency said.

The case pertains to the arrest of three accused with 500 gm of heroin and Rs 1,20,000 drug money, over which an FIR was registered on May 31, 2019 at Tarsikka police station in Amritsar under sections 21 and 29 of the NDPS Act. Later, three more suspects in the case were arrested in the December last year.

Thereafter, the NIA re-registered the case on January 22, 2020 under sections 13 and 17 of the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act, and sections 21 and 29 of the NDPS Act and took over the case for investigation.

Title: Patiala Farmers say tomato crop hit by bad weather, officials unaware
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

The affected tomato crop in Sanaur on Monday

PATIALA: Several farmers in villages of Sanaur area in Patiala district on Monday claimed that their tomato crop had been damaged by the blight disease, triggered by bad weather and fog. However, horticulture department officials claimed that they were unaware of any such reports.

The farmers alleged that the bad weather led to crop damage in Asarpur, Jogipur, Kartarpur, Nurkhedi, Budhanpur Basar and a few other villages. They said horticulture officials should visit them and assess losses. They also demanded compensation from the state government. In Sanaur division, tomato is grown on around 500 acres. Gurvinder Singh, farmer in Asarpur village, around 10km away from Patiala, said, “In our village, the tomato crop has been sown in around 50 of the total 100 acres has been completely damaged. The crop takes four months to be harvested. We had sprayed chemicals on the crop to save it from the diseases, but bad weather ruined everything.”

Another farmer, Surinder Singh, said he had sown the crop on more than four acres, but it was damaged by the blight disease. Sanaur MLA Harinder Pal Singh Chandumajra of SAD visited some of the affected villages and demanded girdawari (revenue assessment) for crop losses.

Patiala deputy director of horticulture Swaran Singh Mann said no farmers had visited the department or informed it about the crop loss. “We are unaware about any damage to tomato crop. We will send the officials soon to look into the matter.”

Title: Donald Trump India visit: White House announces Trump visit to India on February 24-25
Content:
US President Donald Trump and First Lady Melania Trump will visit India on February 24-25, the White House has... Read More

President @realDonaldTrump & @FLOTUS will travel to India from February 24-25 to visit Prime Minister @narendramodi… https://t.co/qJdvS9duwz — The White House (@WhiteHouse) 1581368732000

WASHINGTON: The White House on Monday formally announced that U.S President Donald Trump and First Lady Melania Trump would visit India on February 24-25, with stops in New Delhi and Ahmedabad."The President and The First Lady will travel to New Delhi and Ahmedabad, which is in Prime Minister Modi’s home state of Gujarat and played such an important role in Mahatma Gandhi’s life and leadership of the Indian independence movement," a White House release said, adding that during a phone call over the weekend, Trump and Modi agreed the trip will "further strengthen the United States-India strategic partnership and highlight the strong and enduring bonds between the American and Indian people."Separately, officials in New Delhi also revealed that it would be a “State visit” — which involves pomp and ceremony — at Prime Minister Modi’s invitation, and the President and the First Lady “will attend official engagements in New Delhi and Ahmedabad, Gujarat, and interact with a wide cross-section of Indian society.”This will be Trump's first visit to India as President and one of his rare solo bilateral visits with the First Lady. Neither side made any mention of a widely-anticipated stopover at Agra’s Taj Mahal, an enduring symbol of love and togetherness that has been so appealing to Trump in the past that he named one of properties (Trump Tajmahal in Atlantic City) after it.Both sides also appeared to have abjured a US Presidential address to the Indian Parliament, an item that was part of Democratic Presidential visits (Jimmy Carter 1978, Bill Clinton 2000, and Barack Obama 2010) but which George Bush skipped during his 2006 visit. Dwight Eisenhower was the last Republican President to address the Indian parliament in 1959.It was however confirmed that the President would visit Ahmedabad, where plans are afoot to host a rousing "Kem Cho, Trump! (Howdy Trump) rally to return the gesture of the Trump administration allowing the Howdy Modi fiesta in Houston — the largest rally ever by a foreign leader on US soil.The two leaders are expected to inaugurate the Motera Stadium, one of the world's largest sports arenas with a capacity of 110,000, although local reports suggest it will be a race against time to complete it by February 25.The most likely backdrop for a walkthrough and informal talks will be the Sabarmati waterfront, one of Modi's signature achievements in his home state.Besides the adrenalin of a India-sized rally that is expected to wow Trump, who loves large adoring crowds, the two sides are also expected to ink a trade deal and agreements aimed at boosting Indian purchase of US armaments, including a $2 billion value NASAMS air defense system and $2.6 billion naval helicopter deal.India is also ramping up energy purchase from the US that has gone from zero a decade ago to $6 billion annually, and is expected to touch $10 billion in the next couple of years.“The global strategic partnership between India and the US is based on trust, shared values, mutual respect and understanding, and marked by warmth and friendship between the peoples of the two countries. The relationship has further evolved under the leadership of Prime Minister Modi and President Trump, with significant progress in all areas including trade, defence, counter-terrorism, energy, coordination on regional and global issues as well as people-to-people ties. The visit will provide an opportunity for the two leaders to review progress in bilateral ties and further strengthen our strategic partnership,” a statement from the Indian Prime Minister’s office said.Read this story in Bengali

Neither side made any mention of a widely-anticipated stopover at Agra’s Taj Mahal, an enduring symbol of love and togetherness that has been so appealing to Trump in the past that he named one of properties (Trump Tajmahal in Atlantic City) after it.Both sides also appeared to have abjured a US Presidential address to the Indian Parliament, an item that was part of Democratic Presidential visits (Jimmy Carter 1978, Bill Clinton 2000, and Barack Obama 2010) but which George Bush skipped during his 2006 visit. Dwight Eisenhower was the last Republican President to address the Indian parliament in 1959.It was however confirmed that the President would visit Ahmedabad, where plans are afoot to host a rousing "Kem Cho, Trump! (Howdy Trump) rally to return the gesture of the Trump administration allowing the Howdy Modi fiesta in Houston — the largest rally ever by a foreign leader on US soil.The two leaders are expected to inaugurate the Motera Stadium, one of the world's largest sports arenas with a capacity of 110,000, although local reports suggest it will be a race against time to complete it by February 25.The most likely backdrop for a walkthrough and informal talks will be the Sabarmati waterfront, one of Modi's signature achievements in his home state.Besides the adrenalin of a India-sized rally that is expected to wow Trump, who loves large adoring crowds, the two sides are also expected to ink a trade deal and agreements aimed at boosting Indian purchase of US armaments, including a $2 billion value NASAMS air defense system and $2.6 billion naval helicopter deal.India is also ramping up energy purchase from the US that has gone from zero a decade ago to $6 billion annually, and is expected to touch $10 billion in the next couple of years.“The global strategic partnership between India and the US is based on trust, shared values, mutual respect and understanding, and marked by warmth and friendship between the peoples of the two countries. The relationship has further evolved under the leadership of Prime Minister Modi and President Trump, with significant progress in all areas including trade, defence, counter-terrorism, energy, coordination on regional and global issues as well as people-to-people ties. The visit will provide an opportunity for the two leaders to review progress in bilateral ties and further strengthen our strategic partnership,” a statement from the Indian Prime Minister’s office said.Read this story in Bengali

Title: Crops on 1.49 lakh hectare hit due to locust attacks: Minister
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Jaipur: Crops in over 1.49 lakh hectares have been damaged in various districts because of locust attacks since May and around Rs 90 crore has been provided as subsidy to the affected farmers, agriculture minister Lalchand Kataria told the assembly on Monday.

The minister said locust control programme was carried out in about 5. 29 lakh hectares and due to a joint effort of the state and the Centre, they were able to prevent the spread of pests to other states.

He, however, said no significant damage was caused to kharif crop because of prompt action by the authorities when swarms of locusts entered Jaisalmer on May 21.

“Fresh locust swarms entered the country in December 2019 due to wind intensity and lack of effective control over locusts by Pakistan,” he said amid the BJP criticism that the state did not take timely action to tackle the problem.

He said crops on 1,49,881 hectares — 54,989 hectares in Jaisalmer, 53,682 hectares in Jalore, 33,788 hectares in Barmer, 2,549 hectares in Bikaner, 2,308 hectares in Jodhpur — was damaged.

He said till date the locust control exercise had been taken up on 5,29,602 hectares and pesticides were given to farmers at 100 per cent subsidy.

Kataria said over 33% loss of crops, Rs 13,500 per hectare up to two hectares for irrigated land and Rs 6,800 for non- irrigated areas were given to affected farmers.

Earlier, deputy leader of the opposition, Rajendra Rathore, said the state government could shy away from its responsibility. They demanded waiver of power bills for a year to affected farmers and adequate compensation.

Some members demanded that the state government should carry out a study on the negative impact of the large-scale spraying of insecticides and pesticides.

On this, chief minister Ashok Gehlot intervened and said he was speaking without complete knowledge.

Gehlot said, “Your Union minister in the Rajya Sabha has said the Rajasthan government did the best job in locust control. Even if you don't believe us, trust the Union minister of your government.”

Title: Applicants suffer due to shortage of cards at RTO
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Indore: It’s something or the other. After shortage of smart cards halting work of Indore RTO around a month ago, it’s now shortage of cards that has now apparently affected vehicle registration work for past 20 days or more.

Over 5000 registration certificate (RC) applications are pending due to unavailability of cards, claimed sources. Officials engaged in work complained that delay in clearing pending applications is putting them under pressure even as they struggle with shortage of cards.

The applicants can be seen running pillar to post on any given day at RTO to obtain RCs of their newly purchased vehicles.

Rakesh Kumar of Vijay Nagar said that he had bought a two-wheeler in second week of January. “The dealer had applied for my vehicle’s registration, but I haven’t received it yet. Even officials at RTO are not ready to explain about the reason behind the delay,” he said.

Sources claimed that even applications that have already been processed and cards have been generated, officials are not ready to issue it. “They are not able to take record of applications owing to increase in pendency, and this is leading to delay in issuance of cards,” they said. RTO officials refuted the allegations and said that there is no major delay. “RCs are delivered within 30 days and applicants who have not received their RCs can approach senior officials,” said Archana Mishra, an assistant regional transport officer with Indore RTO.

She however admitted slight delay in printing of cards due to limited supply and said that issue would be addressed soon. “The staff engaged in processing applications has also been instructed to speed up work to clear pendency,” she added.

On an average, Indore RTO receives around 500-700 applications of fresh and transfer of RCs. These cards are sent to applicants through speed post.

Title: IMC eyes Rs 100cr revenue from tax for diverted land
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Indore: To meet the annual revenue target of Rs 1161cr set by state government, Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) is now targeting at least Rs 100cr from owners of diverted lands of 29 villages that were included within municipal limits of Indore.

Exploring avenues to achieve the numbers, the corporation has issued a public notice instructing diverted land owners to get their property registered with IMC and pay due property tax.

Officials said that there are around 1000 such diverted lands of which accounts have yet not been opened.

“We conducted a survey of 29 villages and found that each of these villages have at least 30-40 diverted lands of which information is not available in IMC’s record,” IMC’s additional commissioner SK Chaitanya told TOI.

He said that apart from public notice, individual notices have also been sent to each of the identified plot owners instructing them to pay property tax of their respective land from 2014-15 – the year, when their property was included within municipal limits of Indore.

“All of them have been instructed to clear dues of their respective diverted land within the next 15 days. If they fail to do it, then IMC would start sealing their property,” he added.

Most of these properties fall under southern zones of city.

Corporation officials expect a recovery of at least Rs100 crore from these property. The corporation has so far collected around Rs280 crore as property tax and this action is seen as part of an ongoing recovery drive of corporation to achieve a target of Rs1161 crore set by state government.

The civic body has also launched a drive to identify power grids set up by Madhya Pradesh Vidyut Vitaran Company Ltd (MPPKVVCL) in 29 villages. Officials found that there are no records of some of grids set up on public space and discom was not paying tax against land on which grids have been installed.

Title: ‘Delhi win won’t help AAP much’
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Chandigarh: Punjab Congress president Sunil Jakhar on Monday said Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) could get a ‘second chance’ in Punjab if it won the Delhi assembly elections, but it would not be able to capitalise on it as its house was not in order in the state.

Talking to media on the sidelines of a press conference, Jakhar said in reply to a question on AAP: “Punjab was the only state where people gave AAP a chance, but they proved themselves to be a massive failure. In the last three years, they have nothing to redeem themselves. If one goes by the exit polls for Delhi elections, they may get another opportunity to prove themselves again, which I feel they won’t.” “They may get a second life. Otherwise they have been written off. I don’t think AAP will be able to use it (a win in Delhi) to its benefit,” he said.

Jakhar said a decision on rebel AAP leaders should have ideally been taken by now, but it was the prerogative of the assembly speaker. “Otherwise, I think people elected them and the way they (MLAs) have failed to performed in the three years, they are only exposing themselves,” he said.

Title: No private land will be acquired, assure minister
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: State tourism minister Muttamsetti Srinivasa Rao and minister for municipal administration Botcha Satyanarayana lashed out at the opposition on Monday and said that instead of backing corrupt officials, the opposition should support the government when it is taking action against such officials.

In two separate meetings in the city on Monday, the ministers alleged that former chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu was supporting corrupt officials and was blaming the government for taking action against them.

Saying that rumours are being spread about land pooling, the tourism minister said, “No private patta lands are being acquired. Only government and assigned land is. Moreover, in case of government land, encroachers are being provided 400 square yards, while in case of government land, assignees are being provided pattas for 900 sq yards.

M Srinivasa Rao further said that 25 lakh houses are being planned for the poor, of which 2.47 lakh will be in Visakhapatnam district and of that, 1.47 lakh will be within GVMC limits. Each beneficiary in the city will be provided 70 sq yard plots, he added.

Minister for municipal administration, Botcha Satyanarayana said 6,116 acres of government land has been identified within GVMC limits and clarified only those squatters who have occupied the land for at least 10 years will benefit.

Title: My stormy old friend Giriraj is no more
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

The death of a friend is like the loss of a limb’ goes a saying in the German. Today, as I hear about the passing away of Giriraj Kishore , I experienced the same feeling. When I first met the Hindi writer in Delhi, I was overwhelmed by his simplicity and commitment.

A Padma Shri awardee, the unadorned and unfussy writer was easy to befriend. Over the years, I lost touch with many of my friends, but Giriraj continued to remain close to me, perhaps because we shared ideological perspectives. A man of conviction and commitment, he was firm in his faith in the values he cherished. With no pretentions and no inhibitions, he always remained unassuming and undemanding.

When you go through his works Pahala Girmitiya and his latest novel, Baa, you realize how much he is immersed in the life and ideology of Mahatma Gandhi. As the author of the book, he maintained textbook objectivity, making the novel an authentic account of the years in the life of the Mahatma. Writing Baa must have been a difficult exercise for him, as he wrote about the bittersweet relationship the couple shared. A reading of Baa evokes sympathy for Kasturba to an extent the reader feels sorry for her and angry with Gandhi. When you are weighed down by the greatness of the Father of the Nation, it is indeed difficult to write about the shortcomings of the great man. But the author would have failed to uphold the truth as was perceived by Gandhi if he was to push the hardships faced by Kasturba under the carpet. I feel sorry that Giriraj did not live to see his novel Baa translated into Konkani.

As a valued colleague at the Sahitya Akademi and a close personal friend, I have been privy to his positive contribution to this premier institution of literature. He was invariably on his toes to praise good work and was critical of things that were not in the interest of literature. Edmund Burke once said, “For evil to flourish, all that is needed is for good people to do nothing”. Giriraj, my fellow writer, was not among the indifferent. When the situation demanded, he stood up unhesitatingly. This is yet another quality he had absorbed from his in-depth study of Gandhi.

In 2012, Giriraj returned the Padma Shri bestowed upon him by the government of India when Gandhi memorabilia was auctioned despite his protests. When Amitabh Bachchan was invited to a literary conference of the Vishwa Hindi Meet sidelining many Hindi writers, it was Giriraj who condemned the move. In 2015, after the death of M M Kalburgi, there was a spate of ‘award wapsis’. Here, too, Giriraj was at the forefront.

He would not tolerate any attack on freedom of expression, and neither would he accept ill-treatment to fellow writers who spoke for free speech. When I was in Delhi to participate in a panel discussion on ‘Sarkar v/s sahityakar’, organized live on a reputed TV channel, I was happy to find Giriraj on my team. He did not spare a single opportunity to air his views, whether or not they clashed with the establishment. In today’s India, when the very idea of free India is threatened, we breathe easy only because we have people who are on their toes to voice their concern for a united and secular India. With Giriraj Kishore gone, we will miss a stalwart to fight alongside.

Giriraj visited Goa several times at my invitation — on a couple of occasions with his better half, Meera. When the father figure of Goan writers, Ravindra Kelekar, was bestowed with the Sahitya Akademi’s fellowship, Giriraj was all praise for the candid and forthright speech by the Gandhian Kelekar. In April 2011, Giriraj inaugurated the All-India Konkani Sahitya Sammelan.

To date, writers in Goa continue to remember his words of wisdom. He attended the seventh edition of the Goa Art & Literature Festival. And two years ago, he visited Goa yet again to attend the Sangman conference. The stalwart will be remembered for both his literary contribution, as well as his fearlessness.

The writer is a Sahitya Akademi award-winning author

Title: Citrus cultivation can up farm income: Experts
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

VISAKAPATNAM: Horticulture experts in Visakhapatnam district are of the opinion that cultivation of citrus fruits can augment farm income and improve soil conservation practices in orchards in north Andhra Pradesh.

Citrus trees were traditionally grown in coconut plantations along the coastal belt of Visakhapatnam district but disappeared after the plantations were taken over for industry. The trees, which require shade, were easier to grow on coconut plantations where the canopy cover was greater than in traditional mango orchards. Experts said that at present, citrus trees can be grown on mango orchards as hybrid strains of the fruit are closely planted and provide a dense canopy, but added that ample water is also required.

“The problem with most mango orchards is that the owners do not utilise groundwater resources. We frequently request them to dig borewells, replenishment holes and also provide a 70 per cent subsidy to farmers for drip irrigation, but these are not done,” said K Sailaja , assistant director of the department of horticulture, Visakhapatnam.

Sources in the department said mixed cropping would provide farmers with a buffer income and also enrich the soil as leaves of citrus trees are rich in nutrients.

Farmer and soil conservationist D Srinivas from Jagammpeta in East Godavari district said, “Citrus leaves are soil enrichers and the compost helps the soil regain strength. It is also an excellent soil binder and requires little water. Citrus trees thrive in any orchard provided there is canopy cover and the soils are loamy and well-drained.”

K Sailaja added, “If farmers become aware of the advantages of planting citrus trees on their orchards and provide enough water, the north-coastal stretch could have mixed plantations that yield citrus fruit as well.”

Title: 200 policemen search for missing girl
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Jaipur: Recent cases of minor girls’ being raped in Jaipur, Churu and Sikar, have kept city police on toes.

On a missing report of an 11-year-old girl in Muhana police station limits, city police deployed a fleet of 200 policemen to search for the girl which ended around 7am on Monday when the girl was found sleeping at the doorsteps of a temple in Muhana area.

The girl left the house around 9pm. When her relatives filed the complaint, police launched a massive search to ward off any crime against the minor girl. Recently, a case of minor girl being raped in Murlipura gave sleepless night, but police managed to arrest the accused within 24 hours of the incident.

“The girl left the house by herself. She is mentally unstable. No crime has happened against her,” said Yogesh Dadhich, DCP, South Jaipur.

Police said the parents of the girl died recently and she is staying with her younger brother at her uncle’s house. “Since she was minor, we took it seriously and the higher officials deployed teams of 200 policemen in the area to search the girl. We searched her at railway tracks, temples, houses in the neighbourhood, streets and roads and around 7am, we found her sleeping outside a temple. She is safe,” said Heeralal Saini, station house officer, Muhana.

Police said it is not the first time that the girl went missing. But, this time around, she went far and since she did not come back and the family did not find her in nearby areas, they filed a missing report.

Title: IMC’s Vanchu Point guesthouse to open for public
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Indore: Indore Municipal Corporation’s luxurious guest house at Vanchu Point will soon become a prefect weekend getaway for Indoreans.

The civic body is going to lease out the facility to a private agency, which operate and maintain the facility as a hotel — a perfect place for picnickers planning short travel around the city.

A decision in this regard has been taken by corporation authorities to ensure proper maintenance of the rest house and also generate revenue.

IMC commissioner Asheesh Singh said that they are considering the option to hire a private agency to run the Vanchu Point guest house as a hotel.

“We are going to hand over this property on a 30-year lease to private party to run and maintain it. A fix annual premium would be collected from the agency with around 5 per cent increase per year,” Singh said.

“Tenders have already been invited and if all goes as per plan, the facility will be made open for public in April this year,” he added.

Officials said that it’s a seven-room rest house, which was developed in 1978 by public health engineering (PHE) department and the facility is now managed and run by IMC.

The agency will be allowed to renovate and operate the guest house as a hotel for tourists to stay.

For people of Indore and adjoining areas, Vanchu Point located atop hills on Narmada water supply route between Jalood and Indore and known for having a perfect sun set view, has always been a favourite destination for picnickers.

Madhya Pradesh State Tourism Development Corporation (MPSTDC) had earlier announced to develop this spot at a tourist destination. However the plan could never materialize.

Sources in MPSTDC said that the area sees tourists’ footfall only during monsoon and generating revenue from there by promoting it as a tourist spot for round the year was not found feasible.

Title: Man dupes people of Rs 11.5 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

VISAKHAPATNAM: The city’s cybercrime police, on Monday, arrested 32-year-old S Abdul Mufeez for duping people to the tune of Rs 11.5 lakh in the guise of selling them herbal products.

V Gopinath , an inspector at the city’s cybercrime police station, said Abdul Mufeez—a native of Kurnool—posted an advertisement in a newspaper for the recruitment of a distributor for herbal and ayurvedic products. A Md Hidayatullah from Vizag city came across the advertisement and contacted Adbul Mufeez, expressing interest. Later, Hidayatullah deposited Rs 1 lakh in Mufeez’s bank account for the herbal products and dealership of the products. When Hidayatullah didn’t get anything, he realized that he had been cheated.

Based on Hidayatullah’s complaint, police investigated the case and nabbed the accused. Investigation revealed that Mufeez has duped several people from parts of Vizag, East Godavari and Vizianagaram districts of Andhra Pradesh, as well as a few from parts of Telangana.

Gopinath said that Mufeez had duped people to the tune of Rs 11.5 lakh by assuring them of dealership of the herbal products. Police have recovered Rs 34,000 cash and three mobile phones from the accused. They are still investigating the case to zero in on the exact number of the victims.

Title: Rajasthan: Now, pay through your nose for booze from April
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: After rumours of liquor ban in Rajasthan abounded following the visit of a team of officials to Bihar, chief minister Ashok Gehlot clarified that the government was not planning any such move.

But the liquor policy announced on Saturday may turn out to be prohibitory for the state’s thriving tourism industry and its numerous segments like weddings, conference business and hotel industry.

Come April , when the new policy kicks in, you may have to shell out nearly 50% the price you are paying now in hotel bars, if they pass on the full increase in licence fees. There is not much relief even if you visit resto bars, as annual charges for them have also gone up from Rs 9 lakh to Rs 12 lakh.

Even the aam aadmi has not been spared either. After undertaking two increases last year, the excise department has raised the additional duty by another 5% to 25% (for liquor costing Rs 950 distillery price). Additionally, the licence fees for government shops have shot up from Rs 22 lakh to Rs 26 lakh.

Nilesh Mewara, president of Rajasthan Liquor Welfare Society, said, “With such hefty increases in licence fees, hike in additional duty and application fees, the prices are expected to go up significantly for customers who also buy from government licenced liquor shops. The price list for 2020-21 has not been declared, but we expect an overall increase of 15-20% for common people.”

Last year, five-star hotels paid Rs 17 lakh as licence fee and 10% more for every extra counter. As per the new policy, while the basic fee remains at Rs 15 lakh, it is now mandatory for them to get three additional counters with each costing Rs 5 lakh.

The new fee structure is similar for all star-categories hotels. Four-star hotels will now have to cough up Rs 22 lakh against Rs 12 lakh earlier, while for three-star properties the fee will rise to Rs 15 lakh against Rs 8.5 lakh last year. Rates for all other hotels without any star category have also been doubled.

Many in the hospitality and tourism industry expressed disappointment that the exorbitant rise in liquor prices would cripple the tourism industry, wedding and meetings, incentives, conferences and exhibitions (MICE) business for which Rajasthan was emerging as a new hub in the country.

“You cannot kill a goose that gives golden eggs. We will lose a significant part of our MICE business to our rival cities. The fate of many sub-segment industry is tied to tourism and hospitality. Such a steep hike in liquor prices will make Jaipur or any other city of Rajasthan economically uncompetitive,” said a hotelier preferring anonymity.

While the new policy talks about some innovative features like licenced shops offering bills, and bottles having chips that will provide information about where it’s made and to be sold, the industry feels the policy will be potentially detrimental to the growth of tourism industry.

Hotel Licence Fees

2020-21 2019-20

5-star hotels Rs 30 lakh Rs 21.8 lakh

4-star hotels Rs 22 lakh Rs 14.20 lakh

3-start hotels Rs 15 lakh Rs 9.35 lakh

In 2019-20 policy, all non-star hotels within urban limits were charged licence fees according to number of rooms: 1-50 room hotel – Rs 9 lakh, 51-100 room hotel – Rs 11 lakh, 101-room and above – Rs 16 lakh. But now they will have single fees at Rs 20 lakh.

Title: Hackers target Visakhapatnam bizmen’s e-mails, lakhs siphoned off
Content:
Representative Image

VISAKHAPATNAM : The number of cybercrime cases—e-mail hacking , fake website, and online frauds—have been on the rise in Vizag city. In the past three years. As many as 316 such cases have been reported in Vizag city alone.Cases of e-mail accounts being hacked have been many in the city, since most of the targets are businessmen involved in import and export.A senior police officer said that the information mined from the e-mail accounts of businessmen is being sold on the darknet and cyber criminals, who get a hold of the information, use it to siphon money off netizens.“A few weeks ago, a city-based businessman—who has an import and export firm—was duped of over Rs 25 lakh by cyber criminals who hacked his e-mail account,” said S Ravi Kumar , sub-inspector of cyber crime police station in Vizag. After hacking into his e-mail, the fraudsters kept a tab on the businessman’s transactions. After some time, they set up an e-mail account similar to that one of the businessman’s supplier and sent him an e-mail stating he had to deposit money in a new bank account for an upcoming business transaction. Since the fraudster’s e-mail was similar to the supplier’s, the businessman deposited the amount believing it is the same supplier.“In some cases, some businessmen have deposited money foreign bank accounts too,” Ravi Kumar added.“We have been appealing to people to set a strong password and change it frequently so that their accounts are less susceptible to hacking. Fraudsters are also creating fake websites with advertisements for girls for friendships and fun and friendship clubs, to name a few,” the SI added.City police chief RK Meena said that, in the past three years, the city saw over 1,100 cybercrimes, the majority of which were related to e-commerce sites, job frauds, e-mail hacking, and few others.Revealing that not more than 30% of these cases were detected, RK Meena said that the police are chalking out plans to seek the support of a few cyber experts to solve the cases.Another senior police officer said that while the police had nabbed the fraudsters, they were struggling to recover the money.

Title: Speaker accused of shifting med college
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Jaipur: Rajsamand BJP MLA Kiran Maheshwari has accused assembly speaker CP Joshi of taking a proposed medical college from her constituency to close to his own constituency Nathdwara by flouting norms to gain political mileage.

Maheshwari accused Rajsamand DM Arvind Kumar Poswal of working for Joshi while manipulating rules and regulations.

Maheshwari told TOI that the central government had allotted the medical college in Rajsamand under Centrally Sponsored Scheme(CSS) for better medical facilities to citizens of the district. “Our proposal was to establish the medical college in the civil hospital of Rajsamand which is spread over 17.5 acres and to meet the remaining 2.5 acres by acquiring it from the allotted land for a girls college nearby,” said Maheswari.

She accused Joshi of influencing the administration for taking the location in Devpuria village almost in his constituency. She produced documents pointing that Rajasthan State Road Development and Construction Corporation in its inspection report on the land noted that it would double up the cost of the hospital.

“Along with the cost, the land is amid the marble slurry which will further put the lives of patients and staff in danger,” said Maheshwari.

Joshi while refuting the allegations said, “Rather than appreciating the efforts of the state government which is making efforts to start the medical college, the accusations are laughable,” said Joshi.

The rule says a college should be in districts which doesn’t have any medical institute. However, the district has one private medical college. The state has moved a file seeking an exception to the rule.

Poswal told TOI that as per directions from the state, the land has been identified at Devpuria Village. “The medical college is allotted to Rajsamand district which means it can come up at any suitable place. Our civil hospital in Nathdwara has 200 beds while in Rajsamand it has 150 beds, which makes the former the ideal choice for the college. Even the distance of the identified place is just 7km from Nathdwara and 8km from Rajsamand district,” said Poswal.

Tehsildar of Rajsamand Dhyan Chand told TOI that Devpuria village is in Rajsamand. “The village is some 8 km from Rajsamand and 7 km from Nathdwara,” said Chand.

Title: Farmers seek to extend water release from PAP
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Coimbatore: Nearly 50 farmers from in and around Vettaikaranpudur who receive water from the Parambikulam Aliyar Project (PAP) to irrigate their farmlands on Monday petitioned district collector K Rajamani to release water daily from Aliyar Dam till March 18.

Alleging that they have received only half the water that’s usually released from the dam, farmers said as a result their cultivation has been affected. They blamed it on the poor condition of Vettaikaranpudur canal, which they said was having seepage issue, and requested water to be released from Aliyar Dam daily from today (Monday) till March 18 or beyond that, if required.

The farmers said according to the government order, the Public Works Department (PWD) was ordered to release water from Aliyar Dam for irrigation from November 4 to March 18, for around 135 days.

“Usually, out of the 135 days, they will release water for 70 days,” said Vikram Muthurathinasabari, young farmer from the Parambikulam Aliyar Pasanthottai Neerani Payanpaduthuvor Sangam (PAP irrigated water users association). “By that calculation, we should have received water for around 25 days so far. However, we have received water only for 14 days.

The farmers said while the Vettaikaran canal serves around 11,181 acres of farmland, only around 5,558 acres were under cultivation now. “They released water from two different directions. So on any given day, only half the 5,558 acres received water. Which means we got water only for 14 days,” says Vikram.

Farmers fear that the PWD will follow the government order and stop releasing water on March 18. It means water will be released for only 24 of the remaining 48 days, while farmlands will get water only for 12 more days. “This is not enough to moisture or water for our lands, where we cultivate coconut, maize, groundnut and banana, all of which are perennial crops,” said another farmer.

Farmers demanded that PWD should release water every day from the Aliyar Dam for the remaining 48 days, to make up for the deficit or continue releasing water after March 18 also, if required.

Farmers said the bad shape of the Vettaikaran canal is the reason that the entire area does not receive water every day that it is released. “The water seepage from the canal is so severe, that 50% of the water is lost on the way before it reaches our lands,” says Vikram. “PWD should repair the canal to ensure that every litre of water they release actually reaches our lands,” he adds.

Title: Recent train robberies raise concerns over lack of security
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Kannur: The recent cases of two train robberies , reported on the same day in two trains , Chennai-Mangaluru Superfast Express and Thiruvananthapuram-Mangaluru Malabar Express, has once again brought to the fore the question as to how safe our trains are, especially for night travel.

Though the railways is said to be making all efforts to ensure the safety and security of the passengers, most stations do not have surveillance cameras and there is dearth of security personnel.

Though railway has integrated security system (ISS), as part of which surveillance cameras have been installed at major stations, it is yet to cover many stations. In Palakkad division, only Kozhikode and Mangaluru have cameras, many of which are not functioning.

“When the authorities buy surveillance and security systems, they should also ensure that there is manpower to manage it, but in many places, it is lacking,” said an official associated with the railway protection force (RPF).

In Kannur, there are no cameras under the surveillance system and manpower is insufficient. Out of the total strength of 25 including the inspector, only 21 staffers are present and three of them must be deployed at Mahe. The post of the inspector has been lying vacant for nearly a year. Sometimes the RPF personnel have to work round-the-clock, without taking an off, to handle surveillance.

This is not unique to Kannur alone. Most railways stations in India face the same problem and this has started affecting the safety of passengers too. As per the deployment in 1980, the calculation was that there would be six personnel per train. Now the number of trains have increased but the manpower remains the same. “The higher officials have said that increasing manpower is out of the question but if that is the condition, how can security be enhanced, as the number of trains and passengers have increased manifold,” asked an official who did not want to be identified. Moreover, there is no proper system in place to repair and maintain the security systems. However, surveillance cameras are there in some stations, which are not disclosed to others, and the footages from these are expected to shed some light on the thefts, said some official sources in the railway.

Unlike the past, the profile of the thieves has changed and they are often well dressed, not to create any suspicion among the passengers, and even reserve tickets, said the officials. “In the two recent cases, the investigators suspect a gang attack, and the police team is investigating if they had information that the victims were carrying valuable items, and if the listed criminals are involved,” said a railways spokesperson.

Title: Ministers have no collective responsibility: Dy Oppn leader
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Jaipur: Deputy leader of opposition Rajendra Rathore on Monday cited several instances of rift between chief minister Ashok Gehlot and his deputy Sachin Pilot.

While speaking on the governor’s address in the assembly, Rathore said Pilot, while achieving the milestone of completing uninterrupted six years in the post of Congress state chief on January 20, claimed that the party was in power due to the long struggle against the policies of the BJP government by his party workers under his leadership. In the same breath, Rathore said Gehlot had on January 10 claimed that he had become the chief minister on popular demand. “Whom should we believe,” he questioned.

While drawing the attention of Article 162 of the Constitution, Rathore alleged that the cabinet had no collective responsibility.

He said Rajasthan was in the limelight in November- December after 112 children died at J K Lon Hospital in Kota. When the news reached the Congress high command, a team under deputy chief minister visited the hospital and said “the government is in power for over a year and we cannot pass the buck. Responsibility had to be fixed.”

The opposition leaders also visited the hospital and found that its condition was pathetic. Medical and health minister visited the hospital and accused the PWD handled by deputy chief minister of dereliction of duty.

He said the dual power centre was visible everywhere under this government. “Whether it is the Rajasthan Cricket Association (RCA) election or the hybrid election to local bodies, the cabinet was a divided house. The deputy chief minister was found missing from posters and hoardings of the first anniversary celebration of the state government. Pilot while inaugurating the students’ union at Rajasthan University on January 17 accused the government of arrogance on returning to power. Now the central leadership had formed a coordination committee.

Title: Narol fire: Investigation transferred to SC/ST Cell
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Ahmedabad: After the horrific blaze at Nandan Denim Ltd on Narol-Pirana Road killed seven persons, investigation of the case, filed under IPC Section 304 (culpable homicide not amounting to murder) and 114 (abettor present when offence is committed), has been transferred to the SC/ST Cell of the city police.

The fire that started on Saturday evening spread quickly in the production unit and claimed seven lives — primarily from the shirting and designing sections. The bodies were found from the first floor of the unit where they were completely charred. Ahmedabad Fire and Emergency Services (AFES) carried out the operation for nearly nine hours. Four bodies were found on Saturday and three more on Sunday.

Senior city police officials said that the decision was taken after one of the deceased was found to be belonging to scheduled caste (SC). Critics however saw the move as ineffective to provide justice to the families of the deceased. They claimed that with the sections applied, a local police station would have been better equipped for such a case.

On Monday, a team consisting of police and forensic science laboratory (FSL) officers visited the unit. “Primary reason was to inspect the spots that could not be accessed due to debris on Sunday. The team spent close to three hours and collected samples including charred cloth, parts of machinery tools and remains of the metal to get an idea of the possible temperature, cause of fire and direction of its spread,” said an official associated with the process.

Meanwhile, relatives of the deceased could not get the bodies due to forensic procedure. “We have been told that the DNA extraction and matching is pending and it might take a day or two. We want the responsible to be brought to book,” said Vinod Bhanderi, the relative of a deceased. “We have started rites for the deceased though.”

Only 584 have fire NOC

In Ahmedabad, which has at least five major industrial clusters in and around the city, only 584 units have no-objection certificate (NOC) issued by the Ahmedabad Fire and Emergency Services (AFES), said sources. Nandan Denim did not have the certificate, they added. In a letter written on Monday, M F Dastoor, chief fire officer of AFES and also director of state fire services, has asked the government to give more powers to the AFES and fire service to act. Thirteen out of 27 fatal fire accidents in Ahmedabad had taken place in industrial units. In the first 40 days of this year, 14 including the 7 in Narol incident have lost lives in fire accidents.

AMC suspends operations at Nandan Denim

Ahmedabad: A day after a massive fire killed seven people at Nandan Denim factory in Narol area, the civic body directed the company to stall processing activity till further notice. The Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation’s South Zone office has suspended all licences (non-edible) issued to the company for operating the processing plant. It has also accused the company of violating all fire safety norms and has directed it to reapply for a fresh set of licences. The notice mentions that the licences have been suspended ‘till further notice’ and until ‘proper inspection is conducted at the premises.’

Title: Coimbatore: School boy held for sexually assaulting minor
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

Title: Renovated Marripalem station to be operational by 2022
Content:
Photo for representative purpose only

Visakhapatnam: With the Union ministry recently allocating funds for East Coast Railway’s (ECoR) Umbrella Works—a special category for the creation of new coaching terminals—the decks seem to have been cleared for setting up a new coaching terminal or railway station complex at Marripalem .At present, the city has only one major station. Now that Visakhapatnam is the headquarters of South Coast Railway (SCoR), it will need more stations to de-congest traffic .To develop another major railway station, ECoR sent a proposal to renovate the Marripalem railway station, which included a detail project report with an estimated cost of Rs 76 crore—to the Railway board few months ago. Responding to the report, the Centre allocated Rs 5 crores for the ECoR’s Umbrella works in the budget, railway sources said.They added that the works would hopefully begin in the next financial year and all project details would be displayed in the Railways’ annual ‘law book’, which is likely to be released in next two months.“The renovation of Marripalem station is a part of developing the headquarters of South Coast Railway (SCoR). Nearly 37 trains originating in Vizag will be shifted from the existing station to Marripalem once the project is operational,” a senior railway official told TOI.Four new railway lines, with two main lines, will be laid and all the lines will be integrated into a terminal connected to the existing Visakhapatnam railway station. Currently, 118 trains pass through the existing main station daily. The average footfall is around 50,000 per day and during peak season, it goes up to around 1 lakh. Once the renovated Marripalem station is ready, the existing footfall of 1,000 is likely to be increased to 10,000, sources said.“At present, 37 trains pass through Marripalem from the city railway station. In future, all 37 trains will be originating at Marripalem. It is like Bangalore-Yeswanthapur, Hyderabad-Kachiguda, and Chennai-Egmore,” the railway officer said.Even the length of the platform will be changed. “The present length is 420 meters. This will be doubled,” officials said. Similarly, the seating capacity of a platform—which is 120 passengers—will also be increased to 250 to 300 seats, at Marripalem.

Title: Edappadi K Palaniswami: EPS writes to Centre, seeks support for protecting Cauvery zone
Content:
Edappadi K Palaniswami

Armed with “additional facts” to strengthen his case against oil and gas exploration in the delta region, chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami on Monday sought the Centre ’s support to declare the belt an “ecologically sensitive agricultural zone”. On Sunday, the CM sprung a surprise by announcing in Salem that the Cauvery delta would be declared a protected agriculture zone .A delegation of AIADMK MPs and senior officers, led by senior minister D Jayakumar, presented a letter from the chief minister to Union minister for environment, forests and climate change Prakash Javadekar in New Delhi. Ministers Dharmendra Pradhan (petroleum and natural gas) and Pralhad Joshi (parliamentary affairs) were also present.In the letter, a copy of which is available with TOI, EPS requested the Centre to stop future plans for exploration and mining of hydrocarbons in the delta. “It is our strong view that the ecologically sensitive Cauvery delta region should be excluded from any exploration, development and production of hydrocarbons in future,” the CM said. The Centre is requested to add a provison excluding the region from the purview of the January 16 amendment notification, he said.“The negative aspect of hydrocarbon projects outweigh advantages claimed by the proponents. Pipeline failures, accidents, spills and explosions can lead to property and ecological damage, loss of life and adversely impact health and habitat in a densely populated agrarian belt,”The delta region is known for its rich archaeological and cultural heritage, with famous monuments like Brihadeshwarar temple of Thanjavur, the Gangaikonda Cholapuram temple, the Navagraha temples, the Velankanni church and the Nagore Dargah dotting the region. EPS said it was apprehended that hydrocarbon exploration will destroy the cultural heritage of the country.“There will be a good response from the Centre in four days,” Jayakumar told reporters later. Agriculture department sources said discussions on legal aspects were on.In the letter, the CM pointed to additional facts (based on empirical reports) and said it would “clearly reinforce the need to preserve the ecologically sensitive agricultural zone of delta region”, which contributed more than 32% of state’s food production. Based on an expert committee report, the state had observed in 2015 that exploration of coal bed methane (CBM) would cause the risk of sea-water intrusion in the delta. “The exploration of hydrocarbons would detrimentally affect the livelihood and food security of the state… It is apprehended that the exploration of hydrocarbons will adversely affect sub-surface water, including causing possible damage to borewell shafts. Further, criss-crossing of gas and waste water pipelines will detrimentally affect the natural surface and sub-surface features now existing in the delta,” the CM said.
