Title: Residents oppose panchayat’s bid to use park site to build hall
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Coimbatore: Residents of KG Nagar in Kazhangal town panchayat on Monday petitioned district collector K Rajamani against the local body’s move to take over the open space that was earmarked for park in the area to construct a community hall. They said the residents’ welfare association had been working to convert the open space into a park and playground since October last year and appealed the collector to protect the reserved site.

Kazhangal panchayat president Ranganathan, however, said only less than a sixth of the land was required to construct the hall and that the residents were opposing the move as they didn’t want the poor and lower caste people to conduct functions in their neighbourhood. He also said the protest was backed by DMK members in the area.

Pointing out that the property developer had handed over 56 cents land as reserved site to the panchayat more than 16 years back, S Sivakumar, secretary, KG Nagar Residents’ Welfare Association, said, “But the panchayat hasn’t taken any step to develop the space into park so far.”

Vellai Pandian, association president, said the residents had unanimously decided to turn the open space into a park and playground for children and elderly people in October last year. “We then planted almost 250 tree saplings and also set up a volleyball court and two badminton courts.”

Meanwhile, Kazhangal village panchayat board approached the residents recently, stating they had decided to use the land to build a community hall. “How can they use the land to build a community hall, while it has been earmarked as open space reserve land? It is against the rules,” Sivakumar said.

The panchayat president admitted that he had begun work on the community hall in the area. “But I am taking only 8.5 cents land out of the 56 cents. They can create a park in the remaining area. I chose this space for the 3,500sqft hall to be set up at a cost of Rs 74 lakh, as it is closer to the bus stand than the earlier chosen space. Also, roads are 45ft wide and vehicles could be park on roadsides. It is also a clean area.”

Ranganathan said the residents were opposed to the project as they were afraid that scheduled caste people would hold functions in the community hall, which is less expensive. “Also, this protest is politically motivated by the previous panchayat president, who lost the elections, and the DMK,” he said.

Title: Some got rewarded while a few were given a chance to prove their mettle
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Jaipur: Some got rewarded while others were given a choice to prove their mettle in the reshuffle of 36 Indian Police Services ( IPS ) officers on Sunday night.

Prashaka Mathur, who has an MBBS degree, was allowed to use her expertise by making her the director of Forensic Science Laboratory.

Eight RPS officers, who were promoted as IPS recently, were given new postings. Smita Srivastav, who had served in Jaipur, was asked to take charge as ADG (traffic), the post which was left vacant after Pankaj Singh moved to BSF as ADG.

Likewise, Rahul Prakash, who remained instrumental in curbing drunk driving during his stint as deputy commissioner of traffic and was recently promoted as DIG, was made the additional commissioner of police(traffic).

Dinesh MN, who is a known face for corrupt public servants, has been ratained in the ACB and has been made additional director general.

Biju George Joseph, who had proved his mettle in the recruitment process of police in 2017 and 2018, is the new ADG (recruitment and promotion board).

Title: ‘Giriraj Kishore promoted use of Hindi in IIT-K’
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

A condolence meet was held at IIT-K to pay tributes to Giriraj Kishore

Kanpur: IIT-Kanpur, on Monday, held a condolence meet to pay tributes to Padma Shri Giriraj Kishore who passed away at his residence in Sooterganj on Sunday.

Giriraj Kishore had served as registrar of the institute from December 1975 to November 1983. He also served as assistant registrar and deputy registrar of CSJM (Kanpur) University between 1966 and 1975.

Remembering the author, IIT-Kanpur’s media cell stated that it was due to efforts of Giriraj Kishore that a separate department, Centre For Creative Writing and Publication, was set up in the institute. Kishore remained the head of this department till 1997.

A technical institute like IIT, where English was the only language for academic and research purpose, the use of Hindi was propogated by Giriraj Kishore and he immensely contributed to its cause. Several literary fest at national level were also organised in the institute due to his efforts, said the IIT-K authorities.

Giriraj Kishore wrote several novels, story collections, drama, articles and essays promoting Hindi and received various awards for his literary work including Padma Shi given by the then Central government in 2007.

The IIT-K authorities said that demise of Giriraj Kishore is a huge loss not only to the literary world but also for the institute.

Among those who were present at the meet were IIT-K director Prof Abhay Karandikar, deputy director Prof Manindra Agarwal and others. A two minute silence was observed for the departed soul.

Meanwhile, mortal remains of Giriraj Kishore were, on Monday, handed over to GSVM medical College by his family, as per his last wish.

Title: 2 staffers suspended, 54 issued notices
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Jind: The Haryana animal husbandry and dairying department has suspended two employees and issued show-cause notices to 54 staff members for remaining absent from duty during office hours.

Director general of the department O P Chhikara said surprise inspections were conducted in the department’s offices across the state in the past one week to look for absentees.

In the surprise checks, 245 institutions were inspected in 22 districts, where 10 veterinary surgeons (VS), two block level extension officers (BLEOs), 27 veterinary and livestock development assistants (VLDAs), and 15 sweepers were found absent. The employees put under suspension are Sukhvinder Singh, a clerk, and Sudhir Chauhan, an assistant, deputed in Barara town of Ambala district.

In Bhiwani, the home district of animal husbandry and dairying minister J P Dalal, 16 employees were found missing during office hours, followed by 13 in Fatehabad, nine in Jind and five in Ambala. Apart from these, four employees were found missing from office in Hisar, three in Rewari, two in Sirsa and one each in Rohtak and Mewat.

Talking to TOI, Ravinder Hooda, department’s deputy director in Jind, said 11 teams had been formed to carry out inspections in 22 districts of Haryana. “Each team had the charge of two districts and issued show-cause notices to employees who were not present during office hours. In Jind, nine employees have been sent notices.”

Title: PM to inaugurate UN Summit on migratory species in Gandhinagar
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Gandhinagar: Prime Minister Narendra Modi will inaugurate the 13th conference of parties (COP) of the convention on conservation of migratory species of wild animals (CMS), which will be held at Mahatma Mandir in Gandhinagar from February 17 to 22. The COP-CMS is an environmental treaty under the aegis of the United Nations Environment Programme.

Addressing a briefing in New Delhi, Union minister for environment, forest and climate change, Prakash Javadekar, said, “Hosting COP-CMS-13 is a significant step towards wildlife conservation in India. PM Narendra Modi will inaugurate the opening of the COP-CMS 13 on February 17. Representatives from 130 countries, eminent conservationists and international NGOs working in the field of wildlife conservation will be attending the COP”.

As the host, India will be designated the president of the treaty for the next three years. The government of India is a signatory to the Convention on Conservation of Migratory wild Animals (CMS) since 1983. Seven species that include dugong, whale shark, marine turtle (two species) and others have been identified for preparation of conservation and recovery action plan.

On February 15 and 16, pre-COP meetings will take place including the stakeholder dialogue, high-level segment meetings and the champion night award ceremony. The opening ceremony and plenary session of the COP will take place on February 17, followed by side events and working group meetings until February 22. The minister said that simultaneously, a number of national and international organizations will showcase best practices in wildlife conservation in the exhibition area.

The theme of the COP-CMS-13 in India is, “Migratory species connect the planet and we welcome them home”. The COP-CMS-13 logo is inspired by ‘kolam’, a traditional art form from South India. The logo depicts key migratory species in India like Amur falcon, humpback whale and marine turtles.The mascot for COP-CMS-13, “Gibi - The Great Indian Bustard” is a critically endangered species which has been accorded the highest protection status under the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972. The Indian sub-continent is part of the major bird flyway network - the Central Asian Flyway (CAF) which covers areas between the Arctic and Indian Oceans, and covers at least 279 populations of 182 migratory water bird species, including 29 globally threatened species.

Title: State to have 3 more medical college: Vij
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Chandigarh: Haryana health and medical education minister Anil Vij on Monday said a medical college each will be opened in Yamunanagar, Kaithal and Sirsa districts at a cost of Rs 1,000 crore. With this, he said, the number of medical colleges opened during the tenure of BJP government in Haryana would go up to 13.

Vij said the construction of colleges would begin soon. He said the central and state governments had already given approval to this and more than Rs 325 crore would be spent on each of these medical colleges.

The state government, he said, had been making efforts to activate the working of these medical colleges by 2023. He said these colleges would be constructed on 20 acres each and with the arrangement of around 200 beds. He said this step will help the state produce more doctors and improve medical care.

The minister said government medical colleges, which had been approved by the BJP government during its last tenure, were already underway. These colleges include Government Medical College and Hospital, Koriyawas, Mahendragarh; Government Medical Colleges and Hospital in Jind; Government Medical College and Hospital in Gurgaon; and Government Medical College in Bhiwani.

Besides, his government had already started six other medical colleges over the last five years, Vij said.

Title: Endosulfan victims to resume agitation
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Kannur: Alleging that the government has not kept its promises and the authorities are ignoring and side-lining them, the endosulfan victims in Kasaragod have announced yet another round of agitation, and they are planning an indefinite sit-in at Kasaragod collectorate from March 25.

There were many promises that CM Pinarayi Vijayan had made during a discussion with them last year, but till date many of the promises have not been kept and this has forced them to launch this agitation, said Muneesa Ambalathara, who is an endosulfan victim and the president of the Endosulfan Peeditha Janakeeya Munnani, which fights for the cause of the affected people.

“We are not getting pension regularly and when we raise our voice, some dues are cleared but it accumulates again,” she said.

When they raise their issues, the government says everything is handled by the district collector, but when the collector is of the stand that endosulfan is not the culprit for their tragedy, how they could expect justice, she asked.“The collector claims that endosulfan has no such problems, but till date they have not removed the barrels of the killer pesticide kept in the warehouse of the Plantation Corporation, and the claim is that it needs over Rs 40 lakh to dispose of it safely, which underscores the irony,” she said.

The chief minister had also promised that over 500 affected people under the age of 18, identified as the victims through medical camps in 2017, would be included in the list without further medical check-up, and those above 18 would be included after medical check-up, but nothing has append so far, said Muneesa.

There is concern that the government is going back from the promises and the benefits announced for the victims would be stopped one by one, said Munnani convenor Ambalathara Kunhikrishnan.

“Though it is said that Rs 19 crore has been earmarked for the victims, there is no clarity about it and even if the fund has been earmarked, how it will be utilized by the administration is also a question,” he said.

The victims have no other way than continuing agitation to call the attention of the authorities, he added.

Title: NMC to hire agency to transplant over 50 trees
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Nashik: The civic body will hire a private agency for scientifically uprooting and transplanting over 50 trees that are located either in the middle or edges of different roads in the city.

“These trees have to be carefully uprooted and transplanted to ensure their survival. Hence, the Nashik Municipal Corporation has decided to engage a private agency to carry out the task,” said NMC officials.

The civic body is in the process of inviting bids from interested parties for the work.

“The party winning the bid would have to carry out the task in a time-bound the manner and they have to ensure that these trees survive at the new location,” said NMC officials.

The private agency would be given about two years to complete the task.

The city police last year had written to NMC drawing its attention to accidents caused due to those trees. NMC’s tree authority committee in November had approved the civic administration’s plan to relocate these trees elsewhere following its proposal on the issue.

According to the police, these trees pose danger to motorists, especially at night. There have been accidents where motorists have dashed against the trees sustaining injuries, some have even lost their lives. A couple of policemen were injured while returning home during wee hours.

NMC sources said these trees cannot be chopped off as the tree authority has asked the civic administration to transplant them. According to some traffic police officials, the relocation of these trees is imperative to make the roads safer.

The environmentalists have demanded that NMC must direct the private agency to seek the guidance of experts about the transplantation for the survival of the trees.

Title: Take over aided school on verge of closure, govt urged
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Coimbatore: Residents of Pillayarpuram near Kuniyamuthur in the city on Monday urged the district administration to convert the aided elementary school in their locality into a government school, instead of shutting it down. They also petitioned district collector K Rajamani in this regard.

Set up in 1986, Bethel Livesey Memorial aided school initially had a strength of close to 1,000 students, said M Arun Kumar, one of the petitioners.

Pointing out that the school education department had not been renewing the school’s recognition for the past few years, he said as a result the student strength has plunged to 14 presently.

Arun said there were 2,000 families in the locality and that parents would admit their wards to the school, if it was turned into a government school. “It will help the school regain its recognition. While there are two government schools within 3km radius, residents are scared to send their children to those schools as they have to cross two highway roads to reach there.”

The school education department had sent a notice to the school management in 2018, directing them to get building stability certificate for the school. It had subsequently issued a final notice in July 2019, directing them to close the school by the end of the academic year.

Following this, the school management decided to handover the school to the government and has submitted a letter stating the same to the school education department.

When contacted, an official with the office of district educational officer (Perur) said the school was constructed on government poramboke land and that the school management had not paid the lease amount for more than 10 years. “The pending lease amount will come around Rs 1 crore. Now that only 14 students are there, we have sent a notice to the school directing them to close it by the end of the academic year.”

When asked about the possibility of converting it into a government school, the official said a final decision was yet to be taken. “The decision would have to be taken by the directorate of school education.”

Title: Additional coaches in trains
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: With a move to provide a comfortable journey for passengers, East Coast Railway has decided to permanently attach additional coaches to Visakhapatnam-bound trains.

The train 18519/18520 Visakhapatnam- Lokmanya Tilak Terminus-Visakhapatnam express will be augmented with one more third AC coach. The train 18567/18568 Visakhapatnam-Kollam-Visakhapatnam express and the train 20816/20815 Visakhapatnam-Tata-Visakhapatnam express trains will be augmented with one more sleeper class coach. Title: Thousands bid tearful adieu to martyr
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Jaipur: Thousands, including politicians, ministers and locals on Monday bid a tearful adieu to Rajiv Singh (36) who was killed during the unprovoked firing at Poonch sector of J&K. As the mortal remains of Singh were consigned to flames by his son Adhiraj Singh people shouted patriotic and anti-Pakistan slogans at Luhakana Khurd village near Viratnagar on the city outskirts.

Singh joined the Indian Army in 2002 and had joined his duty on January 8 after a long vacation. Family members including father Shankar Singh, mother Pushpa Kanwar and wife Usha Kanwar have been inconsolable ever since they got the tragic news.

Everyone had tears in their eyes when Singh’s sister Seema Kanwar tied Rakhi on his wrist prior to consigning the mortal remains to flames. “I have lost my father because of Pakistan. I too will join the Indian Army to teach a lesson to Pakistan,” said Adhiraj Singh.

When the funeral procession was taken from the village lanes people shouted, ‘Rajiv Singh Amar Rahey’ ‘Pakistan Murdabad’ ‘Rajiv Tera Yeh Balidan Yaad Karega Hindustan’. People went to the terraces of houses, shops and schools to bid adieu.

Some of the youths also organised a tri-colour rally on bikes across the village.

“My grandson is also willing to join Indian army to serve the country and to teach a lesson to Pakistan. Though I lost my son but I’m proud of the fact that he sacrificed his life for the country,” said Shankar Singh, the deceased’s father.

Title: I have limited time to deliver today and dream for tomorrow: CM
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Vijayawada: Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy , in his first media interaction since coming to power in May last year, said he has limited time to “deliver today and dream for tomorrow” to ensure that the state meets its welfare and development goals. The CM spoke on a range of issues, including his government’s achievements in the last eight months, bifurcation of capital, abolition of legislative council and his plans for the rest of his term. Excerpts:

You have brought in a number of welfare schemes . But how do you plan to bring in investments?

Welfare schemes are my commitment to people. Every scheme is the result of my interaction with them, be it Rythu Bharosa or Amma Vodi or any other scheme. This government is committed to ensure industrial growth in the state. We are giving corruption-free governance, we are offering land, water and electricity to investors. Applications are being cleared fast, the investors do not have to run around offices for permissions. We are inviting some, some are coming in on their own. The previous government had promised Rs 4,000 crore worth incentives and we have to honour it. Before setting up new industries, we should retain the existing ones. We can’t offer more incentives merely for the sake of inviting new industries and fail to deliver as my predecessor did.

The state’s finances are not in good shape. How do you plan to raise revenue?

It is true that the state’s fiscal position is poor. My predecessor had not only emptied the exchequer but also left a huge burden on me. He ( Chandrababu Naidu ) went for maximum borrowing at high rates of interest. But we have still been able to manage welfare schemes and development with limited sources. If we can balance it in the first year, we can do it in the remaining four years. I am confident God will help us.

Some of your decisions are under judicial review...

Nothing can stop us from doing what we are planning. I have invited judicial review on some of my decisions like tenders. My government has no hidden agenda. Things will fall in line when they are planned for people’s welfare and the state’s development.

Your father revived the legislative council. Why did you decide to abolish it?

The council was created by the legislative assembly to be a guiding force. When that spirit is defeated, and rules are flouted for political benefit, why should the assembly accept the council? The council should have understood people’s mandate and honoured the assembly’s decisions. Moreover, I could have got majority in the council by next year. But I don’t have that much time.

But the reason and timing of your decision is being criticised...

No, it was the right time and right reason. The council can delay a decision by maximum three to four months. They can’t stop the assembly’s work (Bills) for more than that stipulated period. But three to four months is too long a time for me. I have to dream and deliver whatever I promised and whatever people want in five years. I can’t waste precious time for political interests that the council members have. Take for example, the English medium issue. It can’t wait as the academic year starts in June and we have to prepare teachers and schools by then. If one party wants us to stop our work at every step for its political interests, we can’t wait.

What is your biggest challenge as chief minister?

Planning for future generations is important. I have taken up modernization of schools, hospitals and farming. ‘Nadu-Nedu’ for schools and hospitals is a big challenge. You will see the difference when basic infrastructure is provided to schools and hospitals. Even agriculture is going to get a facelift. Rythu Bharosa kendras in every village, soil testing centres in every assembly constituency and market yards are going to change the scene. This government plans to give tough competition to private buyers in the market.

Visakhapatnam is cyclone-prone. Is it safe to have the capital there?

Of the 13 districts in the state, nine are along the coast and cyclone threat is everywhere. Diviseema in Krishna district was badly hit in 1977. Why only Visakhapatnam? Machilipatnam, Nizampatnam are equally prone to cyclones. Even Kakinada. But we have to live with that. Chennai is along the coast like Visakhapatnam and there is no problem. Moreover, we are not going to disturb the existing city. We would be adding to this city a little away from the sea shore.

What is the reason behind selecting Visakhapatnam as executive capital when Amaravati was decided by the previous government?

AP is a new state and we have big capital cities in the neighbourhood to compete with. We should select an existing city to develop and join the competition and not invest on building a new capital. Amaravati is still a village and it will take decades to compete with Chennai, Bengaluru or Hyderabad, whereas Visakhapatnam is an existing city and it will be ready for competition with any of these three capitals in less than 10 years. I don’t want the youth of AP to look at other cities for opportunities. Their capital should be able to live up to their expectations soon. We don’t have to wait for 50 years for Amaravati to become a city and then compete with other capitals. Visakhapatnam would start challenging Chennai in no time, with less investment.

Your police have found a major land scam in Amaravati land pooling scheme. Who is behind this?

The previous government committed several such mistakes. The CID had conducted an initial investigation and handed over the details to the enforcement directorate (ED). We are also thinking of constituting a special investigating team (SIT) as requested by assembly speaker Thammineni Sitaram. Those who have indulged in insider trading will be punished as per the law of the land.

What are you going to do with Amaravati and its 33,000 acres of land taken from farmers?

Amaravati will continue to be the legislative capital of the state. The chief minister, ministers, MLAs and officials will be here for 60 to 70 days in a year. The assembly will remain here. We have increased the annuity period from 10 years to 15 years. We have enhanced agriculture labourers’ pension from Rs 2,500 to Rs 5,000 per month. We have promised to give equal share to ‘B’ form lands on par with patta lands. We are promising proper utilisation of land collected from farmers. The development will take its due course.

Is special category status demand still in your agenda?

It’s very much there in our agenda. There is no going back on it. Special category status for AP was promised on the floor of the Parliament. But, they (BJP) should have the same commitment to fulfil it. BJP leaders may say SCS is a closed chapter, but it is very much alive for us and for the people of AP. We thought the BJP would fall short of numbers (in Parliament) and would require our support. It did not happen and they have full majority. But we will not give up and keep asking for SCS.

What about Polavaram project?

It took us some time to correct the mistakes of the previous government. They constructed the cofferdam without completing the spill channel, which caused inundation of the project site and the new contractor could not take up the works. But I am confident of completing the irrigation component of the project as per schedule, by June 2021.

Your plans for the remaining four-and-a-half years of your government?

I have to take care of every part of the state, not just one place. Amaravati, as it is, and as estimated by the previous government, would require Rs 1.09 lakh crore. The previous government had spent only Rs 6,000 crore or a little more. But we can’t think of spending Rs 1.09 lakh crore in one place. For head of the family, every person in the family is important. Likewise, for the head of the state, every part of the state is important. Health, education, agriculture and industries are my priorities. We will plan and spend accordingly.

Title: Maharashtra: Five teens in car hurt after it hits bike, rider killed on spot
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

The five teens were trapped inside the car that turned turtle and rammed into a tree at Boisar on Monday

MUMBAI: A joyride after bunking college turned tragic for five teenagers when their speeding car rammed into a two-wheeler, killing the rider on the spot at Boisar in Palghar district on Monday. Tarapur police said the teens are out of danger. The friends, all aged 18, sustained injuries when their car turned turtle.

Tarapur police have booked driver Hritik Sharma (18) for the death of Laxman Wavre (30) who worked as a garden contractor with Bhabha Atomic Research Centre Colony in Tarapur. Sharma does not have a driving licence.

The incident took place around 7.20am when Sharma and his four friends, including two girls, all Class XI students of a junior college in Boisar, decided to bunk lectures and go for a drive to Chinchani, a beach destination at Boisar.

They were in their college uniform when the accident took place.

Sharma, who is believed to have borrowed the car from a friend—who was not travelling with them—was speeding down the road. When he reached Kurgaon village, he rammed into the bike. Wavre, the biker who was wearing a helmet, was thrown at a distance and died on the spot.

A resident of Popharan village in Boisar, Wavre was on his way to work. He was identified based on his identity card found in his pocket. His family was informed by locals. Sharma tried to control his vehicle but it turned turtle and rammed into a tree. Eyewitnesses said the teens were pulled out of the car by locals.

Sharma and his two male friends sustained head and body injuries. The two girls, on rear seats, suffered minor injuries. All five are being treated at Boisar’s Anand Hospital. API Santosh Jadhav said Sharma is booked under IPC and Motor Vehicles Act. He will be arrested after his release from hospital. The car owner was summoned.

Title: Three BBMP staffers, 2 others siphon off Rs 4.2 crore from agency
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

BBMP employees allegedly colluded with two individuals to divert the civic agency’s payment of Rs 4.2 crore.

BENGALURU: Three BBMP employees allegedly colluded with two individuals to divert the civic agency’s payment of Rs 4.2 crore to a contractor towards execution of road work in KR Puram, according to an FIR registered with the Bengaluru Metropolitan Task Force police station. The amount was allegedly transferred to the account of an unrelated individual.

Acting on the complaint lodged on February 12 by BBMP chief accounts officer Govindaraju R, BMTF police have named accounts superintendents Anitha M, 48, and Ramamurthy R, 50, second division clerk Raghavendra, and two others, Gangadhar, 38, and Nagesh, 36, as the accused. All three Palike employees worked in the agency’s headquarters and have been suspended.

The complaint was lodged in the wake of the letter from contractor CG Chandrappa, director, CGC Infra Project Pvt Ltd, to BBMP commissioner BH Anil Kumar.

Chandrappa’s firm had won the tender for executing road improvement and resurfacing work worth Rs 4.4 crore in several localities of KR Puram. Two work orders were issued to the firm on September 15, 2018.

“I finished the project in time and as per the standards and specification mentioned in the tender,” said Chandrappa. He had provided a cancelled cheque of his firm to the BBMP executive engineer for transfer of payments.

“After audit and deduction, the BBMP executive engineer said I would receive Rs 4.2 crore towards the two work orders,” Chandrappa said.

“I was to get the money earlier this February. But I got suspicious when it didn’t arrive in my account for over a week. I went to the head office and learnt the money for the work had been transferred to another account in Janatha Seva Cooperative Bank, Vijayanagar,” said Chandrappa.

A senior BBMP official said the accused opened an account in the bank using fake documents and transferred the money to it instead of the account of Chandrappa’s firm.

BMTF police said they have arrested the four accused. A special team headed by Obalesh, SP, is investigating the case. “We have recovered Rs 3.9 crore and it will be handed over to Chandrappa. We will recover the remaining amount soon,” said mayor M Goutham Kumar.

Title: Plea in HC seeks removal of IAS officers from VC posts
Content:
Photo for representative purpose only

HYDERABAD : The Telangana high court on Monday issued notices to the state, its higher education secretary, the University Grants Commission (UGC) and to vice-chancellors of several universities in the state asking them to explain their stand on a public interest petition that questioned the state’s decision to appoint IAS officers as in-charge vice chancellors of various universities.The petitioner, Dr S Karunakar Reddy — an assistant professor of Osmania University , also questioned an office note issued by the chief minister’s office (CMO) on July 24, 2019 that facilitated the entry of IAS officers as in-charge VCs of scores of universities in the state.The petitioner sought the suspension of this CMO note and make senior faculty members of respective universities as in-charge VCs till permanent VCs are appointed as per UGC norms.“Universities are supposed to function independently and maintain high academic standards. But governmental intervention would prove to be detrimental to the autonomy of the varsities,” the petitioner said.“The only way available to the authorities to make these appointments is through UGC regulations 2010 and 2018 as was directed by the Supreme Court and was also adopted by the state government,” he added.The petitioner contended that in several universities, executive coucils have not been in place for the last five years. “The annual budget for these universities are getting cut and areas of teaching and research are being adversely affected,” he said and added that though the state has sanctioned a thousand teaching posts — 600 assistant professors and 400 associate professor posts — three years ago, the notification to fill them has not yet been given.“This is because the IAS officers who are working as in-charge VCs do not have enough time to deal with these important tasks,” he said.The bench gave the state four weeks to explain its case.

Title: Savadi’s push for Hungarian firm’s electric buses raises eyebrows
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Bengaluru: The controversy over expensive electric buses seems to be never-ending in Karnataka.

After the previous coalition government and then transport minister DC Thamanna landed in soup over purchasing electric buses rather than leasing them on long-term basis, incumbent deputy chief minister and transport minister Laxman Savadi ’s hope to induct electric buses from a Hungarian firm — bypassing the tender process — has raised eyebrows.

Last month, Savadi said the Hungarian company had pitched an “attractive” proposal for the Karnataka government after having successfully sold it to Assam, Harayana and Maharashtra in the last one year when they were under the BJP regime.

“We are quite impressed with the Hungarian firm’s proposal of leasing buses to us. However, they are outside the tendering process and we are considering their proposal,” Savadi had said, claiming the company was on the verge of signing an MoU with Maharashtra and had presented a letter of intent to Assam.

Recent reports suggest Assam State Transport Corporation will induct 1,000 such buses shortly.

Accordingly, transport department sources say they are planning to do away with floating tenders by seeking 4G exemption under the Karnataka Transparency in Public Procurement Act. “There is a pressure to induct e-buses from the Hungarian company without floating tenders. The firm is not eligible to participate in tenders since it has no prior experience in operating e-buses in India. If the minister is convinced, then he could induct buses on lease basis without any tender,” said a senior transport department official.

But 4G exemption can be used only under extraneous circumstances (see box).

The firm has reportedly proposed different slab rates: Rs 6,500 per bus per day (32 seater), Rs 13,000 per bus/day (53) and Rs 14,000 per bus/day (88). It also offered buses on inter-city routes: Rs 21,000 (36-sleeper) and Rs 25,000 (42-sleeper). All buses will be air-conditioned.

Unlike other firms, the Hungarian company quoted the rate on per bus per day basis. Normally, firms quote rates on a per kilometre basis.

However, an addition which the firm brings to the table is that of investments to set up its manufacturing unit in Mangaluru. It has already identified 250 acres of land near Mangaluru airport for the purpose.

What does 4G exemption entail?

Exceptions to applicability of KTPP Act, clause 4 (exemption from tender process)

* During natural calamity or if emergency goods or services are available from a single source

* Where additional goods must be procured from same supplier for reasons of standardisation and compatibility

* Where value of goods or services does not exceed Rs 1 lakh

* Where goods or services are procured under rate contracts from the director-general of supplies and disposals

* In respect of specific procurements as may be notified by the government from time to time

Title: Haryana shifts 7 IAS, 6 HCS officers
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Chandigarh: The Haryana government has transferred seven IAS and six HCS officers with immediate effect, said a statement here on Monday.

Among the IAS officers, Anita Yadav, CEO , Mewat Development Agency, Nuh, has been moved as additional director, Haryana Institute of Public Administration, Gurgaon. Nuh DC Pankaj has been given additional charge of CEO, Mewat Development Agency. Shyam Lal Poonia, municipal commissioner, Yamunanagar, will replace Dharamvir Singh as the DC, Charkhi Dadri, while Dharamvir Singh will hold the charge of CEO, Shivalik Development Agency, Ambala.

Pratima Chaudhary, additional controller, civil defence, Ambala, has been given the charge of additional controller, civil defence, Ambala, additional DC, Yamunanagar, and secretary, regional transport authority, Yamunanagar.

Dharmender Singh, Faridabad MC additional commissioner, has been posted as director and additional secretary, social justice and empowerment department, while Jaspreet Kaur, awaiting posting, has been moved in his place.

Among the HCS officers, Vijender Hooda, Jind city magistrate, will now hold the charge of CEO, Jhajjar Zila Parishad. Bharat Bhushan, Yamunanagar additional DC and RTA secretary, has been posted as Yamunanagar city magistrate and Joint CEO, Saraswati Heritage Board. Mandeep Kumar, SDO (civil), Safidon, has been given the additional charge of Jind city magistrate. PTI

Title: Karnataka: Doubling of 2 railway lines hits hurdle
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: The long-pending doubling of two crucial railway lines — Byappanahalli-Hosur (48km) and Yeshwantpur-Channasandra (21km) — has once again hit a hurdle. Sources say the railways now wants to rework the cost-sharing.

After the state government refused to shoulder 50% of the cost burden, the railways agreed to take up the projects under the 20:20 model, where the remaining 60% was to be raised through loans.

However, the railways again began insisting on a 50:50 cost-sharing model but the state said it’s ready for a 20:20 formula as the projects will only help railways operate long-distance trains.

Sources said the railways and state government are yet to reach a consensus, which may further delay the project.

The railways in 2018 invited bids for civil work on doubling of the Byappanahalli-Hosur line . With the state government insisting that these projects be taken up through a special purpose vehicle, the railways in 2019 handed over the two projects to Karnataka Rail Infrastructure Development Enterprises, which is recruiting 37 officials to execute them.

“The source of revenue from these two projects is not clear so it’s difficult to quantify the rate of returns. In this scenario, financial institutions are unlikely to be keen on these projects. We are hoping the railways and state agree on a 50:50 cost-sharing model and resolve this issue in a month,” said a K-RIDE official.

A senior state government official said: “After agreeing to the 20:20 model, we don’t know why railways did a U-turn. In fact, the Rs 18,600 crore dedicated suburban rail system is also under the same model and we wanted the same SPV to take up these projects too. The projects largely help the railways operate long-distance trains since the extends till Hosur in Tamil Nadu.”

Once the railways and state are on the same page, it will take another three-four months to float new tenders. It will take three or four years to complete the doubling work.

While doubling of these two lines was proposed several years ago, it remained on paper even though the lines pass through high-density corridors like Outer Ring Road and tech hubs like Electronics City. Doubling could help the railways operate more trains, including suburban services, particularly between Byappanahalli and Heelalige stations, which would spell relief for techies working along Hosur Road, ORR, Sarjapur Road and Electronics City who battle road traffic every day. Traffic congestion on ORR is likely to worsen once BMRCL commences the construction of Metro corridors. The railways has allocated only Rs 5 crore each to the two projects in its Pink Book.

Will reduce traffic

Doubling of these two lines will significantly reduce traffic along ORR from Silk Board to Hebbal. It would be a big achievement if the railways is able to double these lines in three years. It was announced in the 2018 budget but there’s been no progress for two years

Vivek Kalkur, public transport activist

Title: Bank claims chief adviser flouted loan norms; FIR filed
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Sri Gururaghavendra Sahakara Bank Niyamitha (SGRSBN), a co-operative bank in Basavanagudi, has filed a complaint against its chief adviser for disbursing loans worth several crores of rupees in violation of norms. It hit the headlines after Reserve Bank of India (RBI) imposed a cap on withdrawals of its customers.

SGRSBN chief executive officer (CEO) Santosh Kumar A filed the complaint against Vasudev Maiya, chief advisor, at Banaswadi police station, accusing him of lending loans by violating bank norms. According to the complaint, RBI during its auditing said loans for five people were given in violation of norms, which led to the crisis. Banaswadi police registered an FIR on Friday.

Maiya, who’s been working with the bank since 2000, was elevated as CEO in 2012 and retired in 2018. He continued to work as chief adviser. Sources said the case was registered on RBI’s directive. On January 10, RBI had capped withdrawals from SGRSBN at Rs 35,000 for six months over non-performing assets (NPAs).

The complaint said, “Maiya has caused a loss of several crores of rupees to the bank and is in syndicate with a few borrowers like Jaswanth Reddy, Ashok Reddy, Ranjith Reddy, M/s Megatex and Naveen DP/Geetha Naveen.”

Santosh added in the complaint: “As per the recent inspection by RBI, it was found that Maiya illegally sanctioned and disbursed loans to several people to cheat the bank and its depositors. He misused his position in the bank with the criminal intention of siphoning off several crores of rupees of depositors’ money. Maiya committed breach of trust and routed the funds fraudulently by dodging the bank accounts.”

Banaswadi police have registered a case under sections of Karnataka Protection of Interest Depositors Exorbitant Act and IPC. Santosh chose not to comment as police probe is under way.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: 74 cases negative for coronavirus, one returning passenger kept in isolation
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A passenger who had recently returned from China was kept in isolation at Gandhi Hospital on Monday. A total of 74 cases have tested negative for the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) so far.Another passenger who had returned over 15 days back and had previously tested negative, was admitted to the Gandhi Hospital on Monday after he developed cold and cough and was apprehensive of his condition. His sample was taken for repeating the test, said health authorities. Currently, 70 people continue to be in home isolation after being suspected for the virus.“If any of the suspected patients who have been quarantined at home develop symptoms of fever, cough and cold, they are being referred to the Gandhi hospital and tested for the virus. The remaining are being closely monitored,” said Vijay Kumar, state nodal officer for Coronavirus. Meanwhile, health authorities have advised public to adhere to advisories issued by government. “Those who have arrived from affected countries should remain under home isolation for 28 days from date of arrival in India, irrespective of whether they are symptomatic or asymptomatic,” says one advisory.

Title: VC aspirants await government call as panel sits on applications
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

HYDERABAD: Even after four months of constituting search committees, the Telangana government is yet to commence screening of applications for appointment of vice-chancellors (VCs) for the nine state universities. On July 24, 2019, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao had appointed senior bureaucrats as in-charge VCs of the universities after seven academicians had retired from the post. The term of the ninth VC at Prof Jayashankar Telangana State University was extended by three years.

The government had constituted search committees for appointment of VCs in September last year and had received nearly 984 applications from 273 candidates for the nine VC posts. Subsequently, the search committees were expected to screen all the applications and recommend three names for each post to the Governor Tamilisai Soundararajan, who is also chancellor of all the state universities. The governor will have final call on appointment of VCs.

However, sources said that the search committees are yet to commence screening of applications as they have not received any communication from the state government following its constitution. “A meeting of all search committees was expected to be held around the end of 2019. While a meeting was organised in October-November, the same was subsequently postponed without giving us any reason,” said a member of a search committee.

Search committee members claimed that the government has not informed them on the number of applications it had received. “The government was expected to conduct preliminary screening following which they were supposed to hand over the applications to us. Ever since the constitution of the committee, not even a single meeting has been convened to discuss the time-line and other modalities of scrutinising applications,” said the search committee member.

Top bureaucrats have attributed the delay to the model code of conduct due to municipal elections in Telangana. On the other hand, teachers claim that the state universities are yet again lying headless due to the state government’s delay in appointing the VCs. Even in 2015, the government had appointed regular VCs after a gap of over two years. The varsities were headed by IAS officers for almost two years until the government appointed VCs in 2015.

“For the past two to three months, every time we question the authorities, they inform us that the process will be completed in a month. However, till date, there has been no progress on the matter,” said Battu Satyanarayana , retired professor of the OU.

Title: Telangana: Diploma courses more in demand, up by 65% in 5 years
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

HYDERABAD: Diploma courses have gained increasing popularity in Telangana with the state seeing 65% rise in enrolments over the last five years. According to figures from the All India Survey on Higher Education, 72,123 students had enrolled for diploma courses in academic year 2014-15 which increased to 1.28 lakh in 2017-18.

There are total 47 diploma courses offered by Telangana State Board of Technical Education and Training ( TSBET ). These courses offer students education and expertise in fields such as textiles, packaging, hotel management among others. Officials have attributed the rise in number of students pursuing diploma courses to industry-relevance and employment opportunities.

Students from across boards—CBSE, ISC and the state— with a focus on engineering and other competitive exams are now opting for these diploma programmes since most of them have focused courses on engineering. “While majority students pursue computer, mechanical and other engineering-based diploma courses to secure lateral entry into BTech/BE, there are also others who opt for footwear technology, hotel management and catering, packaging technology, textile technology among others,” said TSBET secretary, UVSN Murthy .

Rising demand for diploma courses has also been attributed to a decreasing popularity of degree courses. Changes in the diploma curriculum by TSBET last year has also contributed to its growing popularity.

Title: Lamborghini driver makes photo op of police kiosk after crash; arrested
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

The Lamborghini driver had ploughed into the police chowki on Sunday. The crash left the kiosk with a gaping h... Read More

BENGALURU: The owner of the Lamborghini Gallardo, who posed for a photograph at the accident site a few hours after he ploughed his green car into a traffic police kiosk, was arrested on Monday.

The accused is Sunny Sabharwal, 28, one of the directors of city-based Fun World and Resorts India Private Limited. Cubbon Park police booked him for rash and negligent driving and slapped a penalty of Rs 2,000 on him.

Sunny, a resident of RT Nagar, had taken the car (PY05 B4345) for a spin in central business district (CBD) on Sunday evening. He had come from the MG Road side and was proceeding towards Raj Bhavan around 5pm when he lost control while drifting. The car rammed the concrete traffic police kiosk.

The impact of the crash was such that it created a 2x3 feet gaping hole in the kiosk and left the car’s front portion completely damaged. The furniture inside the kiosk was also broken. Fortunately, no constable was present in the kiosk when the crash happened. With fellow motorists and passersby rushing to the spot, the Lamborghini driver was lost in the crowd and police struggled to establish his identity.

Following the incident, joint commissioner of police (traffic) BR Ravikanthe Gowda set up a special team led by DCP (traffic-east) M Narayana to trace the errant driver. The cops collected CCTV footage and other evidence pertaining to the case when they learnt about a man having uploaded a photo in which he’s seen standing in front of the damaged kiosk and showing a thumbs-up. Based on the information, police identified him as Sunny Sabharwal.

“Sunny is a member of a WhatsAapp group with young businessmen and entrepreneurs from across the country. With pictures and videos of the post-crash scene going viral, Sunny started receiving queries from his friends who were eager to know if he was fine. He decided to answer them by visiting the kiosk and taking a picture, which he posted on social media,” police said.

On Monday morning, a police team visited Sunny’s residence in RT Nagar and the family members reportedly tried to convince the cops that he wasn’t behind the wheel when the accident occurred. However, the team showed them the CCTV footage and Sunny’s photograph. He appeared before Cubbon Park traffic police in the afternoon and was arrested.

Title: Poor frequency discourages many from taking public transport: B.Pac survey
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Bengaluru: As many as 33% of respondents in a survey said lack of frequent public transport services in the city is the reason they use private vehicles .

The Bangalore Political Action Committee (B.Pac) online survey was on first-and last-mile connectivity to public transport in Bengaluru

Poor first-and last-mile connectivity was why 24% of the respondents said they used private transport. Other factors discouraging people from travelling in public transport included accessibility (22%), convenience (19%) and affordability (3%).

Alternative modes of transport of those not using public transport are 83% (personal mobility), 16% (shared mobility) and 1% (rental mobility).

The survey revealed 88% men use personal mobility compared to 63% women, reflecting that more men hold driving licences in the city. In fact, more women (37%) use shared mobility than men (11%). Among public transport users, 51% use shared mobility, 44% personal mobility and 5% rental mobility for first-mile connectivity. For last-mile connectivity, 68% used shared mobility and 6% rental mobility.

“Differences were observed in the travel pattern of men and women in choosing modes for first- mile connectivity: 65% of the women said they prefer shared mobility – auto, cabs, shared cabs to access public transport whereas 50% of the men preferred private vehicles for first-mile connectivity,” said the report.

“Connecting Transit Stations (bus/Metro/suburban rail) to high footfall locations emerged as another urgent and immediate priority. New-age mobility service providers in the city have been working on solutions to address this first-and last-mile gap. At present, app-based bike taxis, rental bikes/cycles, shared cabs and carpooling are options to cover the first and last leg of the journey. However, not all public transit stations at present have parking facilities for app-based rental vehicles,” the report released by B.PAC read, proposing to allow shared autos.

Multimodal integration of all public transit modes in the city would enable service providers to build solutions to close the first-and last-mile gap, it said.

Times View

These statistics are interesting and they reinforce the importance of managing end-point connectivity to decongest Bengaluru. While startups in the mobility service space have been tackling this problem, the government can’t expect them to do everything. Mobility providers need to be encouraged and usage of public transport should be incentivised further. Most importantly, there’s a need for reliability — in terms of frequent services, priority bus lanes and more Metro coaches. Piecemeal approaches will not work any longer; a comprehensive plan that takes into account the city’s past and future growth needs to be drawn up and implemented.

Title: Nashik finds place in top-20 performing smart cities
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Nashik: The Union ministry of Housing and Urban Affairs (MoHUA) has ranked Nashik 12th among the top-20 performing smart cities for planning and implementing projects.

The ministry has also directed Nashik to pair with Jammu city and lend a helping hand in improving the latter’s execution of smart city projects and improve its ranking. Jammu city has been ranked 95th for lagging in implementation of smart city projects.

CEO of the Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation Ltd (NMSCDCL) Prakash Thavil said that securing a high rank among 100 cities under Smart City Mission is praiseworthy. “It will give boost to the entire team involved in the implementation of the projects related to Smart City,” he added.

Some other cities that have found place in the top-20 performing smart cities include Ahmedabad, Nagpur, Tiruppur, Ranchi, Bhopal, Surat, Kanpur, Indore, Visakhapatnam, Vellore, Vadodara, Agra, Varanasi, Indore and Pune.

MoHUA sources said the ministry had undertaken internal assessment of the overall performances about implementation of projects based on the weekly progress of the projects over a period of time.

“Based on these assessments the ministry has ranked the cities in the manner the projects are planned, tenders & work orders issued, status of projects, among others.”

The ministry has decided that each of these top-20 cities would pair with the worst performing 20 cities.

“We have been given the responsibility of guiding the Jammu municipal body for implementing projects. Initially a team of officials from the Jammu civic body would visit Nashik so that we can explain to them the manner in which projects are planned and implemented,” Thavil said.

The ranking of Nashik among the top-20 cities come at a time when the NMSCDCL has received flak from various quarters about the implementation of the city’s maiden smart road.

Title: Karnal’s first case of yellow rust in Indri
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Karnal: The first case of yellow rust on the wheat crop this season has been detected in Karnal district, confirmed an official of the state agriculture department on Monday.

Soon after getting information, the district agriculture and farmers’ welfare department swung into action and a team comprising assistant plant protection officer (APPO) Suresh and agriculture development officer (ADO) Rakesh Kumar inspected the affected fields in Nalvikhurd village, Indri sub-division, on Sunday and confirmed the fungal disease on wheat.

“We got information about the disease on Sunday morning. We visited the fields and found around four acres of wheat crop of farmers Amit and Sandeep Kumar affected. The disease has been identified at an initial stage and under control. The farmers have sprayed propiconazole,” APPO Suresh said.

The farmers, he said, had sown HD-2851 variety of wheat. “We have already launched an awareness campaign among farmers and intensified surveys to identify more areas. It will be controlled in time,” he said. The district agriculture department has issued an advisory to farmers too.

Farm department’s sub-divisional officer Sunil Kumar Bazad advised farmers to inspect their fields every day. He said if they find yellow rust, farmers should spray 200 ml of propiconazole in 200 litres of water in the affected fields. Cases of yellow rust attack have been reported in Ambala, Panchkula, Kurukshetra and Yamunanagar districts too.

Title: Kataria falls ill
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Opposition leader Gulab Chand Kataria left the assembly during question hour after he fell ill. Kataria left the assembly after he complained of diarrhea. Talking to TOI over the phone the BJP leader said he suffered from food poisoning. Hence, he had to leave the assembly by the end of the question hour. However, he is now on his way to recovery. The 75-year-old leader is an eight-time MLA currently representing Udaipur assembly seat.

Title: Man pelts stone at procession, booked
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Jind: Police have booked a man for allegedly throwing a stone at a religious procession taken out to observe the birth anniversary of Guru Ravidas in Singhana village of Safidon sub-division in Jind district.

Members of the Dalit community were taking out the procession in the village on Sunday, when one Sonu of the Rajput community threw a stone at them. Dalits stopped the march and demanded action against the accused for hurting their sentiments. They also raised slogans against police and administration. Soon after, Bhim Army activists also reached the spot and demanded action against the stone-pelter.

DSP (headquarters) Pushpa Khatri said a case had been registered against the accused under the Scheduled Castes/Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act and he would be arrested soon. TNN

Title: Coronavirus Hyderabad: Granite business hits coronavirus bump, down by Rs 100 crore
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: The latest to be hit by the outbreak of novel coronavirus (2019 n-CoV) in China is Telangana ’s thriving granite industry. Industry sources said sales of at least 15,000 cubic metres of granite had been put on hold. This has resulted in a loss of around Rs 100 crore.With Chinese businessmen who othewise frequent granite quarrying units in Karimnagar, Warangal and Khammam in January and February confined in their country, trading took a beating. “Chinese traders come to these districts every month. In March, China conducts a big international exhibition where their businessmen buy more granite from us in January and February alone. We sold 15,000 cubic metres of granite for which they paid up to Rs 20,000 per cubic metre this season. The loss is estimated to be around Rs 100 crore,” Telangana Smallscale Granite Industries’ Association president R Nageswara Rao told TOI.Industry sources said Telangana along with Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka exports quality granite to several countries, including China and Taiwan. A major chunk of exports from Telangana go to China, while Rajasthan, Mumbai and Delhi are leading importers of granite. “Around 20% of our business depends on exports to China. We can manage with (revenues) through the domestic market for some time but our main profits accrue from exports to China,” said a trader from Karimnagar.Adding to traders’ woes, the Centre has also prohibited Chinese traders from coming to Bengaluru where an international exhibition took place recently.With granite quarry owners losing business, the industry is also suffering from lack of movement between the two countries with import of many tools used in the granite making stopped as a result of the coronavirus outbreak . This is likely to hit several small-scale industries in the state.“There won’t be any improvement in the situation for at least a year. If this persists, only 10% of the industry will survive. This is a big threat as the granite industry survices on exports. There is a possibility that many of them may become non-performing assets (NPAs),” said Yerram Raju of the Telangana Industrial Health Clinic Limited.“For instance, the Hyderabad international airport has been built using furnished granite from China but the raw stone had gone from here,” he added.

Title: Man murders wife over family dispute
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

KRISHNAGIRI: A 39-year-old man murdered his wife by slitting her throat near Veppanahalli here in the early hours of Monday over a family dispute .

Police identified the deceased as N Priya, 35, of Gangojikothur village. She was a homemaker.

An investigation officer said Priya was a native of Chennai and that she had been married to V Natarajan, a car driver, for more than five years. The couple have a five-year-old son.

“They had been moving around Chennai, Bengaluru and Hosur as part of their works, before settling down in Hosur along with Natarajan’s parents,” the officer said.

Priya, the officer said, was employed with a private hospital in Hosur. “She lost her job in January. Her husband too was not doing well at work. Some 15 days ago, Priya and Natarajan had picked up a quarrel over remaining jobless and after that she had left for Chennai to live with her mother.”

However, Natarajan managed to pacify her and brought her back home on Sunday morning. But they entered into another big fight the same night. “At one stage, Natarajan slit Priya’s throat using a knife, killing her on the spot,” the officer said.

Natarajan then told his parents that he had murdered his wife and they alerted the neighbours, who called in the Veppanahalli police.

Police held inquiry with Natarajan, who confessed to the crime. They registered a case based on his confessional statement and arrested him. He was subsequently lodged in the Salem Central Prison under judicial custody in the evening.

The Veppanahalli police, meanwhile, sent the dead body to the Krishnagiri government hospital for postmortem.

Title: Health department to promote organ donation at village level
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Times News Network

Jaipur: The health department has decided to generate awareness on organ donation at the gram panchayat level, the move coming barely a month after the SMS Hospital conducted its first cadaver heart transplant on January 16.

The state plans to rope in swasthya mitras under Nirogi Rajasthan scheme to spread awareness on organ donation. There are 40,000-odd villages in the state with each having two swasthya mitras — a man and a woman.

“We will deploy 80,000 swasthya mitras at all the gram panchayats under Nirogi Rajasthan. For each village, we will identify a man and a woman. We are planning to promote organ donation at the grassroots level,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary, health department.

These swasthya mitras will be deployed in every village with a purpose to bridge the gap between the health department and patients and to promote health schemes.

Apart from the existing fleet of auxiliary nurse midwives, ASHA and anganwadi workers in every village, the health department is gearing up to deploy a different sort of ‘force’ in the village.

The swasthya mitras, who will be trained in national and state’s health programmes, should have the knowledge of health and medical policies launched by the state government.

Title: 14 flights delayed from SVPI airport
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Ahmedabad: The departure of 14 flights from the city to various destinations got delayed from Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International (SVPI) airport in Ahmedabad on Monday.

These include flights to Mumbai, Amritsar, Jaipur, Kishangarh, Delhi, Pune, Kolkata, Chandigarh and Goa, among others. These flights were delayed from 30 minutes up to two hours, due to operational reasons.

One international flight from Ahmedabad to London was also delayed by some 4 hours and 45 minutes. Well-placed sources, however, confirmed that the said flight had a scheduled delay due to delay in arrival of incoming aircraft and that passengers were informed on the previous night.

Title: Chennai Accident: Man killed as unidentified vehicle hits bike
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

ERODE: A 22-year-old man was killed near Sathyamangalam in Erode district on Sunday night after an unknown vehicle hit his two-wheeler.

Police identified the deceased as K Navin Kumar, of Nehru Nagar in Sathyamangalam. He was working in a private company in Andhiyur and was staying in his sister’s house there, a police officer said.

“On Sunday, while returning to Andhiyur after visiting his father at Sathyamangalam, an unknown vehicle rammed his bike near a private arts and science college on Sathyamangalam-Athani state highway. He sustained severe injuries,” the officer said.

After being alerted by passersby, the Sathyamangalam police reached the spot and took him to the government hospital in the town. “But he died before reaching the hospital,” the officer said. Police have registered a case and launched a search for the vehicle. “CCTV footage from nearby shops is being checked to identify the vehicle,” the officer added.

Title: Labour unrest: Kanjikode may lose one more industrial unit
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Palakkad: The soft drink giant , Pepsi Cola closed its bottling plant at Kanjikode industrial area from Friday due to the strike by nearly 200 contract labourers of a Labour supply company.

The company management has moved the Kerala High Court for police protection as the striking contract workers had allegedly attacked a manager and a driver of the company and prevented the movement of products and stopped the management and staff from entering the company.

The sources in the company management said that the workers did not allow the management staff to come out of the company after their shift.

The management is seriously thinking of closing the unit and bringing the products to Kerala from its plants in the neighbouring Tamil Nadu, the sources said. They said that Pepsi Cola India Limited that was running the company gave the plant to Varun Breweries to run, due to the loss it’s units were facing in different parts of the country.

The management sources said that the contract workers went on strike because the wage revision issue was pending with the regional labour commissioner.

Many major industrial units were closed despite industries minister E P Jayarajan announcing that an Industrial Felicitation Centre would be set up at Kanjikode and declaring that all those industrial units that had shifted its units to the neighbouring states will be brought back during his visit to Kanjikode on January 27, 2020. While inaugurating the adalat at Palakkad collectorate on January 26 the minister said, “the LDF government is trying to attract industries to Kerala to prove that the state is industrial friendly.”

Because of the picketing and strike by the contract workers more than 250 permanent workers are not allowed to enter the company for work. The company provides direct and indirect employment to nearly 1,000 persons. The contract workers are on strike demanding wage hike. They are paid Rs 605 daily plus PF and ESI benefits. The contracting company offered to hike Rs 25 per day but the workers are demanding a hike of Rs 200 per day. But in other plants of the company in the neighbouring states the contract workers are paid Rs 250 to Rs 300 per day.

Title: Organs harvested in govt hosp airlifted to Chennai
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Salem: Ten organs of a brain-dead man were harvested at the Salem Government Mohan Kumaramangalam Medical College Hospital (SGMKMCH) in the city on Monday. The organs were donated to hospitals in Salem, Coimbatore and Chennai.

Hospital dean Dr Balajinathan said, “We have harvested 10 organs from J Surendar, 20, of Perumangalam village in Kallakurichi district.”

He said the victim had met with an accident on February 8 at Yethapur near Vazhapadi in Salem district and admitted to the hospital.

P Jayakumar, father of the victim, told reporters that doctors at the hospital had declared his son brain-dead on Sunday.

“The family members immediately agreed to donate the victim’s organs to the needy,” Dr Balajinathan said.

A team of doctors harvested eyes, kidneys, lungs, liver, heart, spinal bones and skins from the victim’s body.

He said heart and lungs were donated to a private hospital in Chennai, while the kidneys were given to private hospitals in Salem and Coimbatore. “Bone and skins were given to another private hospital in Coimbatore and the lungs were given to a private hospital in Salem,” he said.

After completing the organ harvesting procedure, the doctors handed over the body to Jayakumar.

Meanwhile, the Salem city police made elaborated arrangements to transport lungs and heart to the airport at Kamalapuram near Omalur from Salem city to be taken to Chennai.

“The airport is 22km away from the government hospital and the team of doctors reached the airport within 15 minutes,” T Senthil Kumar, Salem city police commissioner, told TOI.

The commissioner said they had deployed police personnel for governor’s security to make arrangements. “So, it was easy for us to transport the vital organs to the airport,” he said, adding that the traffic was halted between the stretch for a while.

Title: Urban local body polls in April: EPS, OPS seek to put house in order
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Chennai: The state election commission is likely to hold elections to the urban local bodies in Tamil Nadu in April, sources said.

The AIADMK leaders chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami and his deputy O Panneerselvam on Monday convened a meeting of party functionaries, including ministers and MLAs, and issued a stern directive about putting an end to internal squabbles for the forthcoming civic polls to the urban local bodies.

The party leadership took serious note of the factional feud taking a toll on the party’s poll prospects. “The election to urban local bodies will take place in April, while the newly-constituted nine districts will go to polls after delimitation. So the party is gearing up for polls,” said a source.

The four-day long meeting began in the morning at the AIADMK headquarters in Chennai. EPS and OPS met functionaries led by their secretaries, district-wise. Most of the district secretaries are ministers. Among the first batch were the delta districts, including Karur, Thanjavur, Nagapattinam, Tiruvarur, Pudukkottai and Perambalur. Barring Karur, the party fared poorly in the delta belt in the rural local body elections.

The secretaries of the districts that put up a poor show in the civic polls and where the DMK and its allies scored handsomely were pulled up. “Thanjavur functionaries pointed to AMMK denting their prospects in many areas,” said a party functionary.

The functionaries pointed to the party’s stand on the contentious Citizenship Amendment Act and National Population Register as one of the reasons for losing minority votes, even as the opposition was exerting pressure on the government to pass a resolution in the assembly against it.

“The leadership also tried to pep up morale of the functionaries and ready them for the 2021 polls. They said losses and gains were part of life and that we should strive for future victories. Announcements in the upcoming budget session will give the party a boost,” said a minister, seeking anonymity. Later in the evening, the party announced that the meeting scheduled on Thursday, a day before the start of Budget session, would be postponed to Saturday.

Title: ‘Heading finance dept a new experience’
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Haryana chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar says handling the finance department is a new experience for him. Busy holding various rounds of meetings with stakeholders ahead of the state budget, he tells Manvir Saini that the document would have something for everybody

For the first time, Haryana will have a CM present the budget. What prompted you to keep the finance department with you?

This is certainly a new and lifetime experience for me. I am able to understand the technicalities behind finance management. As I had to keep one important or major department, I chose to keep this. Last time, I had the home department etc.

We have seen an extraordinary exercise ahead of the presentation of the budget. What do you have in store for the state?

There are two categories of people in the state — haves and have nots... both require equal attention. I’ve travelled across the state to know the pulse of businessmen, traders, industrialists, farmers and common man. Now, we shall have a session for interaction with elected representatives -- MLAs and MPs -- to know their feedback and finalise the document. Yes, we shall have something for everybody, especially the youth.

In your last term as CM, BJP had come to power on its own. This time, you have a coalition government.

There’s not much of a difference. We all are a team. During the last term, we had our cabinet colleagues and we used to organise small official and unofficial meetings. It is the same now. I, deputy chief minister and other ministers speak to each other on regular basis. Our main focus is to ensure an early completion of public interest projects.

What kind of issues come up regarding manifestoes of two parties (BJP & JJP). How do you deal with it?

Both the parties released their manifestoes in public interest. BJP’s manifesto (regarding social benefits) would put a burden of Rs 30,000 crore on the exchequer, and JJP’s Rs 36,000 crore. As the difference of financial allocation is not much and most promises are common, we don’t face any problem. We are moving ahead with the common minimum programme.

How does the government plan to ensure that 75% unskilled jobs go to local youth?

This issue is right at the top of the common minimum programme with our coalition partner. Labour and industry cannot work without each other. We intend to bring in legislation to make it a reality. But, one thing is for sure, this system will not be forced upon industries or businessmen. They will have at least a three-year period to decide whether they want to go with it or not. We have this kind of provision in the town and country department. While applying for CLU, an entrepreneur has to ensure at least 75% jobs for locals. But, this has not become workable. It will be done now in a systematic manner.

As CM, what are your achievements in getting projects in the general budget this time?

One, we have managed to get the museum at Rakhirgarhi. Second, orbital rail corridor and state getting special attention in allocation for tourism. Orbital is a major project wherein cost will be shared by state and Union governments and private stakeholders. It will help in transportation ease in Haryana and NCR. Similarly, there’s Kurukshetra circuit for promoting tourism.

Despite your claims of achievement in 100 days (of governance), the opposition continues to target the coalition, especially while referring to law and order unemployment.

Our projects and development are for masses, not the opposition. We are the ones who increased social security pension schemes, started the concept of setting up examination centres within a 50km radius and so on. More than 100 small and big works have been done.

You count the number of criminals arrested and the cases solved. Look at the conviction rate. The opposition is looking for issues to disturb communal harmony by provocation. In other words, the opposition is jobless these days. It is not necessary that we reply their every question.

Be it the CID issue or paddy, the opposition has grabbed the opportunity to take on government.

There was no such controversy or issue. Anil Vij ji is a senior MLA and a very good friend of mine. Our party as well as the democratic system allows us to speak up. The issue was technical in nature. It now stands resolved and we continue to work as good friends and team. As for scam, let the Congress count the number of vigilance or CBI probes ordered during its tenure. Now they should count ours.

Title: Woman sets herself on fire in front of police station
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Nashik: Upset with her married daughter, a 55-year-old woman set herself ablaze in front of a police station in the city on Monday evening. The woman has suffered 90% burns, said the medical officers in the burns ward of the Nashik civil hospital.

Senior police officials said the incident took place at around 6.15 pm on the road in front of the police station.

DCP Laxmikant Patil said, “The woman’s 27-year-old daughter got married to a man from Raipur in Chhatisgarh on January 18 this year. According to the daughter, her husband had started beating and abusing her within seven days of their marriage. The girl’s parent had also been to Raipur to resolve the problem. The girl was unhappy with her parents’ attitude as they were not supportive of her.”

DCP Patil added that two days back, the girl left her husband’s house in Raipur and returned to Nashik. She has been staying with a female friend since.

Her parents were upset with her for leaving her husband and also for not coming home to stay with them Therefore, the parents came to the police station.

The police had also called the girl to the police station for inquiry. Patil said the girl neither wanted to return to her husband’s house nor her parents’ residence and said that she preferred to stay alone. In frustration, the mother went outside the police station and set herself on fire, while the police were recording statements of the newlywed girl and her father.

The incident shocked everyone. The police and others managed to douse the fire and rushed the woman to the Nashik civil hospital. Medical officers said the woman was brought to the hospital at around 7 pm and that she had suffered 90% burns.

DCP Patil said, “It is yet to be ascertained how the woman set herself on fire and whether she had come with a bottle/container of petrol or kerosene with her. We are investigating the case further.”

Title: Gandhipuram flyover isn’t for joggers
Content:
