This story is from February 11, 2020

Coimbatore: The city police have said the Gandhipuram second level flyover is off limits to walkers and joggers and warned against taking selfies on the flyover.

Advising the residents to not use the flyover for walking and jogging, R Mutharasu, deputy commissioner of police (traffic), said the flyover which connects the 100 Feet Road – Chinnasamy Road is only for vehicles. “Action would be taken against people who are using the flyover for jogging and walking,” he said.

Besides, some people stop their vehicles on the flyover to take selfies. “People should not take selfies on the flyover. Cases would be registered against violators,” he added.

To prevent truck movements during the peak hours near Tidal Park, the traffic police have put up displays from Avinashi Road to Thaneerpandal Road against it. The displays state that trucks are not allowed on the stretch between 8am and 11am as well as between 4pm and 8pm. If trucks were found using the stretch, police will impose a fine of Rs 20,000 under Section 115 and Section 194 of the Motor Vehicles Act. tnn

Title: Teachers hold Save Agra University yajna to protest alleged scam by VC
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

AGRA: Instructors of Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University on Monday organised a “Save Agra University” yajna to register their protest against vice-chancellor Arvind Kumar Dixit, for allegedly withdrawing Rs 1.5 crore from the account of teacher’s welfare fund (TWF), in violation of norms.

Under the banner of Agra University Teachers Association (AUTA), teachers of 39 government-aided colleges in Agra and seven nearby districts organised the yajna. Association leaders accused the VC of financial irregularities and demanded strict action against him, besides immediate transfer of the amount he had allegedly withdrawn back to the TWF account.

Protestors said the VC on January 3 transferred Rs 1.5 crore from the TWF account to the university's main account, in violation of norms. AUTA demanded that the state government should investigate the matter, and that the fund, mandated for use only on welfare of teachers, be deposited back in its account. They also demanded action be taken against the VC for financial malpractice.

AUTA general secretary Nishant Chauhan said, “Until the VC reimburses the TWF funds, he will not be invited to any programme organised by government-aided colleges. If he still visits for any other purpose, teachers will protest with black flags, he said. From Tuesday onwards, teachers will also boycott work between 11am- 2pm.”

Earlier on January 20, AUTA had handed over a memorandum to varsity administration, demanding return of the fund withdrawn from TWF within three days. However, the VC did not take any action.

BAU public relations officer, G S Sharma , said, “The claims and allegations of AUTA leaders are baseless and part of a tactic to put pressure on the university administration. TWF is generated from the fee provided to teachers for evaluation of answer sheets. We had Rs 2.5 crore in its account, of which, the contribution of teachers of government-aided colleges in Agra is around 9%. Presently, Rs 1 crore is available in the TWF account. The remaining Rs 1.5 crore has been utilised to build a guest house for teachers on Khandari campus. Standard procedure was followed in utilisation of the fund, and on construction work.”

Title: Rural cops to take custody of MP suspects
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Nashik: A team from the Nashik rural police will soon leave for Madhya Pradesh (MP) to take custody of five suspects who have been arrested by the Tikamgarh police in connection with two cases of automated teller machine (ATM) thefts.

A senior police officer said that on February 4, unidentified burglars had broken an ATM in Vinchur of Niphad taluka and decamped with Rs 4.75 lakh from it. On the same day another ATM was broken with the help of a gas cutter in Pimpalgoan Baswant, from where Rs 25,400 was stolen.

Police inspector KK Patil of the local crime branch of Nashik rural police said that during investigation, they got information that the burglars have been arrested by the police in Madhya Pradesh in connection with a theft case.

“Five suspects have been arrested by the Tikamgarh police. While three are from Haryana, two are from UP.”

There was one more attempt to uproot an ATM in Niphad taluka on Friday. However, the criminals escaped from the spot soon after spotting a police patrol team arriving in the area.

Title: 7 Delhi tourists injured as car plunges into gorge
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Manali: Seven tourists from Delhi sustained minor injuries after the their car fell into a 100m deep gorge near Manikaran in Kullu on Sunday night. According to police, the vehicle met with the accident near Jainala due to skidding on the road. The injured were rushed to the hospital at Jari, from where three were referred to the regional hospital Kullu. TNN

Title: Himachal Pradesh: 21-year-old killed while paragliding
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

DHARAMSHALA: A 21-year-old youth from Kangra district died on Sunday late evening during tandem flight at international paragliding site at Bir Billing, the police said. It was learnt that the youth was learning paragliding for the last few days. He was having flight with one of his friends and had hired the glider from a company.

The deceased has been identified as Akshay Kumar. DSP Pooran Chand Thukral said a case has been registered and an investigation started. “One person has died while other received injuries,” he added.

Police have registered a case and the matter is being investigated.

Earlier, four people--three tourists and a pilot--were killed and two injured in three separate accidents in Himachal Pradesh 's Kullu district.

A Kerala tourist, Altho Bachu, and pilot Naresh Kumar died in a paragliding crash near Dobhi village in Naggar area of Kullu on April 7 last year.

Similarly, a tourist from Punjab's Mohali district, Amandeep Singh (23), died and pilot Ranjir Singh injured in the Solang valley of Kullu on May 18. TNN

Title: Mumbai: Consumer forum orders Rs 13,000 payout for cockroach in coffee
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: A district consumer forum has ordered Coffee Day Global to pay a compensation of Rs 13,000 to two Navi Mumbai residents after one of them found a cockroach in her cold coffee. The patrons had paid Rs 224 for the coffee and some eatables. The forum held that the company was negligent in maintaining basic hygiene standards and had to compensate the patrons for it.

Prachi Patil and Rameshchandra Kumawat submitted a complaint before the additional Mumbai suburban district consumer disputes redressal forum on January 16, 2018. They said they had visited the Café Coffee Day outlet at a Kurla mall, where after consuming the coffee, at the bottom of the glass, they found a cockroach. They further stated that after seeing the insect, they felt nauseous, giddy and had chills. The patrons said they immediately complained to the coffee shop and subsequently even sent an email to the customer care. They said since they got no favourable response, they lodged a complaint with the forum.

Patil and Kumawat also submitted pictures of the insect, a copy of the bill and the emailed complaint copy.

The company responded to the complaint and denied the allegations.

They said the complaint was filed with a mala fide intention to extort money from them. The company also submitted that the complainants were lawyers and they were misusing the law. It said the duo had themselves got the dead cockroach and planted in the coffee. The company further submitted it was not plausible that the patrons would come all the way from Navi Mumbai to have coffee at their outlet at Kurla.

It said that all these circumstances showed that the duo had submitted a false complaint.

The forum, though, refuted the company’s submissions. It said the company had not submitted any evidence to back its claims that the patrons had themselves brought the dead cockroach and planted it.

It also observed that the company had not brought anything on record to show how it maintained hygiene at its outlets.

The forum said the company had not brought any evidence to counter photographs given by the complainants.

Title: Push credit to MSMEs: RBI to banks
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Panaji: Concerned about the survival of Goa’s MSME (Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises) sector, the Reserve Bank of India on Monday urged private and public sector banks to enhance lending to entrepreneurs in a proactive manner.

RBI General Manager for Goa N J Nampoothiri said that lack of basic understanding of the financial products, banking procedures and risk-return framework were some of the challenges that inhibit the progress of MSME units.

“This (MSME sector) is where the GDP will come from so this is something that needs to concern all of us. Unfortunately, the sensitisation or awareness that we try to do for bankers through financial literacy centres, much more needs to be done,” Nampoothiri said.

Candidly admitting that entrepreneurs often face problems while sourcing funds, Nampoothiri encouraged banks to appraise MSME projects in a different manner.

“We need to move away from collateral and look at proposals which are inherently good,” he said. His suggestion was supported by Nabard general manager Kamakshi Pai. “Bankers need to appraise the entrepreneur along with the project. Appraise the attitude of the entrepreneur,” she said.

Addressing bankers while launching the financial literacy week, Nampoothiri said that MSMEs play a significant role in economic development of the country. At the same time, knowledge of financial norms and compliances is missing.

“The sector contributes about 45% of the manufacturing output of the whole country. More than 40% of the exports comes from sector and nearly one third of the GDP is accounted for by MSMEs. It employs 11 crore people,” the RBI official said.

Nampoothiri, who took over as Goa officer-in-charge just a week earlier, said that all stakeholders need to work together. “Many MSMEs have not been brought into the formal fold which is why it makes banks reluctant to lend. Only if the credibility of the MSME is there, will the banker come forward. This is where the government should play a helping hand in trying to bring the MSMEs into the formal fold,” he said.

Title: Calf killed in suspected leopard attack
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Coimbatore: The forest department on Monday deployed anti-poaching watchers and set up cameras in and around Chittepalayam village near the Sirumugai forest after a four-month-old calf was killed in a suspected leopard attack.

Forest officers said the calf, reared by N Murugan, 48, of Chittepalayam, was found dead with bite marks near his house on Monday morning.

“On Sunday night, Murugan had let his cattle graze on his farmland at the foothills of Thenkalkaradu, which is just 50m from the forest. As the calf did not return, he launched a search in the morning and its carcass was found near his field,” a forest officer said.

When alerted, Sirumugai forest range officer E N Manoharan and his team reached the spot. Villagers complained that a leopard had been roaming in the area and urged him to capture it immediately. They also threatened to stage a protest if the incident were to be repeated.

Following this, the forest department deployed anti-poaching watchers and fixed four cameras to monitor and capture the movement of wild animals in the area. “We installed camera traps to find out which animal killed the calf. If leopard is roaming in the area, we will immediately place traps to capture it,” Manoharan said. tnn

Title: Company shortlisted to lift water for Shimla from Satluj
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Shimla: With Shimla Jal Prabandhan Ltd (SJPNL) almost completing the tendering process to draw water from Satluj river through Kol Dam by shortlisting a company, the residents of hill town can look forward to round-the-clock water supply in next three years, as the project is likely to be completed by 2022. Water to will be brought to Shimla by lifting it 1,600-meter high with four pumping stations. TNN

Title: SC issue notice in Agra defence property scam
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Supreme Court

AGRA: The Supreme Court has issued notice to the government of India, Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) and headquarters of Army’s Central Command seeking their response in the alleged defence property scam in Agra.

According to the petitioner and local RTI activist Bir Bahadur Singh , CBI even after four and a half years of delay has not been able to complete investigation in the case which involved a Rs 20 crore defence property illegally acquired by Agra cantonment board vice-president in 1996 in connivance with the defence estate officials.

The activist who is also an ex-serviceman has been pursuing the matter since 2011. On basis of response to RTI queries filled by the activist, in 2012, four members of Parliament, including the then minister of state for human resource development Ramshankar Katheria and incumbent Maharashtra governor Bhagat Singh Koshyari , had recommended a CBI probe into the defence property scam.

According to the defence estate records, 1.36 acres of defence land was given on lease to one Mitthan Lal for 30 years on March 2, 1936. After Lal’s death, the property was transferred to his wife Anara Devi. In 1966, the lease of the property was extended for another 30 years. On July 7, 1972, Anara Devi died. Mitthan Lal and Anara Devi had no son or daughter.

According to the petitioner, taking advantage of the situation, two women, Prakash Singh and Kalawati Devi , claiming to be relatives of Mitthan Lal and Anara Devi came forward to take hold of the property. Later, the high court found papers provided by the two women to be fake. The quarter was taken back by the defence estate department.

According to the petitioner, in 1984, one KS Bhatnagar, son on Kalawati Devi, got the property transferred in his name from defence estate. In the entire process, no approval was taken from the defence ministry.

According to the petitioner, incumbent Agra cantonment board vice-president Pankaj Mahendru in conveyance with the defence estate officials got the property transferred from Kalawati’s son to Mohammad Nasim and Raisuddin in 1996. Later, he on basis of fake documents got the property registered in his name, the petitioner alleged.

Petitioner Bir Bahadur Singh said, “It is surprising that CBI has not been able to come to any conclusion in the case. Now, after the court notice, they will have to submit the probe report. The ministry of defence should immediately attach the property. Besides, FIR should be registered against all those involved in the scam.”

When contacted, ACB vice-president Pankaj Mahendru said, “The allegations are completely baseless and politically motivated. I have all the valid documents related to the property. The property was transferred to me after approval from the ministry of defence. Later, the lease was also extended.”

Mahendru has been the vice-president of ACB since 1998. His father, OP Mahendru, held the same post for around 25 years till 1991.

Title: Tribals in Cotigao to boycott ZP elections
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Poinguinim: Peeved by the lack of basic amenities, nearly 200 residents of Nadkem and Keri in Cotigao have resolved to boycott the upcoming zilla panchayat polls.

Residents of these hamlets that are located in forested areas, have lamented that even after 59 years of Liberation, they have been deprived of a motorable road among other facilities.

Reshma Gaonkar, a local of Nadkem, lamented the lack of a primary school for children who walk long distances.

Former Cotigao sarpanch Rajesh Gaonkar said the people are forest dwellers, many of whom have submitted land claims under the Forest Rights Act.

Though some residents have obtained sanads, they have to endure a lot of hardship to carry out maintenance work of their homes, said sarpanch Umesh Gaonkar. “When they want to expand their homes, obtaining necessary approvals is cumbersome,” he said.

Meanwhile, the residents of Keri, Nadkem, Kuskem, Yedda and Bhutpal have submitted a petition to the government through Canacona MLA Isidore Fernandes to exclude their areas from the Cotigao Wildlife Sanctuary.

Title: Cong: Ready for public debate with Rane over medicine scam
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Panaji: Keeping up the attack on health minister Vishwajit Rane, Congress on Monday challenged him to reveal the rate at which Goa Medical College and hospital, Bambolim, procures medicines and medical equipment from a private pharmacy.

Accepting Rane’s challenge to a public debate, state Congress president Girish Chodankar said it should be held in front of the Pharma Traders’ Association and the media. He said Rane’s veiled threats were an indication that the minister wanted to “cover his medicine purchase scam”.

“What kind of special rate contract for special discount was signed between the pharmacy and the government? What exorbitant cost is he (Rane) procuring the medicines to give them free to patients at GMC?” Chodankar asked.

Chodankar wants the health minister to specify if the private pharmacy in question offers discounts to patients who purchase medicines directly, if other government hospitals in India purchase medicines at maximum retail price (MRP), and why GMC does not have sufficient stocks of medicines.

“Are Vishwajit and Goa FDA aware that the pharmacy supplies medicines to GMC at MRP using a wholesale licence? Is this legal and allowed ?” Chodankar asked.

Title: 5-year-old girl killed in accident, 2 relatives hurt
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Nashik: A five-year-old girl was killed while two others suffered serious injuries after the two-wheeler they were travelling on was hit by a speeding pick-up vehicle on the Shinde-Naygaon road in the Nashik Road area on Sunday evening.

According to the police, the driver of the pick-up vehicle fled the scene after the accident. The deceased girl has been identified as Ashlesha Shamrao Pagare, a resident of Mohagaon in Jakhori.

The victim was travelling on the bike with her 40-year-old aunt and one more relative. At 6.30 pm, when the three were near the Uni Deritend company, their vehicle was hit by an unidentified pick-up vehicle coming from the opposite direction.

The girl’s father, who was working in his farm, got a call from his sister’s cellphone by an unidentified person informing him about the accident.

The caller also told Ashlesha’s father that the pick-up vehicle driver had fled the scene after the accident.

“By the time Ashlesha’s father reached the spot, the injured trio had been taken to a private hospital,” a police officer said.

“When the father reached the hospital, the doctors admitted the injured and referred the girl to NMC’s Bytco hospital. Later, Ashlesha was declared brought dead at the civic hospital. She had suffered injuries on her head and face,” a police officer said.

“We have registered an offence of causing death by negligence against the unidentified driver. So far, we have not received any clue about the motorist who caused the accident. His vehicle registration number was also not noted down by any passer-by. Ashlesha’s aunt and another relative are out of danger now,” he added

Title: Illegal hawkers return to Shalimar area, traffic congestion likely to follow
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Nashik: Illegal hawkers have returned and reoccupied the M G Road-Shalimar stretch — from where they were removed just 10 days ago. As a result, traffic problems and congestion have also returned to the area.

On January 31, the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) and the city police had undertaken a special anti-encroachment drive in the area to clear the congestion on roads. Before that, senior police officials had also conducted a meeting with the hawkers to inform them about the anti-encroachment drive. The hawkers were given the choice of relocating to the area behind the Regional Referral Hospital. However, many of the hawkers had objected to the proposal. Nonetheless, the anti-encroachment department went ahead with its drive and cleared the MG Road-Shalimar area known as the Nepali Corner.

Over the past few days, one of two hawkers started returning to the stretch. However, on Monday, the entire stretch was again filled with hawkers. Many commuters said the situation is back to square one. They said they would again start facing traffic congestions.

Amit Kawale, a salesman at a shop in the MG Road area, said, “Riding a bike becomes difficult during the evening hours. The hawkers don’t just occupy one side of the road. They sit on both sides.”

Kawale added that the police and the NMC should continue the drives regularly.

Sajan Sonawane, senior PI of the Bhadrakali police station, said that the police are driving away the hawkers on a regular basis. However, soon after the police are gone, the hawkers return. He said that the vehicle of the NMC’s anti-encroachment department should be visiting the place on a regular basis as they seize the articles of the hawkers, which is a great deterrent. “We would communicate the problem to the NMC officials,” he said.

The encroachers also occupy space near the Shalimar bus stand leaving very little space for the movement of vehicles, especially city buses.

Title: Apple growers to get imported saplings from US
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Shimla: The Himachal Pradesh government will import apple saplings this year from the US instead of Italy for distribution among farmers under Rs 1,134-crore World Bank-funded project. The decision came following complaints about the saplings imported from Italy, including 3.05 lakh drying up before their distribution to farmers.

However, under pressure from the state, the Italian nursery, which had supplied the saplings in wrong season, has now agreed to replace the same. In the first round, 75,000 plants will be replaced. Under the Rs 1,134-crore horticulture development project, the state government had imported 7,55,250 apple plants from Italy in 2015-16 and 2016-17 at a cost of Rs 400 per plant. Later, chief minister Jai Ram Thakur had decided to give relief to apple producers and provided 50% subsidy on these plants at the rate of Rs 200 per plant.

Horticulture minister Mahender Singh Thakur said that the apple plants imported from Italy in past had complaints, including 3.05 lakh plants going dry before their distribution among the farmers, as plants were sent from Italy in the months of April and May.

Title: Int’l workshop on crop diversification begins
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Dharamshala: Nearly 150 agricultural experts from Myna mar, Pakistan, Japan and from India have gathered at this hill town to participate in an intern ational workshop on crop diversification. Project director Kishore Chandera Azad said the workshop would conclude on Wednesday with a field visit of experts in this part of the state. CM Thakur addressed the gathering during his short visit to attend this programme. TNN

Title: Vulture population down from 4 cr to 4 lakh in 3 decades
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

NEW DELHI: The population of vultures, which are carrion-eaters and considered quite useful for ecosystem services such as scavenging, has declined sharply in India from four crore to less than four lakh in three decades, environment minister Prakash Javadekar said on Monday.

"In India, vultures died after consuming dead cattle, which were given 'diclofenac' drug, and their population reduced from four crore to less than four lakh. We are taking efforts to revive the population," said Javadekar while addressing a press conference on the upcoming 13th Conference of Parties (COP13) of the UN Convention on Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (CMS).

'Diclofenac' is a veterinary drug used to treat cattle. It leads to death of vultures who feed on dead animals.

"Representatives from 130 countries, eminent conservationists and international NGOs working in the field of wildlife conservation will be attending COP13," said Javadekar, adding that the issue of decline in population of vultures would also be discussed.

Though wild life conservationists have long been demanding complete ban on 'diclofenac', it has not yet been banned across the country. The drug has only been banned in Tamil Nadu.

COP13 will be opened in Gandhinagar by Prime Minister Narendra Modi on February 17 through video-conference. The CMS is a global platform for the conservation and sustainable use of migratory animals and their habitats and brings together the range countries through which migratory species pass.

Title: Ramsar site may get more sluice gates
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Nashik: The district water resources department (WRD) is planning to install more sluice gates at the Nandur Madhmeshwar pickup weir in the Niphad taluka to tackle the issue of inundation of villages during floods.

The WRD is consulting the Central Water Power Research Station (CPWRS) to chalk out the number of sluice gates that can be installed at the weir, which was constructed by the British to ensure drinking water supply for the parched regions of Aurangabad and Ahmednagar districts in 1902.

“There are seven gates in bunches of four and three on each end of the weir, which take up more than half-a-kilometre width of the Godavari river. A few more gates will have to be installed to tackle the issue of inundation of villages during the floods,” said executive engineer of the Nashik irrigation division, Sagar Shinde.

The need to install more sluice gates was felt after Chandori and Saikheda villages were inundated due to heavy flooding last year, added Shinde.

In 2005-06, a few villages, including Chandori and Saikheda, had completely submerged due to the floods. The magnitude of the flood was such that water from Godavari river had submerged the road leading from Nashik to Aurangabad near Odha village and the road had to be kept shut till the flood water subsided. This was because the weir did not have sluice gates and sedimentation had eaten away a major portion of the weir.

“Because of the weir, the river always swelled and inundated the villages. The flood in 2005-06 was the worst. It was then that district guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal decided to install gates for the weir, took up the matter with the government and had the gates installed in 2010,” said Shinde.

Once installed, the gates at the weir addressed the problem of inundation of the villages, but not completely.

“The additional gates will ensure quick discharge of water coming from the upstream areas. Just as the seven gates reduced the risk of inundation by more than 70%, chances are that the additional gates will fully combat the risk. This will definitely have huge an impact on the lives of the people and even on the economy of the region,” he said.

Title: Grievance meetings in corpn turn damp squib
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Trichy: In the absence of an elected council in Trichy Corporation, the weekly grievance meet on Mondays plays a crucial role for locals to get their grievances redressed. But, with the corporation undermining the significance of meet by not letting the petitioners meet the corporation commissioner and also his frequent unavailability, the number of petitioners coming there has declined over the past few months.

Every Monday, the chamber of the commissioner and special officer, S Sivasubramanian witnesses residents waiting to submit grievances. But, for the past few months, as the civic body chief is mostly unavailable, people were told to submit the complaints to second-level officers which yielded no solution.

Meanwhile, on Monday, petitioners from Makkal Needhi Maiam (MNM) approached the commissioner’s chamber to demand basic needs. But, officials told them that Sivasubramanian is away for an inspection and insisted them to submit the grievance to the city engineer. But, they decided to wait and meet the commissioner. “This is not the first time. We could not meet the commissioner twice earlier too. As we decided to wait, it took around three hours to meet him. Not all petitioners can afford to wait for long hours,” petitioner S R Kishore Kumar said.

Since petitioners are repeatedly told to submit the complaints to their respective assistant commissioners which are not materialising, residents said the purpose of grievance meets is diluted. “We tried to meet the commissioner twice last month for discussing the needs of street vendors. Till now, we could not meet him,” K Suresh, general secretary, Trichy district AITUC said.

The corporation has also cancelled the conduct of zonal-level grievance meet that was underway every Saturdays since July 2019. Efforts to seek a response from the corporation commissioner S Sivasubramanian went in vain.

When contacted, an official in the main office said, “If the district collector is absent, people submit grievances to the district revenue officer. Similarly, residents can submit their grievances to the city engineer.”

Title: Farmers stop digging of new ONGC oil well
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Trichy: A section of farmers of Alivalam village in Tiruvarur district on Monday opposed the digging of a new ONGC oil well on a piece of land owned by two farmers. Both had handed over their land to ONGC on lease for oil extraction two decades ago and two wells were completed. When ONGC workers were preparing to dig a third well on their land, both registered stiff opposition, alleging that operations had already depleted groundwater table.

ONGC authorities, who did not wish to be named, told TOI that as per the contract entered into with the farmers, they had begun work to dig a third well. Both the farmers had already received the monetary compensation as per the agreement. “So, they have no right to object,” they said. On Sunday, DMK’s principal secretary K N Nehru had dubbed the state government’s move to give a protection tag to delta districts as “double standards”.

Meanwhile, farmers’ leaders and activists have demanded that chief minister Edappadi Palaniswamy’s announcement to make the delta a protected zone be made the government’s policy decision. It should spell out that exploration or extraction process of hydrocarbon will not be allowed in the delta region anymore.

“There are some apprehensions about the manner in which the Union government and the oil companies will react to the CM’s announcement,” Anti-methane Project Movement coordinator T Jayaraman said. “There are several instances where the courts have nullified decisions taken by the governments. However, if the government would make it clear that it has decided to implement the plan as a policy decision, even judiciary cannot intervene in it”, he added. Moreover, the state government should adopt a resolution unanimously in the assembly and get it notified in the gazette by the Union government, he added.

Title: Pak kabaddi cup row: ‘Indian’ players being adjusted in other teams
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Amritsar: Participation of a group of circle kabaddi players, suspected to be mostly from Punjab, in Pakistan’s first kabaddi world cup 2020 has led to a new controversy as Pakistan Amateur Circle Kabaddi Federation (PACKF) has claimed many ‘Indian’ kabaddi players were being adjusted in the teams of other countries such as Australia, England and Canada.

The players, estimated to be 45 in number and accompanied by a group of some 12 officials and coaches, are in the neighbouring country without any official permission or clearance.

The Pakistan federation also demanded an investigation into why the unauthorized players from India were being treated as an official Indian team.

PACKF secretary general Muhammad Sarwar Bhatt told TOI on phone that Indian passport holders have been included in the teams of England, Canada and Australia as kabaddi players. He said only a few players from these countries had arrived in Pakistan and their teams had been completed by including kabaddi players from India.

Sierra Leone, Azerbaijan and Iran also have send their teams for the eight-day tournament. “Iran’s team is somewhat a serious contender but Sierra Leone and Azerbaijan are non-kabaddi playing nations and do not have much at stake. USA, Canada and Kenya did not send their teams to participate,” Bhatt said.

Highlighting the issue of invitation, a letter dated November 28, 2019 and written on the letterhead of Punjab Kabaddi Association surfaced on Monday, purportedly shows that the body had been informed by Pakistan about the kabaddi world cup. The authenticity of the letter, which carries reference number 1151, could not be confirmed but it includes signature of its secretary Amanpreet Singh Malhi.

In the letter, the association expressed gratitude towards Pakistan Kabaddi Association secretary general Muhammad Sarwar Rana for extending invitation for kabaddi world cup and confirmed participation of a team representing India.

Punjab Kabaddi Association Sikander Singh Maluka and Malhi were not available for any comment on Monday.

Justice S P Garg (Retd), administrator of the Amateur Kabaddi Federation of India (AKFI), the governing body of the sport in India, said it was up to the central government to take action against the unofficial kabaddi team. The AKFI, he added, would ask Punjab Kabaddi Association whether it had any role in sending the players to Pakistan and would take action accordingly.

BOX: Jakhar demands inquiry

Punjab Congress president Sunil Jakhar has demanded an inquiry into ‘Indian’ kabaddi players playing in Pakistan. Jakhar said the BJP at the Centre and Akalis in Punjab preach nationalism, but at the same time they allowed as many as 60 players to cross over without due permissions. “It is a matter of serious concern and it needs to be investigated if these players have gone there as couriers. They may not be Indian citizens and only Indian passport holders and one wonders if there is a Referendum 2020 angle to it. What is the ulterior motive?” he asked.

“Obviously, they are not there to migrate to Pakistan. The episode reminds one of the ‘kabootarbazi’ incidents in the state. The intent behind sending the players needs to be probed and I would request the union home minister to put NSA on the job,” said Jakhar, adding, “I want to ask (SAD president) Sukhbir Singh Badal, whose close aide were involved in sending the team to issue a clarification,” he said. “Since they did not have the necessary permissions, it is being speculated that someone powerful might have recommended their names and Union ministers from Punjab are from BJP and Akali Dal,” he said.

Title: Fomento gets mine in Odisha, ops to begin next year
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Panaji: With no signs of mining activities resuming soon in Goa, mining firm Fomento had decided to expand its footprint outside the state. The Centre has allotted iron ore mine in an area of 7,50,00 sqm to Fomento in Odisha with a production limit of 5 million tonnes per annum.

Before mining came to a halt in Goa in September 2012, the production at Fomento mines was around 15 million tonnes per annum. The Odisha mine is set to be the biggest in the company’s portfolio. Mining activities in Odisha are likely to commence next year, director Partho Banerjee told TOI.

“This mine will be an additional asset for the company and it is our first footprint in Odisha,” he said. Ore extracted at Odisha would mostly be used for domestic consumption, he said.

He said that if there is domestic requirement, and given the high export duty on high-grade iron, it would be better that the ore is sold for domestic consumption. Iron ore in Odisha is of the 62-64 grade.

Banerjee said that the mine allotted in Odisha was being operated by Bonai Industrial Company Ltd (BICO). The lease was to expire in March 2020 and the Union government decided to e-auction all mines expiring in 2020.

The director said that the total reserve at mining leases is estimated at around 35 million tonnes, and the environmental clearance was for the extraction of 5 million tonnes per annum. “If we are able to extract at least 80% of the EC limit, the company would extract around 4 million tonne per annum,” he said.

. “It will take six to eight months to complete the paperwork. We will be able to start operating the mine from next year,” he said.

Presently, Fomento operates iron ore and bauxite mines in Maharashtra and Karnataka. The director said that the total extraction limit of iron ore mine in Maharashtra is 4 lakh tonne per annum and for bauxite, around 3 lakh tonnes per annum. In Karnataka, the total production limit of three iron ore mines touches 3.5 million tonne per annum.

He also said that Fomento is developing mines in Brazil and Australia.

Title: Finance company director held for cheating investor
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Nashik: The Ambad police have arrested a director of a group of finance companies, who has multiple cases registered against him in different parts of the state, for cheating an investor. He has been remanded in police custody till February 13.

A person approached the Ambad police recently alleging that the director, Vishnu Ramchandra Bhagwat, had cheated him of Rs 2.10 lakh. The complainant has told the police that he had not only invested money in one of the schemes floated by Bhagwat, but had also worked as an agent for the same group of companies. He alleged that the director also did not pay him his commission.

The Ambad police have registered a case of criminal breach of trust under section 406 of the Indian Penal Code, criminal breach of trust by public servant, or by banker, merchant or agent (section 409) and cheating (section 420). Sections of the Prize Chits and Money Circulation Schemes (Banning) Act, 1978 have also been invoked.

The police said the suspect started one scheme in October 2018 and by January 2019, he collected crores of rupees from thousands of investors. The Mumbai Naka police station in Nashik had registered a case against Bhagwat in May last year, in which he had secured anticipatory bail.

The case at Mumbai Naka police station against the director has been registered under the Prize Chits and Money Circulation Schemes (Banning) Act, 1978. So far, eight agents appointed by the suspect to collect deposits have been arrested by the Mumbai Naka police station.

The police said the suspect has cases with the Alephata police in Pune, Jaikheda police in Nashik rural, Bhandup police station in Mumbai and even in Himachal Pradesh.

The police have advised investors to conduct all checks of the companies and business houses before investing in any scheme.

Title: Cops come across another illegal adoption for Rs 7,000
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Trichy: The anti-child trafficking unit (ACTU) attached to rural police came across another case of baby sale at Badharkottai in Trichy recently. A couple from Vaalaiyur had a fourth child on January 13, a one-month-old baby boy. The couple already had two sons and one daughter. Bogged down by poor economic conditions, they gave the baby to their relative, a childless couple, at Badharkudi on February 1, in a case of illegal adoption.

While the ‘illegal adoptive parents’ were happy with the entry of a newborn into their life, ACTU got a tip recently about the illegal sale of the baby. A team led by inspector of police P Azeem of ACTU probed the matter and found that a woman engineer was involved in the case. Police said the engineer had already approached the baby’s parents before birth and struck a deal to sell their fourth baby. The buyer couple also allegedly accepted the deal.

However, when the baby was born, they changed their mind and gave the baby to a relative couple who have been childless for eight years after marriage. It was alleged that they sold the baby for Rs 7,000. In the wake of the change of mind, an anonymous caller tipped the police about the illegal adoption, following which the police recovered the baby from the couple in Badharkudi and produced it before the child welfare committee (CWC) on Saturday.

CWC sources said that the woman engineer with the connivance of a woman staff nurse of a primary health centre (PHC) in Trichy doctored the birth record of the baby boy by changing the name of the parents who were initially promised the child by the woman engineer. On Monday, ACTU filed a case in this connection and process of including the accused is under way. Meanwhile, CWC gave the child’s custody to a specialized adoption agency in Ariyalur on Monday. The police were on the lookout for the woman engineer and staff nurse.

Title: Twist in proposal to set up govt medical college
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Nashik: The state government is contemplating on starting the postgraduate and undergraduate medical courses at the same facility in Nashik to reduce expenses.

District collector Suraj Mandhare said a video conference was held on Monday with chief secretary Ajoy Mehta to follow up on issues discussed with chief minister Uddhav Thackeray during his recent visit here.

It may be recalled that the earlier BJP government had announced setting up of the first undergraduate and postgraduate medical college in Nashik district. Unlike other big cities in Maharashtra like Mumbai, Pune and Nagpur, Nashik does not have a government medical college.

The state government’s plan was to run the medical college at the civil hospital for three years, by which time it would have set up a new campus that would house the medical college and a 700-bed hospital in Nashik district on about 25 acres. The district administration was to identify the land.

“The government is now contemplating to club both the medical colleges,” the collector said. The Nashik civil hospital has 600 beds, six operation theatres and other facilities like blood bank. The hospital treats about 1,200 patients on an outpatient basis daily. The norm of the Medical Council of India is to have at least 300 beds at a hospital to start a medical college with intake capacity of 100 students.

The officers further added the government has sought a report about the Vinchur Wine Park, where only four establishments were working and 19 of the 22 plots were sold out over the past decade. The Maharashtra Industries Development Corporation has been asked to present a report about the park. The government would then decide about raising of the food park in the region.

The chief secretary also took up the issue of ‘Metro Neo’ project – the proposal of which is pending with the Union government. The chief secretary has asked the Maha Metro authorities to present a report of executing the project.

The BJP government had planned for the ‘Metro Neo’ project for Nashik city and Thackeray requested the European Investment Bank (EIB) to fund the project. Both the state and the Union governments are to contribute Rs 307 crore for the Rs 2,100-crore project.

Title: Counsellors to be present at all centres for Class XII exams
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Panaji: The Goa Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education said that every sub-centre of the Class XII state board exam will have a counsellor posted during the examination hours. The board recently held a meeting for the public exam conductors and observers in view of the Class XII board exam which is scheduled from February 26.

The board also informed the conductors and observers that now invigilators will have to upload the exam attendance online every day after the examination.

Before entering examination hall, students will be checked for any gadgets including bluetooth and smart watches, which are banned from the exam hall.

“The office will form a WhatsApp group of all conductors and observers. You will get a new link everyday. By clicking on the link, please make entries of subject-wise attendance of the day at 11.30am. Observers are required to counter-check before submission of information,” the board said.

The exam conductors were told to write to the power department and the traffic police two weeks in advance, to ensure smooth supply of electricity during the exam and to ensure free flow of traffic at least an hour before the exam on all roads leading to exam centres and sub-centres. A day before the examination begins, conductors will have to ensure that any scribbling on the benches or walls of the examination hall is erased and any maps, models or posters are removed from the hall.

A notice warning against malpractice should be displayed prominently at the main entrance and at the entry of each block of the examination hall, the board said. The exam conductors were also informed to not permit any additional time to any candidate for answering the paper on grounds of illness, accident or any personal reason, except when such loss of time is caused to any candidate by an act of omission on part of the board or its agent.

The board has also directed conductors to ensure the cleanliness of toilets at all examination centres.

Title: Kolkata: Domestic help in net for looting biz family
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

The house at Hindustan Park where the theft had taken place; (right) the booty recovered from Murshidabad

KOLKATA: A 55-year-old woman, who has been working as a domestic help-cum-caregiver in a business family for six years, has been arrested for stealing diamond and gold ornaments worth several lakhs from the residence.

The accused, Anjali Das (55) — who acted in connivance with her entire family — has been arrested along with her husband Imran Sk (57) and son Laltu Sk (38). The family of the complainant, Shivangi Agarwal (33), owns an iron-and-steel business.

The incident was reported from Hindustan Park on February 6. A joint team from Gariahat police and the burglary section of the detective department nabbed all the three accused within three days of receiving the complaint and recovered the booty. The theft, once again, has put to test the question of trust on helps, who spend several years with the employers but suddenly fall to momentary greed. The cops though said they were investigating if she had been habitually stealing from the household.

Agarwal on February 6 reported that gold and diamond ornaments and cash more than Rs 1 lakh, which were kept in her second-floor room, were missing. “There were five domestic helps. With all the security guards and drivers employed there, we had more than a dozen suspects. Since no almirah was broken, we knew it had to be an insider job,” said an investigator.

Das was asked to look after the elderly member of the family since she had won their trust. She also cooked food and was in charge of the kitchen for the joint family comprising of two brothers, their mother, their wives and children.

“When we probed Das’ whereabouts — where she had travelled lately, the calls made and her actions just before the theft — we found her son had returned to their Lalgola residence barely a few days before the theft,” said an investigator. But a confident Das continued working in the household and faced police questioning, trying to put the blame on the newly inducted employees.

A four-member team went to Murshibad even as cops asked Das to join a second round of questioning. “They broke down subsequently. We arrested the accused from Pirtala near Upar Fatepur at Lalgola in Murshidabad and all the stolen diamond-studded ornaments was recovered. We found the items concealed buried in the courtyard of their home,” said DC (southeast) Debasmita Das .

“We do not want to speak about the incident,” said a family member. Cops though said that even after five years, her employers had not verified the maid’s background local police.

Title: Jakhar seeks inquiry into players’ visit
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Punjab Congress president Sunil Jakhar has demanded an inquiry into ‘Indian’ kabaddi players who have gone to Pakistan. Jakhar said the BJP at the Centre and Akalis in Punjab preach nationalism, but have allowed as many as 60 players to cross over without due permissions. “It is a matter of serious concern and it needs to be investigated if these players have gone there as couriers. They may not be Indian citizens and only Indian passport holders and one wonders if there is a Referendum 2020 angle to it,” he asked.

“Obviously, they are not there to migrate to Pakistan. The episode reminds one of the ‘kabootarbazi’ incidents in the state. The intent behind sending the players needs to be probed and I would request the union home minister to put NSA on the job,” said Jakhar, adding, “I want to ask (SAD president) Sukhbir Singh Badal, whose close aide were involved in sending the team to issue a clarification,” he said. “Since they did not have the necessary permissions, it is being speculated that someone powerful might have recommended their names and Union ministers from Punjab are from BJP and Akali Dal,” he said.

Title: Canacona locals want more stops at rly stn
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Poinguinim: A memorandum has been submitted to the railway authorities to have more train halts at the Canacona railway station by deputy speaker and Canacona MLA Isidore Fernandes.

This has been a long-standing demand and several representations were made to former South Goa MP Narendra Sawaikar and former railway minister Suresh Prabhu .

The memorandum states that trains;12133, 12134(CSTM-Mangaluru-CSTM) and 09009 (Bandra to Mangaluru), should halt at Canacona. Similarly, residents have demanded for a pedestrian overbridge.

Title: Sewerage plants at Ponda, Colva, Sakhali to start functioning this yr
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Panaji: Work on sewerage treatment plants (STP) at Ponda, Colva and Sakhali is in advanced stages and they can be expected to be commissioned this year, Sewerage and Infrastructural Development Corporation of Goa Ltd (SIDCGL) managing director PB Seldarkar said.

The Sakhali plant, which has the capacity to treat 0.8MLD of waste, is receiving final touches and will be the first to be commissioned. “To start with, 150 houses will be connected to the plant,” Seldarkar said.

The larger and much-awaited 15MLD Ponda STP is expected to be ready by May or June this year, officials said. Nearly 4,500 houses will be connected to this plant.

“The structure is almost ready and only electrical and mechanical work is left. This plant will cover Ponda municipal area and Kavlem area. Over 90% of the network has already been laid. Presently, work on a main 400m link is on, where we had to use micro-tunneling method. We have hit hard basaltic rock and are finding ways to break it,” Seldarkar said. This 400m stretch is from the mamlatdar’s office up to the Dhavali bypass, he said.

Once these remaining works are completed, the STP can be expected to become functional by mid-2020, he said.

The Colva STP is 95% complete and over 70% of the sewerage line is already laid out, Seldarkar said.

“A PIL was filed in the high court of Bombay at Goa and the court has directed that the plant must be completed within a year’s time. Accordingly, we have to meet the October 2020 deadline. We had a meeting with panchayat officials and are confident of making the plant functional by the given deadline,” Seldarkar said.

Panaji, Vasco and Margao municipal areas are the only ones in the state where around 80% of the households are connected to STPs.

Seldarkar said that in the case of the Porvorim and Curti plants, while over 90% of the sewerage treatment lines have been laid, the process of finalising land for the plant is still on.

Title: Couple illegally adopts baby boy, lands in trouble
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Trichy: Acting on a directive from the child welfare committee (CWC), the anti-child trafficking unit (ACTU) attached to Trichy rural police registered a case on Monday in connection with the illegal adoption of a three-month-old baby boy by a couple in Thiruverumbur recently. The unit is in the process of implicating those involved including a woman broker and the biological mother of the baby born from an illegitimate relationship.

The illegal adoption was exposed after neighbours of the couple, Ashwini and Govindhan, grew suspicious over a newborn baby in their house for the past three months. Acting on the tip, ACTU inspector P Azeem enquired with the couple and found that the baby was sold to them for Rs 1 lakh by its 42-year-old mother through a woman broker on November 2. Further interrogation brought to light that the couple had seven-year-old and four-year-old daughters. They had tried for legal adoption of a baby boy. Sensing their longing, a woman named Velammal approached the couple with an offer to get them a baby boy for Rs 1 lakh through illegal means.

In their statement to district child protection unit (DCPU) officials, Ashwini said they decided to take the offer from the woman as legal adoption will have lengthy processes lasting two or more years. Accepting the deal, the couple also gave her the money and took over the baby. CWC officials summoned the couple Ashwini and Govindhan following the information received from their neighbours. They appeared before CWC with the baby on Saturday. The committee ordered temporary stay of the baby with the buyer mother at a home in Mannarpuram on Sunday. On Monday, CWC gave temporary custody order of the child to a specialized adoption agency in Ariyalur district following which the baby was being taken to the home in the evening.

The biological mother and broker Velammal evaded the inquiry by CWC and ACTU. Superintendent of police Zia Ul Haq said that a case has been registered while inspector Azeem said that further inquiry will be conducted with the biological mother and the broker woman.

Title: Plea to stop water theft from Cauvery
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Trichy: Trichy farmers have alleged that those in their neighbouring districts are misusing Mettur reservoir water meant for them by taking it away to irrigate their farmlands during summer. Farmers have urged the district collector to take necessary action to stop the practice.

Farmers said banana and black gram crops cultivated on hundreds of acres are in the hope that they will get water for irrigation from the river. However, farmers in Namakkal, Karur and Erode districts are stealing the water using pumps for irrigation.

They urged the district collector to take steps to disconnect the power supply of hundreds of motors used to pump water from river Cauvery. As the Mettur reservoir has been downed its shutters on January 28, only a small quantum of water – 1000 cusecs to 2000 cusecs – is released from Mettur reservoir for drinking purpose.

Farmers from Trichy district are usually using the water in Cauvery to irrigate their banana and black gram cultivation, said Puliyur A Nagarajan, state organizer of farmers’ wing of Tamil Manila Congress.

“However, farmers from the upstream districts pump huge quantum of water from the river using giant motors from Cauvery to raise cash crops like sugarcane, turmeric, leaving Trichy farmers in a lurch”, he alleged.

Title: Noida man missing for 15 days found dead in Auli, suicide note recovered
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Dehradun: The body of a 30-year-old man from Noida, who was missing since January 26, was found near a local temple in ski town of Auli in Chamoli district on Monday.

The man, identified as Mayank Gupta, is a resident of sector 77, Noida. He had left his home after an alleged altercation with his family on January 21, police said. Police have also recovered a suicide note from his pocket stating that no one should be blamed for his act as he had “come here to attain peace.”

Jaipal Singh, in-charge of Joshimath police station, said, “Gupta left home on his bike, reached Joshimath on January 22 and checked into a hotel here. On January 26, he left for Auli in a ropeway and had been missing since then. He last spoke to his friend in Delhi on the same day.”

Police added that his family had filed a missing complaint in Noida and had approached Uttarakhand police on February 7 after Mayank remained inaccessible for over 10 days. “He was unemployed and the family told police that he was also under depression,” said inspector Singh.

Chamoli SP Yashwant Singh said, “The family contacted us and said that their son had been missing since January 26. I took his mobile number from them and gave it to our district surveillance team. His phone was switched off for the past many days.”

During investigation, police found that Mayank Gupta stayed in a hotel in Joshimath for three-four days before heading for Auli on January 26. “After reaching Auli, he informed the hotel in Joshimath that he would stay in Auli for a few days,” the SP said.

A search was conducted by a team of local police and State Disaster Response Force and the body was recovered from the snow near a local temple in Auli. Police said that the body has been handed over to the family members.

Title: ‘Durga Bhagwat strongly supported freedom of expression’
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Author Meena Vaishampayan delivering a lecture ‘Durga Bhagwat: Vyaktitva ani sanshodhan parv’ at Vidarbha Sahi... Read More

NAGPUR: Durga Bhagwat was devoted to literature until her last breath. A prolific author, she wrote across genres. She raised her voice while doing research work as she was a staunch proponent of freedom of expression, said author Meena Vaishampayan from Asiatic Society of Mumbai .

Vaishampayan was delivering a lecture ‘Durga Bhagwat: Vyaktitva ani sanshodhan parv’ organized on Saturday at Vidarbha Sahitya Sangh (VSS), Sitabuldi, to mark Bhagwat’s birth anniversary.

Senior writers Asha Bagge, Vamanrao Telang, Ravindra Shobhane , Ulhas Vaisayan, Shubhada Fadnavis and others were present.

Addressing Bhagwat fondly as ‘Bai’, Vaishampayan said, “With extreme perseverance, she translated 547 Jatak Tales and paved the way for Buddhist literature’s entry into mainstream. In a way, Bai laid the foundation stone for building Buddhist literature into one framework from the disorderly fashion it was in earlier.”

Throwing more light on Bhagwat’s contribution, Vaishampayan said Bai was a scholarly figure who has written about diverse themes dealing with society, tribal education, nature and humanity in depth. “Besides being a writer and thinker, she will be remembered in the annals of Marathi literature for her knowledge and curiosity that formed the core of research as she travelled alone across the country to prepare a thesis on tribals.

“She also studied the epics Mahabharata and Ramayana to a great depth. Bai decided to study Early Buddhist Jurisprudence and undertook the path of research,” said Vaishampayan.

Vaishampayan also spoke on Bhagwat’s stand taken during Emergency. “Bai’s firebrand opposition to Emergency and attempts to curb free expression inspired dissent all over Maharashtra. She was arrested and sent to Arthur Road Jail where she continued her work of translating texts,” said Vaishampayan.

Bhagwat also found out that Hindu culture is one without divisions, added Vaishampayan and pointed out that she is popular even today for her contribution to folk literature. “Bai's writing style of unfolding life truths was laid out in simple language by her for everyone to understand,” said Vaishampayan.

At the outset, Fadnavis informed the audience about various activities carried out by Granthsahwas of VSS. Madhuri Wadibhasme conducted the programme.

Title: Now, BJP asks if rights under Art 30 are not discriminatory
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Panaji: State BJP spokesperson Narendra Sawaikar continued hitting out at the archbishop of Goa and Daman, Filipe Neri Ferrao, for the second day in a row on Monday, when he said that if the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) was discriminatory, Article 30 of the Constitution was even more so. He said if that was the case, religious minorities should stop claiming benefits at the cost of taxpayers.

Article 30 promises all linguistic and religious minorities the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice. It also restricts the state from discriminating while providing help to any educational institution on the ground that it is managed by a linguistic or religious minority.

“If #CAA is discriminatory for Goa #Archbishop, then Article 30 of Constitution of India is more discriminatory. Don’t claim benefits at taxpayers’ money by claiming minority status! #CAA,” Sawaikar tweeted.

Ferrao on Saturday had appealed to the Centre to “immediately and unconditionally” revoke the CAA.

Stating that the archbishop should not “misguide and misinform”, Sawaikar, in another tweet on Monday, said, “#Archbishop’s statement is based on ifs and buts. Without any logic, reasoning & rationale. In fact #CAA is not #divisive but the #statement is.” He was also referring to Ferrao’s opposition to the NRC and NPR.

“Let Archbishop be informed that #CAA is a law and that any law can be repealed or rescinded. 1. by act of legislature OR 2. the Court striking it down. In present case challenge is already before the SC,” Sawaikar tweeted.

Power minister Nilesh Cabral said he did not think the CAA was wrong and that if the Church thought so, he was ready to discuss it. “Church, temple, mosque, all this is a different issue. We are Indians first. It is a democratic country. Anyone can say anything. But I have to use my knowledge and think. As per my knowledge, what has been done is not wrong. If it is wrong, I have to be convinced that what I think is wrong. If anyone calls me, I am ready to sit across the table and talk. If you convince me this is wrong, I will also back the statement,” he said.

Health minister Vishwajit Rane said the archbishop had the right to express his view while the government had the right to make the laws it thought necessary. “The archbishop holds such a high position in the state. He has the right to express his views. Our party has the right to do what it has to do. Ultimately we have to respect each other’s view. It is a democratic society,” he said.

Title: Water purifier for railway station ready, but spot not identified yet
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Nashik: A high-tech water purifier, to be installed for free at the Nashik Road railway station, is ready with a city-based NGO, but the railway authorities are yet to identify the spot for it.

Anjuman-e-Hakimi Dawoodi Bohra Jamaat had proposed to install the ultra-violet (UV) water purifier that treats micro-biologically unsafe water with germicidal UV light and the railway divisional headquarters at Bhusawal gave the go-ahead for it late last year.

Asked why the delay in finding a spot for the purifier, a railway official said a survey is under way to identify the right spot for the water purifier. “We have to place the device at a location where water from the overhead tank will be purified and linked to the taps at proper pressure. We are working on the different spots where the device can be installed.”

Mufaddil Parvez, a functionary of the NGO, said passengers face problems due to a lack of drinking water at the station because of the water dispenser over there is non-functional.

“We want to provide clean drinking water to passengers at the station for free. The water filtration plant will have a capacity to filter 500 litres of water per hour. It will be fully automatic and function 24x7. It will be connected to several taps at the station.”

According to him, a cooler in the filtration plant would be made functional during summer, so that passengers can get cold water.

The organisation’s initiative will be a boon for thousands of passengers as the only water ATM at the station has been lying defunct for several months. The machine used to dispense clean water to passengers at a low cost, thereby reducing the need to buy bottled water.

“The responsibility for maintaining the device, like changing the filter every three months, will be borne by the trust,” said Parvez.

Title: E-cart fleet to take full control of Kolkata’s garbage collection by end of 2020
Content:
Photo for representative purpose only

KOLKATA: Come May, the streets, lanes and by-lanes of Kolkata will wear a cleaner look, thanks to a garbage collection-&-disposal modernization plan adopted by the Kolkata Municipal Corporation solid waste management department. Under the project, the civic body will press into service 500 battery-operated vehicles in three months that will do rounds in the city to collect garbage.This will replace the rickety handcarts that are now being used for collection of waste from households. By the end of this year, such handcarts will be phased out as the civic body rolls out similar machines, a senior official in the KMC solid waste management department said.The official said that the KMC has bought over 200 such battery-powered machines in past three years in phases and put them to use in different wards. “However, this time when we get delivery of a fleet of 500 such machines, the city’s garbage collection and disposal system will see a major change,” he said.According to Debabrata Majumdar , the member, mayor-in-council overseeing the KMC solid waste management department, 500 battery-operated vehicles will be brought into Kolkata from Maharashtra by May and pressed into service.Majumdar said, “We shall improve the garbage collection by pressing into service the battery-operated vehicles that will be able to collect ten times more garbage compared to the handcarts. Moreover, unlike handcarts, the new vehicles will not cause spillover of garbage on the streets,” Majumdar said.Another official said the new vehicles will be commissioned in areas where the civic body has set up garbage compactors. These are stationed in localities for the whole day, taking in garbage and squeezing it for easy transportation. Besides this, the new machines will have facilities for taking segregated waste that will make it very useful in areas where the civic body has introduced garbage segregation at source.“We shall take help of the new fleet of vehicles to collect segregated wastes from households,” said a KMC solid waste management department official. Currently, the civic body has made waste segregation at source mandatory in 20 wards.A section of the KMC conservancy staffers who collect garbage from households using handcarts was happy with the decision. They said the new fleet will not only reduce their burden, but also reduce health hazards. “I am glad that now I will drive a car and collect garbage instead of pushing a heavy hand cart full of waste that made us prone to diseases,” said Manab Biswas a KMC conservancy staffer.

Title: Kolkata’s Oscar links happy to be part of history
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Amit Ray (left) and Subrata Chakraborty

KOLKATA: When Bong Joon Ho became the first Korean director to win the Palme d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival for his film ‘ Parasite ’, little did Asian cinema fans realize that it was just the beginning of rewriting records. The 92 years of Academy history were rewritten when ‘Parasite’ became the first non-English language film to win the Oscar for best picture. Back in India, it gave reasons for two Bengali production designers, who were invited by the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences to be its member in 2019, to feel a tad happier than others who rooted for Joon Ho. The Bengali duo had voted in the technical category of this year’s Academy awards and are happy to be a part of history.

At this year’s Golden Globes , Joon Ho had made headlines, saying, “Once you overcome the one-inch tall barrier of subtitles, you will be introduced to so many more amazing films”. His big Oscar win, both 43-year-old Subrata Chakraborty and 44-year-old Amit Ray insist, is only going to help other Asian films get more global recognition. Chakraborty and Ray have done the production design of 36 Bollywood films, including ‘Rangoon’, ‘Project 24’, ‘Udta Punjab’, ‘Padmaavat’ and ‘Bajirao Mastani’, and are now busy with ‘Prithviraj’ and ‘Gangubai Kathiawadi’.

The duo was asked to vote for this year’s Oscars between January 30 and February 4. Chakraborty, who hails from Jhargram, said he was pleasantly surprised on being invited to be a member of the Academy in 2018. “I was told that Indian films have become very strong in terms of production design. Though I voted only in the technical category, I am sure the decision to include members like us has also contributed towards giving a non-English film such recognition,” said Chakraborty, who studied at Rabindra Bharati.

Ray is equally happy with the four wins of ‘Parasite’. “This is a big achievement. Earlier, English movies had complete monopoly at the Oscars. Though the monopoly hasn’t gone, one can feel the winds of changes. We have jury members from other parts of the world. Joon Ho’s Oscar win has opened new avenues for films from this subcontinent,” added Ray, who hails from New Barrackpore and is an alumnus of The Indian College of Arts and Draftsmanship.

In 2017, directors Buddhadeb Dasgupta and Goutam Ghose were in the list of Indian personalities to have been extended such invitation to be a part of the Academy committee. Though neither Ghose nor Dasgupta voted this year, both are happy with the Oscar story of ‘Parasite’. “It feels good to know that a Korean film has won at Cannes and the Oscars,” Dasgupta said. Ghose had once sent a note to the Academy as the jury chairman of the Indian entry for the Oscars. “For all the non-English speaking films, the Academy had instituted only one award. In my note, I had said that there should be more entries. Parasite is a fascinating film with many layers. I do not define it as just a thriller. The structure of the script is so interesting. It is a great gesture of the Academy to consider a non-English language film for the top award,” Ghose said.

Incidentally, “Parasite” also had a nomination in the technical category of the Oscars this year. However, the award went to Quentin Tarantino’s Once Upon A Time… in Hollywood where the production design was done by Barbara Ling and Set Decoration by Nancy Haigh. On being asked why “Parasite” lost out in this category, Chakraborty described the production design of Tarantino’s film as “rich”. According to Chakraborty, who along with Ray personally voted for this category, “Apart from excellent set design, I really liked the choice of colour palette. Instead of opting for a contrast colour, this film uses a dilute palette. That’s why it was chosen as the Best Picture. Technically, Parasite is also very strong. It is just that one has to come and another second.”

Title: U’khand to witness rapid rise in mercury in next few days
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Dehradun: The maximum temperatures in Uttarakhand are likely to rise sharply in the next few days as dry weather is going to prevail over the Himalayan state, the regional meteorological centre said on Monday.

According to the Met office, the maximum temperatures will rise rapidly in the state reaching up to 6 to 8 degrees Celsius above normal, while the minimum temperatures are expected to hover around normal levels.

Bikram Singh, director of regional meteorological centre, said, “Dry weather will prevail in Uttarakhand for at least 8-10 days. As a result, temperatures will sharply rise, especially the maximum temperatures, in both hills and plains. The temperature will remain significantly higher from February 11 to 14.”

The plains and foothills, including Dehradun and Haldwani, might witness maximum temperature touching 28 degrees Celsius during the current week, Met officials said.

Due to the expected rise in days temperatures, the diurnal variation in the day and night temperature is likely to go above 22 degrees Celsius in plains and 15-18 degrees Celsius in the hills.

The Met office has also issued an advisory on the likely weather conditions in Uttarakhand. “Due to the prevalence of dry weather conditions and increase in diurnal temperature variability in plains, especially from February 11 to 14, conditions are becoming conducive for spread of flu and cold,” Singh said.

The increase in maximum temperature in the hills is also likely to trigger snow melting and thereby making conditions favourable for avalanche at isolated places in higher reaches of Uttarkashi, Rudraprayag, Pithoragarh and Bageshwar districts.

Title: NIT-T scholar’s exhibit a hit at Defexpo
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Trichy: A PhD research scholar from National Institute of Technology (NIT), Trichy, who developed the mechanism to prevent combat aircraft radar from getting detected by enemy radar, received much attention at the Defence expo 2020 - a gathering of defence equipment manufacturing companies in Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh.

V Krushna Kanth, along with his research guide, S Raghavan, former professor, NIT-Trichy, participated in the event while exhibiting his work on ‘Frequency RADOME technology’ at Defexpo 2020, organized by the department of defence production, Ministry of defence that concluded on Sunday.

Kanth’s project was awarded commendation last year and a cash prize of Rs 5 lakh from defence minister Rajnath Singh in the 41st DRDO directors’ conference in New Delhi on ‘Technology Leadership for Empowering India’.

His invention on frequency selective Radome, for which he is also awaiting patent, will help hide radar in combat aircrafts from getting detected by enemy radars. The front nose cone point of the aircraft accommodates radar for scanning and identification of target for bombing. This needs to be protected from enemy radar from identification.

“The Radome is designed in such a way that it will allow only certain electro-magnetic frequency from radar. That basically means, we should see others, but enemies should not see us. Our Radome works in specific frequency, which will be known only to us,” said Kanth.

“It was a great opportunity for us to exhibit our work to the national and international delegates and our product was seen by Prime Minister Narendra Modi himself,” he said.

We received very good response from the defence chiefs from India and abroad. The proposed frequency selective Radome technology is the game changer of modern stealth technology for aircrafts, which helps in protecting the aircraft radar systems from enemy radars, Kanth added.

The scientist and former associate director at Electronics and Radar Development Establishment (LRDE), Bengaluru, D C Pande said in DRDO not much research was carried in this area. There have been papers published in this area, but no product was developed so far.

“Such technology is not shared by other countries, even those from whom we purchase aircrafts, so it was pivotal for us to develop our own technology,” said Pande, who is also a Dr Rajaramanna DRDO distinguished fellow.

Title: Drama competition for kids with disabilities from Feb 13
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Nashik: The city will host a drama competition for children with disabilities at the Kalidas Kala Mandir from February 13 to 15.

The event, organised by the state culture department, is being held for the second time in the state.

Writer-director Dhananjay Wable said “There is no stage fright among these children. The state government has given us an opportunity to portray the social challenges on the stage.”

Although the children cannot hear or speak, they understand expressions very well and express themselves effectively, he added.

A total of 12 plays of about 40 minutes will be performed in the three days. Day 1 will see five plays, following six plays on day 2 and one play on the final day.

Of the 12 plays, four are from Nashik, two each from Mumbai and Igatpuri, and one each from Latur, Solapur, Nagpur and Amravati.

Child actors in the play ‘Home Arrest’ belong to the 8-15 years age group and are from a school in the Cidco area for hearing-and-speech impaired children.

Pallavi Patvardhan, the writer and director of the play, said “We are performing a mime act with 12 children. These children enjoyed a lot while rehearsing for the act.”

As many as 13 children with learning disabilities, who are aged between 10 and 16 years, have been practising for three months. They will present a play to show how the environment is being harmed due to changes brought in the modern days.

“The children will showcase the ill effects of technology and other changes that have caused a decrease in the number of birds,” said Manisha Nalge, writer of the play ‘Kav Kav’.

Title: Salt Lake waits for joyride to turn transport backbone
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

E-W Metro will be thrown open to public on Valentine's Day

KOLKATA: Salt Lake residents, who have been looking forward to a rapid transit service all their lives, are happy that East-West Metro will finally start rolling but they are not sure if they can use it for daily use. It will be more like a joyride as of now and be helpful when the full stretch becomes operational, they feel.

“I can’t think of taking a Metro ride for some work along the short route between Sector V and Salt Lake. But I will certainly take rides on and off just for the feel of the Metro in my neighbourhood,” P N Saha, a retired IPS officer and resident of AJ Block, said on Tuesday. “Bus services in Salt Lake are erratic and auto drivers are rude. Salt Lake has always been a subject of ridicule when it comes to connectivity because rickshaws are the safest bet. We will be able to make most of Metro services when the full stretch becomes operational,” Saha added.

Senior bureaucrat and Hidco chairman Debashis Sen sounded optimistic. “It’s a great beginning,” the CF Block resident for 40 years said. “The East-West Metro’s purpose will be met when it runs till Howrah Maidan. It will be a fine value addition to Salt Lake’s infrastructure. Metro, after all, is the most environment-friendly way to commute.” Sen is eager for the Metro project to get over. “When fully operational, the new Metro will connect Sealdah and Howrah stations. This means, I can travel straight to Howrah station through river Hooghly and board a long-distance train and go on a holiday. That’s a very comforting thought,” he laughed.

CF Block resident Sonali Mundhra , who was born in Salt Lake, said, “The new Metro will only be a symbolic service for now. It’ll boost Salt Lake’s connectivity and be of enormous use when the project is completed. When Phoolbagan is added, it will certainly curtail people’s dependence on autos.”
