Will the Metro ever emerge as the backbone of Salt Lake’s transportation, wondered Mehul Agarwal , a second-year student of St Xavier’s College. “The ground reality is that people will continue to wait for hours at key bus stops like Karumamoyee, PNB crossing, College More or City Centre like they do now. I don’t think Metro will emerge as an alternative to these missing buses,” Agarwal said.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Man stabs wife to death after dispute in Thanjavur
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

THANJAVUR: Police have launched a hunt for a man who is on the run after allegedly stabbing his wife to death near Orathanadu in Thanjavur district in on Sunday night.

Police said Ilayaraja, 35, of Ambalapattu Kudikadu near Orathanadu, murdered his wife, identified as I Sangeetha, 30, after a row between them went out of hand. The couple has two children.

Sangeetha was upset that her husband has been wasting money by visiting countries under the guise of finding jobs.

The murder took place when Sangeetha began questioning her husband for his wastefulness. Police said that they frequently quarreled over this which created a rift between them.

Ilayaraja, who lately joined a company in Chennai and was staying in the place, returned home on Sunday and fresh dispute broke out.

Police said the quarrel later turned violen and Ilayaraja stabbed Sangeetha with scissors before fleeing the scene.

Grievously injured Sangeetha was rushed to a private hospital in Thanjavur where she succumbed to injuries on Monday. Based on a compliant, Papanadu police registered a case.

Title: NGT seeks state report on EKW encroachment
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Photo for representative purpose only

KOLKATA: The National Green Tribunal (NGT) on Monday asked the state government to file an affidavit on the action it had taken and what it proposed to do on encroachment in the East Kolkata Wetlands ( EKW ) while expressing concern over the absence of any measure to demarcate the boundary.

NGT has also asked Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC) and Bidhannagar Commissionerate to expedite the proper management of their respective municipal solid waste dumpsites in the EKW area.

Though the actual number of encroachments in EKW number in thousands, of the 357 FIRs that have been registered in EKW, action had been taken in only five cases, said Subhas Datta, the green activist who had moved NGT on the grave condition of the internationally recognised Ramsar site. A state environment official present at the hearing said it had been unable to act in several instances as the cases were pending in Calcutta high court.

On legacy sites like Dhapa, where KMC has been dumping Kolkata’s municipal solid waste for decades, NGT had called for removal of the garbage mound by segregating bio-degradable and non-degradable waste and then use the former in compost and latter in road construction.

KMC has in recent years attempted to scientifically cap a section of the garbage dump and convert it into a green mound with trees. The project has been funded by the West Bengal Pollution Control Board. NGT also asked Bidhannagar Municipal Corporation to exploit all possible tools to expedite the remediation of Mollar Bheri where the civic body dumps municipal solid waste from Salt Lake . The civic body had earlier been penalised by NGT for continuing to dump waste at Mollar Bheri.

Title: EPS gets assertive; Takes sheen off opposition
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Cleared

Chennai: Last Friday, chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami welcomed a delegation from Haldia Petrochemicals and held initial parleys for establishing a Rs 50,000 crore petrochemical complex at Cuddalore. Two days later, he took everyone by surprise by announcing on Sunday his government’s intent to declare all the eight districts, including Cuddalore, of the Cauvery delta region as Protected Agriculture Zone.

For long CM Palaniswami has been accused by the opposition of running a 'slave' government of the BJP in the state . In one stroke, EPS has not only taken the wind out of the opposition sail over issues affecting the delta farmers, but is also seemingly taking on the Centre, which is keen to drive hydrocarbon exploration more aggressively in that region. He will need the support of the Centre to implement his intent.

Recently, when the Centre exempted hydrocarbon exploration projects from the need to hold public hearings and obtaining environmental clearances, a miffed Palaniswami shot off a letter to PM Modi and Union Environment minister Prakash Javadekar - questioning the Centre for skipping consultations with the state, before arriving at such a decision.

On Monday, the CM wrote to the Centre again, explaining the rationale behind his announcement to protect the Cauvery delta region. But, he ensured that it was hand delivered by his senior cabinet colleague D Jayakumar. It looks like EPS is keen to be a different person to different people and issues.

Ends/dg

Title: National Skiing and Snowboarding Championship concludes
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Dehradun: The National Skiing and Snowboarding Championship concluded on Monday in Auli. The skiers from Himachal Pradesh excelled in their performance garnering six gold, eight silver and three bronze medals. The SSCB team representing the Army won six gold, five silver and five bronze. The skiing team from Jammu & Kashmir bagged four gold, one silver and six bronze. Uttarakhand won one gold, three silver and two bronze whereas the teams from Delhi, Bihar, Maharashtra and Karnataka couldn’t register any win.

Title: Mapusa civic body passes surplus budget
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Saligao: The Mapusa Municipal Council (MMC) approved a surplus budget for the 2020-2021 financial year at a special council meeting held on Monday.

The consolidated budget has an opening balance of Rs 33.1 crore. Total receipts for 2020-21 have been pegged at Rs 79.7 crore and total expenditure at Rs 72.4 crore. The total closing balance for the current financial year stand at Rs 40.3 crore.

MMC chairperson Ryan Braganza presented the budget in the presence of chief officer Clen Madeira, vice-chairperson Marlene De Souza and other councillors.

Reacting to the budget, councillor Sandeep Falari said, “We have not been serious in terms of recovery and implementation, either from receipts side or payment side. We are putting these figures on paper, but we have to see that those figures are actually realised.”

Acknowledging that the municipality is lacking as far as recovery is concerned, MMC chairperson Ryan Braganza said the civic body plans to strengthen its recovery team to ensure payments.

Further, stressing that the civic body does not intend on hiking taxes for the financial year, he elaborated on plans to tie-up with a private bank to make it easier for citizens and vendors to pay their taxes and dues

Title: BDU running distance courses sans UGC nod for five years
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Trichy: Bharathidasan University (BDU) has been running distance education programmes for the last five years without the mandatory approval of the distance education bureau (DEB) of University Grants Commission. It has come to light that the university was unsuccessful in its attempts to secure the DEB nod, but chose to offer the programmes without it.

The university became eligible to offer programmes through distance mode after being accredited with A+ grade in April last year in the third cycle of national accreditation and assessment council (NAAC). It is also likely to secure DEB approval for offering such programmes in future. However, questions are now being raised about the validity of certificates issued over the last five years by the university without getting due approval. Roughly 50,000 students have graduated in various distance education programmes with degree certificates.

Asked if institutions can offer distance education programmes without getting approval from DEB, New Delhi, its joint secretary, Avichal Kapur, told TOI over phone that only category – 1 institutions can do so and BDU doesn’t come under it. This has put the candidates who secured distance education degrees from the university in trouble. “We have been trying to get everything under the legal framework and NAAC score will enable us to get approval for the course,” said A Ilangovan, director in-charge of the centre for distance education, BDU. He said they have approached the ministry of human resource development seeking retrospective approval for the programmes apart from writing to DEB. “We only wish that the university gets DEB approval retrospectively for courses offered over the last five years. But we are sceptical if DEB will do so as the university was disqualified for not being eligible to run these courses,” said K Pandiyan, former president, Association of University Teachers (AUT).

Another senior faculty member said DEB had asked to suspend some of the programmes offered by many universities. “BDU too has suspended those courses from this year as seen in its admission notification released recently,” asked the faculty member. Questions are also being raised about the university not mentioning the status of DEB approval in the admission notification issued on January 26. “The university managed to sweep under the carpet the status of its approval from DEB. If the university is sure about getting DEB approval in the next few weeks, what prevented it from mentioning the same in the admission notification,” said another faculty member.

Title: Sawaikar’s ignorance of Constitution exposed: Cong
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Panaji: Congress slammed state BJP spokesperson Narendra Sawaikar for condemning archbishop Filipe Neri Ferrao’s statements on the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). Congress media cell convener, Trajano D’Mello said on Monday that Sawaikar’s statements proved that the BJP was trying to crush not only minorities but the underprivileged as well.

“By questioning why the archbishop does not criticise Article 30 of the Constitution, Sawaikar has further exposed his ignorance of the secular fabric of our Constitution,” D’Mello said.

Congress said that if Sawaikar could not accept the archbishop’s appeal for better sense on the CAA, National Population Register and National register of Citizens, then the former South Goa MP should “put on earplugs”.

“Sawaikar has exposed his autocratic DNA,” said the Congressman.

D’Mello said that Article 30 of the Constitution acts as a safeguard for minorities to run their institutions, where several Hindus also study.

“Sawaikar should also know that the Supreme Court has upheld the constitutional validity of Article 30 that was challenged,” D’Mello said.

Title: Visakhapatnam’s famous Rushikonda beach features in Beams list
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

A view of a popular tourist spot at Rushikonda

VISAKHAPATNAM: The city’s own Rushikonda beach is set to be included in the Beams (Beach Environment and Aesthetics Management Services) project under the Integrated Coastal Zone Management Project. The Beams project is aimed at maintaining the pristine coastal environment and developing environment-friendly and sustainable tourist amenities in beaches in coastal parts of the country.

Rushikonda beach is among 13 beaches in the country located across coastal states and Union territories that have been identified for the Beams project on a pilot basis.

These beaches will have infrastructure, facilities and amenities for tourists such as bio-toilets, parking facilities, play zones for children, fitness equipment and purified drinking water. A water treatment plant, a solid waste treatment plant as well as a solar power plant will be part of the Beams infrastructure.

Prakash Javadekar, Union minister for environment, forest and climate change informed in the Rajya Sabha that the Beams project will also include CCTV surveillance and guards to ensure security. The Union minister was responding to a query raised by YSRC MP V Vijaysai Reddy .

The Union minister further said that the project will include infrastructure for differently-abled visitors with provisions of amphibious wheelchairs. Most facilities will be made of eco-friendly material, he added.

According to the Union environment minister, the government has decided to extend these facilities to 100 beaches around the country in the course of five years.

The Union ministry is also taking up a beach sustainability assessment survey in collaboration with the state government.

Title: KMRC has experts’ nod for tunnelling
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

KOLKATA: KMRC , the implementing agency of East-West Metro, on Monday told Calcutta high court that it has validation from experts of IIT-Chennai to resume tunnelling at Bowbazar.

While hearing a PIL filed by residents of Bowbazar on December 21, the division bench of chief Justice TBN Radhakrishnan and justice Arijit Banerjee asked KMRC to seek opinion of National Disaster Management Authority’s (NDMA) before resuming the tunnel-boring work between Bowbazarand Sealdah . The division bench had asked KMRC to submit the experts’ report to the court.

On Monday, Bikash Ranjan Bhattacharya , counsel appearing for KMRC, told the court that the report was ready: “We have taken the opinion of experts from IIT-Chennai. According to them, there are no difficulties in resuming tunnelling operations.” But the petitioners said they hadn’t gone through the experts’ opinion. The court then directed the petitioners to read the report within next 24 hours. The matter will be heard again on Tuesday.

East-West Metro’s tunneling operations has remained suspended since August 31 when one of the two tunnel boring machines (TBMs) hit an aquifer, leading to subsidence.

Title: Kolkata: Maa flyover pillars to get vertical gardens
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

A vertical garden on a Metro pillar in Salt Lake

KOLKATA: Prodded by the urban development department, the Kolkata Metropolitan Development Authority (KMDA) will set up vertical gardens on the pillars of Maa flyover. The initiative will start on the EM Bypass stretch. This will act not only as a beautification drive but will also increase the green cover.

KMDA sources said it has been asked to prepare a project proposal for the vertical gardens on the pillars of Maa flyover. “Initially, about 10 to 15 pillars from EM Bypass end will be selected to host the vertical gardens. If the first phase is successful, the initiative would be extended on the Maa flyover pillars towards Park Circus,” a KMDA official said.

Structural engineers have welcomed the initiative, saying that it will help to increase greenery and boost the oxygen levels on stretches where pollution is high. “The additional load of the vertical gardens on flyover or bridge pillars is negligible. Such initiative is highly appreciated,” said construction engineer Anjan Kumar Dutta .

The vertical garden concept has become very popular in cities across the globe.

In New Town , Housing Infrastructure Development Corporation (Hidco) has already developed vertical gardens on several of the Metro rail pillars on the main arterial road. Hidco now plans to use internet-of-things (IoT) to facilitate watering the plants. The authorities have planted creepers such as bougainvillea and madhabilata to develop the vertical gardens on the Metro pillars.

More such gardens are coming up on Metro pillars, on which flower pots will be placed with jute or tin covers. An IoT device with a sensor will also be fixed on the pillars that would send an alert to the gardens’ control room whenever the plants need watering. Water pipes will be fixed with the vertical garden as it would automatically start watering the garden after receiving the signal.

Title: College auditorium to be named after Pbi writer
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Bathinda: In a tribute to noted Punjabi writer Jaswant Singh Kanwal, who passed away on February 1 after completing 100 years, the Punjab government has decided to name the auditorium of the government college at Dhudike village after him. The announcement was made on Monday, at Kanwal’s bhog, which was attended by hundreds of persons.

Punjab rural development and panchayat minister Tript Rajinder Singh Bajwa made the announcement. A five-day programme was held in the auditorium in June 2019 to celebrate the 100th birthday of Kanwal.

Among those who paid tribute at bhog was Faridkot MP Mohammad Sadiq and MLAs Darshan Singh Brar, Sukhjit Singh Lohgarh and Manjit Singh Bilaspur. tnn

Title: Coast Guard ships in Sri Lanka
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: To help the fishermen at sea, Indian Coast Guard ships Veera and Abheek are on overseas deployment to Sri Lanka and Maldives with an aim to enhance cooperation and interactions between ICG and the maritime forces of these countries.

The ships entered Trincomalee port on February 9.

“India and Sri Lanka share a common maritime boundary on which maritime surveillance is being maintained by both the countries with an aim to help fishermen at sea,” a Indian coast guard press release stated.

During the stay, the ship’s command team also had professional interaction with the Sri Lankan Coast Guard .

The ship will sail from Trincomalee along with ICGS Abheek on Feb 12.

Title: Kiran Bedi: Assembly doesn’t have powers to deliberate on CAA
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Puducherry: As the ruling Congress party is planning to become the fourth state to pass a resolution against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi on Monday wrote to chief minister V Narayanasamy pointing out that the legislative power of the Puducherry legislative assembly does not extend to discuss or deliberate on citizenship matter as it falls squarely within the domain of Parliament and the Centre.

She said CAA is already under the adjudication before Supreme Court and cited relevant rules to declare that resolution of any matter which is under adjudication by a court of law is 'not admissible'.

Bedi in the letter said three members nominated by the Centre to Puducherry legislative assembly - V Saminathan, K G Shankar and S Selvaganabathy - called on her on Monday and submitted a memorandum.

She said the nominated MLAs in the memorandum said the ruling party proposes to bring a resolution in the legislative assembly against the CAA passed by the Centre on February 12. Bedi said they had given a representation to the Speaker of the legislative assembly V P Sivakolundhu urging him not to permit any discussion or resolution on CAA as it 'exceeds the power of legislative assembly under Section 18 (1) and 18 (2) of the Government of Union Territories Act, 1963.

"In this regard, I would like to bring to your kind notice that the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019 (No 47 of 2019) has been passed by both the Houses of Parliament and been assented by Hon'ble President of India and notified in the Extraordinary Gazette of India No 71 dated December 12, 2019," Bedi said in the letter to Narayanasamy.

She cited the Section 18 (2) of the Government of Union Territories Act, which read, "nothing in sub-section (1) shall derogate from the powers conferred on Parliament by the Constitution to make laws with respect to any matter for (the Union territory) or any part thereof."

Bedi said the law passed by Parliament (CAA) is applicable to Puducherry Union territory as well, which cannot be questioned or deliberated in any manner.

The three nominated MLAs in the memorandum to Bedi said any discussion on CAA violates the Constitution of India and infringes the rights of the Parliament. They cited reference (3) and (4) of Section 5 of the Administrators rules for the Puducherry legislative assembly. The rule empowers the administrator (lieutenant governor) to direct the Speaker of the legislative assembly to decline any resolution prohibited under it. The administrator can communication his decision to the Speaker and the administrator's decision will be the final.

"If any doubt arises whether any resolution of which notice has been given or any part thereof is or is not within the prohibition imposed by sub-rule (1) the administrator shall act in his discretion, decide the point and his decision shall e final," the nominated MLAs said in the memorandum while quoting reference (4) of the Section 5 of the rules.

Title: 8 hours 17 minutes: Vizag-based Naval officer runs fastest 100-km in country
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Lt Cdr Jha at the Chandigarh run

VISAKHAPATNAM: Armyman and sprinter Milkha Singh was popularly known as ‘The Flying Sikh’ for his athletic accomplishments. What would one call the Navyman from Visakhapatnam who completed a 100-km run without rest in 8 hours 17 minutes to become the fastest 100-km runner on Indian soil?

Meet Lieutenant Commander Abhinav Jha , an officer of the Indian Navy based in Visakhapatnam, who recently completed the 100-km Tuffman competition in 8 hours 17 minutes 2 seconds in Chandigarh. He beat 22 other contestants. The cut off time for the competition was 15 hours. Lt Cdr Jha said he is self-training to participate in the world 100-km championships, which is scheduled in the Netherlands in September 2020.

Lt Cdr Jha achieved this feat during a stadium run by looping around 250 times on a fixed track. He didn’t take any walking breaks or relax during the run. “I had prepared several bottles of energy drinks beforehand and a friend handed me a bottle every four kilometres to keep me hydrated during the run. The only times I slowed down were to finish a drink. I, more or less, maintained an even pace through the run,” the officer said, giving credit to the Indian Navy and the Marine Commandos (Marcos) unit in Vizag for encouraging him and providing him the platform to participate in such activities.

Running on tough terrains is not new for this marine commando, but sprinting 111 km in the La Ultra - The High at an altitude of 11,000 feet in Leh, or in the Rann of Kutchh is no cakewalk. In 2018, Lt Cdr Jha also was the first of the Indian participants in the 100-km World Championship held in Croatia. However, his stint with long endurance running began only three years ago.

“Being a commando and training for it has definitely helped build my physical and mental fitness and the strength to go on for several hours,” said the 34-year-old Jha. He added that his fascination of the bright white uniform of Navymen and the Navy’s multi-dimensional (all terrain – water, air, land) charter of duties prompted him to join the Indian Navy.

As part of his self-coaching, Lt Cdr Jha walks 12-15 kms daily, runs 20-25 kms twice a week—some days he runs even 30-40 kms. He says prefers a balanced natural vegetarian or vegan diet and avoids packaged food. Lt Cdr Jha is gearing up to participate in the 12-hour stadium run in Gurgaon on March 1.

Title: Over 500 of 60k bio-toilets installed in rural households
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Panaji: The directorate of panchayats, through the Goa Solid Waste Management Corporation (GWMC), has constructed over 500 individual household latrines (IHHL) in rural areas as of January 31. The initiative is part of the government’s move to install bio-toilets for citizens who don’t have a basic household latrine.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi had launched the open defecation free (ODF) programme on October 2, 2014 under the Swachh Bharat Mission–Gramin. All states were affixed an October 2, 2019 deadline to eradicate open defecation. To ensure that Goa achieves the status of an ODF state, former chief minister Manohar Parrikar had said that the state government would install 60,000 bio-toilets, costing Rs 280 crore.

In a bid to achieve this, the state government planned to erect these toilets in rural and urban areas last year. However, while areas have been declared as ODF, installation of IHHLs as well as community toilets continues even in 2020.

After applications were opened in 2019, the state government received a total of 17,150 applications for installation of bio-toilets. GWMC then started issuing work orders to about five selected firms to supply the bio-digestor toilets.After installation started in September 2019, till date, a total of 472 IHHL toilets have been completed. In addition, 514 community toilets have been built in densely populated areas where houses are built very close to one another.

So far, the highest number of completed projects has been in Bicholim, with 155 bio-toilets erected. The region, however, showed a requirement of 1,710 units. The Ponda jurisdiction showed the highest requirement for bio-toilets with 4,143 units. Of these, 61 bio-toilets are in the process of being installed. The least requirement was in Sanguem with 622 units. So far, no bio-toilets have been installed there.

Title: Cool winds make Sunday coldest of season at 18.1C
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Panaji: The mercury rose by nearly three degrees to 20.9 degrees Celsius on Monday, disrupting the onset of mild winter chill that saw the minimum temperature drop to 18.1 degrees Celsius on Sunday — the lowest of the season so far.

It was the cool winds blowing in the evening that triggered the drop in temperature with the last few days seeing the mercury slide below 20 degrees Celsius. Sunday morning was the coldest due to the combined effect of the cyclonic circulation over Marathwada region of Maharashtra and the north-easterly winds.

All last week, the nip in the air could be felt after dusk . However, in contrast, the peak winter month of December witnessed the warmest nights in five decades and the minimum temperature did not fall below 21 degrees Celsius, causing farmer sof cashew and mango crops to worry.

India Meteorological Department ), Panaji, has forecast a slight rise in minimum temperature due to the dispersal of the cyclonic circulation. Within a day, the mercury rose by nearly three degrees.

The winds have been mostly northerly to north-easterly during the last few days. The day temperatures have been normal or near normal. Maximum temperatures recorded during the last few days have hovered around 31 to 32 degrees Celsius.

Title: Delhi polls 2020: Police to deploy 15,000 personnel at centres
Content:
A security layer has been created around each counting centre within which only authorised agents of the polit... Read More

NEW DELHI: Possible clashes between the supporters of different political parties after the declaration of results have kept the cops on their toes. Delhi Police is making all-out efforts to ensure there is no untoward incident on Tuesday.A security layer has been created around each counting centre within which only authorised agents of the political parties can enter. Flying squads will be deployed around the headquarters of the political parties, say police sources.Drivers have been asked to avoid DDU Marg where the party headquarters of both Bharatiya Janata Party and Aam Aadmi Party are situated. Victory celebrations will be allowed only in designated areas, added a police officer.Delhi Police will deploy more than 15,000 cops to guard 21 counting centres. Of these, 10 have been marked sensitive. Police have already held a meeting with the candidates and the election managers to ensure that no instances of political workers clashing with each other take place anywhere.A special team will keep an eye on suspicious movements outside the counting centres. Apart from Delhi Police personnel, paramilitary forces and the cops on poll duty from Punjab, Karnataka and Uttar Pradesh will also be there to tackle any situation. Routes for victory rallies have already been announced.Police officers said that special security arrangements have been planned around DDU Marg and ITO. The Delhi BJP headquarters at Pant Marg will also be under extra security cover. “Once election results start getting declared, the road might be turned into a pedestrian-only zone, depending on the volume of people gathering in the area,” they added.

Title: Another ‘timetable’ trial for Phase I run
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

KOLKATA: ‘Timetable’ trials were repeated along the 5km Salt Lake tracks of East-West Metro’s first phase on Monday. Railway minister Piyush Goyal is due to flag off the section on Thursday.

The three-hour ‘timetable’ trials were conducted independently by Metro Railway personnel in a mock service in which the display boards flashed train timings and the public address system (PAS) announced arrivals and departures. A train took 13 minutes to complete the 5km ride between the terminals — Sector V and Salt Lake Stadium — stopping for 20 seconds at each of the six stations.

During the services, a rake will take three minutes for the changeover. All these specifications were fed into the system as the timetable software was loaded into the operations control centre (OCC), which is the control room that will automatically run trains from the Central Park depot in Salt Lake.

East-West Metro is equipped with the communication-based train control and signaling system that uses advanced telecommunication technology to run trains. The software has been prepared by Ansaldo, the company that has provided software integration between the trains, signaling system, tracks and platform screen doors.

Title: ‘Gallantry award winners, widows, handicapped soldiers to get free travel in U’khand Roadways buses’
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

DEHRADUN: CM Trivendra Rawat while chairing a meeting of the state sainik board in Dehradun on Monday said that an in-principle approval has been given to the proposal of granting free travel facilities to gallantry award winners, their widows as well as those soldiers who were handicapped during war in state transport buses.

Title: Delhi polls 2020: Police to deploy 15,000 personnel at centres
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

A security layer has been created around each counting centre within which only authorised agents of the polit... Read More

NEW DELHI: Possible clashes between the supporters of different political parties after the declaration of results have kept the cops on their toes. Delhi Police is making all-out efforts to ensure there is no untoward incident on Tuesday.

Complete coverage on Delhi elections

A security layer has been created around each counting centre within which only authorised agents of the political parties can enter. Flying squads will be deployed around the headquarters of the political parties, say police sources.

Drivers have been asked to avoid DDU Marg where the party headquarters of both Bharatiya Janata Party and Aam Aadmi Party are situated. Victory celebrations will be allowed only in designated areas, added a police officer.

Delhi Police will deploy more than 15,000 cops to guard 21 counting centres. Of these, 10 have been marked sensitive. Police have already held a meeting with the candidates and the election managers to ensure that no instances of political workers clashing with each other take place anywhere.

A special team will keep an eye on suspicious movements outside the counting centres. Apart from Delhi Police personnel, paramilitary forces and the cops on poll duty from Punjab, Karnataka and Uttar Pradesh will also be there to tackle any situation. Routes for victory rallies have already been announced.

Police officers said that special security arrangements have been planned around DDU Marg and ITO. The Delhi BJP headquarters at Pant Marg will also be under extra security cover. “Once election results start getting declared, the road might be turned into a pedestrian-only zone, depending on the volume of people gathering in the area,” they added.

Title: Uppal success spurs HMDA to go for land pooling in 3 more villages
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

HYDERABAD: Buoyed with the response to land pooling scheme implemented at Uppal Bhagat near Nagole, the Hyderabad Metropolitan Development Authority (HMDA) has decided to implement land pooling schemes (LPS) at more places in the metropolitan region. The authority has decided to take up the scheme in Malkaram in Choutuppal mandal of Yadadri-Bhongir district, Bhogaram village in Ghatkesar mandal of Medchal-Malkajgiri district and Lemuru village in Kandukur village of Ranga Reddy district.

“On pilot basis the scheme will be taken up in three villages, where farmers have come forward voluntarily. It will be taken up in a major scale in later phases,” Sista Vishwanth, heading the land pooling wing of HMDA told TOI on Monday.

Under the LPS, if farmers come forward to give their land to the HMDA, it develops the land as per the norms and gives them the developed plots depending on their land. It became a huge success at Uppal Bhgat where the authority also got nearly Rs 1,000 crore in land auctions conducted in two phases.

Officials said it would be a win-win situation for both the farmers and authority. While the development gives developed land (minimum 30% of their land) to the land owners back, it gets some revenue by way of its share (including development cost). Land owners get good value for their share of the land.

Official sources said farmers of Malkaram have expressed their readiness to hand over 160 acres —100 acres in Bhogaram and 60 acres in Lemuru village. While Lemuru village is close to the proposed Pharma city at Mucherla in Rangareddy district , Malakaram is close to Apparel park and Vijayawada highway. Bhogarama is near IT corridor on Warangal highway.

HMDA has issued a GO and guidelines on LPS in December, 2017 where the minimum extent of the land should be minimum 50 acres to implement the scheme. A notification was issued by HMDA in November, 2019 for the scheme at Pratap Singaram and Mokila villages. It has announced survey numbers in both the schemes and conducted stakeholder consultation meeting.

The authority is waiting for the response from the farmers. The government says if more farmers come forward and HMDA develops it, it can arrest haphazard growth of the city.

Title: Large stretches of S Goa beaches witness untimely sand erosion
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Colva: In an unusual occurrence, huge stretches of the beach at Benaulim and Sernabatim are facing sand erosion again, at this time of the year, leaving fishermen, environmentalists and shack owners worried.

Villagers say that at this time of the year the sea usually brings sand that was eroded during the monsoon, back to the shore.

The coastal belt in Salcete shows erosion at Vaddy beach in Benaulim and at Sernabatim. At Vaddy beach, erosion has hollowed out cavities in the sand over half a metre tall along the shore.

The erosion is visible on the water line so that's less alarming, an expert said, pointing out that it would have been worse had it happened along the dune.

Retired NIO scientist Antonio Mascarenhas said that irrespective of where it has occured, erosion of this magnitude was quite significant and was definitely unusual at this time of the year.

“I strongly suspect the erosion took place due to winds from north which induce a littoral current towards the south. Human interference is also responsible for this. Beaches should be free of any interference, so sand can move freely”, he told TOI.

Beach restoration needs to be carried out, where lost sand needs to be dumped where it belongs, he said.

An environmentalist pointed out that Goa’s coastline took an unusual beating last year from various cyclones and other weather conditions. “The government is not paying attention to the eroding shoreline and it should put in more money to study this, and find a long-term solution to stop sand erosion,” the environmentalist said.

Shack owners are worried about the erosion, pointing to the space between their shacks and the water line of the sea, which they say is reducing every year.

A shack-owner said that in the last two years, sea water rushed into their shacks and in some cases, even destroyed their shacks, causing losses.

Fisherman Caitan Rodrigues pointed to the Casuarina trees at Betalbatim which have fallen and some whose roots are exposed, said, “These trees help in maintaining sand dunes. The government has not even bothered to undertake planting of more trees to replace these, and this has resulted in sand erosion.”

Title: Goa: Sugarcane farmers to hold back protest for 15 days
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

PONDA: After getting assuarance of an amicable solution in the next ten days, the sugarcane farmers have decided to hold back their protest for another 15 days.

Vice-chairman of the Goa Sugarcane Cultivators’ Association Harshad Prabhudesai said that chief minister Pramod Sawant has assured them that he will find a solution to the payment of canes and also starting crushing at Sanjivani Cooperative Sugar Factory.

Prabhudesai further said, “The chief minister has said that their payments have been delayed as the Laila Sugar Factory in Khanapur in Karnataka has failed to make payments on time.”

The farmers are demanding that their canes be crushed at Sanjivani plant either with modernisation or by setting up a new plant.

Presently, Sanjivani factory is shut for production, so the canes are sent to Laila Sugar Factory.

“The chief minister, during his visit to the factory on January 8, had promised to pay 70% of the cane price within 15 days of the supply, however, only 30% payment has been done,” Prabhudesai said.

“Since the payments are not on time, the farmers could not muster capital to cultivate new seedlings as it needs a sizeable amount to begin with land preparation and sowing the seeds,” the association vice president said.

Stating that late payments discourage farmers, he said, “Some years ago, there were over 1,500 farmers cultivating canes, but now the number has declined to around 940 farmers and if the situation continues, the number of farmers would decline further,” Prabhudesai said.

Title: Counting to start at 8am, trends to start pouring in 3 hours later
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

New Delhi: Counting for the 70 assembly seats in Delhi will begin at 8am on Tuesday and trends will start pouring in around 11am. Officials said the votes will be counted at 21 locations in 11 districts. About 2,600 administrative officials will be involved in the process.

Though the official announcement of results will be done only in the evening, Election Commission officials said the winning candidate and the estimated margin of votes will be known by the afternoon. The smaller the size of the constituency, the sooner the result will be announced.

East Delhi district election officer Arun Kumar Mishra said the counting centres have a three-tier security involving the local police, CAPF and paramilitary forces. “The outermost ring will have Delhi Police personnel, while the second ring will have local police and CAPF. The innermost security ring will have paramilitary forces,” he added.

The counting centre at Commonwealth Games Village has been set up as a model centre with state-of-the-art facilities, Mishra said.

In all, 33 counting observers have been appointed to oversee the process. The counting of votes will start with postal ballots. Votes polled in EVMs will begin only after that. The EVM votes will be counted simultaneously at 10-14 tables set up for each assembly segment. Depending on the size of the constituency, the votes will be counted in 10-16 rounds.

After each round, the results will be uploaded on the “Suvidha” mobile app. Once all votes are counted, election officials will randomly pick VVPAT slips from five polling stations in each assembly segment and match the results with those generated by EVMs.

Paper chits with the number of each polling station in an assembly constituency will be put in a container and shuffled in presence of all candidates or their agents. The returning officer will then pick up five slips to tally with the EVM results.

“The paper trail of votes will be kept in separate bundles and then matched with the EVM results. The tabulation of paper trails will be carried out simultaneously. The result will be declared after completing the entire exercise,” said an official.

Title: Looks like RaGa again reached parliament after having ‘nasha’: U’khand CM
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Dehradun: Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat courted a controversy on Monday when asked about his response on Rahul Gandhi ’s statement over the Supreme Court order on reservation and promotion in government jobs.

“It looks like Rahul Gandhi has once again reached Parliament after having nasha (intoxicating substance),” Rawat said, adding, “the Congress leader must remember that it was their government in Uttarakhand that ended reservation in government jobs in 2012.”

Meanwhile, Uttarakhand Congress unit’s vice president Suryakant Dhasmana strongly reacted to the statement saying, “Things trickle from top to bottom, and when the top-most BJP leaders make such baseless and meaningless statement against opposition party leaders, what can one expect from Rawat. He is following the path shown by his senior party members.”

Title: Common man swims against the tide in ‘Ek Zunj Varyashi’
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Play ‘Ek Jhunj Varyashi’ was staged as part of the 21st Bharat Rang Mahotsav’s Parallel Theatre Festival, orga... Read More

NAGPUR: Critically acclaimed Marathi play ‘ Ek Zunj Varyashi ’ tries to convey a message that a common man should fearlessly seek answers from his leaders. The play written by legendary playwright PL Deshpande is an adaptation of Russian writer Vladlen Dozortsev’s ‘ The Last Appointment ’.

The play was staged at Sai Sabhagruh , Shankar Nagar , on the first day of 21st Bharat Rang Mahotsav’s Parallel Theatre Festival organized by National School of Drama , Delhi. The seven-day festival will continue till February 15, simultaneously in other cities like Delhi, Dehradun, Puducherry, etc. Seven plays — two foreign and five Indian — will be staged in Nagpur.

Shriniwas Narwekar is director of ‘Ek Zunj Varyashi’. It’s the story of a man who seeks an appointment with a minister (a former doctor) and when he gets the chance to meet him, he bluntly asks him to resign from his post.

Baffled, the minister and his colleague try to kick him out taking him for a bibber. But the man is adamant and attempts to seek justice for some other man wronged by the minister. A slew of arguments ensues which characterizes the body of the classic play.

The play depicts the pursuit of a common man for justice, accountability and transparency from his leaders. The nameless common man, played by Narwekar himself, is raw, unapologetic and fearless. Narwekar embodies him brilliantly.

Minister Dr Deshmukh is played quite convincingly by Deepak Karanjikar. Shobhna Mayekar plays wife Chitra to the common man and Ashutosh Ghorpade plays the minister’s colleague.

The thought-provoking play is a comment on the political situation witnessed by the country over the last many years. As the play progresses, the audience is forced to think are we really choosing the right leaders for us? The two-and-a-half hour play manages to keep the audience glued to their seats till the end.

Title: Touts continue to hound passengers at Central bus stand
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Trichy: There is a gag going rounds among the city folk that a visit to Trichy’s Central bus stand may land you either in Chennai or a hospital. It clearly indicates how the touts and agents, who sell tickets at the bus stand for Chennai-bound private buses, torment the passengers. IN a recent incident, a 39-year-old man was repeatedly assaulted by touts for refusing to board a private bus to Chennai after enquiring about the ticket fare.

Weekends at Trichy central bus stand are busy with people arriving from various parts of the state looking to board buses to Chennai. As the number of State Express Transport Corporation (SETC) buses is limited, passengers mostly depend on private buses. However, during weekdays, touts are deployed by private bus operators to sell bus tickets as passenger turnout is low.

On February 7, R Karthik, a native of Pudukottai, enquired about the ticket fare to Chennai with a tout. It is alleged that the touts identified as V Srirangam and M Venkatesh abused and assaulted Karthik for not buying tickets. "I was told that such assaults are quite common near the Central bus stand but nobody complains. Since I registered a complaint, the issue has come out," Karthik told TOI. Two touts were arrested and remanded by the Cantonment police for assaulting the individual.

Police said that many touts work under a supervisor appointed by private bus operators to sell tickets. The touts are paid Rs 20 to Rs 50 for each of the tickets they sell. Since they will be paid only for the sold tickets, police said that the touts tend to harass passengers while pushing them to buy tickets. Sources said that around 75 touts on rotation operate at the Central bus stand.

Though it is an offence to forcibly sell tickets to passengers who prefer SETC buses, the touts were never questioned by the authorities. In the wake of the assault on a passenger, people urged the city police to take steps to prevent such incidents. "We have already requested police to stop the touts form harassing passengers. But the practice is still continuing even after a man was assaulted last week," an official with SETC said.

Title: Court denies bail to murder accused
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

COLVA: South Goa principal sessions judge B P Deshpande, on Monday rejected a bail plea filed by Melburn Coutinho in connection with his alleged involvement in the murder of Francisco Carvalho last year.

On September 6, 2019, the accused allegedly assaulted and stabbed the victim at a bar at Nuvem and then dumped him on a pier of the Borim bridge, at Loutolim.

Maina-Curtorim police said the 33-year-old victim from Manora, Raia, was already inebriated when he stopped at a bar for more liquor.

Police said that Coutinho, Royan Alvares, Vilton Coutinho and Valencio Vaz, who were drinking at the bar took objection to Carvalho loudly demanding drinks, and ended up assaulting him with bottles and a weapon. In October, the additional sessions court granted bail to Royan, Vilton and Valencio. However, Melburn’s bail plea was rejected.

Title: Ambala: Ex-MLA’s son, three others held for murder plot
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

AMBALA: The Ambala police have arrested the son of a former BJP MLA and three others for the conspiracy to kill a hotelier here on December 6 last year.

Anil Kumar, the son of three-time Ambala City MLA Master Shiv Prashad, and the others were arrested on Sunday evening and produced before a court here on Monday, which remanded them in two-day police custody.

Police said there was a dispute over a property between the hotelier and the accused.

According to police, the accused had hired a contract killer from Ludhiana to kill hotelier Rajesh Kumar.

The shooter, who is yet to be arrested, came on a motorbike from Ludhiana and fired at Rajesh when he was going to his residence here after closing the hotel on December 6 night.

Rajesh had sustained serious injuries and was referred to the PGIMER in Chandigarh.

After the incident, Ambala Superintendent of Police Abhishek Jorwal had handed over the probe to the Crime Investigation Agency of the Haryana Police. PTI

Title: Former sacrilege inquiry chief for action against cops, others
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Chandigarh: Justice Ranjit Singh, former chairman of the inquiry commission probing sacrilege incidents, has written to Punjab chief minister Amarinder Singh, calling for action against all police and administrative officers who had either harassed or failed to attend to deceased witness Surjit Singh’s grievances.

Surjit (56) was a key witness in Behbal Kalan police firing incident of October 2015, and died of a heart attack on January 15. Family members of Surjit, former sarpanch of Behbal Khurd village in Faridkot district, have alleged that Surjit was under stress because of continuous harassment by Punjab State Power Corporation Limited (PSPCL) officials and others. “We can now bless his soul by taking action against all those who had harassed him no ends, against those whom he had filed a complaint against, and those who failed to listen to him and attend to his grievances,” reads the letter written by Justice Singh. “I think we are all responsible for failing the cause of justice (by) being insensitive to the plight of this person who suffered at the hands of police because he had helped the cause of justice.”

Justice Singh informed the chief minister that Surjit's wife had told him over phone that Surjit was harassed by some persons and agencies for making statement before the commission about police firing incident. “He (Surjit) had carried a serious grudge against one Manjinder Singh of his village and the electricity department had imposed a fine on him on the asking of influential persons,” reads the letter.

Surjit had approached Justice Singh on more than one occasion to highlight these issues. “I remember that I (Justice Singh) had spoken to SSP Faridkot and the electricity department in this regard. Remaining dissatisfied, Surjit had turned back to me again and again,” Justice Singh has written.

The former judge finally advised Surjit to file a petition before the high court. For this, the former judge had even arranged legal help for Surjit, states the letter.

Justice Singh had earlier written to the chief minister, the home secretary and the DGP to ensure that witnesses were not harassed for appearing before the commission. “To ensure this, there is a need to issue directions to SSP, Faridkot, making him personally responsible for security of this (Surjit) witness and to see that the complaint made by the witness to the police is attended to in accordance with law, and justice is done to him,” Justice Singh had directed.

The inquiry commission had also written to the human rights commission as well as the Lokpal for taking action against police officials responsible for acting against the witness. Justice Singh has now informed the chief minister,

“The concern expressed by the commission apparently has not received requisite attention. The police and the administration seem to have continued with their tirade against Surjit Singh without taking action on his complaints.”

Title: 1 member joins rights panel, head to take over on Feb 26
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Panaji: The Human Rights Commission, which was rendered defunct without any member or chairperson for more than six months, will soon be operational again. Last week the government issued a notification reconstituting the commission with retired high court judge U V Bakre as the chairman.

Retired principal district judge Desmond D’Costa has taken over as member of the commission. Retired judge and former law secretary Pramod Kamat, who has given his resignation as member of RERA, will join as member shortly.

Bakre, who is presently serving as chairperson of the Goa State Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission, will complete his term on February 25 and is expected to join the commission on February 26.

The posts of senior stenographer, senior assistant, junior assistant and assistant are vacant.

The commission had 325 complaints pending with it as of July 26, 2019, when its only member, retired district court judge A D Salkar, completed his term.

With no member since July 2019, the commission has only been inwarding new complaints but not registering them. “The commission has to follow the procedure of scrutinising the complaints before registering them,” an official said.

In a number of cases, replies by parties have already been filed, but hearings have not been held. Parties will be given new dates soon, the official added.

The body hasn’t had a full fledged commission for many years now. It has been headless for close to four years after its chairperson and former chief justice of the Patna high court P K Misra retired in March 2016.

It was functioning with only a single member since September 2018 after J A Keny expired.

The commission would receive an average of five complaints each week and hear up to 12 cases each day on various human rights violations ranging from police assault, ill treatment of jail inmates, denial of pension and salaries, pollution of waterbodies, and , lack of common burial spaces for people across faiths and disrobing of women before cremation among others.

Title: Man strangles wife for spending money on her relatives, arrested
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Agra: Ten days after a 24-year-old woman’s body was found in a nullah in Firozabad district, police arrested her husband.

The accused was identified as Jipender Singh, alias Bhupinder of Laduapura village under Basai Arela police jurisdiction in Agra district. He claimed that he strangled his wife for spending his money on her relatives.

Police said the accused had a love marriage with Lakhi Jaatav, who belonged to another caste, in 2015. The couple has a four-year-old daughter.

According to police, due to their inter-caste marriage, the couple and their families could not get along with one another. After their marriage, they shifted to a rented accommodation in Gokuleshpuram colony under Quarsi police jurisdiction, Aligarh, where accused, Jipender, worked in a private finance company.

Rajesh Kumar, superintendent of police (rural), said, “During interrogation, the accused claimed that the couple had problems from the initial days of their marriage. After their marriage, his wife constantly badgered him to shift to Aligarh permanently after selling off his ancestral property. After a while, Jipender came to know that his wife was spending his salary on her relatives and this infuriated him. Then, he plotted to get rid of her. On the night of January 29, he drove his wife and daughter to his ancestral village. After reaching home, at around 1 am on January 30, he allegedly strangled his wife to death. Later, he drove to Nai Tor village in Firozabad district and dumped her body in a nullah,”

Kumar said, “It was a pre-planned murder which he executed alone. But to dispose of the body, we believe, the accused took help of his relatives.”

Deceased Lakhi Jaatav hailed from Khandari Gadi village of Hathras district. Based on her father’s written complaint, Jipender was charged under IPC section 302 (murder) and ST/SC Act.

Title: Dilapidated Cortalim road raises risk for commuters
Content:
Though tankers water the dusty road, the uneven surface is a death trap

TimesView The Cortalim stretch has been posing problems regularly due to the bridge construction work, yet the authorities never act proactively to ensure its upkeep. Knowing it is a narrow stretch and that too one that sees a huge traffic load, it is the responsibility of both the government and the bridge contractor to ensure the stretch is motorable and risk factors are mitigated.

PANAJI: It’s a rough ride for motorists, especially two wheelers, on the Cortalim road on NH 66 along which the new Zuari bridge is being built. Although steps were taken after the monsoon to level out the pothole-ridden road, it has deteriorated now, making riding a bumpy and back breaking experience.Although tankers water the dusty road, its uneven surface is a death trap. The lack of consideration for the common man can be seen in many stretches that are unsurfaced and full of rubble, resembling a dirt track, commuters said. On other stretches only a very fine narrow strip in the middle of the road remains intact, clearly not enough for the two and four wheelers who jostle for space on it. Slowing down and manoeuvring the uneven road, puts lives of two wheelers in danger.Excuses in the name of bridge work are not acceptable, motorists said. “This cannot be an excuse to damage old roads and leave them in this state for so long. Clearly contracts have been given out without proper planning. In certain parts, there’s a steep decent with no warning and suddenly there’s no road at all,” motorist L Godinho said.“If I don’t slow down, my car takes a battering. It’s very bad and unsafe for bikes. It’s just a question of PWD delivering better quality roads to commuters,” he said.Another citizen says public should not be made to suffer considering its their money being used for infrastructure works. “How long do we have to wait for the bridge to get ready. Earlier the excuse was the heavy monsoon. There is no excuse now,” businessman Blaise Cotta said.Principal chief engineer Uttam Parsekar said traffic cannot entirely be diverted on the newly-built concrete road alongside until work on the bridge overhead is completed. “This is temporary. After work is complete the traffic will be entirely diverted on the concrete road,” he said.PWD began taking the issue of dangerous potholed and uneven roads seriously and patched up stretches after the monsoon.

Title: Kerala high court dismisses plea against Ramesh Chennithala
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Ramesh Chennithala

KOCHI: The high court on Monday dismissed a petition seeking registration of case against opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala for realizing damages during a UDF hartal against fuel price hike in 2017.

A division bench comprising Chief Justice S Manikumar and Justice Shaji P Chaly considered a public interest litigation (PIL) filed by advocate Sojan Paviyanose, panchayat member of Madappally in Kottayam.

Chennithala had allegedly exhorted for conducting the hartal as chairman of UDF. As the leader of the opposition has cabinet rank and associated facilities, he should be considered as a public servant and a case should be registered against him, the petitioner had demanded.

Citing a full bench decision of 2007 (S Sudin vs Union of India and Others), the court pointed out that there is no ban against hartal as there is no legislation for it. Through the judgment, the court had directed the government to take necessary action to prevent violence on the basis of the reports filed by the district administration and police. The government is liable to prevent violence and damage to property during hartals and action can be taken against violators. The court’s judgment is applicable in the case of Chennithala also, the court pointed out.

Advocate T Asaf Ali had argued on behalf of Chennithala that the hartal was exhorted against the anti-people activities of the central and state governments and that only a peaceful hartal was called. Citizens have the right to protest peacefully and it cannot be prevented, the court said while dismissing the plea.

It was alleged by the petitioner that exhortation for hartal is in violation of Section 166 of Indian Penal Code (public servant disobeying law, with intent to cause injury to any person). Hartal was declared illegal and unconstitutional by a division bench in 2000 (Kerala Vyapari Vyavasayi Ekopana Samithi vs State of Kerala), the petition had stated.

Title: Coronavirus in Shimla: Visitors from coronavirus-hit nations under watch in Himachal Pradesh
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

SHIMLA: With death toll from coronavirus continuing to rise in China, Himachal Pradesh has put people arriving in the state from virus-affected countries under strict observation.A list of 145 residents of the state coming from abroad was received from the government of India on February 3, after which district health authorities had put all of them under surveillance. While 46 persons have completed the mandatory 28-day observation, the remaining 111 are still under observation, including 12 additional self-reported four cases from Chamba and eight from Solan district.Health and family welfare minister Vipin Singh Parmar said 10 persons, including two Himachalis and eight Chinese in Solan district, have self-declared about China visit, but none of them travelled to Wuhan city in China. He said all of them are asymptomatic and being observed by the health department for fever, cough or respiratory distress.Parmar said a health outpost has been created at Primary Health Centre, McLeodganj (Dharamshala) with effect from February 1 for the benefit of visitors coming from China or any other Coronavirus-affected country.He said three dedicated ambulances with personal protective equipment (PPE) kits earmarked are available in case of requirement for transportation of cases. Regular reporting is being done by all the districts and then final compiled report being shared with the Union government on daily basis.The minister said said isolation wards have been identified at IGMC, Shimla and Dr RPGMC, Tanda. Isolation wards have also been identified at all the district-level hospitals from February 7 onwards.According to him, hoteliers have been requested through DCs for sensitization of visitors for self-declaration if any of the guests has visited China during the last 14 days or any time after mid-January.Parmar said immediately after receiving an e-mail alert from the Centre, necessary advisory has been issued to all the chief medical officers of the state to take preventive and control measures regarding Novel Corona Virus.

Title: 300 tribal people trying to stage a protest arrested by police in Valparai
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Coimbatore: The rural police detained 300 people from 16 tribal settlements who were trying to stage a novel protest by walking from Valparai to the district collectorate in the city – 120km on Monday morning. The protesters were let off in the evening. The protesters claimed that if the government fails to fulfill the demands of the tribal people, they would get legal permission from the court to conduct the protest.

On Monday morning, the 300 people started their walk and they were stopped by the Valparai police. Police detained the protesters and lodged them in a marriage hall. Later, they were let off.

S Thanaraj, tribal rights activist, said the tribal people gave authorities 15 days to fulfill their demands. If the government fails to fulfill, then they would get permission from the court to conduct the protest to walk to the district collectorate from Valparai for a stretch of 120 km.

As per the Forest Rights Act, the respective district administration should issue patta to the tribal people who are residing at various settlements in the hilly terrain. The tribal community people were also engaged with the agriculture inside the reserve forest. But they were not given any patta to enjoy the agricultural lands. Though many people from 16 tribal settlements from Valparai approached the revenue department and forest department to get patta for their residential areas and agricultural fields, their pleas were long pending.

The tribes demanded the district administration to provide alternate lands for the people of Kallarkadar settlement as earlier the settlement was completely damaged due to landslide and heavy rainfall. They also demanded the district administration to change all tribal settlements to revenue villages in the Anaimalai tiger reserve. Then only they would get drinking water, roads, toilets electricity, medical, education facilities and opportunities.

They also demanded the district administration to hand over the houses to people of Nagarooth tribal settlement near Sarkkarpathy.

Meanwhile, the forest department and revenue officials convened a meeting with the people of the 16 tribal settlements at Valparai on Saturday. Valparai AIADMK MLA Kasturi Vasu had sought 15 days’ time to fulfill their demands. But the tribes did not give any time. Each settlement has more than 20-30 tribal families and the district administration is expected a crowd of more than 600 people.

Valparai forest officer Senthil Kumar, Valparai tahsildar P Venkatachalam and officials from other department participated in the meeting.

Title: MP condemns slashing of annual funds for Jipmer
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Villupuram: Villupuram MP D Ravikumar condemned the Centre for slashing the annual budget for Jawaharlal institute of postgraduate medical education and research (Jipmer) in Puducherry for 2020-21 by Rs 100 crore when compared to that of the previous financial year.

In a statement, Ravikumar said the Centre allotted Rs 1,100 crore for Jipmer in 2019-20 financial year and the institute spent Rs 1,053.48 crore during the fiscal year well within its budgetary allocation. However, for the present fiscal year, the Centre allotted Rs 1,000 crore, which is Rs 100 less than the last fiscal year, he said.

"The institute spent 95.77% of its allocation in the last fiscal year. It did not overspend like a few other institutes in the country," Ravikumar said pointing out that Postgraduate institute of medical education and research (PGIMER), Chandigarh spent Rs 260 crore more than the budget allotted for the institute in the last fiscal year.

He said the Centre in the last budget allotted Rs 1,426.53 crore for PGIMER but the institute spent Rs 1,760 crore in the last fiscal year, which is Rs 260 crore more.

"It is unfortunate to note that the Centre is sidelining and ignoring Jipmer year after year. Jipmer does not only cater to the medical needs of the people in Puducherry but also a major number of people from different parts of Tamil Nadu besides attending patients from other states. Slashing the funds for the institute every year reveals the Centre's glaring partisan attitude towards Jipmer," Ravikumar said.

He urged the Puducherry government to take up the issue with the Centre and ensure adequate budget allocation for the institute.

Title: Thousands participate in ‘Run for Merit’
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Youths and elders joined in large numbers at the 3km run on Sunday

NAGPUR: Thousands of students, youths and elders participated in the ‘ Run for Merit ’ — a three km run — organized in the city by state-level forum of Save Merit Save Nation (SMSN) on Sunday.

The run started from Saint Ursula’s High School ground at 7.30am. SMSN state president Dr Anil Laddhad claimed that more than 4,000 students of various schools and colleges participated in it.

Similar runs were organized in 25 cities across the state including Pune, Mumbai, Aurangabad, Jalna, Solapur and Latur the same day.

Arjun awardees, special achievers in education, national sports personalities and prominent citizens flagged off the run in Nagpur. The activity started with Zumba dance to promote exercise while a band of Umiya School also performed. A free blood pressure and blood-sugar check-up camp was organized for runners at the venue.

Dr Laddhad, Raju Morone , Vivek Bhore , Vinod Fafat , Gopal Laddhad , Amit Siroya , Sumeet Bagri , Sarang Paranjape, Sandeep Khirwadkar, Jaiprakash Parekh, Raj Agnani, Vivek Bhalerao, Aniruddha Gurjalwar, Rasmkisan Gupta, Meeta Gupta and others were present.

Title: Woman seeks collector’s help to bring back daughter from Riyadh
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Coimbatore: The issue of daily wage and domestic labourers being lured abroad with promises of fat salary packages, but facing exploitation and torture and being unable to return came to the fore again on Monday. Thenmozhi, a resident of Kavundampalayam, submitted a petition with the district collectorate to help her 26-year-old daughter Priya return safely from Riyadh. She said her daughter who flew to Riyadh three months ago to be a babysitter is being overworked.

Thenmozhi said her daughter was promised a salary of nearly Rs 25,000 a month to work as a babysitter for a family in Riyadh. “She was sent through two agents from Thanjavur and one from Dubai. My daughter agreed to go as it would help us financially,” said Thenmozhi.

In Riyadh, Priya was shocked to find that she was being used as a domestic maid and was made to work in three houses, Thenmozhi said. “She is also suffering because they make her work from before daybreak till late in the night, making her do all the housework, leaving her with less sleep. She is also falling often sick. Now the agents who took her there are demanding Rs 2 lakh to bring her back. They spent as much in arranging to send her to Saudi Arabia,” said Thenmozhi. “I request the collector to take action and bring back my daughter,” she added. tnn

Title: Former TN chief secretary hints at forming political forum
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Madurai: Former chief secretary of Tamil Nadu P Rama Mohana Rao hinted at starting a political forum involving various communities and unorganized workers, who have been left out by the political parties in the state.

He was in the city on Saturday to take part in the 437th birth anniversary celebrations of King Thirumalai Naicker organized by the Tamil Nadu Naidu Mahajana Sangam. Co-operative minister Sellur K Raju, revenue and disaster management minister R B Udayakumar, information and publicity minister Kadambur C Raju and Madurai district collector T G Vinay garlanded the king’s statue in Mannar Thirumalai Nayak Mahal in the city. Various outfits, leaders and people from public paid their respects. Cultural events too were conducted by Naicker and Naidu community outfits.

Talking to TOI, Rama Mohana Rao said that he is already in the political process and has been meeting people from various groups, communities and workers from unorganized sectors. Although launching a political forum may not happen immediately, it may happen later, he said. He categorically denied of starting any political party as of now. However, he said people around him and the situation will decide whether it would turn into a political party or not, he said. There are several communities who are missing in the political process. Each may be having 5 lakh or 10 lakh population, but no political party bothers about them. He would be taking up their issues as they do not have representation in the political parties, he said.

“I want to develop new leadership among every community by taking up leadership programs, which I have already started a few months ago. I wanted to create a space in the political spectrum for the unrepresented and under-represented in the political process. I will be doing social as well political service for them in the process,” he said.

There are already 5,000 cadres solidly working towards the political process and 5000 more will come into the fold in a few months, he said.

Title: J&K students call on Bedi as part of edu tour to Pondy
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Puducherry: Thirty-two students of government higher secondary school, Gandoh Doda, Jammu & Kashmir and 14 students of government high school, Kalta Udhampur, Jammu and Kashmir along with two school staff members and two Indo-Tibetan Border Police personnel called on lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi at Raj Nivas on Monday as a part of their Bharat Darshan educational tour.

The 15th Battalion of Indo-Tibetan Border Police Force organized the tour. Bedi while addressing the students said wearing uniform will not only give them a patriotic feeling but also build their character for life.

She said good education and sports and educational tours like Bharat Darshan will prepare them for joining armed forces to serve the country.

The students came by air from Delhi to Chennai and reached Puducherry by road.

Title: Go to Pakistan, BJP MP tells poet Munawwar Rana’s daughter
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

AGRA: BJP MP from Aligarh Satish Gautam has asked social activist Sumaiya Rana , daughter of leading Urdu poet Munawwar Rana , to go to Pakistan since she claims to be “feeling suffocated in today’s India”.

Sumaiya Rana visited Aligarh on Saturday and addressed anti-CAA protesters of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) and accused the police of using “coercive measures” to crush protests against the amended Citizenship Law and said such measures are “very suffocating” for the people. “Strategies to polarise are being formed every time in today’s India which is creating a suffocating atmosphere. Though every community, including Dalits, Christians, is involved in anti-CAA protests, government is blaming only the Muslims,” she said.

Talking to reporters in Aligarh, Gautam said that if Sumaiya is feeling suffocated in India, where she can take liberties to say such things then she should go to Pakistan. He said, “It is unfortunate that she speaks such language in a country where she lives with full freedom. This would not be possible in Pakistan.”

Gautam questioned as to why Sumaiya did not speak when women from her community were feeling suffocated due to “triple talaq”. “BJP government was the one which gave justice to the victims of triple talaq by enacting a law against it, but she never said anything in this regard,” he said, adding that she is supporting only JNU, Shaheen Bagh and AMU.

The BJP MP claimed that she had given this statement solely to vitiate the peaceful atmosphere of the campus, where a few students have been protesting against the CAA since December 16. “I was not expecting this from her as she belongs to a very cultured family. She should have taught good things to students, who are raising slogans against the country,” said Gautam.

He also warned of action against students protesting against the CAA on the AMU campus. He said, “Those who are protesting on the campus will be out from the varsity from the next academic session as they have all been identified by the police.”

“Government’s aim is to guide students first and if they don’t understand then they will face action like Dr Kafeel Khan , who addressed anti-CAA protesters here and was later arrested by police from Bihar,” said the MP.

Sumaiya visited the university with student leader Maskoor Ahmah Usmani, former president of AMU students’ union. The social activist told reporters, “We are holding all-women protests which are completely peaceful and as per the democratic rights, but as we have seen in Lucknow, the UP police is using coercive measures to crush our protests.” She tried to address women protesters at Shahjamal Eidgah, but was denied permission by the police.

Title: Bajaj Finance agent shot at, injured
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

AGRA: An agent of Bajaj Finance was critically injured after being shot at by three masked bike-borne assailants. They looted Rs 10 lakh cash from him while he was in his office in Aligarh ’s Dhanipur Mandi area on Monday.

According to police, agent Krishna, in his late 20s, was counting cash in his office around 11am when the three unidentified suspects entered. They allegedly shot at Krishna when he tried to stop them from looting the cash. The victim was immediately rushed to the hospital where his condition was stated to be stable.

DIG (Aligarh) Akash Kulhary suspended station house officer of Gandhi Park, Shambhunath, for dereliction of duty. He said that around four loot cases have been reported from the area under his jurisdiction in the past one month but the SHO has failed to solve any of them.

He told TOI that the matter is being investigated and soon the suspects will be arrested. An FIR has been registered against unidentified persons.

Title: Delhi: ‘Current laga kya’ — Dance, music and jibes electrify atmosphere at AAP headquarters
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

The jubilant supporters of AAP reflected a middle India in all its exuberance and none of the machismo

With the temperature soaring alongside Aam Aadmi Party’s seat tally , euphoria met exhaustion at the small AAP headquarters on Deen Dayal Upadhyaya Marg. As the results came in, party members and volunteers erupted in joyous abandon. And why not, it was the third straight victory for AAP since 2013 and perhaps the most difficult given the bitter counter-campaign by BJP. “Delhi voted for vikas, simple,” said Vimlesh Kohli, an AAP municipal councillor, adding, “This is a vote against galat soch (bad intention).”

Complete coverage on Delhi elections

“I have never seen them so happy,” said Shivani, a volunteer with a US-based consultancy and who has worked for AAP for six years now. “They are always stressed — cases are being slapped, offices sealed, something or the other.”

“We fought the first campaign on sachai (honesty), this one on kaam,” said Sanjay Gupta, offering kachori and bread pakoda.

This was middle India in all its exuberance and none of the machismo. Daily struggles don’t leave time for curled moustaches or manicured hands. No Ray-Bans and no fancy totes. Just a sea of Gandhi topis etched with ‘AAP’ and a broom.

“The party stays with the ordinary man. It thinks for the ordinary man,” gushed an ex-BJP, ex-Congress and now “confirmed AAP” well-wisher.

The frenzied dancing was to a party song booming on loop over the small lawn — ‘Saari Dilli bole dil se lage raho Kejriwal’ (Delhi’s own song, keep at it Kejriwal). The quintessential Dilliwala slipped into the baraat mode of dance as the Hari Om band and the dholakwallas joined in. Groups of men, headgear showing their faith — Muslim, Sikh and others in the AAP topi — posed for cameras and selfies. Women in hijabs with babies wearing AAP caps posed for the multiple media swarming the party campus. For every TV camera, a group would splinter off to do a special jig. Everyone was happy to strike a pose, no matter that the media bandobast took up so much ground. At the gate, a party man handed out caps and managed the constant stream of people — “Topi lo, aage badho”. A rare nano in the portico stood almost like a symbol to the ordinariness of the space.

Suresh, in his 60s, quietly watched the revelry from a shaded area. Steady of voice, his weathered face wore no joy, only relief. “This is the ordinary man’s victory. This is precious. The patriwala (street vendor), the cleaner, the repair-wala.”

He stood with a phalanx of party associates, their brows at times furrowed as performance on some seats caused heartbeats to quicken. “It’s a win, but 10 seats are too many to give away (the projected tally was at the time 60-10). Many rounds are still left, but…,” smiled Monce Abraham who campaigned for the party from Chandni Chowk to Nehru Place, Kalkaji to Karol Bagh.

The revelry was peppered with digs at BJP, which had used the Shaheen Bagh protest against the controversial citizenship law to polarise the election on communal lines. One poster read ‘Current laga kya’ with Amit Shah’s face on it while another co-opted Ram into the AAP campaign saying, ‘Ram’s rule has beat the rakshas’.

Some AAP members belted out Bharat Mata ki Jai and Vande Mataram, albeit to a tepid response from the rest of the crowd which just couldn’t get enough of the Kejriwal song. AAP netas asked revellers to take ‘Bajrang Bali’s prashad’, it being Tuesday. Inquilab Zindabad was thrown in for good measure.
