The commission, however, said that the tariff for railways was relatively less in AP when compared to the other states. The commission had also rejected the requests of big farmers to extend free supply to corporate farmers saying there was no justification in their contention.

Title: Maharashtra: IMFL, beer to get dearer, imported liquor cheaper
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: To ease the stress on state coffers, the Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government has decided to levy a green cess on Indian-made foreign liquor (IMFL), beer and country liquor. If that comes as a downer, there is good news too, as excise duty on premium brands of imported liquor will be “rationalised” to make them more affordable, a move expected to increase revenue by generating higher sales.

This way the government aims to mobilise an additional Rs 1,000 crore in the next financial year, said an official. The official said the green tax would be up to Rs 10 per bottle on all IMFL, beer and country liquor. “We may not be able to achieve the target of Rs 17,477 crore for the current year. There may be a shortfall of Rs 800 crore. In such circumstances, it was felt a new strategy was required to mobilise an additional Rs 1,000 crore.”

Title: Hang the accused, demand Ankita’s kin, Daroda villagers
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

DARODA ( WARDHA ): A pall of gloom descended on Daroda village after Ankita Pisudde ’s death spread like wild fire. There was anger and grief everywhere.

“After we got the news of Ankita’s death, no one from our village went to work,” said Gopal Hatwar.

Ankita’s relative, Kumud Shegukar of Sewagram village, said, “I want to request the government to protect women from such incidents. This is a serious issue.”

Another relative, Umesh Chaudhari from Sastabad village, said, “We lost our bright daughter who was intelligent and had a bright future. What was her fault? The government must take stringent action.”

The whole village has demanded capital punishment for the accused. Ankita’s body reached the village at 12.30pm. Villagers stopped the ambulance. They wanted the accused, Vikesh Nagrale , in their custody to set him ablaze. Some villagers pelted stones to vent their anger. The police had to resort to lathicharge to control the emotional crowd.

Ankita’s mother Sangita blamed the society. “Ankita would have been alive had we discouraged her from becoming a postgraduate. Whenever we brought up the topic of her marriage, she didn’t show any kind of interest as she wanted to do PhD. She was a leading light of our family.”

Social activist Ragini Shende said “There is fear in other villages as parents do not wish to give their daughters in marriage to grooms from our village.”

Title: Hinganghat lecturer succumbs to burn injuries
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

NAGPUR: Ankita Pisudde , 24, a college teacher from Hinganghat in Wardha , who had been set afire near her college on February 3 by a stalker, died in a hospital at Nagpur in the early hours of Monday.

Her attacker, Vikesh Nagrale , had been arrested shortly after the attack by MIDC Bori police of Nagpur rural, and booked by Hinganghat police for attempt to murder by setting Pisudde afire with petrol. After her death, Nagrale, who is now in Wardha jail, has been charged with murder.

Pisudde’s death triggered outrage and protests in Wardha district, especially at Hinganghat, where a bandh was observed. Police had to cane charge unruly mobs at Daroda, Pisudde’s native place, where her body was taken in an ambulance for last rites. The protesters pelted stones and smashed the windshield of the ambulance. Cops were also targeted with stones, after which they lathi charged the agitators.

A candle march was also organized at Wardha city on Monday evening.

Senior PI Satyaveer Bandiwar of Hinganghat police station said three platoons of State Reserve Police Force (SRPF) and Riot Control Police (RCP) have been pressed into action.

Earlier, there was drama outside the mortuary at Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) too, as Pisudde’s family members and friends were reluctant to allow the post mortem, and receive the body. They first wanted the government to give in writing that Pisudde’s brother Prajwal would get compensatory employment.

Led by Pisudde’s maternal uncle Prashant Kohle, the protesters raised a demand to hand over Nagrale to them. “Even if for 10 minutes, hand him over so we can make him feel how it pains to get burned,” he said during an impromptu sit-in outside the mortuary at GMCH.

Amid the agitation, a four-member forensic team comprising associate professor HV Pathak, assistant professors Dr Deepak Sangle and Dr Priyanka Patil , under head of the department Dr AA Mukherjee completed the post mortem in less than an hour.

Wardha guardian minister Sunil Kedar, who was present to expedite the post mortem, managed to convince agitators to allow the ambulance to roll out of the hospital with the body after the procedure. Kedar and the outnumbered police physically pushed agitators out of the way of the ambulance. Former city guardian minister Chandrashekhar Bawankule too had reached the place.

Earlier, Pisudde, a post graduate in botany, was declared dead at 6.55am by the team of doctors attending on her at Orange City Hospital and Research Institute (OCHRI). The hospital bulletin cited the cause of death as ‘septicaemic shock in patient of 35% Grade III deep dermal burns with inhalation injury’.

Already on ventilator since February 7, Pisudde’s health had started deteriorating in the last couple of days. In the wee hours of Monday, a team of five doctors; Dr Rajesh Atal, Dr Darshan Rewanwar, Dr Ninad Gawande, Dr Ritesh and Dr Anup Marar, struggled for nearly two hours to revive Pisudde after her condition deteriorated at 4am. The doctors were able to maintain her blood pressure, but the highly fluctuating oxygen level in the blood could not be improved. Her family too was alerted about the deteriorating condition.

At 6.30am, Pisudde’s health deteriorated for the second time. This time, she suffered ‘bradycardia’ or slower heart rate along with the other complications. She was administered a prolonged cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Despite efforts, Pisudde sank beyond any revival attempts and was declared dead.

Title: Electricity panel junks discoms’ bid to nix deal with pvt plants
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Amaravati: In what could be a setback to the state government, AP Electricity Regulatory Commission ( APERC ) has turned down the power discoms’ proposal to not purchase power from private renewable energy plants. Making a guarded review of the issue keeping in view the pending writ petitions before the high court, the commission observed that ignoring power purchases from plants is unwise.

The YS Jaganmohan Reddy government has been trying to scrap power purchase agreements (PPAs) made by the previous TDP government with renewable energy plants since it came into power. APERC while readying the tariff order for 2020-21 took power produced by renewable energy plants into account. Curiously, APERC had advised discoms not to entertain request of Lanco Kondapalli for renewal of PPA and directed it to take over the plant as per guidelines. Lanco Kondapalli is owned by former MP Lagadapati Rajagopal’s family.

The discoms have been arguing that the power from these plants is not dependable and variable.

However, APERC observed that non-inclusion of energy from wind and solar sources in the power purchase estimates would not only be unwise but also legally unsustainable. “Therefore, the Commission has decided to include wind and solar energy in the availability and despatch as per its own estimates based on the data furnished by the discoms and power purchase cost calculations for FY2020-21 are done accordingly,” said the commission chairman Justice CV Nagarjuna Reddy.

The commission pointed out that AP State Load Desptach Centre (APSLDC) has not placed any material to prove that these sources are causing grid instability and security problems during the last two years. “Since the aspect is subjudice before this commission and also before the High Court, any expression of views at this stage is likely to prejudice interests of either party in the pending litigation,” said commission.

Title: Six of a family, tenant hurt in Patna house LPG blast
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

The explosion, which the police claimed was caused due to leakage of gas from an LPG cylinder, left two houses... Read More

PATNA: Altogether seven people, including six members of a family, were injured in an explosion inside a two-room flat on the first floor of a four-storey building at Salimpur Ahra under Gandhi Maidan police station in the state capital on Monday. The condition of one of the seriously injured, Gangajali Devi (70), is stated to be critical.

The injured have been admitted to the PMCH with burn injuries. The explosion, which the police claimed was caused due to leakage of gas from an LPG cylinder, left two houses badly damaged. A joint team of the state FSL and the ATS later visited the site and collected evidences from there.

The incident took place around 8am in the densely populated locality, which is hardly 200 metres from the Gandhi Maidan police station. The debris and damaged articles scattered all around bore testimony to the intensity of the explosion. The locals said they heard the explosion sound in a radius of one kilometre.

A police team led by City SP D Amarkesh first reached the spot and inquired about the incident. Later, Patna SSP Upendra Kumar Sharma visited the spot and subsequently went to the PMCH to know about the health condition of the seven injured.

“A small sized LPG cylinder kept in a room yesterday got leaked due to damage in the connecting pipe. The accumulated gas in the room having no ventilation created a shock wave leading to explosion,” the SSP told the media.

He said the cylinder couldn’t explode as it had emptied by the time one of the family members tried to lit fire in the kitchen. In addition, two other empty cylinders kept in the room were found to be intact. “There is no evidence of explosion due to any explosive. This has been confirmed by the forensic experts,” he said, adding that the 2x5 inches thick brick walls erected without use of any ‘saria’ (iron rods) collapsed due to the impact of the explosion.

House owner Nitu Devi said she had rented out the flat to one Baidyanath Mahto, an autorickshaw driver, about three months back. “We had asked him several times to provide the photocopy of his Aadhaar Card or any identity proof, which he deliberated delayed. As he was living in the flat with his family, we couldn’t suspect any foul play,” she added.

Nitu stays with her family in another house and reached there after being informed about the incident.

The injured were identified as Baidyanath Mahto (50), his wife Rekha Devi (45), mother Gangajali Devi (70) and three children, including Tolu, Mahi and Manisha. Rekha told the police that she caught the fire when she had gone to boil the water in a pot in the morning. “What happened later is not known to me as I fell unconscious,” a police officer quoted Rekha as saying.

A tenant, Tarkeshwar Pandey, who lived in an adjacent room, also received injuries in the incident. Pandey’s relative Sandeep said he helped the injured get admitted to the PMCH for treatment.

The neighbouring house of Anil Kumar Singh was also damaged in the incident. His tenant S K Singh said, “The door of the room, in which he was sleeping at the time of the incident, was completely damaged. Even iron grills in the balcony were uprooted and the wall collapsed causing damage to other household articles in the flat.”

However, the local residents gathered there were not ready to buy the police theory of LPG cylinder leakage. “Police officials are hiding the fact and trying to give it a different colour. Many buildings in the neighbourhood felt the tremor caused due to explosion and windowpanes were damaged,” said a local resident Ganga Prasad.

Another building in the same locality was earlier damaged in a similar explosion a few months ago.

Title: Carcass of tiger found floating in Pilibhit canal
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

BAREILLY: Forest department personnel on Monday recovered the carcass of a tiger which was floating in Hardoi feeder canal in Puranpur area of Pilibhit.

Forest officials said all the organs of the tiger were intact and there were no injury marks on the carcass, which was two to three days old. It has been sent to Indian Veterinary Research Institute (IVRI) in Bareilly for a postmortem.

Naveen Khandelwal, deputy director, Pilibhit Tiger Reserve (PTR), confirmed that “there are no injury marks on the carcass”. Asked if the tiger belongs to PTR, he said, “We will match the picture of the tiger with our database. The report will arrive by Tuesday.”

In 2019, three carcasses of big cats were recovered from canals or rivers in the terai region. In September last year, the carcass of an adult tigress was fished out from Sharda canal near Navinagar village of Banda block in Shahjahanpur district . Another decomposed carcass of a big cat was found floating in river Devha at Deuni dam in Pilibhit’s Amaria block in August.

Similarly, the carcass of a leopard was found floating in Sharda canal in Shardanagar area of Lakhimpur Kheri district in July last year.

Title: ‘Choose between old and new tax system after consideration’
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Nagpur: “Budget 2020 has given taxpayers an option to continue with the existing tax regime or opt for the new proposed tax regime. Assessees today are confused as to which regime they should really opt for. While under the old tax regime, individuals can continue paying taxes as they had been doing till now. Under the new regime, they will be liable to pay lower taxes if they forego the deductions and exemptions available under the old system. One has to choose wisely after taking all factors into consideration as to which tax regime has to be chosen,” said chartered accountant Julfesh Shah.

He was speaking at a programme — Critical Analysis of Budget 2020 organized by Chamber of Small Industry Associations (COSIA) in Nagpur.

The exemptions that taxpayers will have to forego if they opt for the new regime are — standard deduction of Rs. 50,000 for the salaried, house rent allowance for individuals staying in rented accommodation, interest towards housing loan for self-occupied property, leave travel allowance twice in blocks of four years. The most commonly claimed deduction under section 80C towards provident fund contribution, life insurance premium, school tuition fee, ELSS, PPF will also have to be forgone, explained Shah.

Title: Bail-seekers to pay Rs 7.5k each to engage workers for govt home
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Madurai: Granting anticipatory bail to two people, who were apprehending arrest in a case registered against them for illegal sand mining, the Madras high court has directed them to pay Rs 7,500 each to engage two sanitary workers for the government observation home at Madurai after taking cognizance of the fact that the home lacked cleanliness.

Justice G R Swaminathan passed the order while hearing the anticipatory bail plea of Karthik and Senthil. After the petitioners’ counsel informed the court that they were first time offenders and they were willing to abide by any condition imposed by the court, the judge granted bail to the petitioners.

The judge observed, “I would have directed the petitioners to deposit a sum of Rs 7,500 each to the concerned District Mineral Foundation Trust. But, I consciously decided to make a departure and direct the petitioners to deposit a sum of Rs 7,500 each to the credit of the observation home at Madurai.”

Explaining about the reason for giving such a direction, the judge noted that after the Supreme Court had mandated that the implementation of the Juvenile Justice Act must be monitored by the respective high courts, a committee was constituted by the Chief Justice of this court. Justice Swaminathan, who was part of the committee headed by Justice T Raja inspected the government observation home at Madurai recently and noticed that the premises lacked cleanliness.

When the committee inquired in this regard, the superintendent of the home informed that due to lack sanitary workers’ posts, they have outsourced the work to two people who would clean the premises once in 15 days. The superintendent also mentioned that they would require Rs 16,000 per month to engage two full time sanitary workers. The judge observed that by this arrangement and directing the petitioners in similar cases to pay the sum to the observation home, a total of Rs 5.76lakh could be raised in three years which would be sufficient to engage two full time sanitary workers. “Hope the state government would sanction two posts of sweepers in the meanwhile,” observed the judge.

Justice Swaminathan also observed that the jurisdictional magistrate/ chairperson of Juvenile Justice Board shall monitor the attendance and work of the sanitary workers and should send a certificate indicating their attendance, standard of work and salary received by the workers to the registrar (judicial) of the court every month.

Title: Flyers from Singapore, HK to also be screened for coronavirus at MP airports
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Bhopal: Not just China, those with a recent travel history to Singapore, Thailand and Hong Kong will be subjected to screening at airports across Madhya Pradesh. So far, MP has not reported any positive case of Novel corona virus infection.

More than 10 days after World Health Organization declared the outbreak as a ‘Public Health Emergency of International Concern’ on January 30, around two dozen suspected people have been tested for the deadly virus in MP. It includes people from Bhopal, Indore, Gwalior, Mandsaur, Jabalpur and Khargone.

For the past four days, MP health department task force to deal with virus spread has on-record decreased the suspected samples sent for testing to NIV Pune. Health department officials neither confirmed nor denied if any more test samples were sent to NIV Pune on Monday.

Health officers to deal with nCoV skip training:

One-third of health department officials at the front line of surveillance and control of diseases like Coronavirus, Zika, H1N1 have missed their scheduled training for the second time. A health department circular identified 11 epidemiologists who did not attend the training programme in Bhopal.

Epidemiology is the area of healthcare that deals with the incidence, distribution, and possible control of diseases, illnesses and other factors. The epidemiologists are from Betul, Agar-Malwa, Mandsaur, Rewa, Shahjapur, Chhindwara, Panna, Harda, Sidhi, Annuppur and Ratlam. The training under Ayushman Bharat for district nodal officer (Epidemiologist) was scheduled for January 17 and 20.

Earlier in 2014, a health department proposal inviting doctors to apply for a two-year post doctoral training — India Epidemic Intelligence Service Programme (EIS) — was missed by many in the health department. The programme is run by National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) to train doctors on how to investigate and contain serious health threats.

Title: Govt apathy hurting agri, oppn alleges; min hits back
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state assembly on Monday witnessed heated arguments between the ruling and the opposition members on the ‘ crisis in the farming sector in the state’ before the latter staged a walkout, alleging that the LDF government was making hollow promises instead of helping farmers ‘who were on the verge of committing suicide’.

Though speaker P Sreeramakrishnan, after nod from agriculture minister V S Sunilkumar, allowed discussion on an adjournment motion moved by Congress MLA Sunny Joseph. The rare gesture of treasury benches accepting notice for adjournment motion couldn’t prevent the usual walkout by the opposition.

The intention of the treasury bench was clear from the beginning of the discussion — to corner Congress for the Asean agreement India signed in August 2009, during the Manmohan Singh-led UPA government, which according to them triggered the crisis in the agriculture sector.

“After cheating the rubber farmers to help tyre companies, the UDF and the Congress is now shedding crocodile tears for them,” said Sunilkumar, concluding the discussions, and his remarks triggered a commotion which went on for a few minutes. The minister also urged the UDF to join the LDF in opposing and defeating the move to import dairy and other agricultural produces from the US, a matter under consideration in the ongoing Indo-US discussions.

“The Kerala government is doing nothing for the farmers who are in deep financial crisis and the number of farmer suicides under the LDF tenure now stands at 22,” said opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala, while leading the walkout after the speaker rejected the resolution. But the minister retorted that the number of farmers who committed suicide during the previous government’s tenure was 69.

UDF members including K C Joseph, P J Joseph, Anoop Jacob and Shafi Parambil alleged that farmers were not the priority of the state government, ‘which was evident in the hollow promises and low plan fund expenditure’. CPM MLA Raju Abraham hit back, demanding the UDF to apologize to farmers for all the global agreements signed and wrong polices, ‘which now the BJP-led government is following in a more aggressive manner’.

Taking part in the discussions, former minister Mullakkara Ratnakaran stressed the need for a central debt relief act, ‘a long-pending demand’, while Congress MLA Shafi Parambil demanded waving off all agricultural loans to prevent farmer suicides.

Dismissing allegations that the government remained insensitive to farmers’ issues, as P J Joseph tried to convey through an old Malayalam film song ‘Kannu thurakkatha daivangale...’, the minister said that the farming sector was witnessing a speedy revival under the LDF government.

Title: Lekhpal suspended after audio of him demanding bribe goes viral
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Bareilly: A lekhpal has been suspended in Budaun after an audio clip of him demanding bribe from a woman went viral on Monday.

According to sources, an audio conversation of 3 minutes and nine seconds long between a woman, who is a resident of Nawab Nagla village in Budaun district, with lekhpal Kesari Lal over the phone was widely shared on social media. In the purported audio, the lekhpal demanded Rs 1,000 from the woman for making income and caste certificates and later brought down the amount to Rs 500.

Taking cognizance of the audio, sub-divisional magistrate Parasnath Maurya suspended Lal. “Prima facie, the lekhapal has been found guilty for demanding bribe. He has been suspended,” Maurya said.

Title: Delhi election 2020: AAP vigil outside strongrooms and counting centres
Content:
Crowd outside the AAP office on the eve of counting

NEW DELHI: Aam Aadmi Party candidates and their election agents have been tasked to maintain a vigil at the 21 centres at 11 districts across the city where the 92.5 lakh votes polled in the assembly election will be counted on Tuesday. AAP national convener Arvind Kejriwal will monitor the results from the party headquarters.The focus will be on the war room at AAP's office from where key functionaries will be monitoring the results and remaining in touch with all 70 candidates to get feedback in real-time. Senior AAP functionaries will be present at the headquarters. AAP volunteers, who are hopeful of the party winning the elections, are also expected to gather there.An average of the exit polls has predicted that the broom (AAP's symbol) will sweep Delhi on February 11. Some of the exit polls even predicted that AAP will repeat its 2015 landslide victory when it had bagged 67 out of 70 seats.A huge number of AAP volunteers had come to Delhi from different parts of the country to participate in the poll process. They have planned to return only after the results are announced as they want to join in the celebrations, said party sources.Meanwhile, on Kejriwal's instructions, AAP's volunteers are keeping a strict vigil outside the strongrooms across the city where the EVMs have been stored to ensure there is no "tampering" of the machines. Party functionaries are concerned about the security of EVMs and are not letting their guard down. "We have deployed around 20 volunteers outside each strongroom to keep a vigil round the clock in shifts," said a senior party functionary.In many constituencies, the contest is reportedly very close. Impressive voting has taken place in favour of both AAP and BJP and, in some areas, for Congress too.

Title: Waterlogging: IAS officer, 14 others suspended in Bihar
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

File photo of waterlogging at Rajendra Nagar in Patna after heavy rainfall.

PATNA: State government on Monday suspended IAS officer Amarendra Prasad Singh, the then BUIDCO MD, and 14 other senior officers for their lapses that caused prolonged waterlogging in the state capital following incessant rain in the last week of September last year.

The other officers put under suspension are Birendra Kumar Tarun (executive officer, Bankipur circle of Patna Municipal Corporation), Poonam Kumari, (then EO of Kankarbagh circle, PMC) Shailesh Kumar (EO, new capital circle, PMC), Bhawani Nandan, (then chief engineer), Om Prakash Singh (superintending engineer), Suryakant (superintending engineer in-charge), Sanjiv Choudhary and Yogendra Kumar (both executive engineers), Ram Chandra Prasad (SE-HQ), Santosh Kumar (then executive engineer), Daya Shankar Prasad (EE), Sudarshan Prasad (EE-Mechanical), Anil Kumar Mahto and Vijay Singh (both junior engineers) in BUIDCO.

Besides suspension, the government would also initiate departmental proceedings against all these 15 officers.

The action against them were taken on the basis of findings of the high-level committee headed by development commissioner Arun Kumar Singh.

The then PMC commissioner Anupam Kumar Suman (an officer of Indian Revenue Service) was also found negligent in his duty by the high-level committee. Since Suman has now returned to his parent cadre-controlling department under the Union Ministry of Finance, the state government also decided to write a letter to the Union ministry concerned for taking “appropriate action” against Suman on the basis of findings of the high-level committee.

Earlier in October last year, the state government had removed Urban Development and Housing Department’s principal secretary Chaitanya Prasad and Patna divisional commissioner Anand Kishor from their positions in the wake of prolonged waterlogging. Then BUIDCO MD Singh was shifted to Bihar State Road Transport Corporation as administrator.

Title: Data of school students being sold for Rs 2-5 per head
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

NAGPUR: Getting access to lakhs of names, contact numbers of school students and their parents apart from the financial status is apparently an extremely easy and cheap exercise. By paying merely Rs 2 to Rs 5, private firms are buying the data from school employees and using it to target prospective customers to sell services like coaching facilities, educational loans , insurance etc.

One such buyer confirmed to TOI that this is extremely common in Nagpur and is usually done without the management’s knowledge.

Speaking on the condition of anonymity, he said, “Staffers in the administration department have details of all students in the school. It’s usually in an excel sheet or can be downloaded in an excel sheet from the proprietary software.” The price paid for the data depends on the school in question. “Depending on the school’s reputation and financial strata of students attending that institute etc, data is sold for anywhere between Rs2 to Rs5 per student. And, usually this is sold to multiple buyers.”

With majority of private schools having enrollment of over a thousand, this has become an easy “business proposition”.

Since this buyer had never dealt directly with a principal, there is no evidence of higher-ups being involved. TOI reached out to a few schools to get their views, but all denied the same. One such principal said this does not even make financial sense. “For a school of thousand students, it comes to maximum Rs 5,000. So, even if one’s ethical sense was questionable, the financial part too is not lucrative for any principal or management to get lured,” said the principal.

The security in schools revolves mostly in checking for pilferage of cash or tangible items by staff, hence it is unlikely that theft of such data can ever be detected. A small pen drive is more than sufficient to store the data even though Internet usage is monitored in schools.

SC Kedia, honorary secretary of Unaided Schools Forum, said, “This is a serious issue and schools must ensure that no infringement of privacy happens in their institutes.”

Lawyer Mahendra Limaye, who recently did his doctorate in the field of cyber law, said theft of such data attracts provisions of Information & Technology Act. “The data is being stolen in electronic mode and calls to prospective customers are also being done through a tech device, hence the law is applicable. Parents should question all callers from coaching classes or policy agents about where they got the data from. File a complaint and it can be traced back to the original source,” said Limaye.

Title: MSEB holding co director quits, exposes state power officials in letter
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

NAGPUR: RB Goenka , the director of MSEB Holding Company Limited (MSEBHCL), has resigned slamming the power officials and charging them with ignoring most of the resolutions passed.

In his resignation letter (dated January 29) addressed to principal secretary (energy), Goenka stated, “On a number of issues raised by me and directions issued by MSEBHCL, the subsidiary companies (MSEDCL, Mahatransco and Mahagenco) did not follow the directions.”

Citing the issues, Goenka stated that one of them was taking prior approval for tariff petitions before filing with Maharashtra Electricity Regulatory Commission (MERC). MSEBHCL resolved that any petition or appeal relating with or affecting consumers’ tariff may be submitted to the Board of MSEBHCL for information. In spite of the above resolutions and directives, all the three subsidiary companies filed tariff petitions to MERC without any discussions in MSEBHCL.

Goenka pointed out that two tariff hike petitions were filed by MSEDCL after discussion in MSEBHCL and suggestions were given by the directors which were implemented and the tariff was within control. But the last tariff petition was filed with MERC and post facto approval was asked from MSEBHCL without any discussions on the tariff.

MERC allowed an increase of Rs8268 crores only in ARR in spite of the fact that MSEDCL has requested for a huge deficit of Rs. 34,646 crores.

The power expert further stated that he had many suggestions for rationalization of tariff but they were not discussed at all. “I suggested in the past meeting that special MSEBHCL board meeting should be called for discussing the tariff and amended petition be filed with MERC by incorporating suggestions of board of directors of MSEBHCL,” he added.

MSEDCL suppressed the facts in the case of converting consumer tariff from continuous to non-continuous in which there was a loss of revenue to the tune of more than 800 crores. This issue was regularly raised by Goenka for three years. “MSEDCL did not submit a proper reply and did not fill up the format issued by me as per directives of MSEBHCL,” he said.

The holding company board had resolved that the report of the committee formed by the board of directors in relation to the conversion of MSEDCL’s consumers’ tariff from HT continuous to HT non-continuous be submitted to the Government of Maharashtra. However, MSEDCL did not comply with this directive.

The Board had also directed to examine feasibility of creating a dedicated position in the Holding Company for regular monitoring of the pendency of court cases and for submission of a periodic action taken report to the Board. Even after this resolution was passed, MSEDCL filed a tariff review petition with MERC on the issue of approving non continuous tariff to some selected consumers and MERC did not allow about Rs. 180 crore in annual revenue requirement (ARR) to MSEDCL because of such illegal change of tariff category.

Goenka had also pointed out in the Board meetings that compliance of order issued by consumer grievance redressal forums (CGRFs) and ombudsman were kept pending. He had demanded that a time frame should be fixed for completion of infrastructure projects of power companies.

According to the power expert, decentralization of power and restructuring of MSEDCL in four regions had not provided any benefit since the regional directors were powerless and powers are centralized at the head office only.

Title: PWD min: Will accept SC verdict
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: PWD minister G Sudhakaran told the assembly on Monday that the state government will accept whatever verdict the Supreme Court might issue on conducting a load test on the Palarivattom flyover .

The state government had earned a stay order from the apex court last Friday against the Kerala high court’s interim order directing the government to conduct a load test on the Palarivattom flyover to determine its structural stability and load-bearing capacity before demolition.

“The government will accept the SC verdict and will not go for an appeal even if the court directs to carry out the load test,” the minister said, while replying to a submission by senior Congress MLA P T Thomas demanding a speedy opening of the flyover ‘to solve the severe traffic congestion in Ernakulam town’.

Thomas, in his submission, demanded the LDF government not to delay the load test, ‘eyeing the forthcoming elections’. “The government’s stand against the load test has created suspicion about the argument that the flyover lacks structural stability,” he said.

The minister, meanwhile, said the court cases were delaying the demolition and reconstruction of the flyover.

The government had opposed the load test as demanded by the associations of contractors and engineers. They had argued that it was the government’s discretion to decide on such a load test, and had cited expert opinions that such a test would serve no purpose at this juncture as the flyover was already in a distressed condition.

Title: No lobbying for top posts, CM’s decision final, says govt
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Bhopal: The Madhya Pradesh government on Monday rejected reports of intense lobbying among IPS officers for the posts of director general of police (DGP) or chief secretary, amid speculation that the incumbent DGP V K Singh may be shifted. Chief secretary S R Mohanty retires on March 31.

The government’s denial came a day after special DG-police reforms Maithili Sharan Gupta took the unprecedented step of pitching himself publicly for the post of DGP. Gupta, an officer of the 1984 batch, is on the UPSC list among three other top cops that the state government has rejected. In a social media message on Sunday, Gupta claimed that he has the capacity to turn around policing in the state, taking the government by surprise.

The state government rejected Gupta’s claims and asked him to follow procedure. “Maithili Sharan Gupta is a senior police officer and he knows the appointment procedure. In case of appointments of DGP or chief secretary, the chief minister takes the final decision after administrative procedure are followed,” said public relations minister P C Sharma.

“One cannot stake claim to a post on the basis of assumptions. The chief minister has the prerogative to assess officers as per their performance. He can take a decision after procedural exercise. In all such cases, the chief minister takes the decision according to requirement and time for the best results. If necessary, he can effect changes any time, but at this time there is no such process going on,” the minister added.

Controversy over DGP’s post erupted on February 8 after the MP government rejected the UPSC panel that had the names of incumbent DGP V K Singh, BSF DG Vivek Kumar Johri and Maithili Sharan Gupta. The government argued that the ‘willingness’ of Johri had not been taken in writing. The next day, DGP V K Singh had a lengthy closed-door meeting with chief minister Kamal Nath.

A day after that, speculation grew that the government would decide a name for DGP and chief secretary. On Monday, minister Sharma did not comment on any imminent change in the administration.

Gupta’s social media post, which went viral on Sunday, said: “I feel others (esteemed journalists and good public personalities) should come forward to convey my point of view and potential to make a difference in delivery to public and transforming police as real saviour and helper. I would not like to project myself as victim or aggrieved. Government should realise I have the capacity to turn around policing in the state.”

Former CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan called this a sign of “chaos in the MP administration”. “Officials themselves are demanding that they need such a post. It’s a mockery of the state,” Chouhan tweeted.

Title: SC seeks response from governments on infant’s death at Shaheen Bagh
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

MAKING A POINT: Whether a child was called Pakistani in school was not related at all to the issue of an infan... Read More

NEW DELHI: Supreme Court on Monday sought responses from the Centre and Delhi government after taking cognizance of a letter from a 12-year-old bravery award winner who sought to prevent infants and children from being taken to protests citing the death of a four-month-old at Shaheen Bagh in Delhi.

Immediately after a bench of Chief Justice S A Bobde and Justices B R Gavai and Surya Kant took cognizance of Mumbai student Zen Gunratan Sadavarte ’s letter, a large number of advocates representing some women protesters at Shaheen Bagh said under the UN Convention of Child Rights, children had a right to protest.

One advocate, representing three such protesters, said their children faced a tough time as they were being called “Pakistani” in schools. Another went on to claim the Citizenship Amendment Act and the National Register of Citizens had resulted in detention of many children, which also violated their rights. Yet another said even Swedish environmental activist Greta Thunberg was a minor and had been protesting against global warming.

Taken aback by women advocates vociferously pitching against scrutiny of an important issue — whether children and infants could be part of agitations and protests — CJI Bobde said, “We do not want people to use this platform (Supreme Court) to create more problems. Whether a child was called Pakistani in school is not related at all to the issue here.”

Solicitor general Tushar Mehta asked, “Can that be a ground to take a four-month-old child to the protest site?” Referring to the argument that children had a right to protest, the CJI asked, “Did that four-month-old child go to the protest site? Mothers should support this scrutiny.”

This did not deter women counsel from raising CAA and NRC issues, the mainstay of the nearly two-month-long protests at Shaheen Bagh. The CJI did not buy the arguments and said, We will stop those from arguing in the court if they raise such irrelevant issues. We have highest regard for motherhood and societal peace. But do not make general arguments. We are only considering the death of the child and the issue of stopping children and infants being taken to protest sites.”

A woman lawyer came to the defence of the couple who had taken the infant to the protest site regularly despite the extreme cold weather which eventually led to the baby’s death. “The child’s mother lived in a place which cannot be called home. It is an enclosure made of mere plastic sheets,” she said.

Sadavarte’s mother said she had researched the issue and would like to place it before the court. The bench remained firm on dealing only with the issue at hand and said, “We are not stifling anyone, but do not disturb the proceedings by making irrelevant arguments.”

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Rampur man ‘sets wife afire’ after triple talaq
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

RAMPUR: A resident of Kheda Tanda village in Rampur was arrested for allegedly setting his wife afire after giving her triple talaq for not meeting his dowry demands.

The woman, who suffered 75% burn injuries, was admitted to the trauma centre of Teerthanker Mahaveer Medical College in Moradabad, where she is stated to be critical.

The woman’s father in his complaint alleged, “My son-in-law first pronounced talaq thrice to my daughter and then set her afire as I could not fulfil his demand of a car.”

According to police, the couple got married two years ago and have a one-year-old daughter.

Speaking with TOI, Azeemnagar police station SHO Amrish Kumar said, “The woman’s statement has been recorded. We are investigating the matter after registering an FIR against her husband and his relatives under sections 498A (husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty) and 307 (attempt to murder) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC), and under relevant sections of the Dowry Prohibition Act and the Muslim Women Protection Act.”

Read this story in Bengali

Title: Maharashtra: Slow traffic flow at Satara toll plazas despite FASTag
Content: PUNE: The rollout of FASTag across the country from December 15 last year has failed to streamline traffic and reduce travel time on the Pune-Satara highway.Long queues of vehicles can be seen on both flanks of the road at the two toll plazas on the stretch — Khed Shivapur and Anewadi. The introduction of 10 toll collection lanes on each side at Khed Shivapur toll plaza has also failed in streamlining traffic movement. Regular commuters claimed that it takes nearly 20 minutes to cross the Khed Shivapur toll plaza at any time of the day.Pavanjit Mane, a Satara resident working in Pune, said, “Cash and FASTag lanes have not been marked clearly on the toll nakas, which creates confusion. Vehicles enter any lanes, slowing down the progress of queues. Many drivers get into arguments with the toll plaza attendants over various issues.”Mane said a new argument that sparked off recently was lack of concession for return toll. “Arguments over lack of provision for a lesser return toll increases the wait time at toll plazas.”The National Highways Authority of India (NHAI), through a policy circular on January 15, clarified, “In order to promote digital payment, it has been decided that discount for users who make return journey within 24 hours shall be provided only if the toll payments have been made via FASTag. No return journey discount shall be provided to toll payments made in cash or any other mode with effect from January 15.”Mane said no such information was shared by the toll plaza attendants, who stated that they were unaware as to why the concession on return toll was withdrawn.Another Satara resident, Virat Raje Ghadge, who regularly commutes on the stretch, said, “There is no specific cash lane at both the toll plazas between Satara and Pune. According to the rules, 25% of the toll gates must be cash or hybrid lanes. But the toll attendants accept cash in all the lanes. They are also not charging double toll for vehicles that don’t have FASTag. The management at the toll plazas, especially at Khed Shivapur, is bad,” he said.Pune resident Yash Jalan, who recently travelled to Kolhapur , said, “The situation at Khed Shivapur and Anewadi is quite chaotic. The authorities have made 10 toll gates for vehicles commuting in either direction, which leads to chaos. The situation is a complete contrast at the two toll plazas between Satara and Kolhapur. Cash and hybrid lanes have been marked and only vehicles with FASTag are permitted to enter the FASTag or Express lanes. I cannot understand why this cannot be adopted at Anewadi and Khed Shivapur.”An official from the NHAI confirmed that concessions had been withdrawn for those paying toll in cash. B K Singh, the project director for Pune-Satara highway, said, “If those paying by FASTag are also not getting the concession on return fares, there could be a technical glitch in the system. We are also working on easing the chaos at the toll plazas.”

Title: Sandip Joshi, Tukaram Mundhe yet to meet in last 14 days
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

NAGPUR: Having assumed charge as municipal commissioner 14 days ago, Tukaram Mundhe is yet to meet mayor Sandip Joshi . Mundhe did not find time to meet Joshi even after the latter sent notices thrice for a meeting to finalize shifting of private travel operators outside city limits. The word in Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) corridors is that the Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government is virtually taking control of the BJP-led NMC.

On Monday, chief secretary Ajoy Mehta held a meeting to review NMC’s working. Earlier, the state government, including chief secretaries, used to hold meetings of NMC or any other urban local bodies for review of projects etc. This is probably the first time the top state officer is reviewing NMC’s working.

Mundhe along with deputy commissioner Rajesh Mohite, chief engineer Ulhas Debadwar, and superintending engineers Manoj Talewar and Shweta Banerjee were present. None of the NMC office bearers, including mayor or corporators or local legislators were invited for the meeting. Even the three ministers from the district were not present. All officials were tight-lipped about the meeting.

Sources from Mantralaya and NMC said Mehta has never convened a meeting to review working of other municipal corporations.

The government, all of a sudden, replaced Abhijit Bangar with Mundhe despite the former having completed only 14 months, and an IAS official’s tenure here considered as minimum 36 months. Mundhe assumed charge on January 28.

As per protocol and common practice, the civic chief meets the mayor immediately after joining. In the last 14 days, Mundhe and Joshi have not met each other or even held any joint meeting with officials or corporators.

Joshi said, “Mundhe might be busy so could not meet me. I hope he will meet me soon so that we can plan and take forward the development of city.”

Joshi pointed he was not in city from January 28 to 31 while Mundhe left for Mumbai on February 1 for meetings. “We both were in NMC for only two days over last 14 days. Now, he is again at Mumbai for last couple of days for meetings,” he said.

Joshi said, “The plan to develop infrastructure and shift private travels buses out is a very crucial issue. I have sent notices three times to Mundhe but he seems to be busy. I hope he gives time between February 11 and 14, so the policy can be finalized.”

Joshi held a general body meeting on February 4 to discuss Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT) issues but it was postponed due to Mundhe’s absence. Then, Joshi postponed the meeting to February 20. On Monday, Joshi preponed the meeting to February 13.

Mundhe said, “Our meeting will happen soon and there should be no miscommunication. I called the mayor right on the first day and discussed two issues. I could not meet Joshi as we were not at NMC on same days. Joshi was busy with his janata durbar on the two days we both were present at NMC. I am here to ensure Nagpur’s development and ensure availability of all types of civic amenities to the people. My job is to work for Nagpur,” he said.

Despite the mayor’s ongoing janata durbar, Mundhe has launched his own campaign to meet people and resolve some issues. He also held a series of meetings with officials.

Sources also said Mundhe did not attend meetings of standing committee, consultative committees etc. “Mundhe also directed additional municipal commissioner Ram Joshi not to attend meetings of consultative committees, and instead send deputy commissioners etc,” said sources.

Earlier, MVA cabinet had constituted a committee of ministers to execute and monitor Nag River Pollution Abatement Project despite NMC being the nodal agency. None of the BJP legislators, leaders or office bearers in NMC are in the committee.

On Monday, Mundhe and his team gave a presentation on NMC’s financial condition for decision on 7th Pay Commission to employees at urban development department, which will take a final decision soon.

Title: Bengaluru: Two Bangladeshis held with fake passports
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Immigration officials at Kempegowda International Airport arrested two Bangladeshis for possessing fake Indian passports. The duo was detained while trying to board a Malaysia-bound flight on Saturday. Akel Barua Roy Tanmoy, 28, of Lohagara and Tiul Barua Das Arnab, 21, told police they had come to India in October 2019 by sneaking in through the West Bengal border. Catching a train from Kolkata, they arrived in Bengaluru later.

“In Bengaluru, the duo approached an agent who helped them get an Indian passport with fake documents. In December 2019, they went to Nagpur and became monks. Stating they were visiting Malaysia for spiritual purposes, they got visa,” police said. “The address and other details in the passports were not clear. When questioned about their citizenship, they failed to provide proper answers,” sources said.

The duo has been sent to Central Jail, Bengaluru.

Title: Once famed across the country, Nainital’s candle market now flickering
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Nainital: For decades, tourists from across India and even abroad would visit Nainital to buy its famous locally-made scented candles. However, in the past few years, the market has been on a downslide. Traders and shopkeepers say that till a few years ago, there were over 60 to 70 candle shops in Nainital but now there are barely a dozen of them left and even they are moving to other businesses.

“People have started taking to other businesses and the shops that used to only manufacture and sell candles have taken to other gift items as well,” said Amit Virmani, a candle manufacturer and one of the oldest traders in the town.

Virmani said that his father had started the business in Nainital in the 1960s, adding that the trade which was booming till a decade ago has almost collapsed now. “There was a time when even tourists from foreign countries would come to Nainital in search of candles, However, now even the locals are not interested in them,” he added.

The candle business in Nainital has supported hundreds of people and dozens of families who settled in the lake town after the British left. Over the years, the entire Mall Road and the Bara Bazaar area were lined with dozens of shops selling aromatic candles.

Gaurav, another manufacturer of the aromatic candles, said that there are barely half a dozen manufacturers left in the business now. “Earlier, I used to have 15 workers working for me but now I am left with only six because the demand has decreased,” he said.

Those in the candle business put the blame of the falling demand on the abundance of Chinese candles in the market. “There are some tourists who demand the locally-made candles, but many just need a souvenir and they are content with buying cheap alternatives. Therefore, they prefer the Chinese candles which barely cost Rs 100 while the locally-made ones range between Rs 250 and Rs 10,000,” Gaurav said.

Virmani added that excessive taxation under GST on the candles has resulted in the increased prices and therefore the government should revise the rates. “Before GST, there was no tax on handmade candles, but now it’s as high as 12%. The government should revise the GST rate and bring it down to around 5% so that the local businesses can be saved from dying.”

Title: Upset over daughter’s inter-caste marriage, family members end life
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative Image

NAGPUR: Cases of honour killings are reported often. From Gadchiroli, a case of honour suicides has come to fore. A couple and their son killed themselves by jumping into a well at their farm in Anand Nagar of Semana-Navegaon locality in Gadchiroli on Monday because their daughter had eloped with her lover.

The daughter and her newly wed husband too jumped into a river after consuming poison after hearing of tragic end of her family but both were rescued by cops and are being treated at the Gadchiroli’s civil hospital.

Ravindra Wargantiwar, 56, his wife Vaishali, 47 took the drastic decision to end their lives along with their son Sairam, 19. Police sources stated that Wargantiwars were devastated when daughter got married on Friday. Having eloped, the two had tied knot at Markanda temple and were staying together. It is learnt the family was were vehemently opposed to the marriage as their daughter’s boyfriend was from another caste.

The newly wed couple are learnt to have recorded their decision to end life in an audio clip before sending it to their friends, families and also in social media groups. The message also reached cops from Gadchiroli town who started looking for them.

Gadchiroli SP Shailesh Balkawade said police started collecting information about the couple in order to prevent their suicide. “Two of our constables risked their life by jumping into the river near Chamorshi and dragging out the couple from the water. They were rushed to the Civil hospital. Our primary concern is now to save their life,” said the SP.

Senior PI Pradeep Chaogaonkar of Gadchiroli police station said neighbours had informed police about the bodies in the well following which they were taken out.

Balkawade stated that police are trying to find out at what time did the family commit suicide. Gadchiroli police have so far registered a case of accidental death and are conducting further probe.

Title: IIMC suspends 11 for protesting against fee hike
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Photo fore representative purpose only

NEW DELHI: Eleven students of the Indian Institute of Mass Communication on Monday were served a show-cause notice and placed under suspension for five days for “concerted acts of indiscipline” within the IIMC campus.

The protests, a public talk on affordable education, were held on IIMC campus despite repeated counselling by the administration and faculty members. The February 10 order gave time to the 11 students until 5pm on Tuesday to explain why “further disciplinary action” should not be taken against them for violating the code of conduct for students. On humanitarian grounds, however, the order said suspended students would not be asked to vacate their hostel rooms.

Protest against hostel fee hike on the neighbouring JNU campus spread to IIMC in December last year, when students protested against the “unaffordable fee structure”. Some IIMC students also staged a strike on campus against the high tuition fee and hostel and mess charges.

Title: One booked for ‘extorting’ Rs 75 lakh from doctor
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Pune: The Vishrambaug police booked a man on Sunday night for allegedly extorting Rs75lakh from a medical practitioner by threatening to file a case against him under the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act.

The 69-year-old doctor, a resident of Parvati, lodged a complaint with the anti-extortion cell of the crime branch, following which a case was lodged at the Vishrambaug police station.

A woman, who visited the nursing home of the medical practitioner, had filed a molestation case against his son, also a medical practitioner.

According to the FIR, the suspect contacted the medical practitioner, saying that the woman would file a case under the act if the money was not paid. The medical practitioner paid Rs 21lakh cash and gave a check of Rs54lakh to the suspect, the police said. When contacted, the medical practitioner refused to comment.

The case has been taken over by the crime branch for further probe, the police said.

Title: Rahul launches CAA protest day after his removal as ADS prez
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Malappuram: Demanding the repeal of CAA , a local unit of Ayyappa Dharma Sena ( ADS ) organized hunger strike in Changaramkulam in the district on Monday.

Former state president of the organization Rahul Easwar inaugurated the hunger strike organized by Sunil Valayamkulam, a local leader of the organization. Earlier, the Khateeb of Changaramkulam Juma Masjid handed over national flag to Sunil prior to beginning of the one-day-long hunger strike at 10am.

After Rahul announced the hunger strike two days ago, Ayyappa Dharma Sena trustee board had clarified that the ADS had no link with the protest to be held at Changaramkulam. The board meeting held at Thrissur had also decided to remove Rahul from the post of state president of the organsiation. However, the programme was held at Changaramkulam under the local unit of Ayyappa Dharma Sena.

While inaugurating the protest, Rahul said the CAA will divide people based on religion and the protest is being organized to express solidarity with Muslims who have raised serious concern over the implementation of the act.

Rahul said he is sticking to his earlier stand that Indian Muslims are more important than Hindus in Pakistan. “We should respect each other irrespective of religion. Our country upholds the philosophy of secularism and we cannot divide people on the basis of religion,” he said.

Rahul welcomed the SC decision to refer questions of law in Sabarimala case to a larger bench. Rahul said the hearing by larger bench will give a clarity on issues related to freedom of religion under the Constitution and faith.

Title: Maharashtra: Man murders brother-in-law, surrenders before police
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A 30-year-old man from Parbhani district surrendered before the Bhosari police in the early hours of Monday after hacking his brother-in-law to death with a sharp weapon.

Vishnu Jagade murdered his brother-in-law, Mohan Levade (45), on the latter’s terrace in Dhavade Vasti at Ganeshnagar in Bhosari around 2am. Probe revealed Jagade killed Levade as the latter was allegedly harassing his sister, Nanda. She lodged an FIR against him with Bhosari police.

Assistant inspector Siddheshwar Kailase of the Bhosari police said Levade stayed in Dhavade Vasti. His wife suspected he was having an affair as he was harassing her. “When Jagade came to know of it, he came to Bhosari around two days ago to sort out the issue,” Kailase said.

On Sunday night, Levade and Jagade had dinner on the former’s terrace. Then they discussed the issue again and got into a heated argument. Around 2am, Jagade hacked Levade to death when he was sleeping.

Jagade, a dailywager, was arrested under the charges of murder, the assistant inspector said.

Title: Criminal, aide arrested for bid to steal ATM cash
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Pune: A timely response to an alert relayed by the police control room foiled an attempted heist at an ATM of a nationalised bank in Yeolewadi in the early hours of Sunday.

The Kondhwa police had received a call from the control room around 2.50am in this regard. The call specified that some men were in the process of stealing money from the cash dispensing unit of an unmanned ATM kiosk at Digamber House near Sinhagad College.

Responding to the alert, a night patrol police team from the nearby Khadi Machine chowkey rushed to the spot and nabbed the two men inside the ATM kiosk.

The bank’s Kondhwa branch manager, Rakesh Nagendranath Sahay, was informed of the attempted theft at 10am on Monday, following which he filed an FIR with the Kondhwa police.

“The duo — Shriram Vikas Hanvate (26) and Rameshwar Baliram Deshmukh (24) — are from Parali taluka of Beed district. While Hanvate is a criminal on the records of Pimpri Chinchwad police, Deshmukh has no criminal history,” the FIR stated.

“By the time the night patrol team reached the spot, the duo had managed to remove the cash box’s cover, snapped the cash dispensing unit wire and damaged the smoke alarm installed inside the kiosk. They, however, failed to steal the cash,” the FIR further read.

The branch manager said the police had recovered a grinder machine, screwdriver, crowbar, wire cutter, spanner, hacksaw and a motorcycle from the possession of Hanvate and Deshmukh.

“The ATM unit did not have an armed security guard or an emergency alarm. A CCTV camera installed in the kiosk captured the images of the duo, while they were breaking the cash dispensing unit. Investigations revealed that Hanvate and Deshumukh targeted the machine as they were well-versed with the area. Hanvate had earlier worked for a private firm in Khadi Machine Chowk,” said assistant inspector Chetan More from the Kondhwa police.

Sub-inspector and investigating officer Santosh Shinde said the duo decided to steal cash from the ATM as Hanvate was in dire need of money. “He roped in Deshmukh, who had come to Pune only last week. They decided to break into the kiosk in the wee hours of Sunday to escape detection,” Shinde said.

“We are questioning the duo to find out if they had visited the spot earlier. We are also trying to ascertain if they had sought help from someone else. Investigations are on to establish if they had targeted any ATMs in the city earlier,” Shinde added.

The Pune Cantonment court on Monday sent the duo in police custody remand till February 12.

Title: Cops say more CCTVs helped curb chain-snatching incidents in city
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Madurai: The number of chain-snatching incidents in the city, which has gradually witnessed a slowdown over the years, saw a sudden decline in 2019 compared to its previous year. While 132 incidents were reported in 2018, the number dropped to just 66 in 2019, an RTI pettion filed by TOI has revealed.

Police officers attributed it to the increase in CCTV camera installation and increased visible policing for the last couple of years. Recently, city police commissioner S Davidson Devasirvatham told TOI that all sorts of crime incidents have come down in 2019 due to the increasing number of CCTV cameras being installed by the police, private and commercial establishments. The work taken up by the police to install CCTV installations in all major junctions in each station and providing link to the respective station has been progressing well. More than 12 stations have already been covered and work is underway in the rest, he had said. In 2017, as many as 173 snatching incidents were reported. Since then, the number has been coming down. The quantity of jewellery lost in snatching incidents has also been coming down rapidly. While gold jewellery weighing 6.7kg were lost in 2017, it was 3.6kg in 2018 and 2.4kg in 2019.

However, detection cases and recovery of lost gold jewellery has been a challenge task to the city police. Only 30% of the lost jewellery in 2019 was recovered. A higher official said that they have been working in this area as well.

“We are facing challenge mainly because, most of the snatching cases involved new offenders. When youths with no prior criminal record enters a crime incident suddenly, it becomes hard to detect. Moreover, often stolen bikes are used in such incidents, which makes it hard to trace them using the number plate details,” he said.

Title: K Chandrasekhar Rao: Revenue reforms; Telangana government scraps joint collector posts
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

K Chandrasekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: After bringing in amendments to the Panchayat Raj Act and Municipalities Act with more responsibilities and accountability to both officials and elected representatives, the Telangana government is gearing up for overhaul of the revenue administration.

Two days before the collectors’ conference, the government transferred 49 cadre and non-cadre officers and created two new additional collector posts in each district. An additional collector would be incharge of local bodies, likely to supervise panchayats and municipalities on day to day basis. “Additional collector will be made incharge for overseeing Palle Pragati and Pattana Pragati programmes,” a senior official said.

Official sources said creation of new additional collector posts was part of revenue reforms, which would be brought in the form of a new revenue legislation. CM K Chandrasekhar Rao has been expressing his unhappiness over present revenue administration, especially land administration issues, and vowed to revamp the revenue system. The government was also mulling either to merge the revenue department with panchayat raj department or transfer some powers to other departments.

The CM might unveil his ideas on revenue reforms and job chart of collectors and additional collectors during collectors’ conference on February 11. As of now, joint collectors take care of revenue, civil supplies and education etc, but joint collector post was being scrapped in district administration set-up.

“Since the government is focussing on transparency in land transactions, where registration and mutation of land should be done immediately, and also ensure corruption-free and hassle-free registration at revenue offices, special provisions are being made in the new revenue legislation. It is likely that the registration and stamps department will become part of revenue administration,” a senior bureaucrat said. He said the exercise on the new revenue law has already begun and might be placed in the Assembly in the upcoming budget session.

Presently, the revenue department was being handled by chief secretary Somesh Kumar. Since he has too much on his hand, the government might appoint a secretary to take care of commercial taxes, revenue and registration and stamps departments, the sources said.

Title: Special funds for young scientists in U’khand soon: CM
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Dehradun: Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat on Monday inaugurated the ‘Uttarakhand Space Building' at the state capital. Speaking at the inauguration, the CM said that “in order to boost a spirit of inventions in the state, there would be a provision of special funding to young innovators and scientists of our state.” The proposal regarding the same will be tabled in the upcoming cabinet meeting, the CM added. “We are emerging as one of the few states in the country that are striving hard to make best possible use of technology. In this direction, government offices in the state will become paper-free very soon. Already, we are conducting paperless cabinet meetings and soon, even the secretariat and governor office will become e-enabled.”

Pointing out that there was immense innovation potential in the state, the CM said, “I have seen a class 7 student make a model of a smart city which has solutions to all civic problems we face in our daily life. This shows that we have young talent in our state and they should not be deterred from pursuing their dreams because of financial difficulties. This is why, we have decided to have special funds to help these young innovators.”

Also present at the inauguration of the Uttarakhand Space Building was former chairman of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) AS Kiran Kumar as well as MPS Bisht, director of Uttarakhand Space Application Centre (USAC) and RK Sudhanshu, secretary, science and technology among others. Speaking on the ocassion, Kumar assured all possible help to USAC in all its projects.

“With USAC having its own set-up now, I am confident that the organisation will work with more dedication in the field of remote sensing and disaster alert system,” he said.

Title: ‘Will request Centre to relax CRZ rules’
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Industries minister E P Jayarajan told the assembly on Monday that the state government will approach the Centre seeking temporary relaxations in Coastal Regulation Zone (CRZ) rules — which might adversely affect the life of fishing community— till the state gets its coastal zone management plan ( CZMP ) approved by the Centre.

The minister also said that the government will not initiate any measures which will adversely affect people dwelling in the coastal belt, ‘especially at a time when the government is implementing the Life Mission project, under which houses are being constructed for homeless fishermen’. He was responding to a calling attention motion by MLA T J Vinod, who pointed out that the government had failed to meet the six-month deadline for getting the central government’s approval for the state’s new CZMP as per the CRZ notification 2019.

Jayarajan said that the government had already entrusted the National Centre for Earth Science Studies to prepare the CZMP, taking into account of the special situation in the state.

tnn

Title: Sensors to be installed in Naini Lake to track pollutants
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Nainital: Experts from the United Nations will install sensors in Naini Lake to track pollution in the water body, district administration officials said on Monday, adding that the project will be executed under the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and an MoU will soon be signed to this effect.

“We had a meeting with officials of the UNDP and they have agreed to install two censors to track the concentration of pollutants in Naini Lake,” said Nainital DM Savin Bansal. The project, which is estimated to cost around Rs 55 lakh, will be funded by the UN and the censors will be installed on either sides of the lake by April, he added.

Officials said that the Indian Institute of Remote Sensing (IIRS), a unit of ISRO, has also agreed to conduct biannual surveys of the lake for a more accurate estimate of marine life in the river and the effects on the riverbed. “We want to install sensors because the IIRS survey will be done twice a year. The second sensor will monitor the status of the various minerals found in the lake,” Bansal said.

Title: India’s seed mother & others feted
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Pune: Rahibai Popere, the seed mother of India, was among the recipients of the lifetime achievement award at the 71st Foundation Day of SPPU on Monday.

Hirvebazar sarpanch Popatrao Pawar, former SPPU vice-chancellor Narendra Jadhav, doctor Vinod Shah, social activist Girish Prabhune, advocate SK Jain were also awarded lifetime achievement awards. The Yuva Gaurav award was presented to theatre artist Dharmakirti Sumant and actor Mukta Barve.

The awards were given out by renowned musician and singer Pandit Hridyanath Mangeshkar. TNN

Title: Procurement centres over-charging: Farmers
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Madurai: Farmers from Vellalur in Madurai submitted a petition to the Madurai district collector on Monday, alleging that the procurement centres were charging exorbitant rates for loading their paddy.

The petition submitted by Vellalur branch of the Tamil Nadu Farmers association, stated that paddy was being procured from their village by government-appointed procurement centres.

Last year, the workers at the procurement centre demanded Rs 42 for loading a 41-kilogram bag of paddy.

This was opposed by the farmers. K M Manickam, a farmer, said that last year they had demanded that the loading cost be brought down to Rs 30 and after negotiations it was fixed at Rs 38.

The farmers had hoped that the same would continue this year, but when procurement began on Feb 8, they were asked to pay Rs 47 for a 41-kilogram bag, which was way too expensive.

“It is known that agriculture is no more profitable, and farmers are facing high debts and many of them are being driven to commit suicide. The situation is already bad and now increased in the procurement cost has made things worse for us,’’ he said.

He said that the price should be fixed at Rs 30 and that the district administration should take the initiative for the same.

Title: Bouquets & brickbats for FM as House discusses budget
Content:
This story is from February 11, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Closely sticking to the age-old practice, members in the opposition and treasury benches shared their diametrically opposite views on the state budget presented by finance minister T M Thomas Issac on Monday, the first day of the general discussion on the budget for financial year 2020-2021 .

Members from the treasury benches found the budget a bold attempt which, according to them, showed how adept the finance minister was in devising alternative development plans and proposals at a time when the country was on the brink of recession. “The budget presented by Isaac adopts a proactive approach towards development. The proposals he made in the budget for the development of Wayanad would help the district to scale up new heights of sustainable development. It sends a strong message of alternative development,” he said.

However, Congress MLA V D Satheesan, who opened the discussion at the opposition end, said the budget underscored the ‘far right turn’ of the Left government. By undermining the plan process, Isaac was following the far right policies of the BJP government, he said. He accused the minister for reducing the plan outlay by Rs 3,000 crore, which he said was unprecedented. “Like the BJP government in the Centre, you too are proving to be more interested in projects than plans,” he said.

He said the Wayanad and Idukki packages were mere repetition of what Isaac had announced in his last budget. Satheesan said that there was no truth in the arguments that Isaac has set aside Rs 6,000 crore for the development of Kochi.

“The new projects offered to Kochi was worth just Rs 2.5 crore,” he said. He also questioned the rationale behind Isaac choosing to tax the ailing real estate and automobile sectors.
